title: Limits on how much a drug should cost
author: Susan Estrich
content:
Limits on how much a drug should cost

 September 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Susan Estrich | Page: A6 | Section: News 
 
 602
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. government last week released the list of the 10 medications that will be the first to be the subject of the new price negotiations under the Medicare reform bill, and my arthritis drug, Enbrel, made the list.To make the cut, you either had to be taken by millions of people, like Eliquis, or cost a fortune. Enbrel costs a fortune.I'm one of 47,000 Medicare recipients lucky enough to receive a drug that my old rheumatologist, who originally prescribed it for me, described as a miracle.When he was a young doctor, he told me, his waiting room of patients with rheumatoid arthritis was full of crippled people. With the advent of "biologic" drugs like Enbrel, the crutches and wheelchairs are gone. I count myself very lucky to be mostly symptom-free, which, with RA, is saying a lot. As I say, I'm lucky and blessed. And well-insured.And able to cover the out-ofpocket costs. Which are also substantial.This is the hard part of medical miracles.One month, when I was switching insurance companies, I ran out of Enbrel. I made the mistake of thinking I could actually pay for my weekly shot out-of-pocket if I couldn't get the insurance situation straightened out. "How much would it be?" I naively asked the pharmacist. Enbrel is a SureClick pen; it comes in a pack of four. That would be $1,700 for one pen and $7,000 for the pack.Excuse me? Who can afford that?I managed to get a sample from the doctor's office to tide me over and never asked again. Every month when the specialty pharmacy calls me to renew my Medicare prescription, they confirm my $350 co-pay and I don't so much as murmur a word of complaint, because what can I say? The drug saves my life. But I'm lucky I can afford it. That's why Enbrel belongs on the list.Medicines like Enbrel cost billions to develop, and it is only fair that those costs be recouped. But there are limits, and there is no reason that the market should be foreclosed from working freely when it comes to the prices for these prescription drugs. Enbrel costs too much, but there is nothing that I, one consumer, can do about it. We need to stand together, which is to say, we need government to stand up for us and negotiate for us and give voice to our needs.What is stunning about these negotiations is that it took an act of Congress to authorize the government to use the power of the people on behalf of the people to negotiate fair drug prices.The power of the pharmaceutical industry was so great, so much greater than the power of the American people, that it was literally the law of the land that Medicare could not use its bargaining power on behalf of the American taxpayer.When the bill allowing price negotiation passed last year, the Congressional Budget Office predicted the program would save Medicare more than $100 billion during the next 10 years.Just stop and consider that for a moment: the biggest purchaser of health services unable to use its bargaining power, on behalf of you and I, leaving the industry's power to set prices unchecked. And yet this is precisely what government is for, precisely what government is meant to do, to stand up for and give voice to we the people. The pharmaceutical industry continues to fight against negotiations in the courts. "Today is the start of a new deal for patients where Big Pharma doesn't just get a blank check at your expense and the expense of the American people," President Joe Biden said in announcing the list.It's about time.COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Medicare drug price negotiations, healthcare costs, and the impact of pharmaceutical pricing on patients, all central to the Health topic. While government policy and economics are mentioned, the core subject is healthcare affordability and policy.

title: Greater impact in Guatemala - 'Mission is a part of our DNA,' pastor says
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Greater impact in Guatemala - 'Mission is a part of our DNA,' pastor says

 September 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 944
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO - According to Pastor Doug Morley, it all started with an October 2022 visit from Pastor Luis Martinez, founder of Impacto Ministry in San Juan la Laguna, near the Pacific coast of Guatemala."Several from Greater Impact were moved to action as they caught Pastor Martinez's vision for the indigenous people of this beautiful country," Pastor Morley said. Greater Impact, located in Greensboro, is a Wesleyan church in the Chesapeake District.Nine months later, he and four members of his congregation were flying down to the Central American country.Impacto Ministry is headquartered in the town of about 10,000 on the shores of the volcanic Lake Atitlan. The rugged terrain that surrounds the lake is home to several Mayan villages served by the ministry.The Greensboro team joined another team of five from La Plata, Maryland, led by Dr. Mike Patterson for the eight-day medical mission trip from July 8 to 15.Accompanying Pastor Morley on their first mission trip were his sons Andrew and Ryan, and Greater Impact members Maria Reichart of Greensboro and Barbie Semans of Barclay.Seeing his sons and parishioners "really engage with people and see the world from a different perspective," was his "greatest joy," Pastor Morley said."They say in South America that people are more important than programs.The face that you're looking at is more important than the face of a clock," he said. "And so it has caused us to slow down and to really see others from a different perspective, but also to see our lives from a different perspective.So that was very, very helpful." "Obviously you're ministering in the name of Jesus Christ, so when we share our love with those around us, we're hoping that they experiences his love as well. That's part of our goal," he said.Though no one from the church had medical experience, they were quick learners as they set up a pop-up pharmacy and distributed medicines as prescribed by two doctors certified by the Guatemalan government.Reichart and Ryan Morley took the lead at the pharmacy table while Semans distributed reading glasses and Drew Morley handed out toothpaste and toothbrushes. "Even when we weren't busy with the clinic it was apparent that our presence in the villages was impactful," Drew Morley said.Besides experiencing the local culture, the team felt an earthquake and witnessed volcanic activity from nearby Mt. Fuego.Pastor Morley helped where needed and had the opportunity to pray with many of the more than 300 patients who were seen at the various medical clinics.Many of the supplies handed out at the clinics, which also included including vitamins, ibuprofen, acetaminophen, anti-fungal creams, were provided by local community partners.To help with the cost of travel, donations were given and fundraisers were held by Choptank Recovery, Tenchi Restaurant, Shore United Bank and the staff of Greensboro Elementary School.Pastor Morley had served as the mission director for the Chesapeake District of the Wesleyan Church for several years, and had been a part of several mission trips to Guatemala and the Dominican Republic in the 1990s. His wife Karen accompanied him on several of those missions and served on a trip to Albania."Mission is a part of our DNA," Pastor Morley said. "We just find great joy in being able to serve others, to use our gifts and abilities to help those people who perhaps could use a helping hand to lift them up." Something Martinez said during morning devotions stayed with Ryan Morley. "'There is no culture better than another. Each culture has their own richness and uniqueness that makes them incomparable to any other culture.' I got to see this firsthand," he said."Something that we all came back with is how impatient we are here in the United States," Pastor Morley said. "If things don't go smoothly, if things don't go our way, if the computer is slow, if the light is red too long, we kind of get irritated and anxious too quickly. There, it's a different pace altogether." Following this trip, Greater Impact collected over $700 worth of vitamins (which are five times more expensive in Guatemala, according to Pastor Morley) that were delivered by another medical mission to Impacto Ministry in August.A return trip is already in the planning stages because "everyone on the team was deeply moved by the experience," Pastor Morley said."I am determined to go back," Reichart said. "I would love to one day to lead another team from Greater Impact to head back there." The mission of Greater Impact is to "impact Caroline County and beyond with the love of Christ for eternal gain." For more information, visit www.greaterimpactmd.com.Besides planting churches and hosting medical clinics, Impacto Ministry also provides this region with an after-school program that feeds and cares for malnourished children, ministry to seniors who are alone or neglected, an annual evangelistic youth camp, sports clinics, construction projects and training for pastors and leaders. The ministry also provides sewing machines and lessons to help participants and their families rise out of poverty.To learn more about serving with or contributing to the mission of Impacto Ministry, visit www.impactoministry.com. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY GREATER IMPACT
 
The entire Maryland medical mission team stayed at Impacto Ministry's compound in San Juan la Laguna, Guatemala. From left are Barbie Semans, Ryan Morley, Pastor Doug Morley, Andrew Morley, Maria Reichart, Colin Patterson, Ashley Patterson, Uriah Patterson, Debbie Patterson and Dr. Mike Patterson.
 
COURTESY GREATER IMPACT
 
Greater Impact's mission team recently journeyed to Guatemala on a medical mission. From left are Maria Reichart, Andrew Morley, Pastor Doug Morley, Ryan Morley and Barbie Semans.
 
COURTE SY GREATER IMPACT
 
A Guatemalan family in colorful Mayan garb watches people milling about in the village market. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While cultural exchange and community service are mentioned, the primary emphasis is on the health-related aspects of the mission.

title: New COVID vaccine available this week
content:
New COVID vaccine available this week

 September 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A8 | Section: News 
 
 270
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Most Americans should get an updated COVID-19 vaccine, health officials said Tuesday.Advisers to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention endorsed the new shots for everyone 6 months and older and the agency's director quickly signed off Tuesday on the panel's recommendation.That means doses should be available this week, some as early as Wednesday.The severity of the COVID-19 pandemic has faded, but there are still thousands of hospitalizations and hundreds of deaths in the U.S. each week. Hospitalizations have been increasing since late summer, though the latest data indicate infections may be starting to level off, particularly in the South.Still, experts worry that immunity from previous vaccinations and infections is fading in many people, and a new shot would save many lives.According to a survey last month that CDC cited, about 42% said they would definitely or probably get the new vaccine. Yet only about 20% of adults got an updated booster when it was offered a year ago.Doctors hope enough people get vaccinated to help avert another "tripledemic" like last year when hospitals were overwhelmed with an early flu season, an onslaught of RSV, or respiratory syncytial virus, and yet another winter coronavirus surge. 
 
 Caption: PFIZER
 
This photo provided by Pfizer in September 2023 shows single-dose vials of the company's updated CO VID vaccine for adults. U.S. regulators have approved updated CO VID-19 vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna, shots aimed at revving up protection this fall and winter. The Food and Drug Administration's decision Monday, Sept. 11, 2023 is part of a shift to treat fall CO VID-19 vaccine updates much like getting a yearly flu shot. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: RSV risks, prevention: What you need to know
content:
RSV risks, prevention: What you need to know

 September 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 526
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Centers for Disease Control have issued a health advisory alerting medical providers of an increase in cases of respiratory syncytial virus, more commonly known as RSV. Every year, more than 1,500 Marylanders are hospitalized with RSV infections.RSV is a common respiratory virus that usually causes mild, cold-like symptoms.Most people recover in a week or two, but RSV can be serious.Infants and older adults are more likely to develop severe RSV and need hospitalization.The virus can worsen certain medical conditions, including asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and congestive heart failure.The following are the latest recommendations regarding RSV vaccine and prevention.ADULTSTwo RSV vaccines have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Each vaccine requires a single dose injection.All adults aged 60 and over should discuss the RSV vaccine with their health care provider. This is especially true if you are at increased risk for severe complications from RSV, based on any of the following health conditions: asthma, COPD, congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, diabetes, neurologic conditions, kidney disorders, liver disorders, bleeding disorders or have a compromised immune system. Other factors that may increase your risk are frailty, advanced age, or residency in a nursing home or long-term care setting.One of the available vaccines has also been approved for pregnant individuals between 32-and 36-weeks gestational age in pregnancy.If you are pregnant, discuss the RSV vaccine with your OB/GYN.The RSV vaccines are available through primary care offices and some pharmacies.INFANTSRSV is especially dangerous to infants. The CDC recommends certain infants receive the FDA-approved monoclonal antibody product Beyfortus (also called nirsevimab). Beyfortus has been shown to reduce the risk of both RSV-related hospitalizations and RSV-related health care visits in infants by about 80%.One dose of Beyforuts is recommended for all infants younger than 8 months, born during - or entering - their first RSV season (typically fall through spring). For a small group of children between the ages of eight and 19 months who are at increased risk of severe RSV disease, such as children who are severely immunocompromised, a dose is recommended in their second RSV season.Parents of infants who meet the above criteria should discuss the RSV monoclonal antibody product with their child's pediatrician.PREVENTION You can help prevent the spread of RSV by taking the same precautions used to prevent other respiratory illnesses, like COVID-19:· Cover coughs and sneezes with a tissue or your elbow - not your hands.· Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.· Avoid close contact with people who are sick, such as kissing, shaking hands and sharing cups and eating utensils.· Stay home if you are sick and, if you have to go out in public, wear a face mask.· Avoid touching your face, particularly your eyes, nose and mouth.· Clean frequently touched surfaces, such as doorknobs and mobile devices.· Get vaccinated if recommended by your healthcare provider.· If you have an infant, avoid crowds, ask people to wash their hands before touching the baby and keep the baby away from anyone with cold symptoms, including siblings and other parents or caretakers. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on RSV health risks, medical recommendations, and prevention strategies, directly aligning with the Health topic. While public safety and national news could marginally apply, the primary context is medical/health advisory.

title: Some questions to ask CDC director nominee
author: George F. Will
content:
Some questions to ask CDC director nominee

 September 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: George F. Will | Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 758
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - COVID-19 was not this nation's first or worst pandemic. There probably will be worse. How much worse might depend on the caliber of public health leaders. There is room for improvement.Approximately 1,200 presidential appointees require Senate confirmation. A crucial one does not, until 2025.Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Tex.) has introduced legislation to require immediate confirmation of the new director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Mandy Cohen.Herewith, some questions for her: The Great Barrington Declaration was issued in October 2020 by eminent epidemiologists and public health policy specialists who dissented from federally encouraged and mandated pandemic mitigation strategies - commercial lockdowns, school closures, masking toddlers, etc.The GBD's authors - Jayanta Bhattacharya (Stanford), Sunetra Gupta (Oxford) and Martin Kulldorff (Harvard) - favored targeting protection for the most vulnerable: the elderly and others with comorbidities.Children were the least vulnerable.This might have saved the $6 trillion the government spent to resuscitate the economy after the government suffocated it. And might have prevented a generation's learning loss. Was not the GBD correct?Anthony S. Fauci, the government's top infectious-disease specialist, and Francis Collins, head of the National Institutes of Health, tried to orchestrate what Collins called a "takedown" of the GBD, which Collins denigrated as the opinion of "fringe" scientists.(Bhattacharya alone had more than 100 peer-reviewed articles.)Will your CDC be more receptive to heterodoxy?In March 2020, Fauci said, "There's no reason to be walking around with a mask." Soon, however, masks were mandated. Do such malleable certitudes contribute to what Fauci calls the "smoldering anti-science feeling"?Under your predecessor, the CDC proclaimed - until the Supreme Court said there was no legal basis for this - a national housing policy: an eviction moratorium.Will your CDC have less imperial pretensions?In January 2020, at the pandemic's outset, Sen. Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) said the coronavirus could have leaked from the Wuhan lab that "works with the world's most deadly pathogens." This possibility was promptly denounced as "fringe" and a "conspiracy theory." A March 17, 2020, paper published in Nature Medicine journal discounted "any type of laboratory-based scenario" for the coronavirus's origin. A month later, however, one of the paper's authors said in a private email that we "can't fully rule out engineering" - the possibility that the virus not only leaked from the Wuhan lab but was created there. Today, the FBI strongly suspects the virus had a research-related origin.How do you propose to insulate the CDC from government-promoted orthodoxies voiced by government-financed scientists?"Gain of function" research involves engineering especially transmissible and/or deadly viruses to understand future pandemics and develop vaccines.Fauci has denied funding such research at Wuhan. But John Ratcliffe, former director of national intelligence, called Fauci's disavowal of funding "inconsistent" with some intelligence and said "a lab leak is the only explanation credibly supported by our intelligence, by science and by common sense." Do Americans perhaps have too much confidence in government's handling of science?The New York Times reports that during the pandemic, CDC officials "held 'weekly sync' meetings with Facebook, once emailing the company 16 'misinformation' posts." A federal appeals court has held that the CDC, among other government institutions, probably violated the First Amendment with "intimidating" communications to get social media companies to remove lawful content concerning pandemic policies. The court held that government cannot pressure social media to do something the government itself cannot constitutionally do: censor speech. Should the CDC apologize and embrace legality?About four months ago, Fauci challenged the New York Times to "show me a school that I shut down and show me a factory that I shut down." But in October 2020, Fauci, who once described lockdowns as merely "inconvenient," said, "I recommended to the president that we shut the country down." He now says his recommendations merely "echoed the CDC's." Is this a modified Nuremberg defense - I was only obeying other peopleftDuring the pandemic, as North Carolina's chief public health official, you were enthusiastic about lockdowns, and issued a "secretarial directive" telling people, inter alia, to "wear a mask at all times" outside the home, "do not enter any indoor public space where anyone isn't masked" and to "remain at home between the hours of 10 p.m. and 5 a.m." And you sometimes wore a mask featuring Fauci's picture. Any second thoughts about your enthusiasms?If Congress has curiosity about these life-or-death matters, it will pass Cruz's legislation. Then summon Mandy Cohen. 
 
 Caption: ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, talks with President Donald Trump during a tour of the Viral Pathogenesis Laboratory at the National Institutes of Health, March 3, 2020, in Bethesda 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on questions for the CDC director nominee, addressing public health policies, pandemic responses, and scientific debates. While related to public safety and national news, the core subject is health leadership and CDC operations.

title: Choptank Health Mobile Unit now in Chestertown
content:
Choptank Health Mobile Unit now in Chestertown

 September 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 423
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - Choptank Community Health System is bringing its mobile healthcare unit to Chestertown to help serve people in Kent County. The initiative is made possible through a partnership with Choptank Health, the Town of Chestertown, and the Chestertown Police Department.The mobile unit will be used to provide medical, behavioral health, and dental services to communities in Kent County.The Chestertown Police Department at 601 High Street will house the mobile health unit while not out in Kent County delivering health care to residents.Services will be provided while the unit is out in the community and not from the unit in the parking lot."Choptank Health is very thankful for this opportunity to connect healthcare with our communities and local agencies," said Choptank Health President and CEO Sara Rich."We are especially grateful for Councilman Herz's help while we were exploring the best places to call home for our mobile unit." "The search criteria included having a secure location for overnight parking and accessibility to electricity to recharge the unit's instrumentations," said Chestertown Council Ward 2 Member Thomas A. Herz, Jr. "The Chestertown Police Department fits the criteria, and is centrally located, which is an added bonus." Rich says this is their third mobile health unit and expands Choptank Health's capability to truly meet its patients where they are.Other units are used during the school year to provide school-based medical and dental services and as a platform for Choptank Health's migrant program team to visit various farms, agricultural nurseries, and crab houses across the Shore."Choptank Health is an essential community partner in delivering healthcare to people in Chestertown and those living in rural areas of the entire Mid-Shore region," said Chestertown Mayor David Foster. "We felt it was essential to support the operations of their mobile unit to help break down barriers to healthcare while supporting the health of residents in our community." "Helping Choptank Health provide healthcare to people in our rural communities is important," said Chestertown Police Department Chief Ronald M. Dixon. "We're glad to have the opportunity to support their work and our community in this meaningful way." 
 
 Caption: CHOPTAN K COMMUNITY HEALTH
 
Choptank Community Health System is bringing its mobile healthcare unit to Chestertown to help serve people in Kent County. The initiative is made possible through a partnership with Choptank Health, the Town of Chestertown, and the Chestertown Police Department. From left, Chestertown Police Department Chief Ronald M. Dixon, Choptank Health President and CEO Sara Rich, Chestertown Council Ward 2 Member Thomas A. Herz, Jr., and Chestertown Mayor David Foster.

title: Commissioners proclaim Suicide Awareness Month
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Commissioners proclaim Suicide Awareness Month

 September 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A3 | Section: News 
 
 330
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - "No Matter What, You Matter" is the theme of National Suicide Prevention Month, and the Caroline County Commissioners proclaimed the same for the county at its 9 a.m. meeting, Tuesday, Sept. 19, in Denton.Jen Friedman, a therapist with For All Seasons, a community behavioral health and rape crisis center with seven locations, including at 322 Market St. in Denton, was on hand for the proclamation.According to a 2021 Youth Risk Behavior Survey conducted by local school systems in conjunction with the Centers for Disease Control, "24% of Caroline teenagers ages 14 to 18 had seriously considered attempting suicide in the 12 months prior to the survey, with 42 percent reporting symptoms of depression, and 21 percent of Caroline teens actually attempted suicide," the proclamation stated."As you can see from the statistics, it's a serious issue not only in our nation and state, but also here in our very own backyard of Caroline County," Friedman said."We encourage everyone to check in on the people in their life regularly," Friedman said. "Ask them how they are feeling and listen carefully without judgment. You never know what someone is going through. And if we all take the time to reach out to listen and connect people to resources, we can definitely help save lives." Acknowledging Commission Vice President Larry Porter's frequently saying "It's okay not to be okay," Commissioner Frank Bartz said, "That's pretty much it." "We need to be aware of who's around us and pick up on what's going on in our lives and sometimes just just talk to somebody and make them feel like they're important," Bartz said.To read the proclamation, visit the Commission's website at www.carolinemd.org and click on meeting agendas. The proclamation is linked in the agenda. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Proclaiming September National Suicide Prevention Month in Caroline County are, from left, Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter, Therapist Jen Friedman with For All Seasons, Commissioner Frank Bartz and Commission President Travis Breeding. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on suicide prevention efforts, mental health statistics, and community awareness initiatives, which directly relate to health topics. While local government actions are mentioned, the core issue is public health awareness.

title: New hospital moves ahead with needs certificate
author: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com
content:
New hospital moves ahead with needs certificate

 September 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 571
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's plans for construction of a new regional medical center in Easton have moved a step forward as hospital officials have received notice that the Maryland Health Care Commission has docketed the application for the project's Certificate of Need."Contingent on a successful CON process with MHCC we anticipate construction of the new regional medical center to begin in the spring of 2025," said Trena Williamson, regional director, communications and marketing for University of Maryland Medical System.The commission posted notice of the docketing in the Maryland Register on Aug. 11, which initiated a 30-day window for public comment. As of today, no comments have been posted, and the certificate application is now ready for the commission's review and anticipated approval in the coming months.Docketing of the application not only keeps the project moving forward as is required by the commission's procedural regulations but allows the commission to gather any supplemental information needed to render a decision."There are multiple phases in the certificate of need process.If there were interested parties, there could have been a delay. There were zero interested parties in the 30 days so we are on track with our timeline," Easton Town Council President Frank Gunsallus said. "We need this hospital, so this is good news. Getting a state of the art medical facility is huge.Once certificate of need gets to a point, they can go and fundraise the capital." "The commission has all the information needed to assess the project's viability, including anticipated sources of funds supporting the project, the status of state funding commitments, and plans for obtaining additional state funding," said Ken Kozel, University of Maryland Shore Regional Health president and CEO. "We anticipate that state and local funding, and our capital campaign will gain significant funding once the CON approval is received." The projected cost of the new Shore Regional Medical Center is $550 million."We anticipate receiving state and local funding, and we will be launching a capital campaign seeking private philanthropic support as well," Williamson said.The schematic design phase of the project, which has been completed, involved the participation of multiple departments in refining layout plans and creating new external renderings. The design development phase is now in progress, focusing on the design of individual rooms for optimal workflow.Plans to build the new Shore Regional Medical Center in Easton are critical to the comprehensive health care delivery plan for Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties. The new location on Route 50 at Longwoods Road will promote better access to care, the new design will accommodate advances in high-quality care and improve patient satisfaction, and the new facility will enhance UM Shore Regional Health's ability to recruit and retain health care providers and staff.The construction of a hospital has been a heavily discussed issue in the campaign for the town council president. Al Silverstein was so bullish on building the hospital that he thought we should be banging on the governor's door in Annapolis and the University of Maryland's door in Baltimore to get it done. The ultimate winner, Town Council President Frank Gunsallus, noted the lack of medical talent to fill the new hospital and spoke on creating incentives to attract new medical personnel. 
 
 Caption: CONTRIBUTED
 
University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's new regional medical center proposed rendering following schematic design phase. Although not approved, docketing the application is another step forward for the new hospital. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'Less Stress Doc' Offers Tips For Relief In New Book
author: Annie Hasselgren; Special To The Bay Times Record Observer/Star Democrat
content:
'Less Stress Doc' Offers Tips For Relief In New Book

 September 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Annie Hasselgren; Special To The Bay Times Record Observer/Star Democrat | Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 648
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTER - Seeking happiness and lower stress levels can feel elusive in today's society. As technology advances at breakneck speed and social media demands more of our attention, feelings of inadequacy or discontent in one's life feel more like the rule than the exception. Local physician Dr. Gary Sprouse might just have the antidote, however.An internist on the Eastern Shore for 38 years, Sprouse's interest in lowering the stress levels of his patients began 25 years ago and recently culminated in his book, "Highway to Your Happy Place: A Roadmap to Less Stress."Sprouse has helped to treat the stress of many patients in his office for decades and, upon deciding to retire this year, he set out on a quest to do the same for the general public. Dubbed "The Less Stress Doc," Sprouse developed a framework for helping people apply some simple but profound principles to calming the stressors and anxieties of daily life, and has conducted in-depth research as to how the human brain works and why we are capable of reframing our perspectives."What is unique to humans, unlike other beings, is that we are able to envision the future," says Sprouse."We have language. We use tools. We have these incredible skills, and stressors are side effects to those skills.It is virtually impossible as a human to live for today without worrying, as we spend too much time thinking about the future. 'Don't worry, be happy!' is great advice if you live on an island in Jamaica, but not so much in Queen Anne's County.The premise [of the book] is how to keep the skill and lose the side effect."Sprouse helps patients accomplish this through working on what he believes are the essential ingredients of a low-stress life: contentment, happiness, the anticipation of happiness, gratitude, and fulfillment.Sprouse says to think of contentment as the baseline of how we feel each day, which is typically stable. Happiness is the intermittent change in that baseline that is informed by events or circumstances, but we usually return to our baseline quickly. The anticipation of happiness is critical so that we have something to look forward to.Sprouse identifies this lack in suicidal and Alzheimer's patients who are either unwilling or unable to consider that things can get better - an integral component of contentment. Gratitude is key so that we can appreciate what we do have and not pine for what we don't. Fulfillment involves growing as a person and allowing ourselves to be curious, to learn, and to grow.Some of the inhibiting factors to a low-stress, happy life, says Sprouse, are feelings of being overwhelmed, excessive worrying, guilt, and regret - and these are often not as easy as what meets the eye. Sprouse works with patients to identify the source of their stress and unhappiness and "organize" these issues into more manageable pieces."We can't remove worry from our lives. Worrying is a skill we use to envision the future, thinking of all the things that could happen, and using our skills to address them," says Sprouse."I advise my patients to practice realistic optimism: focus on the good things, but don't ignore the bad things that can happen. Worry itself isn't bad - it's doing too much of it that's the problem. I want you to worry efficiently.""Highway to Your Happy Place" offers tools to compartmentalize our worries into components that can make the "what ifs" of life more feel surmountable and less overwhelming."History can't be rewritten," says Sprouse. "We can only change the future through our behavior. We can lessen our guilt, regret, and worry by modifying our behavior to bring about more positive results."Sprouse's book launched. at the Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department on Sept.10, an event which will also celebrated his birthday and retirement. To learn more about Sprouse, visit www. thelessstressdoc.com. 
 
 Caption: PHOTOS COURTESY OF GARY SPROUSE
 
Dr. Gary Sprouse 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Picnic honors treatment center's past, looks to future
content:
Picnic honors treatment center's past, looks to future

 September 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 1157
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - Earlier this month, after the 2023 5K Color Fun Run/WalK for Kent Goes Purple, The A.F. Whitsitt Center celebrated its 40th year with an alumni picnic.Hosted at the center, honored guests, professionals in the community and residents showed up, ate a meal together and shared memories.Also in attendance was Maryland Delegate Jay Jacobs, R-36, and a resident of Kent County. He presented a Maryland General Assembly official citation to the Whitsitt Center for their 40 years service.The Kent County House Delegation recognized the establishment, for providing in-patient residential substance treatment services for the Eastern Shore and the State of Maryland.Jacobs reminisced, saying back in 2009, when the state was thinking about closing the center, and he was mayor of Rock Hall, they held a 24 hour vigil to prevent its closing.Fortunately, the center did not shut down, he added, and since then, many people have been positively impacted.Jacobs expressed hope, looking toward the future. "I think we'll see some things take place soon as far as infrastructure goes. The building's going to be restored to its real glory and be a real piece of a thread of the fabric of this county."As folks finished their meals, Director of the Kent County Health Department's A.F. Whitsitt Center, Carla Thorpe, talked about the rich history of the center, handing out awards.She produced a plaque dedicated to the staff who used to work there and had now moved on.Thorpe then recognized the first patient at the Whitsitt Center, the late Bill Walls, bringing his family up to applause.Thorpe pointed out, Walls was one of the first to do harm reduction, keeping sufferers of alcohol addiction from seizures or tremors before they got to treatment.In honor of him, they established the Whitsitt Wonder Impact award."It's for somebody who has been through the program and has given back to those who have been in recovery," Thorpe said.To her left, stood a painting of the founder, the late, A.F. Whitsitt When individuals come through the doors, they will see his picture on the wall, she announced. Thorpe asked his grandchildren, Clay Mitchell and Chris Mitchell, to say some words remembering their grandfather and present an award in his honor."Your grandfather was an advocate. His big thing was to work with those suffering from alcoholism," Thorpe said.His grandchildren had memories to share, speaking of his dedication."This thing wasn't popular when he was the health officer in the 40's, 50's or 60's, but he did it anyway because it was the right thing to do," Chris Mitchell said about his grandfather.Clayton Anderson Mitchell added, "I feel like my grandfather never really died because the mission of this organization lives on through the great staff who work here."Thorpe moved on to recognize a friend of recovery in the founder's honor; someone who represented A.F. Whitsitt's values, presenting Executive Director of Mid Shore Behavioral Health, Katie Dilley, the A.F. Whitsitt award.Thorpe said, "She's working with us to see what other supports she can bring to the region. For me, she's been a mentor, and when it comes down to it, it's about the people we serve, and keeping the services we need here on the shore."Mid Shore Behavioral Health covers five counties, Kent, Queen Anne's, Talbot, Caroline and Dorchester.Dilley said, "It's a gift to be in this job and work hard for you. The hope and drive of everybody in this room is what it's all about. We're here to make sure we're on the right path, and we do not lose the resources that bring life, and strength back into our community."To cap the picnic off, there was a rousing testimony by Shiloh Blackburn, accompanied by his wife, Marian.Blackburn's one of the 25,000 the center's helped over the years, since 1983.Blackburn described his life in great detail, from addiction to recovery, and the men who helped him make that change.He told the audience he came to the center with a trash bag of his belongings. He said he was a manipulator, a chameleon, justifying his addictions, blaming his childhood.But at the center, he was confronted with people serious about beating addictions.In Church Hill, he said he got his first 24-hour chip, noting the late Bill Walls was there.But it was not a full recovery. He said that from 12-years-old onward there was a romance to using drugs and alcohol. It was that romance that he was addicted to.After he had been clean for a while, and things were going right again, he took back his will.He found himself back at the Whitsitt Center, where lead counsellor, the late Katrina Tolliver, spoke "some great sense" into him. Her advice to him was to keep his mouth shut."I was a guy who knew a lot," he said, indicating he was not yielding enough to learn.But something resounded within him this time. He began to listen and learn.Then another life changing event with his sponsor.He was sandpaper, Blackburn noted, and did not just simply say, call me everyday. The sponsor challenged him. First of his advice was to pray every night, a simple prayer, to stay sober one day at a time."For the first day in my life it was man in the mirror time," he said.One day, after months and months of praying, he said, that prayer was answered. It was immediate, not desiring."As I was walking to this job, a calmness that I never felt before, and the compulsion to want to drink and get high was totally gone. At that moment I knew it was God who took that from me because that's the only person I was asking every day."He tried to tell his roofer coworkers about it, but they didn't listen.It didn't matter however.He started becoming "childlike," meaning willing to learn.He described working on himself like a "surgery of the spirit."His sponsor told him it's time to forgive his mother. Not by his words, but with his actions. So he started doing chores for her, asking her what he could do, being a continual presence in her life.One day, he said, she asked him if she could attend a meeting. His mother, since last March, is now 15 years sober, he said.Blackburn now has a life he could have never dreamed. He's married his best friend, and he wanted to thank the men in his life who made him.Health Officer Bill Webb, who sees miracles like Blackburn's at the meetings, said the Whitsitt Center is available for anybody who needs the help. They have 44 beds, 12 beds of which are crisis beds, for opioids and stimulants. They also accept health insurance and offer adult care. 
 
 Caption: WILL BONTRAGER
 
Accepting the Whitsitt Wonders Impact award given posthumously to their father, William "bill" Walls, first resident, from left, beth Walls Selinger, adam Walls, director of the a. F. Whitsitt center carla thorpe (presenting the award), and billy Walls. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a treatment center's 40th anniversary, highlighting its role in substance abuse recovery, health services, and community impact. While there are elements of local community events (Local Life) and official recognition (Public Notices), the core subject is health-related services and recovery programs.

title: New book promotes physical activity, family fitness
content:
New book promotes physical activity, family fitness

 September 28, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A6 | Section: News 
 
 277
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland SNAP-Ed, a program of University of Maryland Extension in partnership with Maryland Department of Human Services, has written a new original storybook promoting family physical activity.More than 125,000 free copies of the book will be distributed to low-income sites across the state throughout the summer."The Secret to an Extraordinary Day" follows the story of an ordinary family that takes an unexpected adventure, prompted by a series of mysterious notes. Along the way they discover that being active together is a secret weapon for overcoming the summer blues.SNAP-Ed delivers multi-faceted interventions that support adoption of healthy behaviors by low-income audiences."Physical activity has emerged as a priority for SNAP-Ed, both nationally and in Maryland," Maryland SNAP-Ed Director Lisa Lachenmayr said in a news release. "Among the many lasting effects of the pandemic, sedentary behaviors increased due to increased reliance on technology for school and education. While SNAP-Ed's interest in physical activity is as a tool for obesity and chronic disease prevention, our partners also recognize the power of movement to address critical concerns around social-emotional health." Physical activity is a current focus area for SNAP-Ed, due to well-documented impacts on chronic disease prevention. Supporting youth in developing a lifelong relationship with physical activity also benefits overall well-being.Books are being distributed to partnering schools, early childhood sites, out of school programs, Maryland WIC offices, SNAP Outreach community partners, low-income 4-H youth programs, and summer meals sites, allowing SNAP-Ed to deliver health promotion messages while supporting family literacy and summer learning.For more information or to read the book, go to https://extension.umd.edu/active-fun. 
 
 Caption: Maryland SNAP-Ed has written a new original storybook promoting family physical activity and will donate 125,000 copies across the state. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Guilty but not held criminally responsible - 'I love you,' dad says to son who tried to kill him
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Guilty but not held criminally responsible - 'I love you,' dad says to son who tried to kill him

 September 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 997
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Ridgely man who struck his own father with a car in Cordova last December was found guilty, but not criminally responsible, of assault and related charges.Frank Justin Ashe Jr., 20, who goes by Justin, entered pleas to first-degree assault, use of a firearm in the commission of a violent crime and reckless endangerment, but maintained that he was not criminally responsible by reason of insanity - an argument that Talbot County Circuit Judge Stephen H. Kehoe later agreed with.The case against Justin stemmed from a reported assault in the 11000 block of Three Bridge Branch Road in Cordova around 3:30 p.m. on Dec. 4, 2022.In the roughly 90-minute hearing Thursday, the prosecution and defense shared two sides of the same story, providing joint insight on the day's events and Justin's mental state at the time.According to Frank J. Ashe Sr., Justin's father, his son wasn't acting like himself that morning, said Talbot County State's Attorney Joseph Coale. And to defense attorney Kisha Petticolas, Justin's unusual behavior had started some time before then.By all accounts, Justin was a normal kid who had never had problems, Petticolas said. But at some point in his teen years, he became fixated on Freemasonry, going down a social media rabbit hole that led to him seeing symbols and signs of the organization.Justin believed he knew too much and people wanted him eliminated because he knew their secrets, Pettico-las said. The night before, his mother had considered taking him to the hospital. And that day, he woke up "completely and positively sure" that someone was going to kill him.According to Coale, Justin, then 19, was in an outbuilding the afternoon of Dec. 4 when his father came to check on him. When Ashe Sr. entered, he found his son standing by the windows, holding a firearm and saying that someone was coming to get him, Coale said.Justin believed that the man who looked like his father was a clone who came to kill him, and the teen had armed himself for protection, Petti-colas said.Ashe Sr. told Justin to put the gun down, but Justin aimed it at his father.Ashe Sr. knew he needed to get the gun out of his son's hands and attempted to distract Justin. Ashe Sr. grabbed the gun, fighting to pull it away from Justin. But as the two wrestled, the gun went off, firing a bullet through a wall, Coale said.Justin ran out the back door of the outbuilding while Ashe Sr. went out the front door. He saw Justin get into a car and begin driving away, Coale said.But Justin turned the car around and accelerated toward his father, striking him and knocking him unconscious for several minutes.The family's security camera footage, which both father and son declined to view in court Thursday, captured the strike and the moments after. According to Coale, the video showed Justin approaching his father, taking the gun and stepping on his father's stomach and checking it for an old scar before getting back in the car.After regaining consciousness, Ashe Sr. was able to get up and enter his home, Coale said.Ashe Sr. suffered a broken back, brain bleeds and other smaller injuries from being struck with the car, Coale said. He was flown to the University of Maryland Shock Trauma in Baltimore for treatment.Justin's grandfather, who was inside the house, heard the earlier argument between the two men. By now, Justin had walked back into the house and was tackled by his grandfather, who was trying to secure the gun. A second shot was fired accidentally during the scuffle, according to the grandfather, Coale said.Justin drove off after the scuffle. Coale said he was apprehended by police on Interstate 95 near Rocky Mount, North Carolina, around 11 p.m. that night.Petticolas said while Justin's memory of the day didn't match what Coale presented, she acknowledged that the prosecution would have been able to produce those facts had the case gone to trial.Prior to rendering a verdict and final decision on the case, the court heard additional information to determine Justin's criminal responsibility.In a report from the Maryland Department of Health, a doctor diagnosed the 20-year-old with schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type. The diagnosis, along with Justin's behavior, paranoia and delusions, led to identical recommendations from the prosecution and defense - both asked the judge to find Justin not criminally responsible and commit him to the department.Justin's father provided tearful testimony in support of the best outcome for his son.Choked up with emotion, Ashe Sr. said he couldn't ask for a better son. He knew the teen wasn't trying to kill him, he said."What happened that day (was) just not my son," he said, later adding: "I didn't raise my son that way.""I love you, son," Ashe Sr. said, stepping off the witness stand. Across the courtroom, Justin replied: "I love you."To Petticolas, Justin's not criminally responsible plea was the clearest cut case she'd seen, and one in which justice could be found through the commitment to the Maryland Department of Health. The prosecution not arguing differently "speaks volumes," she said.And the Ashe family is "irreparably scarred," and they too need to heal, she said.After listening to the volume of testimony, Kehoe determined that Justin's actions directly stemmed from the delusions."(It's) clear to me beyond any question that he is not criminally responsible for what he did that day," he said.While Justin was found guilty, the lack of criminal responsibility finding in the case means that he will be committed to a state health department psychiatric hospital indefinitely until it's determined that he is not a danger.Not criminally responsible pleas are "fairly uncommon," according to Coale.After the hearing, Petticolas reflected on the the collegial practice within the smaller jurisdiction, which allowed the prosecution and defense to come up with results that served the public good, she said."I think justice was served today," she said. 
 
 Caption: Frank J. "Justin" Ashe Jr. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a legal case where the defendant's mental health (schizoaffective disorder) was central to the court's decision. While the incident involves criminal behavior, the primary focus is on the medical diagnosis, psychiatric commitment, and legal proceedings tied to mental health, making 'Health' the most accurate category.

title: New cardiac monitors improve emergency aid
author: Will Bontrager
content:
New cardiac monitors improve emergency aid

 October 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Will Bontrager | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 987
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WORTON - In an emergency sit uation, there's no time for equipment to go down. The efficiency of equipment is often the difference between life and death. Even two-seconds difference, Logan Quinn, chief of Emergency Medical Services for Kent County said, are precious to a patient' survivability.Quinn's been researching trends in the medical field, and pre-charging heart monitor machines before administering a rhythm check on a patient for example, is just one of the ways he found is more effective.The new cardiac monitor and defibrillators his staff now possess wil help with that, he added.Seven of them, were delivered this August, from Zoll, replacing the outdated models from their old company, Physio-Control.His crew of 14 paramedics and 12 EMT's, are now better equipped with these Zoll monitors. Each substation in Rock Hall and Galena, the county ambulance vehicle, the primary paramedic unit, and his own vehicle, now have them, he pointed out.Quinn's impressed by these machines, stating that they are top-of-the-line, which will lead to better training practices.Features, exclusive to the Zoll monitors, lend what Quinn calls, "see-through CPR" capabilities. He explained, when a person's in cardiac arrest, they place a CPR feedback puck on the center of the chest, then another on the side. When connected, and compressions are being given, that patient's vital information appears on the monitor's screen.The machine also informs the person administering the compressions. "The monitor shows how deep you compress, how quickly, and really coaches the clinicians," he said.On the monitor's screen, Quinn noted, appears the rhythm of the CPR, the ups and downs, and even reports any changes during defibrillation.Quinn remarked there is also this kind of feedback provided via the bag valve mask sensor, which is connected to the monitor's computer. When they put an airway in a patient, Quinn said, there's a sensor attached to the airway that feeds information back to the monitor. Because of the high cost, they don't carry automatic ventilators, Quinn noted, but the monitor gives them closer control over ventilation required, allowing emerstion required, allowing emergency personnel to set the volume of air they need to administer.From there, the machine tells how many breaths-per-minute, how much volume is being given, and amazingly coaches when to squeeze the bag, with a flashing countdown sequence in the lower left-hand corner.Although they're still using the bags manually to ventilate patients, Quinn said, this helps tremendously, especially because each person's lung capacity's different.The monitors also assist providers treating traumatic brain injuries, provid-ing a trend of the patient's immediate vital signs. Quinn, said it reads how much oxygen is in the patient's blood, how much CO2 they're putting out, reports the blood pressure every five minutes, and takes little readings placing them on the graph, where they can confirm the patient's blood pressure is at a safe level.Quinn received these new monitors after going to the Kent County Commissioners with his request to change the previous contract with Physio-Control to Zoll.During the meeting in July, Quinn provided them a less than stellar review of the previous monitors. Side-by-side with Pete Landon, director of Emergency Services, Quinn gave the commissioners a glimpse of his frustrations with the older machines and his plan to replace them.Quinn said, since he took over as Chief in February, he had ordered two monitors, quickly realizing the shortage was a problem. He then used grant money provided by Maryland Emergency Services, and ordered another one, budgeted for FY24, but lamented that the company he had a contract with was inconsistent with their deliveries.Additionally, Physio-Control had other problems, Quinn added. They didn't upgrade their equipment for some time. He said if something broke inside of the machines, internally, like a chip or a motherboard issue, it didn't get repaired.He said they would be provided loaners, but the problem with those were they were different models - often not compatible with the ones they had.So Quinn, wanting to fix his budget, tired of the inconsistency, sought information from the competitors of these monitors, talking to the Zoll sales representative.He told the commissioners he definitely found something better.All new equipment.A package deal."They'll give us six new monitors up front then put us in a five-year payment plan, replacing all the monitors in our fleet," Quinn said.And, he added, no indeterminate date of delivery either.The contract with Zoll is an annual payment of $59,453 that runs from 2024 through 2028. And it's money well spent.Landon lauded Quinn's efforts, "What he's come up with is a plan that not only will save money for the county in the long run, but also brings together the training and maintenance of the equipment while also being able to replace it in an accelerated fashion."Commissioner John Price saw it was imperative to move with speed in order to get the new contract signed and made a motion to approve. It was an unanimous decision in the yes column.From the commissioner's approval, to signing the contract, and getting the monitors was less than a month.Quinn, who has been with the Kent County Emergency services for nine years, starting out as a dispatcher, sees big possibilities ahead for the department he's now in charge of, at only 30 years of age."I'm very passionate about this system. It has a lot of potential. We're one of the smallest agencies on the Eastern Shore. That can be good or bad, but it gives us the opportunity to work together."He acknowledged the new machines, especially intricate ones, like Zoll, are an adjustment, but commended his crew dealing with the transition training."I'm proud of my staff. Change is hard, but they've been showing they're really committed to not only me, but supporting us as an agency to get better. This was just the first step." 
 
 Caption: WILL BONTRAGER
 
Chief Logan Quinn shows the capabilities of one of the seven new cardiac monitors now being utilized by Kent County Emergency Services. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on new cardiac monitoring technology improving emergency medical services, emphasizing healthcare outcomes, medical equipment advancements, and paramedic training. While public safety and local government aspects are mentioned, the core subject is healthcare innovation.

title: Choptank Health expands school health services
content:
Choptank Health expands school health services

 October 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 453
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Choptank Community Health System is expanding its schoolbased services in Caroline and Talbot County Public Schools with the addition of three new behavioral health providers.Behavioral health therapists Maura Cavalieri and Fiona Kay have joined Choptank Health's Talbot County Public Schools health center team, and behavioral health therapist Reina Ronquillo joins behavioral health provider Lindsay Newcomb in serving the students at Caroline County Public Schools."Choptank Health recognizes the importance of behavioral health as part of the integrated health services we provide to our patients, and that includes students enrolled in our School-Based Health Centers throughout Maryland's Mid-Shore," said Choptank Health President and CEO Sara Rich. "These three new providers are part of our treating the whole person with medical, dental, and behavioral health services."Behavioral health therapist Maura Cavalieri holds a Master of Science in education from the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Education and a Bachelor of Arts in psychology with a minor in justice, law, and society from Washington College.She holds a trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy certification, with counseling experience in school and family environments, including the William Meredith School and Family Center at Jefferson in Philadelphia. Cavalieri sees students at Easton Elementary and the St. Michaels campus of schools.Behavioral health therapist Fiona Kay holds a master's of social work from the University of Maryland, Baltimore. She is an experienced school social worker and clinical mental health therapist in local and rural settings.Her experience includes working with Talbot County Public Schools, For All Seasons, Eastern Shore Psychological Services and the Caroline County Department ofSocial Services. Kay sees students at Easton Middle School, Easton High School and White Marsh Elementary School.Behavioral health therapist Reina Ronquillo received her master's degree in social work from Salisbury University and holds a certificate in advanced trauma treatment Level 1 from the Ferentz Institute.Before joining Choptank Health, Ronquillo worked for Channel Marker in Easton and Denton, Maryland, most recently serving as an adult services director, and working in crisis and youth services.Her community involvement includes serving with the Caroline YMCA Mentor Program, Asian Student Social Workers and the Special Education Citizens Advisory Committee. Ronquillo sees students at Preston Elementary, Federalsburg Elementary and Colonel Richardson Middle and High Schools.Behavioral health provider Lindsay Newcomb joined Choptank Health as the first school-based behavioral health provider in the summer of2022. She holds a Bachelor ofArts in social work with a minor in psychology from Salisbury University and completed the Advanced Standing Social Work Program at the University of Maryland, Baltimore.Newcomb's experience includes working as a Foster Care Caseworker, Parent Education Coordinator, Addictions Therapist, Mental Health Therapist and Behavioral Health Interventionist. She sees students at Denton Elementary, Goldsboro Elementary, Ridgely Elementary School, Lockerman Middle School, and North Caroline High School.

title: State sees surge in COVID-19 cases
author: Shifra Dayak; Capital News Service
content:
State sees surge in COVID-19 cases

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Shifra Dayak; Capital News Service | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 840
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - Maryland is seeing a surge in COVID cases that mirrors national trends - and experts say it might continue as the state heads into respiratory disease season and as some residents take lax approaches to preventive measures.The rate of reported COVID-19 cases in the state saw an uptick during September. Sept. 11 saw the highest recorded case rate in Maryland, with 6.64 cases per 100,000 people. Case rates have seen a gradual decline since then, but are still sitting above rates during the summer months.Before last month, the last time that case rates in the state were above five cases per 100,000 residents was in March.Data from the Maryland Department of Health shows that in September 2022, reported COVID-19 infection rates ranged from 12.08 to 17.06 cases per 100,000 residents. Case rates last month ranged from 4.54 to 6.64 cases per 100,000 people, meaning this year's numbers look better than last year's.But Kate McPhaul, an associate research professor in the University of Maryland's School of Public Health, said the prevalence of testing is lower now than earlier in the pandemic.Amid the September surge, President Joe Biden's administration announced last week that it is appropriating $600 million to companies that produce COVID-19 testing kits to boost the number of tests manufactured in the nation.The same day, the administration announced that all households in the country can request four free rapid-testing kits through covid. gov/tests. Free COVID-19 tests previously were available via mail from January 2022 until June of this year.McPhaul warned that despite a resurgence in testing options, current case numbers may not be entirely accurate because fewer people overall are testing and milder cases have likely not all been reported to the state.However, there's a general indication that there has been a surge in recent weeks, including through anecdotal evidence, she said.This fall surge indicates that COVID-19 could be showing signs of spiking seasonally, McPhaul said, but since it is still a relatively new virus, predicting its behavior is difficult.In line with the surge in cases, hospitalizations and deaths in Maryland have also increased between the start of summer and now, state health department data shows.These upticks will likely continue in the coming months, according to Kristen Coleman, an assistant professor in the University of Maryland's public health school.Coleman said that reinstating preventive measures like masking and air filtration in public spaces, classrooms and more could help keep the surge at bay."I expect that (cases) will continue to climb," Coleman said. "This fall, because of the uptick, I do see more people masking, but certainly not as many as in the beginning of the pandemic." A poll by the business intelligence company Morning Consult in May showed that only 24% of all United States adults were "very" concerned about COVID-19. It's a number that's steadily declined since the start of the pandemic. In April 2020, comparatively, 65% of adults told Morning Consult they were "very concerned." For McPhaul, this decline in concern is evident through a drop in people masking and seeking out the most recent booster dose of the COVID-19 vaccine."People want the pandemic to be over with and to me right now, it seems like there's a bit of a disconnect with the COVID rate going up. A lot of the behaviors that mitigate getting sick kind of don't seem to be happening," McPhaul said.The U.S. Food and Drug Administration in mid-September approved an updated COVID-19 booster vaccine that targets newer variants that have been fueling a rise in cases. But this booster has not been widely administered, McPhaul said.Only 24% of Maryland's population has received an updated bivalent booster vaccine at all, according to the Centers for Disease Control. Additional tracking shows that few residents in the region and nationally have received the most recent booster dose.In addition to the case surge in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia also are seeing similar trends and similar attitudes when it comes to masking and vaccines.Between the beginning of August and mid-September, Virginia's Department of Health recorded an uptick in reported COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations for COVID-19. In all except four of Virginia's 139 counties and independent cities, fewer than 25% of residents have received all the CDC-recommended doses of the COVID-19 vaccine, according to data from the department.Numbers across the past month in Washington, D.C., align with national trends.The rate of weekly reported cases per 100,000 city residents saw a steady uptick from 11.7 cases on Aug. 19 to 33.6 cases on Sept. 9, according to DC Health.As cases may continue rising in the region, McPhaul encouraged area residents to think about preventive measures in their communities, including masking around high-risk individuals and getting vaccinated against respiratory diseases like COVID-19, RSV (respiratory syncytial virus) and the flu."I think people just need to get that person in their head that they're protecting," she said. "All of that stuff that we were promoting during the pandemic can continue to be utilized in the prevention of all of the airborne infections." 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it mentions national trends, the core content is centered on health metrics and medical responses, making 'Health' the most precise category.

title: Students learn to save a life - St. Michaels Y training session prepares students for emergencies
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Students learn to save a life - St. Michaels Y training session prepares students for emergencies

 October 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 554
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS-Nine middle school students gained lifesaving skills Wednesday afternoon, thanks to a partnership between the St. Michaels Community Center, St. Michaels Youth & Law Enforcement (SMYLE), Talbot County Emergency Services and the Perkins Family YMCA.Talbot County paramedic Rachael Cox led the afterschool CPR and AED training class at the Y, guiding the young students through the steps to take in an emergency.The class was free for all who participated, thanks to a $200 donation from SMYLE, the St. Michaels Police Department's youth program, that covered certification costs for the students. The St. Michaels Community Center assisted in facilitating the program.Cox began her class by showing how to check if a person is responsive, then asked the students what they thought the next step was.The answer? Calling 911 and staying on the line with the dispatcher.The next step, as Cox demonstrated, is checking if the person is breathing. If not, it's time to start chest compressions, she said.Each student practiced chest compressions on practice manikins and learned how to use an AED before moving on to learning how to do CPR on infants.As a community risk reduction paramedic and CPR and AED coordinator for Talbot County, Cox loves teaching. She likes being able to introduce preteens and teenagers to CPR, first aid and AED skills to prepare them for any emergency situation, even if they're alone without adults present."I feel like we call EMS, police, fire and dispatch first responders, but I really don't believe we're first responders because we're not there when the emergency happens-the community is," she said. "And that's why I feel these types of classes are so important."Amethyst Monroe, a Perkins Family YMCA staffer who supervised Wednesday's class, is continuing to coordinate other developing middle school programs. She's planning another CPR and AED session soon.Monroe's aim is to make sure future programs are lowcost and provide the area's youth with more life skills.Anyone who wishes to support future after-school programming at the Perkins Family YMCA can donate to the center's annual campaign or reach out to Tracy Eutsler, the Y's executive director, at teutsler@ymcachesapeake.org.Those who are interested in scheduling CPR and AED classes can contact Rachael Cox at rcox@talbotdes.org. 
 
 Caption: NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Talbot County paramedic Rachael Cox demonstrates how to use AED chest pads on a practice manikin.
 
NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Two young girls team up to save the life of their practice manikin. One does chest compressions while the other prepares the AED.
 
NATALlE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Nine St. Michaels middle schoolers smile for a photo before taking a lifesaving CPR and AED skills class. The students were joined by the adults who helped make it happen.
 
NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Amethyst Monroe, left, shows three young students how to deliver back blows to infants who are choking.
 
NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
One young girl practices two-finger chest compressions on an infant practice manikin as another intently watches her technique.
 
NATALlE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
St. Michaels Police Department PFC Justin Newcomb, center, presents Perkins Family YMCA staffer Amethyst Monroe with a $200 check to cover certification costs for a youth CPR and AED class. Left to right: St. Michaels Police Chief Jeff Oswald, Talbot County paramedic Rachael Cox, Newcomb, Monroe, St. Michaels Community Center Executive Director Patrick Rofe.
 
NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Four young students practice chest compressions on infant manikins.
