title: Critical Condition? - Nursing home industry, group of senators push against Biden's bid to require more nursing staff at facilities
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg Newspapers
content:
Critical Condition? - Nursing home industry, group of senators push against Biden's bid to require more nursing staff at facilities

 October 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; Apg Newspapers | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1488
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The nursing home and assisted living industries - along with a number of federal lawmakers - are pushing against a Biden administration plan to require more staffing at facilities including having registered nurses be on-site 24/7.Last month, the White House unveiled details of new rules and regulations on nursing homes - which receive $100 billion annually in Medicare, Medicaid and other U.S. government payments.A centerpiece of the push (and industry opposition to it) centers on federally mandated staffing of registered nurses and nursing aides."If finalized, the proposal would require every facility to have a registered nurse on site 24/7, to have a certain minimum number of registered nurses and nurse aides to help provide routine care, and to staff according to resident needs based on a robust assessment of the facility's residents," the Biden administration said in its September proposal.The rule would apply to approximately 15,000 nursing homes with 1.2 million patients/residents nationwide.The Democratic administration is also promising increased oversight of long-term care facilities spending of Medicare and Medicaid as well as "inappropriate prescribing of antipsychotic medications." The White House is also concerned about private equity firms buying up nursing homes and assisted living centers and subsequent impacts on care.The push would also have facilities provide at least 33 minutes of care to patients from a registered nurse and just under 2.5 hours of care from nursing aides each day."This means a nursing home would need roughly ten nurse aides per each 8-hour shift in a facility with 100 residents," according to the White House briefing report.The rules would not usurp states with even higher personnel requirements.According to an analysis by the Kaiser Family Foundation, more than 80% of facilities would have hire additional nursing staff if the rules go in place - including 90% of for-profit nursing homes and 60% of nonprofit and government-run centers.The Biden administration said understaffed facilities increase the likelihoods of patient injuries and deaths as well as substandard care. "When nursing homes stretch workers too thin, residents may be forced to go without basic necessities like hot meals and regular baths, or even forced to lie in wet and soiled diapers for hours," the White House said in a Sept. 1 briefing paper on the new regulations.To help address the staffing needs, CMS says it is launching a $75 million effort to help train and recruit new nurses including with scholarships and tuition reimbursements.Industry opposition Long-term and congregate care industry groups contend the staffing rules are burdensome and will put facilities out of business - especially in rural and already underserved areas - as their sector faces continued and post-pandemic labor shortages.The American Health Care Association and National Center for Assisted Living say the Biden personnel rules will require nursing homes to hire more than 102,100 new full-time workers (including more than 22,000 registered nurses and more than 80,000 nurses aides).The groups say it will cost the nursing home industry $6.8 billion annually - challenging a $4 billion per year estimate from the U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.If nursing homes are required to reduce their numbers of beds available because of staffing rules and shortages that could impact more than 280,000 congregate care residents, many of them on Medicaid, the industry associations argue."If this rule is finalized without the financial support that nursing homes will need to hire these additional workers, hundreds of thousands of seniors will be at risk of losing the care they need," said Cory Rutledge, chief assurance officer at Clifton Larson Allen LLP (CLA), a Minneapolis-based professional service and accounting firm that analyzed the federal proposals for the two industry groups.Political pushback The industry - and its push against the Biden efforts - has some influential friends in Washington.Twenty-eight U.S. senators wrote U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Service Administrator Chiquita Brooks-La-Sure Sept. 29 voicing concerns about President Joe Biden's push for new staffing requirements on nursing homes and assisted living centers.The 23 Republican, 3 Democratic and 2 independent senators worried about the "staffing mandates" include Montana Sens. Jon Tester, a Democrat, and Steve Daines, a Republican, as well as U.S. Sens.Marco Rubio, R-Florida, James Lankford, R-Oklahoma.Kyrsten Sinema, I-Arizona, Jean Shaheen, D-New Hampshire, Marsha Blackburn, R-Tennessee, Jim Risch R-Idaho, Thom Tillis, R-NC, and Joe Manchin, D-West Virginia."In many parts of the country, America's longterm care facilities are facing severe workforce shortage issues that are harming access to critical care for our nation's seniors. With this in mind, we are deeply concerned that now is the worst possible time for the United States to establish the nation's first federal staffing mandate for long term care facilities," the senators said in their correspondence."We believe the rule as proposed is overly burdensome and will result in additional closures and decreased access to care." The senators want President Joe Biden to rescind the rule and find "alternative approaches" to labor challenges.Tester previously voiced opposition to the Biden nursing home efforts in September and earlier this year and wants different staffing rules for rural areas."I fear a one-size-fitsall staffing mandate would undermine access to care for patients, particularly in rural communities.Instead, I urge you to work with Congress and rural stakeholders on tailored solutions that address the severe workforce challenges in underserved areas," Tester said in a June letter to the Biden administration. "A blanket staffing mandate would not account for individual facilities' operational capabilities and staffing circumstances." His office cites Montana Health Care Association numbers showing 11 nursing homes have closed statewide since 2021 (including the loss of 850 long-term care bids last year.)Since 2021, Montana has seen the closure of 11 nursing homes, and in 2022 alone, the state lost more than 850 nursing home beds, according to the Montana Health Care Association.U.S. Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers, a Washington state Republican who chairs the House Energy and Commerce Committee, also worries the new mandate will put rural nursing homes in a bind."The rule will put nursing homes - particularly in rural areas - in an impossible dilemma as they grapple with how to manage current occupancy levels with the insufficient workforce available to meet the requirements. This rule fails to adequately balance the needs of seniors and nursing home staff in the face of the current staffing shortage gripping our nation."Nursing homes would have three years in rural areas to abide by the 24/7 RN mandate and five years to get in line with all the new rules. Urban and suburban facilities would have two years to have RN's on staff around-theclock and three years for all the other mandates, according to CMS.Labor unions support There are some hardship provisions for facilities with chronic staffing shortages in underserved areas. Comments on the new rules are being accepted until Nov. 6.In many states, a distinct minority nursing homes are currently in compliance with the proposed staffing levels.Those lower percentages include California (21%), Florida (20%), Texas (4%), New York (14%), Idaho (31%), Maryland (17%), Delaware (16%), Wyoming (38%), Montana (38%), Wisconsin (37%), Georgia (6%) and Louisiana (1%), according to KFF.States with higher current compliance levels based on the proposed nursing staff regulations include Oregon (63%), Washington (49%), North Dakota (76%), Maine (75%), Vermont (75%) and Alaska (100%). Those states have staffing rules above and beyond the current federal benchmarks.Part of Biden's push stems from the coronavirus pandemic which saw more than 200,000 nursing home residents and staff deaths attributed to the virus - approximately one-fifth of all deaths attributed to the pandemic nationally.Nursing homes already report labor struggles with 86% reporting staffing shortages and 96% struggling to hire staff, according to AHCA. That includes nursing aides who sometimes make at or barely above state minimum wage levels with pay at times a kin to service and retail workers.While some patient advocates wanted Biden to go even farther with new requirements, labor unions representing nursing home workers support the new federal push."Our country's long term care system is in the midst of a catastrophic crisis, and nursing home workers and residents have suffered unspeakable consequences. In the absence of a federal staffing standard, nursing home workers have endured complete physical, mental and emotional exhaustion due to understaffed shifts and unsafe working conditions, and nursing home residents have been robbed of the quality care and quality of life they deserve,' said SEIU International President Mary Kay Henry after the rule's release last month.AFLCIO President Liz Shuler also backs Biden's push to require more transparency related to nursing home ownership, finances and use of Medicare and Medicaid funds."Workers and the families of residents have been sounding the alarm for decades about the need for a minimum national staffing standard in nursing homes, and we commend the Biden-Harris administration for answering the call." 
 
 Caption: ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
Residents dine together in the dining hall at River Walk, an independent senior housing facility, in New York, Thursday, April 1, 2021.
 
ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
President Joe Biden in the Roosevelt Room of the White House, Friday, Oct. 6, 2023, in Washington. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on federal healthcare policy regarding nursing home staffing requirements, patient care standards, and industry impacts. While there are economic and political elements, the core subject is healthcare regulation and patient safety.

title: It's about community - Chesapeake Bay Walk to Defeat ALS set for Oct. 22 in Centreville
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
It's about community - Chesapeake Bay Walk to Defeat ALS set for Oct. 22 in Centreville

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 892
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE - The Chesapeake Bay Walk to Defeat ALS is on track to reach its $35,000 goal on Sunday, Oct. 22, and organizers are hoping last minute walkers and supporters will join the fight.Walkers will sign in at 9 a.m. at Route 18 Park in Centreville. Even those who wake up and decide to participate that day can get in on the action and register at the walk.When Pam Clark Edwards of Centreville, was diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), in February 2021, her family and friends not only rallied around her, they lost no time launching the effort to raise funds for the ALS Association.Edwards' daughters, Meredith Kulbacki of Centreville and Morgan Edwards of Winter Garden, Florida, spearheaded the Oct. 2022 Walk that rallied some 140 people who walked, ran and wheeled to raise over $30,000.Their team, Pam's Praying Pineapples, will be joined by 10 additional teams this year.As of the beginning of October, the local walk had raised over 80% of its goal."That's pretty amazing," Kulbacki said. "I think we can definitely get close to that, if not reach it by the walk." The community has reached out to help. Other fundraising in the form of raffles and a 50/50 drawing will be held, and about 40 items were donated by local businesses.For example, "we have a foursome golf outing at Queenstown Harbor, an official NFLfootball signed by Justin Tucker of the Baltimore Ravens, a gift basket from Draper Brothers liquor store, cosmetic gift bags, jewelry and various services," Meredith said.Fun activities include pumpkin decorating for kids.The ALS chapter from D.C., Maryland and Virginia will be sending helpers to be stationed at tables, so people can find out more information about ALS itself, and maybe about how they can help, Kulbacki said."If they have become a caretaker to someone with ALS," she said. "There will be workers there to help them through that." Information will be available for people who have been diagnosed with ALS.In fact, some members of Edwards' care team at Johns Hopkins will be attending the walk Ebb Tide Tent & Party Rentals in Queenstown donated a large tent, while Queen Anne's County Parks and Recreation donated the use of the park.Community support has been "just amazing," Edwards said."Having the support of the community helps us as a family deal with all of this," she said.The Clark family has deep roots in the county. Pam and her husband, Fred, and Kulbacki and her family live on the family farm just down the road from the park where the walk will be held.Pam is a retired teacher in Queen Anne's County Public Schools.Pam's mother, June, and her brother Jeff have canvassed local business owners, who are supporting their longtime neighbors.Edwards' longtime friends and colleagues are part of the small committee helping her daughters. Connie Dean, Barb Thompson and Bobbie King have rallied around the Edwards family to help out where they can to help organize the walk.Kulbacki, who was raised in Centreville, spent eight years in York, Pennsylvania, and recently moved back. "It means everything to me. It means family," she said.During the COVID pandemic, she and her family, which includes her husband and two children, decided to move back home "on a whim." "We felt so alone with just no family and (few) friends there," she said. "We had no idea that this would happen.We say it was almost like God told us. He helped us through this, and it was almost a blessing in disguise that we moved home, so that we could help my mom and my dad and my family through this." "So not only to be here with them, and then also to have so much support from everybody in the community and all of our friends and family - it's just amazing and we're so thankful for that," Mer said.Kulbacki knew about the ALS Association's Walk to Defeat ALS through a sad coincidence. The mother of a close friend in Pennsylvania died from ALS about a year before the Kulbackis moved to Maryland, and Kulbacki had participated in a Pennsylvania Walk in memory of Becky Miller's mom."I didn't know that it would affect me so deeply a year later, so it's been amazing to still be friends with her and have support from her because she knows what I'm going through," Mer said."You never know when ALS may affect a friend or family member," Edwards said. "It is becoming, I think, more prevalent. I know five people who have passed away from it, not because I have been in this situation - these are people who have been in my life." "It's a disease that they really do not have a treatment or cure for yet, and we just need to put money into the resources for help for these families, as well as to provide money for research," she said.To register online for the Oct. 22 Walk, visit Walkto-DefeatALS.org.For more information about the ALS Association, donating your time or resources and supporting the Walk to Defeat ALS Chesapeake Bay, visit als.org or contact coordinator Tara Huang at tara.huang@als.org. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Team Chesapeake Bay is ready to lead the Walk to Defeat ALS Oct. 22. From left are, Fred Edwards, Pam Clark Edwards, Meredith Kulbacki, June Clark and Tara Huang from the ALS Association's headquarters in Rockville. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community event organized to raise funds for the ALS Association, highlighting health awareness and support for a medical condition. While it involves local community efforts, the primary purpose is health-related advocacy.

title: UM Shore Regional Health celebrates 'health care heroes' - Luncheons, unveiled murals recognize health care workers' efforts during CO VID-19 pandemic
author: Contributed
content:
UM Shore Regional Health celebrates 'health care heroes' - Luncheons, unveiled murals recognize health care workers' efforts during CO VID-19 pandemic

 October 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 628
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - UM Shore Regional Health's Senior Leadership team recently hosted post-COVID luncheons for team members in each of the five counties UM SRH serves - Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Talbot and Queen Anne's - to celebrate the World Health Organization declaring an end to the COVID-19 public health emergency earlier this year and to honor all team members who served during the pandemic as "caregivers." The luncheons also served as a remembrance for those team members who gave the ultimate sacrifice during the pandemic and lost their lives, Calvin Molock, Jr. and Bronte Johnson.Family members of both Molock and Johnson attended the luncheon in Easton. Plaques honoring Molock and Johnson will be placed at UM Shore Medical Centers at Cambridge, Chestertown and Easton, as well as UM Shore Medical Pavilions at Denton and Queenstown."COVID made us here at Shore, and health care teams and community members everywhere, realize very quickly how nimble and course-corrective we had to be as new information on COVID came to light," said William Huffner, MD, Chief Medical Officer and Senior Vice President, Medical Affairs, UM SRH."There were a lot of unsung heroes during COVID, but especially infection prevention teams everywhere, who helped us address the changes as they came.We all are just so appreciative of everyone who stepped up to help our caregivers and communities during this challenging time and these luncheons are just a small token of our appreciation for our team's dedication." Artwork honoring health care heroes was unveiled during the post-COVID luncheons in Cambridge, Chestertown, Easton and Queenstown.During fall 2022, Kelly Strannahan, Patient Experience Manager at UM SRH, reached out to the Kent Cultural Alliance with an idea of how to honor the commitment of UM SRH team members and health care workers to the communities UM SRH serves in a meaningful and permanent way.The Kent Cultural Alliance proposed having a competition to create mural-size artwork for each UM SRH facility in each county and collaborated with arts councils in Dorchester, Talbot and Queen Anne's counties, working with each to select an artist from their county to complete the commission.Each artist was provided with canvases, made possible with the support of The Finishing Touch in Chestertown.In Dorchester County, the artist is Miriam Moran, for Talbot County, the artist is Kevin Garber, and in Queen Anne's County, then-high school senior Claire Parker was selected.In Kent County, the honor was given to Paul Santori, who early on in the pandemic had a severe case of COVID and was hospitalized at UM Shore Medical Center at Chestertown. Santori succumbed to a non-COVID related health issue in winter 2023.His wife, Inez Santori, made the decision in conversation with Kent Cultural Alliance Director John Schratwieser to transfer the commission to Paul's dear friend, Ron Akins. Paul had sketched his ideas while lying in the hospital for several weeks before his death. With Inez's support, Ron was able to realize Paul's vision for the mural.Each of the county arts councils provided a stipend of $1,250 for their respective artist, and this stipend was supported in part by Kent County's Hedgelawn Foundation.The five arts councils receive funding from the Community Arts Development program of the Maryland State Arts Council, which receives financial support from the National Endowment for the Arts. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF UM SHORE REGIONAL HEALTH
 
Pictured, from left, at the unveiling of artwork at UM Shore Medical Center at Easton, are Joan Levy, executive director of the Talbot County Arts Council; artist Kevin Garber; Sherri Hobbs-Messick, chief quality, safety and experience officer at UM Shore Regional Health; LuAnn Brady, senior vice president and COO of UM SRH; Ken Kozel, president and CEO of UM SRH; and William Huffner, MD, chief medical officer and senior vice president of medical affairs at UM SRH. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on UM Shore Regional Health's recognition of healthcare workers during the COVID-19 pandemic, including events, memorials, and artwork honoring their efforts. While Arts & Culture is tangentially related to the murals, the primary subject is healthcare services and pandemic response.

title: 'We know stigma is killing people' - Childhood traumas often drive addictions, Societal judgments often hinder recovery
author: Laura Tayman
content:
'We know stigma is killing people' - Childhood traumas often drive addictions, Societal judgments often hinder recovery

 October 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 669
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE - Emily Keller, the Special Secretary of Opioid Response for Maryland's Governor Wes Moore, shared her experience with the opioid epidemic right at the beginning of the Queen Anne's County Community Overdose Action Town Hall."I lost my best friend Ashley to an overdose in 2016. She should have had more treatment options. Unfortunately, my story isn't unique." The town hall held Sept. 21 at Kent Island High School, was the ninth out of 24 counties that the State of Maryland's "Before It's Too Late" team is holding across the state, sponsored by state representatives who are continue to tackle the opioid epidemic. A panel of staff from county offices were on hand to share their efforts and listen to testimony from the community.Major Christopher Amoia, Operations Commander of the Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office, gave data he believes indicates the collaboration among county agencies is working. "Since 2018 to the present, we had a reduction of overdoses by 380%, and deaths were lowered 267%," he said. Amoia credited expanding programs like DARE and promoting community awareness. Still, as of the day of the meeting, the number of overdoses to date this year is even with all of 2022.Deputy State's Attorney Christine Rickard shared how her team partnered with law enforcement. "We are going after the drug dealers who are dealing this poison to our residents," she said. She is also working with the county's Drug Court. "We know why people are committing crimes-to support their habits. We are working to get them the help they need." There are positive things happening with the county's drug court program, shared the Honorable Judge Lynn Knight, "We used to just lock addicts away," she said. "Now we are getting very involved with the option of plea deals that allow the offender to enter a treatment program, complete 12-18 months, keep checking in with the court, and submit to regular drug tests." County Commissioner Jim Moran said county efforts have also focused on youth, saying, "We tell them we don't want them to be a statistic." Community member Paula Dickerson of Grasonville addressed the panel, "We feel unseen. We have a community center that sits empty despite our area that has crime and an obvious drug problem." Dickerson, who is now 27 years sober, accepted the challenge from Moran to gather community members and arrange for a similar presentation at the Grasonville Community Center.Linda Kohler, Executive Director of Chesapeake Charities, encouraged the panel to consider creating more sober living homes for adults. "Currently, there is one in Talbot County, ready to assist with services like providing drives to rehab and finding jobs." Kohler said they have a grant now to train more peer support specialists.Tom McKnight, (a county resident who says he is 32 years sober) suggested adults who are now sober might be a better way to reach students."We've lived it," said McKnight."We have stories to tell." Madeline Eskew, a student at Kent Island High School, had an uncle die from substance abuse in 2010 and a close cousin had to move out of state to find an acceptable treatment facility. "I just encourage officials to focus more on the mental health side of the problem." Keller told Eskew, "More often than not, addicts are masking an adverse childhood experience and try to suppress their pain." Kent Island High School student Avery Mortimore voiced concern about students who take the big step to access treatment but face hostile peers when they return to school. "They don't want to be judged or shamed. They can't fully re-acclimate and don't fit in." "We know stigma is killing people," said Keller. "It's the reason people aren't getting help. We see it in adults as well." When asked what she would do in that situation, Mortimore said, "I would focus not just on stopping addiction before it starts but on what you do during and after treatment." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
Laura Reno from Not My Child Opioid Foundation signs a banner in support of recovery from opioid use. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opioid epidemic, addiction recovery, stigma, and healthcare efforts. While public safety and local government aspects are mentioned, the core theme revolves around health crises, treatment programs, and societal health impacts.

title: The Orthopedic Center hosts informational event
author: Contributed
content:
The Orthopedic Center hosts informational event

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 262
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - UM Shore Regional Health recently hosted a community presentation at UM Shore Medical Center at Easton on orthopedic and rehabilitative services offered at The Orthopedic Center.Providers from TOC, a partner of UM SRH, presented information on surgery, pain relief, prehabilitation and rehabilitation services.Jason Jancosko, DO, and Kevin McCoy, MD, spoke about the latest surgical techniques for shoulder and hip surgeries.Myron Szczukowski, MD, described a new innovative cold therapy (cryoneurolysis) that can relieve about 50% of patient knee pain.Sheila Taylor, DO, explained additional non-surgical pain relief options including shock wave therapy, platelet rich plasma, and ultrasound guided needling techniques for tendon pain relief.Jennifer Baima, MD, addressed prehabilitation strategies, such as specific exercise programs, prior to surgeries, radiation therapy and other procedures.And Chris Jobeck, PT at Shore Rehabilitation as Easton, provided videos of the Rehab Center's state-of-the art equipment, including the Guldman Lift and Lokomat."The event was an excellent forum to discuss everything The Orthopedic Center and our Shore Rehab team have to offer patients undergoing orthopedic surgery and rehabilitation," said event organizer Khalid Kurtom, the regional chair of UM Shore's Department of Surgery."These teams work closely together to give our patients state of the art orthopedic surgery and rehabilitation care that promotes the experience and outcomes possible. We are fortunate to have their expertise here on the Shore." For more information about TOC, visit theorthopediccenter.net or call 410-820-8226.

title: Paramedic Foundation raising funds for AED access
author: Contributed
content:
Paramedic Foundation raising funds for AED access

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: A9 | Section: News 
 
 607
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Talbot Paramedic Foundation is conducting its annual direct mail fund drive appeal in Talbot County.The foundation is a national leader, along with the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services and other partners, in placing public access AEDs in area parks and recreational facilities. The program was recently renamed Talbot CARES, or Talbot Cardiac Arrest Rescue Emergency Station."Talbot CARES continues to expand the number of parks where the units are located," said Talbot Paramedic Foundation President Wayne Dyott. "As one of the largest such projects in the country, the goal is to make public access AEDs available at recreational locations throughout Talbot County. Placing AEDs in our communities and parks allows for a greater chance of survival in these time-critical emergencies."There are over 200 AEDs located throughout the community in businesses, government facilities and other locations that are part of the foundation's efforts to increase access in Talbot County.For example, local law enforcement vehicles carry AEDs and officers are immediately dispatched along with EMS and fire/rescue units to any reported cardiac arrest.The foundation also sponsors the Sylvia Gannon and Gary Jones Memorial Scholarships supporting local students pursuing classes related to Emergency Services.In addition, the foundation's grants have helped the county Department of Emergency Services, as well as Talbot's volunteer fire departments purchase life-saving EMS equipment such as the LUCAS CPR device and power lift stretchers.Dyott said it is never easy to ask for donations, but his group carefully works to do good things in the community with the donations.According to Dyott, "The Talbot Paramedic Foundation has a long history of working toward saving lives by increasing awareness, raising funds, developing life-saving programs, providing training and encouraging paramedic professionalism."Additional information and a link to make a donation can be found at the foundation's website - Talbotparamedic.org.The Talbot Paramedic Foundation is conducting their annual direct mail fund drive appeal in Talbot County.The foundation is a national leader, along with the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services and other partners, in placing public access AEDs in area parks and recreational facilities. title: $650,000 allocated for drug prevention program
author: Contributed
content:
$650,000 allocated for drug prevention program

 October 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 360
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - U.S. Senators Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen (both D-Md.) today announced $650,000 in U.S. Department ofJus-tice funding to help implement Big Brothers Big Sisters of the Eastern Shore mentoring programs for youth affected by opioid and other substance misuse."As the opioid epidemic devastates communities across the state each year, drug overdose is claiming the lives of more and more young Marylanders," said the lawmakers in a press release."Early prevention is just one of the many ways we can help win the fight against opioids and other substance misuse. With proper interventions and more community support, we can help curb drug use and improve outcomes for young people who are the most at risk of developing a substance use disorder."The funding was made available through the Office ofJuve-nile Justice Delinquency Prevention (OJJDP) FY 2023 Mentoring for Youth Affected by Opioid and Other Substance Misuse grant program.The federal funds will be used to help implement the youth mentoring program to benefit children impacted by opioids, their families, mentors and communities on Maryland's Eastern Shore.Through this program, Big Brothers Big Sisters of the Eastern Shore will partner with local health departments to provide seminars on opioid and drug use as well as additional training through the learning exchange.The OJJDP FY 2023 Mentoring for Youth Affected by Opioid and Other Substance Misuse grant seeks to enhance and expand mentoring services for children and youth impacted by opioids and other drug misuse.The OJJDP aims to assist youth and their families negatively affected by opioids and other substances, especially youth in historically marginalized and underserved communities who will benefit the most from prevention and intervention programs.The program's goal is to improve outcomes (such as improved academic performance and reduced school dropout rates) for youth impacted by opioids and other substance misuse through mentoring.Senators Cardin and Van Hollen worked to secure $415 million for the Office ofJuvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention (OJJDP) in the Senate fiscal year 2024 appropriations package to further support efforts to connect young people impacted by opioids and other drug misuse with the resources they need to live healthy and stable lives. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland joins DC, 40 other states suing Meta
author: Bridget Byrne; Capital News Service
content:
Maryland joins DC, 40 other states suing Meta

 October 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bridget Byrne; Capital News Service | Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 787
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - Maryland, the District of Columbia and 40 other states are suing Meta alleging that its platforms cause harm to children by building addictive features, Maryland Attorney General Anthony Brown announced Tuesday."Our country is facing a youth mental health crisis fueled by young people's extensive and compulsive use of, and reliance on, social media platforms like Facebook and Instagram," Brown said at a press conference outside Hampstead Hill Academy, a Baltimore public school. "This has placed an entire generation of young people in jeopardy."Maryland and 32 other states are filing a joint lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, and the District of Columbia and eight other states are filing separate complaints in federal, state or local courts.The scope of the legal claims may vary, but all are expected to assert that Meta used harmful and manipulative tactics purposefully to keep children on its platforms.In 2021, a bipartisan coalition of state attorneys general announced an investigation into Meta, focusing on whether the parent company of Instagram and Facebook violated consumer protection laws by promoting the sites' apps to children and teens."Based on the information obtained during that investigation, we allege that Meta's actions have violated the federal Children's Online Privacy Protection Act," Brown said.Nationwide, states have seen a surging youth mental health crisis: the number of children ages 3 to 17 who experienced anxiety or depression from 9.4% in 2016 to 11.8% in 2020 - a 25% increase, according to the National Institute of Health. Maryland ranked 19th in the nation for overall child well-being."Just like Big Tobacco did a generation ago, Meta has chosen to maximize its profits at the expense of public health, specifically the health of our children," Brown charged.In the suit Maryland joined, the attorneys general allege that "Meta has harnessed powerful and unprecedented technologies to entice, engage, and ultimately ensnare youth and teens.""Its motive is profit, and in seeking to maximize its financial gains, Meta has repeatedly misled the public about the substantial dangers of its Social Media Platforms. It has concealed the ways in which these Platforms exploit and manipulate its most vulnerable consumers: teenagers and children. And it has ignored the sweeping damage these Platforms have caused to the mental and physical health of our nation's youth," the filing states.Meta said in a statement that it agreed with "the attorneys general's commitment to providing teens with safe, positive experiences online, and have already introduced over 30 tools to support teens and their families."But Meta added: "We're disappointed that instead of working productively with companies across the industry to create clear, age-appropriate standards for the many apps teens use, the attorneys general have chosen this path."Brown was joined by Hampstead Hill Academy Principal Matthew Hornbeck, who said that over the 20 years he has been at the school he has seen the impact the rise in social media use has had on his students. Hornbeck described measures to curb phone use at Hampstead Hill, but stressed they were "merely a workaround.""(Social media) hijacks normal, healthy thinking," Hornbeck said. "It sucks up so much time and keeps the user wanting more and more. It's not an overstatement to say it can steal big chunks of a childhood.""The urge to check your phone is stronger than any consequence we have at school," he said.Treeme Cannizzaro, an 8th grade student at Hampstead Hill, said at the press conference that limiting phone use in schools does not address the impact social media has on mental health when students are not at school."My friends and I can't help but get on our phones to see what we've missed," Cannizzaro said. "Limiting access to social media has had a positive impact on my mental health during the school day, and I hope that social media companies can find more ways to decrease the anxiety and depression my friends and I feel from social interactions online."In May, the Federal Trade Commission proposed barring Meta from monetizing the data it collects for underage users.Also in May, U.S. Surgeon General Dr. Vivek Murthy issued an advisory stating that, although there are some benefits, social media use presents a "profound risk of harm" for children and called for further research into social media's impact on youth mental health."Children are exposed to harmful content on social media, ranging from violent and sexual content, to bullying and harassment," Murthy said in a statement. "And for too many children, social media use is compromising their sleep and valuable in-person time with family and friends."Efforts to regulate social media's impact on social media have gained traction this year, but also have faced challenges in court. Federal judges blocked newly-passed children's safety laws in California and Arkansas. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a lawsuit alleging that Meta's platforms harm children's mental health through addictive design, directly linking to health impacts. While it involves legal actions (National News), the core issue is the public health crisis tied to social media use.

title: Planning commission OKs new UM Shore facility plan
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Planning commission OKs new UM Shore facility plan

 October 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 439
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Easton Planning Commission on Thursday, Oct. 19 unanimously approved a sketch site plan for the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's new regional medical center with several conditions.The project, which first received planning commission approval of a sketch site plan over a decade ago, resurfaced so hospital officials could discuss an updated sketch plan for the medical center.The proposed six-story, 340,000-square-foot medical center and roughly 55,000-square-foot medical office building are slated to occupy just over 235 acres off of Longwoods Road near U.S. Route 50 in Easton.The largest part of the complex will include a 147-bed hospital, including 122 acute inpatient beds across several units and 25 observation beds, along with labs and imaging rooms and a helipad. The complex will have 18 more beds than the hospital's existing facility.The other main portion of the complex will be utilized for medical offices.Over 1,100 parking spaces, a 36-acre open space area, stormwater management facilities and landscaping are also included in the plan.The new regional medical center will replace the town's existing hospital, which is 3.5 miles away and tucked into downtown Easton.In addition to the large-scale medical center, the hospital system is proposing removal and relocation of a section of Maryland Route 662C and modifying entrances into the Talbot County Community Center, which is adjacent to the property.At the Oct. 19 meeting, the hospital system also sought a waiver of parking lot landscape hedge and vegetative buffer requirements, or approval to plant native grasses and plants instead of hedges to enable proper drainage flow towards proposed stormwater management facilities and to allow for better visibility at parking lot exits.Questions raised by planning commission members during the meeting centered on parking, accessibility, emergency access, landscaping and traffic.After additional discussion, the planning commission voted to approve the sketch site plan with several conditions for the applicant to meet, including addressing remaining comments from the Easton Staff Development Review, meeting with the commission again to review if additional landscape screening is appropriate and working with the town engineer to explore alternatives for emergency access.Though the town's planning commission approved the sketch plan, the start of construction is dependent on receiving a Certificate ofNeed from the Maryland Health Care Commission. UM Shore Regional Health filed the CON application in early January.The hospital anticipates a response from the state by the end of this year or by January 2024, according to Ken Kozel, president and CEO of UM Shore Regional Health. Hospital officials hope to begin construction in late spring 2024.

University of Maryland shore Regional Health's new regional medical center proposed rendering following schematic design phase.

 For All Seasons recently welcomed three interns, Meghan E. McPherson, Brianna Mench and Kevin Nugent, who come from various clinical settings to participate in the internship program.Undergraduate and graduate schools utilize For All Seasons for students who need clinical experiences in social work to meet the requirements of their programs. These hands-on experiences are preparing the next generation of social workers.McPherson is currently the family services case manager and truancy reduction court program intern at the Maryland Judiciary in Cambridge and a care associate in health information management at PinnacleCare.She is pursuing her master's degree in social work at George Mason University and is a graduate of Washington College in Chestertown.Mench joined the For All Seasons Medical team as a preceptor, supervised by Kristen Gordy, RN, MSN, CRNP, psych nurse practitioner.Mench is working as a registered nurse with the Christiana Care Health System and is currently working towards becoming a psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioner while attending Walden University.Nugent was a psychiatric rehabilitation professional at Channel Marker in Cambridge before becoming a graduate student in the Counselor Education Program at the University of Maryland Eastern Shore in Princess Anne.He completed a bachelor of arts degree in psychology at St.Mary's College of Maryland.For All Seasons provides mental health and victim services to children, adults and families across Maryland's Eastern Shore. Services are offered in both English and Spanish and include therapy, psychiatry, victim advocacy, 24-hour crisis hotlines, outreach and community education.For information about For All Seasons and walk-in hours, contact 410-822-1018 or visit ForAllSeasonsInc.org.

title: Psychological practice to host talk on holiday stress
author: Contributed
content:
Psychological practice to host talk on holiday stress

 October 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 8 | Section: News 
 
 240
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Shore Neurocognitive & Behavioral Health, an adult psychological practice in Easton, will host a free community conversation on Thursday, Nov. 2, at 5:30 p.m.Attendees will learn strategies to handle family and other stressors that tend to increase as we enter the holiday season."Personally, this topic is near and dear to me, having lost both of my parents in 2018," said Dr.Maggie Black, Psychologist and co-owner of SNBH. "Since then, my brother and sisters and I can't seem to get the holidays 'right.'" "I want to help others with family conversations that will hopefully lead to more joy and less stress this holiday season." SNBH therapist Jenny Jarrell, LCSW-C, will join Dr.Black in this presentation and will talk about ways to be flexible and let go of expectations, of self and of others that tend to increase stress this time of year."We can draw on past holiday experiences to observe what tends to be stressful for us and spend more time on what's important to us," she said. "We hope to help people focus on what they want to do vs what they have to do this holiday season." "Please bring your questions and stressful scenarios, as our community conversations truly are just that We want to talk with people about what is important to them, not present at them," Black said.Space is limited. Call 443-746-3698 or email maggieblack@snhealth.net to reserve your spot.

title: Community Center to host talk on human-animal bond
author: Contributed
content:
Community Center to host talk on human-animal bond

 October 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 287
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD - Ahead of this Veterans Day, join the Oxford Community Center for an inspiring evening with Meg Daley Olmert, a world-renowned expert on the neurobiology of the human-animal bond.On Thursday, Nov. 2, at 5:30 p.m., Olmert will speak about the profound therapeutic effects of human-animal relationships.Meg Daley Olmert is an accomplished subject expert, author and lecturer, recognized for her groundbreaking book, "Made for Each Other: The Biology of the Human-Animal Bond," published in 2009.This book traces the evolution of the ancient bond between humans and animals, delving into the emerging neuroscience that underlies this profound interspecies connection.With her expertise in the therapeutic effects of the human-animal bond, Olmert has been a trailblazer in the field, and her two TEDx talks have captivated the hearts and minds of thousands."We're thrilled to host Meg and share her wisdom on the healing power of the human-animal connection," said Liza Ledford, Director of OCC. "Her work has made a tremendous impact, especially for our veterans, and her message is perfect for Veterans Day as we honor those who have served our country." In addition to her remarkable contributions to the field, Olmert serves as the science advisor and board member of The Comfort Dog Program of Northern Uganda.She was also a co-creator of Warrior Canine Connection's Mission-Based Trauma Recovery Program at the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda.Additionally, she will be featured in the upcoming documentary, "By My Side," which highlights the impact of service dogs on veterans with trauma. The documentary has been selected for the CFF Virtual Doc program.For more information and to reserve your space, please visit the Oxford Community Center's website at www.oxfordcc.org or contact the center at 410-226-5904

title: Caroline United Way awards seven grants - Focus on mental health, food insecurity, senior services
author: Contributed
content:
Caroline United Way awards seven grants - Focus on mental health, food insecurity, senior services

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 8B | Section: News 
 
 671
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - The United Way of Caroline County recently awarded grants to seven community organizations."Each organization awarded has an intense focus on local needs," United Way President Sherone Thompson said. "We know that every dollar that has been donated will be put to work directly for the benefit of Caroline County citizens." The UWCC chose to focus this year's awards on programs and services that address mental health, food insecurity and programs and services for seniors and the elderly."There are so many needs in our community but we felt these three were the most pressing," past President Samantha Parker said."The pandemic and inflation have created special challenges for our must vulnerable residents, especially children, the elderly and those struggling with a mental health condition." The following organizations received awards from UWCC: Mid-Shore Council on Family Violence: MSCFV's Chesapeake Crisis to Self-Sufficiency Model provides domestic violence victims with a pathway to empowerment that includes hotline services, emergency shelter, on-going case management, counseling and mental health services, economic empowerment, basic living needs, transportation, interpretation/translation, pet safety, support groups, abuser intervention programming, community outreach and awareness.Court-Appointed Special Advocates of Caroline: CASA recruits and trains volunteers who advocate for children in the Caroline County foster care system. CASA volunteers are the eyes and ears of the courts and the voices for the children, monitoring each child's well-being and making recommendations to the court that are in the child's best interest.Critical Repairs Caroline County (formerly Rebuilding Together): The mission of this organization is to enable low-income residents in Caroline County to remain safely in their homes by providing necessary repairs and accessibility improvements they cannot afford. These repairs are intended to improve the residents' quality of life, their overall safety and enable them to access life-supporting activities.Martin's House & Barn (formerly St. Martin's Ministries): The organization assists vulnerable families in Caroline County through a wide variety of programs, including its food pantry, thrift shop, family homeless shelter and homelessness prevention program.His Hope Ministries: Its mission is to offer resources to help vulnerable families, individuals, youth, and elderly citizens experiencing homelessness or living in unstable housing. It operates the largest homeless shelter on the Eastern Shore and provides residents with a wide variety of programs to help achieve their housing goals.Aaron's Place: A community resource center aiding Caroline residents with food insecurity, housing, health and wellness and addressing social determinants of health and health disparities.Caroline Medical Adult Daycare: MADC is a program of services designed to allow health-impaired adults of Caroline County to remain in their homes and community. They live as independently as possible, with dignity and a renewed sense of quality of life, through care in the least restrictive setting, while preventing inappropriate or premature institutionalization.The United Way of Caroline County's mission is to support non-profits meeting the human services needs of our community.For more than 40 years, it has taken care of Caroline County and helped families get back on their feet and thrive. UWCC has given millions of dollars to support the human services needs of the Caroline County community.To learn more about the United Way of Caroline County, including how you can support the mission, visit www.unitedwaycaroline.org.

Seven nonprofit organizations recently received grants from the United Way of Caroline County. title: All hands on deck - How local hospitals handle mass casualty incidents
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
All hands on deck - How local hospitals handle mass casualty incidents

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 3A | Section: News 
 
 757
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - It was all hands on deck Monday morning at two University of Maryland Shore Regional Health facilities as emergency department staff treated patients from a school bus crash in Easton.Ten of the 11 patients involved in the crash between a Caroline County school bus and a SUV were taken to Shore Regional Health facilities - three patients to the hospital in Easton and seven to the freestanding emergency department in Queenstown.The number of patients in need of evaluation and treatment triggered first responders to categorize the crash as a mass casualty incident, or a situation that overwhelms local healthcare systems' resources and capabilities."When (first responders) say, 'we got something bad,' we listen," said Dr.Walter Atha, the regional director of emergency medicine for the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health."They (called) ahead, and that's exactly what happened yesterday: they gave us a heads up and said 'Look, we're going to have numerous (patients), many more' - in fact even (taxing) their own capacity to bring them in," he added.From there, back and forth discussions ensued on which patients could be brought to the hospital in Easton versus the Queenstown facility, though all four of Shore Regional Health's facilities can perform initial resuscitation efforts.An incident command system, or structure that's put in place if there's a large-scale ongoing emergency situation, was also implemented to manage plans to move forward.While emergency medical services personnel triaged patients at the scene Monday morning, a yellow alert, which signifies an internal or external disaster, went out to hospital staff. That partnership between first responders and physicians is crucial in managing an emergent situation.The alert notifies everyone from leadership positions to those on the frontlines to prepare - "just brace yourself" for however the situation may go, Atha said.Sending the systemwide alert lets units far removed from the emergency department prepare to decompress the emergency department's other needs so staff can perform resuscitation if needed.Situational awareness is key when preparing for an influx of patients, Atha said. It's particularly important to evaluate the resources on hand, including personnel needs and the location of certain equipment. The hospital in Easton also can contact an on-call physician in anticipation of increased critical volume.But in preparation for a rush of patients from Monday's crash, an on-call physician wasn't needed - a doctor with expertise in resuscitation concerned about patients needing high level care "came in on his own goodwill" to help, Atha said."So many people in the community say, 'I will come help,'" he said.Treating young patients like those involved in the bus crash can be a challenge though.Atha said physical shock from injuries in children doesn't manifest the same way it does in adults. The resilience of children makes them "notoriously difficult" for first responders to triage because some kids who look well could be seriously injured.Difficulties can also arise with ensuring there is enough staff on hand to answer questions from families and to keep everyone calm.And with any mass casualty incident that occurs in a rural area, distance makes a difference, both positive and negative."Frankly, there's a little advantage in that maybe we have a little extra time if it's far removed in terms of knowing what's coming in, rather than it happening a block away," he said. "On the other hand, you want to get to trauma victims as soon as you can, so that's the challenge: the distance." But still, mass casualty incidents in the Mid-Shore region are "not that frequent," Atha said."This is the largest-scale that I've seen in a while," he said, struggling to remember other serious incidents during his 10-year tenure at the hospital.Even with the low frequency of such incidents in the area, Atha felt the emergency department staff had the resources they needed to respond to it adequately."The feedback I got from the folks on the frontlines who were actually taking care of the patients (said) things went as smoothly as they could," he said.To keep improving emergency department responses to various incidents, hospital staff set up review meetings to debrief on what went well and what didn't. A meeting on the response to the bus crash was held Tuesday morning.Atha commended all who were involved with the Monday's response."It's not just the people who put hands and gloves on those patients; it was everybody at every level stepped up and was ready, I think that's really important," he said. 
 
 Caption: NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
An emergency department staff member at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton works at the nurses' station. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on how local hospitals managed a mass casualty incident from a school bus crash, detailing medical response protocols, emergency department operations, and healthcare system preparedness. While Public Safety is related to emergencies, the primary context is healthcare delivery and medical response infrastructure.

title: County health report shows progress
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
County health report shows progress

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 2B | Section: News 
 
 1004
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - During her biannual report to the Caroline County Commission at its Oct. 24 meeting, Health Officer Robin Cahall touted successes, including significant state grant funding, increased behavioral health services with better outcomes and progress in achieving 2023 initiatives.However, communicable diseases like tuberculosis are present in the county, and the department, along with its partners, is reaching out to vulnerable populations with services.Cahall presented a slide show with Behavioral Health Director Jessica Tuel that provided information on funding, staffing and numbers related to services delivered to county residents.For fiscal year 2023, the health department received about $6.9 million in grant funding. Along with state and local funding, the total is $8.5 million.The approved county match was $409,054 - less than 5% of the total budget for the health department.The department continues to apply for additional grant funding.The fiscal year 2024 budget, however, will increase with a county match of just over $589,000, or about 7% of the department's total budget.Because the state contribution is based on a wealth index, the approximate ratio of state to local percentages of the department's baseline funding is nearly 80% state and just over 20% county.The wealth index hasn't been updated since 1996, Cahall said, but the Maryland Association of County Health Officers has created an ad hoc committee to review the process for determining the formula.Core funding must be used for specific purposes according to the state, and most of that "goes towards our environmental health services," Cahall said.Those local health services include communicable disease control, family planning, maternal and child health, wellness promotion, data management and protective equipment, among others.Among this year's initiatives, the Behavioral Health Program has moved to Denton Plaza, and a second Mobile Treatment Unit is up and running. The department is making progress towards National Public Health Accreditation and expanding chronic disease prevention.The health department's newest partnerships include the ongoing Caroline County Collective Impact."We have several different members of our leadership team that participate in different action teams for collective impact," Cahall said."That's been very successful for us in the sense of collaborating with our community partners and leaders to get some things done." For example, Mobile Integrated Health is a partnership among the Department of Emergency Services, the Basic Life Support Committee and Shore Health, and the Resource Directory Project partners with the Caroline Human Services Council and the Caroline County Public Library.The Communicable Disease, Family Planning and Women and Child Health Division is "definitely one of our priorities," Cahall said.The department performed 180 teburculosis tests and identified 38 latent tuberculosis infections. The department treated 28 of those individuals; primary care providers could treat the others.So far in 2023, the department performed 531 pregnancy tests and a registered nurse handled 1,249 unduplicated office visits. A lot of prenatal care and referrals went to Choptank Community Health providers.commission President Travis Breeding asked about the health department's response to "a really large influx of new English language learners" at the northern end of the county."Are you seeing additional requests for assistance and support among the new American population, the immigrant population?" he asked.Cahall said they were seeing a slight influx in terms of immunization requests, but the department referred people to Choptank Community Health or other providers."We don't want the health department to be primary care for anyone," she said."We have a great immunization team," Cahall said. "We actually have two new nurses and our director of nursing. We can definitely use one more on our communicable disease side.We're trying to work that in, but it's definitely manageable." Cahall said behavioral health is one of the biggest programs within the health department.Cahall said there has been a 37% decrease in visits to receive buprenorphine (the medication used for the management of opioid use disorder), care coordination has increased 84% and maintenance has increased 12%."That data indicates that our clients are shifting from active treatment to maintenance and they're also shifting to discharge," Cahall said. "This is definitely showing improvement in our treatment." She pointed to a 60% decrease in use of the mobile treatment unit (MTU) "because we've worked really hard on discharging and putting our clients into maintenance when it's needed or when they're ready." Cahall reported percentages instead of numbers for drug intoxication deaths because "we're dealing with small numbers" and they may not all be Caroline County citizens.Cahall's last slide listed four top 2024 initiatives. She said the Coordinated Community Supports Project is "going to be huge for us." The department has nearly $400,000 to expand current school-based mental health services; the current capacity is an average of 260 students in five schools.Other initiatives include Mobile Integrated Health, expanding sexually transmitted infections (STI) testing capabilities and establishing organizational performance measures based on the State Health Improvement Plan (SHIP).commissioner Frank Bartz asked how the department is helping those with mental health concerns and if more people were receptive to seeking help."I have seen a huge difference, especially in the last three years," Tuel said. "People are really worried about their mental health and are caring for themselves, which I'm really happy about." Tuel said that most people with "substance use disorder often have mental health concerns, as well. They are treated just like any other patients." "Coordinated community support not only supports children and adolescents' mental health, but the family as a whole," Cahall said. "The other thing we've worked on is an anti-stigma campaign we've seen a shift in the stigma situation." Commission Vice President Larry Porter, who participated in the meeting remotely because of illness, weighed in at the end of the report and thanked Cahall and Tuel for the information."We've come a long way from our health report card that we used to have where we were last in everything you didn't want to be last in, and first in everything we didn't want to be first in," he said. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Caroline County Health Officer Robin Cahall updates County Commissioners Oct. 24. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a county health department's report to the commission, detailing health initiatives, funding, services, and partnerships. While it involves local government structures, the core content revolves around public health programs, disease control, behavioral health, and healthcare services, making 'Health' the most precise category.

title: Local dentist to offer free services to veterans on Nov. 9
author: Contributed
content:
Local dentist to offer free services to veterans on Nov. 9

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 330
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Easton Dental Studio will host its Third Annual Veterans Dental Day on Thursday, Nov. 9, when veterans will receive complimentary dental care throughout the day."Supporting the health and wellness of our veterans is personal," said Dr. Mike Hoglund, owner of Easton Dental Studio. "As a former Naval officer and dentist, it is important to me to continue supporting those who have served and sacrificed for our country. Unfortunately, many former members of our armed services lack dental insurance, and this is one small thing our practice can do to improve the oral health of our local veteran community." Over the past two years, Easton Dental Studio has provided more than $20,000 in pro bono dental services to the Mid-Shore's veteran community."We want to serve as many veterans as we possibly can," Hoglund said.Local veterans and former service members are invited to attend Veterans Dental Day beginning at 9 a.m.Dr. Hoglund and his team will offer free-of-charge checkups, cleanings, fillings and extractions on a firstcome, first-serve basis.All veterans are eligible and should come with some form of documentation of their military service.Advance appointments are encouraged, and walk-ins are welcome.A complimentary continental breakfast will also be available.Veterans Dental Day is part of Easton Dental Studio's Veterans Appreciation Campaign, which also includes a needs-based veteran scholarship program where one local veteran is chosen to receive complimentary dental services for a year.Services provided range from basic cleanings and check-ups to full-mouth rehabilitation. To apply, veterans need to submit an essay by the end of November. To learn more about requirements, please visit www.eastondentalstudio.com.Easton Dental Studio also offers a 10% discount to all former military members and their immediate families who do not have dental insurance throughout the year.To learn more about Easton Dental Studio's veteran services or to make an appointment for Veterans Dental Day, please call 410-822-6177. 
 
 Caption: EASTON DENTAL STUDIO
 
Easton Dental Studio will host its Third Annual Veterans Dental Day on Thursday, Nov. 9.
