While it involves a community event (Local Life), the primary context is healthcare. Public Notices could be a secondary consideration but lacks the direct health focus.

title: How to clean a kitchen sponge
author: Mary Hunt
content:
How to clean a kitchen sponge

 November 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 290
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When asked, "What is the dirtiest spot in the typical household?" most people say the toilet seat.For sure, that would have been my response, until I discovered studies on bacteria and household diseases by Dr. Chuck Gerba, professor of microbiology at the University ofArizona.Gerbas studies have found that on the average toilet seat, there are 50 bacteria per square inch. But the typical kitchen sponge has around 10 million bacteria per square inch. That's no typo! And it gets worse, so brace for what I am about to tell you.Gerba has discovered that usually there are about 200 times more fecal bacteria on the average kitchen cutting board than on a toilet seat. It doesn't necessarily get there through actual contact with feces, but arrives via raw meat products or the organs from inside of the animal, where a lot ofthe fecal bacteria originate.With all those gazillions of bacteria on kitchen sponges, you may assume the best way to clean our kitchen sponges is by a minute or two in a microwave oven set on High. Seems reasonable, right? Well, it's not!Putting that kitchen sponge through a complete cycle with detergent daily, or as often as you run a load of dishes, is a much better solution. The heat plus detergent are sufficient to kill bacteria and mildew.Another option, especially ifyou don't have a dishwasher, is to soak that daily sponge in a good antibacterial sanitizer for at least 10 minutes up to overnight. But don't spend $8 for a 16-ounce bottle from the store. Make it yourselffor pennies!According to the Food and Drug Administrationl, 1 teaspoon ofliquid chlorine bleach per 1 quart ofclean water can be used to sanitize all kitchen surfaces such as cutting boards, countertops, refrigerator shelves - and sponges!CQPYRIGHT 2023 CREATQRS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on bacterial contamination in household items, health risks associated with kitchen sponges, and sanitation methods to prevent disease. While it has educational elements, the primary emphasis is on health and hygiene practices.

title: 'We made it' - YMCA opens new facility in Centreville
author: Doug Bishop; dbishop@chespub.com
content:
'We made it' - YMCA opens new facility in Centreville

 November 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Doug Bishop; dbishop@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 810
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTERVILLE - "We made it!" shouted YMCA of the Chesapeake Executive Director Robbie Gill, Wednesday afternoon, Oct. 18, to begin the grand opening ceremony at the new Queen Anne's County Family YMCA & Active Aging Center in Centreville.This YMCA is the 11th location in the Chesapeake region, which includes all of the Eastern Shore of Maryland and Virginia, and the largest of them all. The QA YMCA is 70,000 square feet indoors (providing a workout just walking around inside the building?)The project to date cost $22.6 million. Of that, $15,235,000 came from private donations (248 donors thus far). QAC government provided $3.5 million, State Capital Grant provided $3,065,000, and the Maryland Department of Aging another $800,000.The goal of the YMCA is for families to live their healthiest lives and reach their full potential in mind, body and spirit. It offers a stay-and-play space for parents to bring their young children to be cared for by trained members of the Y staffwhile the parents workout. This service is provided free within the cost of the family's membership fee.The Active Aging Center is only the second one located in the Chesapeake region to offer congregate meals for seniors at discounted prices, chronic disease prevention programs, Enhance Fitness, swimming classes, social groups and benefits counseling tailored for ages 55-plus.The QAC Active Aging Center is open to all members of the community age 55 and over, and a YMCA membership is not required to enter. Check with the QA Department of Aging or Active Aging Center for more details about this offer.The pool at the Y has six 25-yard length swimming lanes, one ofwhich will always be open for lap swimming. Children ages 16 and under are required to take a simple swim test administered by the lifeguard to be able to swim in the pool.Gill shared an experience he had during the early years of planning of this Y."A father came to our meeting saying, 'My son drowned in the Corsica River in 1974. Ifwe had a YMCA back then, my son would have received swim lessons there, and would be alive today,'" he said. "That father's comments stuck with me as we have gone forward to where we are today." Among those who spoke at the grand opening ceremony, was Patricia Saelens, QACPS Superintendent of Schools. She said, "We have have already begun partnering with the Y to provide water safety training to our school children starting with our elementary school children. We're very excited about doing this."As a not-for-profit organization, the YMCA provides financial assistance to ensure no one is turned away from membership, programs and services due to the inability to pay. The upkeep of the YMCA facility is at no cost to the county. Every Y is self-supporting, funded by private dollars. The new facility in Centreville will employ over 100 staff members.PHOTO BY DOUG BISHOP Area elected officials are pictured at the ribbon cutting ceremony for the grand opening of the new Queen Anne's County YMCA as Maryland Department of Aging Secretary Carmel Roques, Wednesday afternoon, Oct. 18, in Centreville. To her right, Eastern Shore Excutive Director Robbie Gill is pictured. Gill has overseen this project since it was first conceived 17-years ago. Approximately 200 people attended the event.The completed "Phase 1" facility now exists. Phase 2 will include the addition of an outdoor pool, six outdoor pickleball courts and space for family gatherings and activities, again, at no cost to the county. Phase two is planned to be completed by summer 2024.There are rules at the YMCA that may appear to be "a throw back" to a bygone era. "No profanity. Shoes and shirts must be worn at all times. Fighting will result in suspension of YMCA membership."The heritage of the YMCA is to promote Christian values and an environment of caring for everyone. It is to be a happy place to come and be with others.Centreville Town Councilman Eric Johnson Jr. was present at the grand opening. He said, "The YMCA is a focal point for community health, active aging, fitness, family, community, and so much more. I couldn't be more excited about this perfect addition to our town."County Commissioner Jim Moran added, "What have our active adults using the YMCA, We have our families using the YMCA, and we have our students using the YMCA. This facility checks off so many boxes when it comes to our community and quality of life."To make an appointment to tour the new QA YMCA, or have questions answered, call 443-262-9994. Brian Byrnes is the QA YMCA executive director. 
 
 Caption: PHOTO BY DOUG BISHOP A view of the exterior of newly opened Queen Anne's County YMCA in Centreville. The facility is the largest YMCA on the Eastern Shore covering more than 70,000 square feet indoors. The new Y is located directly across the roadway from Queen Anne's County High School. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the YMCA's new facility emphasizing health services, active aging programs, fitness amenities, and community wellness initiatives. While it mentions local community impact, the primary emphasis is on health-related offerings and services.

title: Medical center, juvenile justice top priorities for Shore lawmakers
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Medical center, juvenile justice top priorities for Shore lawmakers

 November 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 883
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Securing funding for the new regional medical center and addressing local impacts of last year's juvenile justice reform laws are priorities for Mid-Shore lawmakers heading into the 2024 General Assembly in January.During a Tuesday meeting with the Talbot County Council and local stakeholders, the three Mid-Shore legislators, Sen. Johnny Mautz and Reps. Chris Adams and Tom Hutchinson, tackled a number of issues affecting the district, discussing ways to advance their progress in the upcoming legislative session.REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTERSecuring financial support for the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's new regional medical center has long been a top priority for local legislators.The proposed 147-bed hospital and medical office building are slated to occupy just over 235 acres off of Longwoods Road near U.S.Route 50 in Easton.The start of construction is dependent on the project receiving a Certificate of Need from the Maryland Health Care Commission.The hospital system filed the CON application in January and anticipates a response in December or January, said Ken Kozel, president and CEO of UM Shore Regional Health.In a separate process, the hospital system is working with the Health Services Cost Review Commission, the state's rate-setting authority, to see if rate relief can be obtained to offset the cost of interest and depreciation for the project.However, MHCC will first need to hear from HSCRC to determine if the project is financially viable before making a decision on the application. Uncertainty lies in how much the HSCRC decision will weigh on the health care commission's answer, Kozel said.That relief, along with government funding, is key to moving forward with the regional medical center.Former Gov. Larry Hogan earmarked $100 million last December for the project in the state's fiscal year 2024 budget.During this year's legislative session, lawmakers secured $10 million in the budget for the new medical center, which the hospital system must spend by June 30, 2024, Kozel said.There's also a pledge for $20 million in fiscal year 2025, though it's subject to change, so the hospital system is asking Gov. Wes Moore to solidify that allocation, along with the remaining $70 million, he added.The county council and lawmakers can write letters of support to help ensure the governor is aware of the project, Kozel said.Del. Chris Adams (R-37B) expressed his vote of confidence and support."We want this project to happen as much as you do and as much as every elected official does," he said, "And most importantly, as much as every citizen that will stand to benefit from the delivery of the services that are possible in a brand new facility and the quality that you get from your organization."JUVENILE JUSTICETalbot County Sheriff's Office Capt. John Bollinger and Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey raised concerns about the significant impacts resulting from the passage of juvenile justice reform measures last year.Bollinger said the legislature was "wrong" for passing the laws last year, highlighting a 42% increase in youth crime in schools and two provisions of the laws that have been particularly burdensome for local law enforcement.One provision bars police from being able to charge a child under 13 years old with a crime unless it's a violent crime, such as murder, attempted murder or rape."The worst part is that these kids know that, and the criminals know that," Bollinger said, suggesting that 12-year-olds could be implicated in illegal activities and not be punished for their involvement."They can do it in front of our face, and we can't do anything other than tell them, 'That's bad, you shouldn't do that,'" he said.Under another law, police are not allowed to interview a child after they're arrested until the child has an attorney to represent them, even if it's to get more information or to find out if others are involved."I'm here to tell you that there's not a lawyer anywhere that's going to say, 'Sure, tell the police everything,' - they're going to shut them down on the phone without even meeting them, knowing nothing about the case, and then our hands are tied," Bollinger said.The increase in crime in schools is mainly from the county's middle and high schools, and the majority of the crimes are assaults, he said. And out of 114 reported assaults in the schools in the last year, 40 of them involved children under 13.However, Talbot County is experiencing less youth crime than some other Shore jurisdictions. In Dorchester and Wicomico counties, the number of assaults on both students and staff are "dramatically higher" than previous years, said Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-37B)."The good newsis every county is now talking about it," he said. "The county executives on the western shore are talking about it, butis anybody going to want to make a change?"COUNTY INITIATIVESWhile there are no specific Talbot County bills being proposed for consideration by the state legislature so far, the county is supporting the Maryland Association of Counties' 2024 legislative initiatives.Those initiatives include launching forward-thinking firefighter and emergency medical services incentives, providing transparency in education spending, modernizing local revenue structures and advancing comprehensive housing solutions. 
 
 Caption: NATALIE JONES/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
University of Maryland Shore Regional Health President and CEO Ken Kozel speaks to Talbot County Council members and state legislators on funding for the new regional medical center in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily focuses on securing funding for a regional medical center, which directly relates to the Health topic. While juvenile justice reforms are discussed, they serve as a secondary issue. The legislative priorities mentioned align more with healthcare infrastructure than broader government or public safety functions.

title: UM Shore Regional Health Board welcomes new members
author: Contributed
content:
UM Shore Regional Health Board welcomes new members

 November 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 736
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Under the leadership of Kathy Deoudes, the UM Shore Regional Health Board of Directors recently welcomed four new members: LuAnn Brady, Marlene Feldman, Wayne Hockmeyer and Valerie Overton.The Board's composition includes representatives from the five counties served by UM SRH, the regional physician community and UMMS.Serving as Secretary of the Board, Brady, MSPH, joined UM Shore Regional Health as senior vice president and chief operating officer in February.Previously, she spent more than 10 years with University of Pennsylvania Health System. She also worked for nearly 20 years for Bon Secours Health System, Inc. in Baltimore. Most recently, she served nearly five years as COO at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania.Brady holds a master of science in public health with a focus on health policy and administration from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and a bachelor of arts in English and economics management from Salem College.She is a member of the American College of Health Care Executives and was selected as one of the Top 100 Chief Operating Officers of 2022 by C-Suite Spotlight, which provides news and information on today's leading C-Level executives.Feldman is a former member of the UM SRH Shore Regional Health Board of Directors (2005-2022) who served on the Executive, Ethics and Governance Committees and as chair of the Quality, Safety and Experience Committee.A current member of the University of Maryland College Park Foundation Board of Trustees, previously she served on the boards of the university's Terrapin Club, the Chesapeake College Foundation, Mid-Shore Community Foundation, the Dorchester Family YMCA and the Dorchester County Public Library.She served as government liaison for the Dorchester Arts Council and as a member of the Dorchester County Board of Education and the Maryland Association of Boards of Education.A resident of Trappe, Feldman is a member of Feldman, LLC, a real estate holding company, and previously served nine years on the Board of Directors of ISG International, Inc.Her early career included teaching at the elementary school level in Baltimore and Cambridge, and varied administrative and policy projects in the field of public education. She holds a bachelor of science degree in education from the University of Maryland.Wayne T. Hockmeyer, PhD, is a retired U.S. Army officer and former chief of the Department of Immunology at Walter Reed Army Institute of Research.Following his retirement from active duty in 1986, he served as vice president of laboratory research and product development at Praxis Biologics. He later founded Medimmune, Inc., a company focused on oncology, infectious and inflammatory diseases, which he served as chairman and CEO for 20 years until it was purchased by Astra Zeneca in 2007.A graduate of Purdue University, Hockmeyer earned his Ph.D. from the University of Florida, which later honored him as distinguished alumnus of the year in 1988.He has been awarded an honorary doctorate by Purdue University and multiple honors and awards, including the Paul A. Siple Award, the Tech Council of Maryland's Lifetime Achievement Award and Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award from Ernst & Young.His civic and community contributions include serving on multiple boards, including at Idenix Pharmaceuticals, Baxter International, Baxalta and the Cleveland Clinic Indian River Hospital, which he chaired for six years.A resident of Trappe, he presently serves as vice chair of the Board of Saints Peter and Paul School in Easton.Overton has served as a principal health policy analyst and Health Policy Department manager at The Mitre Corporation since 2015.During two decades prior to her role at Mitre, she held progressively responsible positions in health care policy, including associate director of policy analysis, research and methodology for the Health Services Cost Review Commission; director of government affairs for the Anne Arundel Health System (now Luminis Health); and senior vice president of governmental policy and advocacy for the Maryland Hospital Association.S he holds a master of public administration from the University of Baltimore and a bachelor of arts in political science and English from McDaniel College.A resident of Chestertown, Overton has been an active member of the community, serving as a member and ultimately secretary, vice president and president of the Kent County Public Library Board of Trustees (2018-2022), and as treasurer for the Chestertown Tea Party (2003-2012).She also is a founding member of the Washington College Masters Swim Team and has served as swim instructor for Horizons of Kent and Queen Anne's summer program since 2016. 
 
 Caption: LUANN BRADY
 
MARLENE FELDMAN
 
WAYNE HOCKMEYER
 
VALERIE OVERTON

title: Patricia 'Pat' Harris remembered at 10th Crabs for a Cure
author: Doug Bishop; dbishop@chespub.com
content:
Patricia 'Pat' Harris remembered at 10th Crabs for a Cure

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Doug Bishop; dbishop@chespub.com | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 590
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENT NARROWS - The 10th annual Crabs for a Cure hosted at Harris Crab House, and sponsored by Bosom Buddies Charities took place with a record turnout of 180 people attending, during the month of October, national Breast Cancer Awareness Month.The event, which originally began 10 years ago with about 40 people, said Harris Crab House President Bill Oertel, has grown every year. The restaurant was at its limit for capacity that weeknight evening.Bosom Buddies Charities, Inc., Chair Claudia Boldyga welcomed all who attended saying, "There's just nothing quite like cracking crabs and enjoying the company of family and friends. BBC's mission is to raise awareness, encourage early detection, support treatment, and celebrate healing. In our 17 years, BBC has raised almost $3 million enabling our organization to purchase state-ofthe-art equipment, including the first digital and later 3D mammography for Anne Arundel Medical Center on Kent Island, and provide invaluable nurse navigator and genetic counseling support for health care facilities on the Eastern Shore and Annapolis." She added, "We're a 100% volunteer organization and the proceeds of our fundraising stays in our local communities.The important work we do to fulfill our mission would not be possible without the support from local businesses like Harris Crab House. We want to thank the entire Harris and Oertel families for this beautiful waterfront venue and delicious food, and we're grateful to Harris Crab House throughout the past 10 years. All the food and drink you are enjoying this evening has been completely donated by Harris Crab House!" She continued, "Ten years ago, a group of ladies came up with the idea to have this crab feast to raise money for breast cancer awareness.One of those ladies was Pat Harris. In her historic battle with this disease, Pat showed courage and tenacity.Tonight, we celebrate Pat - an amazing woman and her unsung contributions to our cause." Harris passed away earlier in 2023 from a 20 year on again, off again battle with breast cancer.Married to Jerry Harris, he and Pat went on the build the restaurant, and have a large family that today includes grandchildren and great grandchildren.The evening's food not only included steamed hard shell crabs, but a wonderful seafood buffet of fried soft shell crab almandine, large steamed shrimp, fried oysters, roast beef, chicken alfredo, and sides of roasted red potato slices, Brussel sprouts, pasta salad and vegetable crab soup.It was announced that the upcoming Bosom Buddies Ball will be held Saturday evening, March 23, 2024, at the Westin Hotel, Annapolis.This event always sells out. This year's theme is "Setting Sail for New Horizons". 
 
 Caption: DOUG BISHOP
 
The 10th Crabs for a Cure was held at Harris Crab House at the Kent Narrows during the October national campaign of Breast Cancer Awareness Month. Members of the Bosom Buddies Charities committee from left, board members Connie Blandford, Holly Rhodes, Treasurer Jenny Griffin, Bosom Buddies Chair Claudia Boldyga, Vice Chair Christina Cugle, board member Jennifer DiDonato and Secretary Karen White. This 10th anniversary crab feast honored the memory of longtime supporter Patricia "Pat" Harris, who passed away from breast cancer earlier this year.
 
DOUG BISHOP
 
Members of the Harris and Oertel families, owners of Harris Crab House at Kent Narrows, are pictured at the October Crabs for a Cure celebration. This year's crab feast celebrated the memory of the late Patricia "Pat" Harris, who was one of the women who helped start the fundraiser 10 years ago. Harris passed away from breast cancer earlier this year after battling the cancer for nearly 20 years.

title: Grace Street, Sheriff Launch Holiday Program For Children Affected By Addiction
author: Contributed
content:
Grace Street, Sheriff Launch Holiday Program For Children Affected By Addiction

 November 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 354
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Grace Street and the Talbot County Sheriff 's Office this week announced a Christmas shopping program for children and teens affected by substance use in Talbot County.Nicole's Promise directly supports young people who have lost a parent to addiction with a special shopping trip hosted by Talbot County Sheriff 's deputies.The program also includes a Christmas gift drive for children and teens with a parent struggling with, or in early recovery from, substance use disorder.The program is in honor of Nicole, a good friend of Bri S., a peer support specialist at Grace Street."Nicole was a vibrant soul, full of life and possibility," Bri said."Addiction took her from us too soon, leaving six children behind without a mother. I cannot take away the pain of those children, who are left motherless, but I can do something meaningful in Nicole's honor."Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble, who says he has long supported recovery and has spearheaded prevention efforts in the region with Talbot Goes Purple and other programs, quickly agreed to partner on Nicole's Promise.In December, deputies will take the children and teens on a holiday shopping trip, before returning to the sheriff 's office for cookies and activities with an elf."I have seen too many families get torn apart by this disease of addiction, and the hardest hit are the children that get left behind when a parent overdoses," Gamble said. "We're glad that we can help bring some holiday cheer to those kids as we continue our fight against the opioid epidemic."Grace Street is accepting donations for Nicole's Promise. To sponsor the program, or to purchase gifts off the wishlist, visit gracestreetrecovery.org.The gift list program also is available in Caroline County.Audra Williamson with Mid-Shore Restoring Hope heard about the program through her volunteer work with Grace Street and partnered to bring the toy drive to Caroline County.Donations are accepted at Aaron's Place at 401 Aldersgate Drive in Denton. For questions, or more information on the Caroline County initiative, call 302-339-5232.For questions or more information on the Talbot programs, including to refer a child or teen to one of the programs, contact marketing@gracestreetrecovery.org. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Seminar Focuses On Trends In Pancreatic Cancer Care
author: Contributed
content:
Seminar Focuses On Trends In Pancreatic Cancer Care

 November 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 8 | Section: News 
 
 698
 Words 

 Read News Document

 NEAVITT - Pancreatic cancer is a relatively rare cancer, representing only 3% of estimated new cancer diagnoses each year.However, it is especially lethal. Presently the third leading cause of cancer death, pancreatic cancer kills more than 50,000 Americans every year.For the Mid-Shore Pancreatic Cancer Foundation Inc., supporting efforts to advance the diagnosis and treatment of pancreatic cancer and educating the public about risk factors and symptoms of the disease are key strategies for saving lives.On this year's World Pancreatic Cancer Awareness Day Nov. 16, the Foundation sponsored a seminar, "New Trends in Pancreatic Cancer Diagnosis and Treatment," in the Cadby Theatre at Chesapeake College in Wye Mills.Designed for clinicians involved in patient care, the evening program featured presentations by three leading University of Maryland Medical System oncology specialists: Nader Hanna, a professor of surgery at UM School of Medicine and director of clinical operations for the Division of General and Oncologic Surgery at the University of Maryland Medical Center (UMMC); Yixing Jiang, a professor of medicine at UM SOM and director of GI medical oncology at the Marlene and Stewart Greenebaum Cancer Center at UMMC; and Jason K. Molitoris, an associate professor of radiation oncology at UM SOM, associate medical director at the Department of Radiation Oncology at UMMC, and director of Clinical Hyperthermia Program.Hanna provided an overview of various risk factors for pancreatic cancer, including heredity (indicating a family history of certain genetic mutations) and smoking, and noted that symptoms of the disease, such as weight loss, back pain, jaundice and adult-onset (over age 65) diabetes, most often don't present until the disease is relatively advanced.He also reviewed various diagnostic strategies and surgical approaches, stressing the importance of surgical resection as the most significant factor for survival.Jiang discussed the genetic aspects of pancreatic cancer and how chemotherapy drugs are tailored to address the specific mutations identified in individual patients.She noted that systemic chemotherapy provides curative results for less than 30 percent of patients and that side effects can be very severe. However, in many cases it does improve survival time and also palliates cancer-related symptoms.Molitoris described the role of radiation in treating pancreatic cancer, including challenges caused by the location of the pancreas near other tissues that can be damaged by radiation.He described the criteria for cases in which radiation is employed prior to surgery to shrink tumor size, or after surgery to palliate complications from the disease and improve quality of life."We were really pleased to have a good turnout for this event, and the presenters provided very clear and detailed updates from the standpoint of their practice," said Bill Shrieves, president of the Mid-Shore Pancreatic Foundation Inc."The Foundation does a lot to support pancreatic cancer patients and to raise funds for research on the disease, but as one of our volunteers commented, this event might be the most important thing we've done as an organization.If just one of the clinicians who attended does something different based on the information that was shared and it improves the outcome for a pancreatic cancer patient, that is the best kind of success," he said.Shrieves also credited support from Tidewater Rotary in making the event possible."A generous grant of $5,000 from Rotary's Flags for Cancer Program made it possible for us to offer this event free of charge, and we are very grateful for that support," he said.Established in 2013, The Mid-Shore Pancreatic Cancer Foundation Inc. sponsors and participates in events that raise awareness about pancreatic cancer in the community, and also helps patients and their families in the Mid-Shore region find assistance, financial support and transportation to and from treatments.The group funds research through direct grants or support for other organizations, such as the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network.For more information about The Mid-Shore Pancreatic Cancer Foundation, Inc., visit midshorepancan.org/or call 410-745-9243. 
 
 Caption: MID-SHORE PANCREATIC CANCER FOUNDATION
 
The Mid-Shore Pancreatic Cancer Foundation, led by Foundation President Bill Shrieves (second from right), recently hosted University of Maryland Medical System physicians Dr. Jason K. Molitoris (left), Dr. Yixing Jiang (second from left) and Dr.
 
Nader Hanna to speak on "New Trends in Pancreatic Cancer Diagnosis and Treatment" at Chesapeake College. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it involves educational elements for clinicians, the primary context is medical research and healthcare advancements. Other topics like Education or Public Notices are less central.

title: November is national Family Caregivers Month
author: Mary Land Department Of Aging
content:
November is national Family Caregivers Month

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Land Department Of Aging | Page: 12 | Section: News 
 
 757
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Enrollment is now open for Medicare.The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) released 2024 premium, deductible, and coinsurance amounts for Medicare Parts A and B, and the 2024 Medicare Part D income-related monthly adjustment amounts.Medicare Part A covers inpatient hospitals, skilled nursing facilities, hospice, inpatient rehabilitation, and some home health care services. However, about 99 percent of Medicare beneficiaries do not have a Part A premium since they have at least 40 quarters of Medicare-covered employment, as determined by the Social Security Administration.Medicare Part B covers physicians' services, outpatient hospital services, certain home health services, durable medical equipment, and other medical and health services not covered by Medicare Part A. The standard monthly premium for Medicare Part B enrollees will be $174.70 for 2024, an increase of $9.80 from $164.90 in 2023. The annual deductible for all Medicare Part B beneficiaries will be $240 in 2024, an increase of $14 from the annual deductible of $226 in 2023.A beneficiary's Part D monthly premium adjustment is based on his or her income and affects roughly 8 percent of people with Medicare Part D. These individuals will pay the income-related monthly adjustment amount in addition to their Part D premium.NATIONAL FAMILY CAREGIVERS MONTHCelebrated every November, National Family Caregivers Month is a time to recognize and honor family caregivers, including spouses, adult children, relatives, and friends, who provide invaluable support to older adults and people with disabilities.More than 53 million family caregivers provide unpaid care across the country.AARP estimates that in 2021, family caregivers provided 36 billion hours of care valued at $600 billion, up from 34 billion hours of care valued at $470 billion just two years before. At the same time, at least 2.7 million grandparents-and an unknown number of other relative caregivers-carry the primary responsibility for caring for grandchildren whose parents are unable to do so."We recognize the need for a robust, coordinated approach to supporting family and kinship caregivers," said Maryland Department of Aging Secretary Carmel Roques. "As the youngest Baby Boomers turn 65 in 2029 and lifespans continue to climb into the 80s and beyond, the demand for at-home care is going to soar."MARYLAND FAMILY CAREGIVER SUPPORT PROGRAMIn an effort to help family and informal caregivers care for loved ones at home for as long as possible, the Maryland Department of Aging administers the Family Caregiver Support Program (FCSP) through the Area Agency on Aging (AAA) network. AAAs provide FCSP services including counseling, case management, training, support group resources, information and referral, and respite care. To learn more about the program, funded by the Administration for Community Living, or find events taking place in your county celebrating family caregivers, go to aging.maryland.gov. To find out what local resources are available in your area, contact Maryland Access Point at 1-844-627-5465 or go to www.marylandaccesspoint.info.VA CAREGIVER SUPPORT PROGRAMThe Veterans Administration Caregiver Support Program (CSP) has launched new legal and financial planning support services, as well as a new web-based educational tool, to provide comprehensive support to veterans and promote the health and well-being of veteran caregivers Eligible participants, including primary family caregivers who support veterans, can access licensed attorneys and certified financial counselors who can provide expert-led consultative financial planning and legal services relating to the needs of injured veterans and their caregivers.In addition, these primary caregivers can access essential financial and legal resources at the VA Caregiver Support: Providing Legal and Financial Services to Veteran Caregiver website."Being a primary family caregiver is a noble and challenging role requiring immense dedication and sacrifice," said Dr. Colleen Richardson, CSP Executive Director. "At CSP, we are dedicated to providing caregivers with the resources they need to navigate the encounters of caregiving and achieve their caregiving goals."SUPPORTIVE COMMUNITIES AND VILLAGESThe Maryland Department of Aging (MDOA) was pleased to take part in the National Village Gathering held last month in Silver Spring, MD to increase collaboration with the Village network as part of the MDOA's Supportive Communities Initiative.Villages are community-based, nonprofit organizations formed through a cadre of caring neighbors who connect members to an array of practical support and social services that enable older adults to enjoy an independent quality of life in their homes and communities.Through the Supportive Communities Initiative, MDOA will continue to engage with the Village network, as well as other neighbor-to-neighbor initiatives, faith-based groups, and nonprofit organizations in an effort to improve opportunities for Marylanders to age in place.Learn more about Villages at vtvnetwork.org or find a Village near you at www.wavevillages.org.The above information is courtesy of the Maryland Department of Aging 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on family caregivers, Medicare programs, and aging support services, which are directly related to health and elder care. While it mentions Maryland-specific initiatives and national observances, the core content revolves around healthcare systems and caregiver support.

title: UM Shore gets seventh consecutive 'A' safety rating
author: Contributed
content:
UM Shore gets seventh consecutive 'A' safety rating

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 354
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton, a member organization of the University of Maryland Medical System, has received an "A" Hospital Safety Grade in The Leapfrog Group's fall 2023 reporting period.This marks the seventh consecutive period that the hospital has received an "A." "This accomplishment is one that our entire UM Shore Regional Health family should be proud of," said Ken Kozel, president and CEO of UM Shore Regional Health. "I am grateful for the dedication of our highly skilled team members and medical staff providers, as achieving the Leapfrog Hospital Safety 'A' Grade is the result of their commitment to patient care and safety."Earning this distinction for the seventh consecutive time means that Shore's progress toward becoming a High Reliability Organization is a priority for each and every team member." Leapfrog's Hospital Safety Grade is a national distinction recognizing a hospital's achievements in providing safer health care by protecting patients from preventable harm and errors. Fewer than a third of hospitals nationwide earn the "A" grade, and even fewer achieve that milestone in consecutive grading periods."Earning a seventh consecutive Leapfrog Hospital Safety Grade 'A' is a testament to the dedication and commitment to excellence of Shore's caregivers," said Sherri Hobbs-Messick, UM SRH's chief quality, safety and experience officer."UM Shore Regional Health and the University of Maryland Medical System are on a journey to high reliability and zero harm, and this external validation helps to sustain our momentum," she said.The Leapfrog Group is an independent national watchdog organization with a 10-year history of assigning letter grades to general hospitals throughout the United States, based on a hospital's ability to prevent medical errors and harm to patients.The grading system is peer-reviewed, fully transparent and free to the public. Hospital Safety Grade results are based on more than 30 national performance measures and are updated each fall and spring.To see the full grade details for UM Shore Medical Center at Easton, and to access patient tips for staying safe in the hospital, visit HospitalSafetyGrade.org and follow The Leapfrog Group on X and Facebook. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF UM SHORE
 
University of Maryland Shore Medical Center in Easton 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: UM Shore cuts ribbon for renovated interventional radiology suite
author: Contributed
content:
UM Shore cuts ribbon for renovated interventional radiology suite

 December 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 497
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Interventional Radiology suite at UM Shore Medical Center at Easton recently underwent major renovations to accommodate new X-ray equipment.Due to the size of the new equipment, the room has been completely revamped, including new cabinetry and flooring, an updated control room and a new area for team members to scrub-in. The cost of the project was $2.3 million."Our prior equipment was more than 20 years old," said Penny Olivi, director of Radiology Services at UM Shore Regional Health. "With this completely upgraded room and the state-of-the-art digital X-ray equipment, we are now able to offer new, more complex procedures that will help patients with minimally invasive interventions." The Interventional Radiology suite typically sees about 100 patients each month, and the IR team provides clinical support for all areas within UM SRH; however, the key areas where the team provides the most support are cancer care and dialysis access.The new suite was designed so that it could be completely disassembled, down to the cabinetry, and then reassembled and integrated into UM Shore Regional Health's new regional hospital, set to open in 2028."This is groundbreaking technology and a huge advantage for our Shore communities," said Ken Kozel, president and CEO of UM Shore Regional Health. "Knowing we could safely transfer the equipment to the new regional medical center, we wanted to offer this state-of-the-art advanced care to our patients now."And now patients don't have to travel across the Bay Bridge for this type of expert care and minimally invasive procedures.They're available right here, close to home." Interventional radiologists diagnose and treat disease and a wide range of conditions in the body by utilizing various small tools, such as catheters or wires.X-ray and imaging techniques, such as CT and ultrasound help guide the radiologist.Interventional radiology can be used instead of surgery for many conditions, and in some cases, it can eliminate the need for hospitalization. Interventional radiologists work closely with a patient's care team and play an important role in a patient's treatment plan.UM SRH Radiology Services also partners with the Radiologic Sciences Degree Program at Chesapeake College. The partnership allows X-ray students to attend clinical rotations in all UM Shore Regional Health facilities.Many current members of the Shore Radiology team attended Chesapeake College's program, and this ongoing partnership enables UM SRH staff to share their knowledge and expertise with the next generation of radiologic technologist graduates.Interventional Radiology training is also provided onsite by UM SRH Radiology Services. General X-ray technologists with an interest in this intense, minimally invasive surgical approach to diagnosis and treatment are trained by experienced and skilled techs and the IR Radiologist team, Dale Johnson, MD, and Brian Callahan, MD.There is also an advanced certification in IR available to UM SRH team members. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF UM SHORE
 
UM Shore Regional Health Radiology Services team members held a ribbon-cutting ceremony for the new Interventional Radiology Suite at UM Shore Medical Center at Easton on Oct. 17. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Lead Persists As Problem In Holiday Gifts
author: Cecelia Shilling; Capital News Service
content:
Lead Persists As Problem In Holiday Gifts

 December 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Cecelia Shilling; Capital News Service | Page: B9 | Section: News 
 
 798
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - Lead poisoning has hit the news recently with pollution from leaded aviation gasoline, poisoning from applesauce pouches and federal lead pipe replacement projects.But some lead poisoning threats come during the holiday gift-giving season from jewelry, toys, makeup and other gifts.
In October, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency highlighted the dangers of lead exposure from leaded gasoline still used by some small planes.Communities near general aviation airports experience disproportionate exposure from emissions, the release said.
The Food and Drug Administration is investigating lead found in cinnamon applesauce pouches sold under WanaBana, Weis and Schnucks brands.
As of Nov. 22, there have been 52 cases of elevated blood lead levels in young children potentially linked to these pouches.
On Nov. 30, the EPA announced a proposal to require replacement of lead service lines nationwide within 10 years, according to a press release. The administration is investing $15 billion in replacing lead service lines, providing technical assistance to communities and developing a national inventory of lead pipes.
"The lead dust equivalent of only three granules of sugar is all it takes to poison a child," said a University of Maryland Medical Center release.
Added to all those threats during the holiday season is the lead sometimes hidden in common gifts like jewelry, makeup or toys, said Jay Apperson, a spokesperson for the Maryland Department of the Environment.
Vintage items or things manufactured in other countries are more likely to be contaminated.
"No child should be left behind because of lead poisoning," said Apperson.
"Public education about the importance of getting tested, along with strong enforcement, will all go a long way towards eradicating lead poisoning."
Children are the most vulnerable to lead poisoning and experience symptoms like irritability, issues with attention and learning, delayed growth and hearing issues. Severe cases can cause brain damage and neurological dysfunction, even death.
And lead poisoning can impact cardiac health, pregnancy and hypertension.
In Maryland, children must be tested for blood lead at 12 months and 24 months according to the Maryland Department of Health. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention uses a reference value of 3.5 micrograms per deciliter to identify children with blood lead levels higher than average.
Lead paint found in older homes is a leading cause of lead poisoning, with most childhood exposure coming from hand-to-mouth contact with lead dust.
"If a child has a very elevated blood lead level, that's almost surely the root cause of lead-based paint. If you get down to these relatively lower levels, say in the 3.5 (micrograms per deciliter) range, then you might need to look at other potential sources that might not be so obvious," Apperson said.
Inexpensive jewelry has often been found to contain lead. Lead allows metals to be shaped easily and is cheaper than alternatives like zinc, said the California Department of Toxic Substance Control.
"Lead is also sometimes used as a stabilizer in some plastics, such as polyvinyl chloride (PVC), which is often incorporated into children's jewelry items," said the department.
Another common gift item, makeup, can also be a problem. Kohl eyeliners, used in Asian and African cultures for example, may contain large amounts of lead and other metals, according to the FDA.
One 2013 case from the New Mexico Department of Health began when an Afghan refugee family brought eyeliner to the U.S. An Albuquerque clinic reported that a toddler had a blood lead level of 27 micrograms per deciliter linked to the use of kajal eyeliner, the report said. Lab testing later identified the eyeliner's lead content as 54%.
Inexpensive toys can also have lead in paint, metal or plastic. Vintage toys made before 1978, when lead paint was banned for residential use, or imported toys are more likely to contain the substance.
In 2007, for example, about 253,000 "Sarge" toys, a character from the Cars movie, were recalled by Mattel for containing lead paint, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.
About 675,000 Mattel Barbie accessory toys were also recalled that same year due to lead paint. Both toys were manufactured in China.
The non-profit organization Kids in Danger said recalls of children's products due to excessive lead content increased to 19 instances in 2022, the highest rate of lead-related recalls in the last 10 years, according to a 2023 document called "Hidden Hazards: 2022 Children's Product Recalls." Nine lead-related recalls were announced in 2020.
"We really have to focus in on what will be permanent eradication of exposure and poisoning and that job needs to be finished," said Ruth Ann Norton, president and CEO of the Green and Healthy Homes Initiative.
"And that takes both funding and diligence." 
 
 Caption: FDA VIA AP

 On Monday, Nov. 13, U.S. health officials are warning doctors to be on the lookout for possible cases of lead poisoning in children after at least 22 toddlers in 14 states were sickened by lead linked to tainted pouches of cinnamon apple puree and applesauce. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on lead poisoning risks, health impacts on children, and medical/health agency responses. While environmental factors are mentioned, the primary emphasis is on health hazards, medical guidelines, and public health interventions.

title: Rabid cat reported in Legion Road, Denton area
author: CAROLINE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT
content:
Rabid cat reported in Legion Road, Denton area

 December 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CAROLINE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT | Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 362
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Department of Health laboratory has confirmed a positive rabid cat in the Legion Road area of Denton. The cat was turned into the Humane Society, which then contacted the Caroline County Health Department's Environmental Health Division to facilitate rabies testing.Any person in the vicinity of Legion Road should avoid contact with wildlife, feral cats, unknown animals and any animal (including cats or dogs) that appears sick or to exhibit signs of rabies. Additionally, all residents in the area are urged to make sure their pets and mammal livestock are up to date on rabies vaccinations.
To report a potentially rabid animal, contact Animal Control at (410) 820-1600 or the non-emergency line of the 911 Center at (410) 479-2222.
Please contact the Caroline County Health Department immediately if you have had, or may know of anyone who might have had, any possible human or animal exposure to a rabid animal at (410) 479-8045.
If you have an emergency regarding a potential rabid animal or exposure and are calling after normal business hours or on the weekend, call (410) 829-5910.
An exposure can mean contamination of open wounds, abrasions, mucous membranes or scratches by potentially contaminated with infectious material from a rabid animal.
Additionally, any penetration of the skin by teeth constitutes a bite exposure. All bites, regardless of body site, represent a potential risk of rabies transmission, but that risk varies with the species of biting animal, the site of the bite and the severity of the wound.
Rabies is a serious, but preventable viral disease that attacks the nervous system. It is predominantly seen in raccoons, bats and skunks, as well as dogs and cats.
All wild or unknown animals must be avoided whenever possible since the possibility of exposure to rabies can occur anywhere and anytime.
Pet owners should remember that the best way to protect themselves, their families and their pets is to keep their animals up to date on rabies vaccination.
The Health Department regularly offers low-cost rabies clinics to help residents protect their pets. The next clinic will be held in the spring. Please monitor the Health Department's Events Calendar for more information.
For more information about rabies, visit CDC's Rabies Prevention webpage at cdc.gov/rabies/prevention/index.html. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is issued by the Caroline County Health Department and focuses on rabies prevention, public health advisories, and vaccination recommendations. While public safety and local government are tangentially related, the primary context is health risk management.

title: Festival of Trees raises $50K for Compass Hospice
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Festival of Trees raises $50K for Compass Hospice

 December 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 891
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Dozens of donated, decorated evergreen trees at the Towers Family Historical Museum in Hobbs were not just a beautiful display of Christmas cheer. They prompted $50,000 in donations for Compass Hospice's work in Caroline County.Despite the rainy weather, the annual Festival of Trees the first weekend of December attracted almost two dozen corporate sponsors who raised over $25,000 of the total proceeds. Sponsorship levels ranged from $5,000 or more to $250.
About 130 people attended the preview party Friday, Dec. 1, to put in their bids for tiny, tabletop trees to elaborately decorated trees with extras, and everything in between.
I think it's the best year yet," said Compass Hospice CEO Heather Guerieri Sunday afternoon.
"A lot of the same people do trees and sponsor over and over, and they just get more talented and more creative every year." Co-chairs of this year's festival were Melanie McMahan and Dave Whaley.
When all the receipts were counted, the result was "the most successful Festival of Trees to date," Baird wrote in a Dec. 15 email.
"It's been great," said Compass Hospice Development Director Shelly Baird Sunday afternoon.
"We have 76 trees, which is the most we've ever had." This is the sixth year the event has been held at the Towers Family Historical Museum on Sennett Road.
Owners Bill and Gail Towers "are so generous," Baird said. "They host this and they donate and they're amazing." "We just want the bids to go up," Gail Towers said, laughing as she imitated the chiming sound of new bids on the Trice Auctions website.
"I just can't wait till it starts bing, bing, bing, bing, bing." The preview party's "Pick of the Tree Lot" raffle raised $3,000. The winner, who could choose any tree in the display, chose "Chestnuts Roasting on an Open Fire," a snowy, woodland-themed tree and extras donated by the Strzempka family. It was won by Jill Pugh of Shore Industries of Denton, one of the festival's sponsors.
The Strzempka family's 2022 tree won the raffle as well. Along with this year's tree, they donated a fire pit and supplies, as well as decorations created by family members from across the country.
Created in memory of the family patriarch who had been cared for by Compass Hospice at the end of his life, "the whole family came three different days to get it perfect," Baird said.
"One of the granddaughters, I believe in Seattle, donated these hand blown icicles. Another grandchild made the skirts. These are handmade mittens by another family member," she said.
"I don't know all the stories, but I'm sure many of these other trees have a story," Baird said.
About four trees sported a Grinch theme. Some trees were rustic, other elegant.
Several tabletop trees were made of seashells. North Caroline High School's Spanish IV class created a "We are Bulldogs!" tree while Choptank Electric Cooperative honored 100 years of Disney.
Some creators donated several trees; florist Sherry Councell created a dozen.
Festival attendees picked up information for online bidding hosted by Trice Auctions of Denton. Bidding ended at 4 p.m. Sunday, and winners picked up their trees the following Monday and Tuesday.
The festival "proceeds stay in Caroline County for hospice services and grief services," Guerieri said. "We don't turn people away based on ability to pay if they don't have insurance for hospice." Baird said fundraisers like the Festival of Trees provides for Compass Hospices services in Caroline, Kent and Queen Anne's counties.
"We have to raise about $500,000 to $700,000 a year through donations" because insurance doesn't cover every hospice service," Baird said.
"Our entire grief services support department is not covered by insurance, so all of about $400,000 of that goes to that department. We provide counseling to close to 800 people a year, and a lot of them were not even involved with hospice." Among them are children in each of the three counties' schools.
Compass Hospice, based in Centreville, provides hospice and supportive care in-home and at the Barnette Center in Centreville and Arcadia Assisted Living in Denton; community grief support; and veterans services.
"This is just such a heartwarming experience to be able to volunteer and be among such a special group of people that do care, and their heart is in it," volunteer Connie Calloway Hutson said. "That's the reason I do it. I'm just so proud that I can do it." Bill Towers said they sponsor fundraisers for hospice "because it's an organization that needs some support." "And he has a heart of gold," Gail Towers said.
"They do a great job.
We've never had to use hospice," Bill Towers said, as his wife added, "It's one of those things that you're glad that they have it." "But you hope you never have to use it," he said. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT

 From left, Compass Hospice Development Director Shelly Baird, volunteer Connie Calloway Hutson, volunteer Jody Herb and CEO Heather Guerieri wrap up the Festival of Trees Dec. 3 at Towers Family Historical Museum in Denton.

 CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT

 This detail is from the "What a Treasure" tree, donated by the Cory Family.

 CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT

 This Christmas Tree Farms tree was one of a dozen donated by Sherry Councell to Compass Hospice's Festival of Trees.

 CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT

 Compass Hospice's Shelly Baird poses with this "God Bless America" tree donated by Nagel Farm Service.

 CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT

 Bill and Gail Towers host the 2023 Compass Hospice Festival of Trees at their Towers Family Historical Museum in Denton. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a fundraising event for Compass Hospice, a health organization providing end-of-life care. While the event itself is a community activity, the primary context is health-related services and charitable support for hospice care.

title: Trans patients face barriers to care
author: Tommy Tucker; Capital News Service
content:
Trans patients face barriers to care

 December 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tommy Tucker; Capital News Service | Page: A9 | Section: News 
 
 840
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - Paisley Parsons is 10 years into his medical gender-affirming transition, and a majority of that time he's spent looking for a good team of doctors in Maryland.Parsons, from near Hagerstown, had limited access to nearby care when starting his transition. Driving to Philadelphia, the District of Columbia or Baltimore were the best options to receive what he needed.
"It took me probably six or seven years to find a team of doctors that I felt like was up to par, but prior to that, finding someone educated and competent was few and far between," Parsons said. "A lot of it was a proximity issue, and most doctors around me just had no idea about anything trans related." While access to gender-affirming care has improved since Parsons first started his transition, it still varies across Maryland.
"Some of my patients travel hours to see me," said Dr. Helene Hedian, the director of Clinical Education at Johns Hopkins' Center for Transgender and Gender Expansive Health in Baltimore. "There has been an increased demand for services in the past year, which at times has led to long wait times." There is a concentration of qualified doctors in urban areas like D.C. and Baltimore, with less access the farther a patient is from a major city.
For those looking for a doctor with experience in gender-affirming care, Hedian recommends looking through the provider directory on GLMA: Health Professionals Advancing LGBTQ Equality's website.
The directory confirms the concentration of doctors in urban areas. For example, a search for gender-affirming hormone therapy in Easton, shows the closest doctor is over an hour away in Baltimore, D.C. or Odenton, Maryland.
"Baltimore City is probably the nexus of the trans community in terms of access, but the wait times are really long for our experienced providers," said Lee Blinder, the executive director of Trans Maryland, a trans-led community organization.
"Many people in our more rural areas of the state, or even in some of our counties in our suburban areas, are not able to access an affirming provider." Blinder is a founder of Trans Maryland, formerly known as Trans Healthcare MD, which started as a community resource for connecting trans and non-binary residents to qualified practitioners.
"Trans Maryland started out of my own and our other co-founders' lack of access to gender-affirming care," said Blinder. "We are extraordinarily lucky to be based in Maryland, certainly looking at the national landscape." In May this year, Gov.
Wes Moore signed the Trans Health Equity Act, which requires the state's medical assistance program and Medicaid to provide coverage for gender-affirming care beginning Jan. 1.
Moore also signed an executive order in June, protecting anyone seeking gender-affirming care in Maryland from legal punishment by other states.
"Those two events in the past year have contributed to increased demand for gender care in the state of Maryland," said Hedian. "People are traveling into the state, especially because in many states they're not able to receive the care that they used to get." As of 2022, 24,000 transgender adults live in Maryland, with an estimated 6,000 enrolled in Medicaid, according to a study by the Williams Institute on Medicaid coverage for gender-affirming care.
The Maryland Department of Health estimated that the number of Medicaid enrollees seeking gender-affirming treatment under the bill would increase by approximately 25 individuals per year, up from 98 in 2022.
"We're aware of the issue and we know that being able to address health care shortages, (is) something that has been long standing within the state," Moore said to Capital News Service. "I also know that things like the Trans Health Care Act was the right thing, in the right manner, and we want to make sure that our state is welcoming." Moore said that having the medical facilities and personnel to treat people is a priority, and that doctor and nursing shortages extend to other areas of medicine.
To adjust to the demand, Dr. Julius Joi Johnson-Weaver, a board-certified family physician, offers gender-affirming care through a program at their private practice. Johnson-Weaver is transgender and non-binary and has experienced many of the care-access issues their patients have dealt with.
It sparks a lot of anxiety, Johnson-Weaver said, when someone is ready to transition "in whatever way it typically starts to feel urgent," and they are told, "Oh yeah, it's gonna be six months, you know, or it's gonna take a long time to get an appointment." Del. Bonnie Cullison, D-Montgomery, vice-chairman of the House Health and Government Operations Committee, cosponsored the Trans Health Equity Act.
She said she is aware of the access issues and works closely with Trans Maryland to solve them. And, she said, she agrees with Moore that the bill was the right step for protecting health care for trans Marylanders.
Cullison encourages transgender constituents to reach out about these issues: "Talk to us, keep us informed. Let us know what we can do policy-wise, or advocacy-wise." 
 
 Caption: TOMMY TUCKER/CA PITAL NEWS SERVICE

 A poster at the University of Maryland Health Center in College Park reminds students to update their name and gender marker in the school's system, Friday, Dec. 1. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on barriers to gender-affirming healthcare access for transgender patients in Maryland, including medical provider shortages, legislative actions, and systemic challenges in healthcare delivery. While public safety and local government aspects are mentioned (e.g., state laws, provider directories), the core issue revolves around healthcare access and medical services.

title: Local children affected by addiction receive holiday gifts through Nicole's Promise
author: CONTRIBUTED
content:
Local children affected by addiction receive holiday gifts through Nicole's Promise

 December 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CONTRIBUTED | Page: 8 | Section: News 
 
 509
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - More than 70 children with parents lost to, struggling with or in recovery from addiction got Christmas gifts this month, thanks to a new program in Easton.Nicole's Promise, a program from Grace Street, a recovery community organization in Easton, directly supported young people who have lost a parent to addiction with a special shopping trip hosted by Talbot County Sheriff's Office deputies.
Nicole's Promise also includes a Christmas gift drive for children and teens with a parent struggling with or in early recovery from substance use disorder.
Bri S., a peer support specialist at Grace Street, thought of the program in honor of her best friend, Nicole, who died of an overdose last March. Nicole left behind six children.
Last week, 19 children and teens aged 3 to 16 who lost one or both parents to addiction met at the Talbot County Sheriff's Office in Easton for the Christmas event.
After a visit and gift from Santa, the group rode in a caravan with Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble and his deputies and staff to Target, where each child had $150 to spend and teens had $200 to spend any way they chose.
The kids fanned out with the sheriff and his crew and had a blast deciding what to buy. Target donated wrapping paper, bows and popcorn.
After a generous Secret Santa paid for the gifts, the group headed back to the sheriff's office for a visit with an elf, hot chocolate and cookies, pizza and gift wrapping, plus an impromptu game of soccer with the sheriff.
Nicole's Promise also provided top wished-for gifts for 22 children in Talbot County and 30 children in Caroline County, thanks to Mid-Shore Restoring Hope in Women. In total, Nicole's Promise provided gifts this holiday season to 71 children and teens.
Grace Street is the area's first recovery community organization. RCOs are a nationally recognized model that help bridge the gap between professional treatment and a successful life in long-term recovery through enhanced supports and services.
Chesapeake Charities received a one-year grant from Maryland's Opioid Operational Command Center to establish the Grace Street RCO.
Easton's center delivers an assortment of non-clinical, community-centered, peer recovery support services, harm reduction resources, workforce training and development, youth programming, overdose prevention activities and resources and support groups. The center helps people establish healthy lifestyles and reacclimate into society while building recovery capital and working to reduce stigma often associated with addiction.
Grace Street serves people in Easton and Talbot County and in neighboring counties across the Mid-Shore. Referrals are not necessary and services are free. The center is open weekdays and Sundays, 4 p.m. to 9 p.m. and Saturdays, 2 to 7 p.m. Daytime hours vary.
For more information, visit GraceStreetRecovery.org.

 Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble, along with some of his deputies and staff, pose with Grace Street Program Director Kate Dulin and several children during Nicole's Promise in Easton.

 Grace Street volunteer Michele Dyott, left, smiles during gift wrapping with Trent Acree, 11, and a Christmas elf during Nicole's Promise in Easton.

title: 'This is a game-changer' - Caroline moves forward with mobile health plans
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
'This is a game-changer' - Caroline moves forward with mobile health plans

 December 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 1074
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Caroline County is one step closer to a mobile integrated health program.Data compiled in a 71-page needs analysis report has set the stage for a grant request approved by the Caroline County Commissioners at their Dec. 5 meeting.
Presenting highlights of the report were four members of an executive committee focused on the program and finding funding for it. They included Director of the Department of Emergency Services Mark Sheridan, Health Officer Robin Cahall, EMS Chief Kathy Jo Marvel and County Health Department Director of Nursing Holly Trice.
Executive committee members who were absent from the meeting are Chrissy Bartz, of the Basic Life Support Committee, and Dr. Jeffrey Uribe, Caroline County Medical Director.
The report describes the current medical needs of county residents, how and where emergency medical teams respond to them and how they can be better served by a more efficient and effective program.
"We don't want to just focus on reoccurring ambulance calls because that is a small part of it," Sheridan said. "We want to look at the health of all the people in Caroline County and how can we provide that point of care that they may need." The goal of the mobile integrated healthcare program is "a huge partnership with all of us coming together to basically take care of people," Sheridan said.
The report, initiated in spring 2023, was compiled by Annapolis-based Tetra Tech and funded by the Caroline County Basic Life Support Committee.
It substantiated what EMS has experienced, but it provided the data needed to seek grant funding from the Maryland Department of Health to create a mobile integrated health program.
Following a nationwide trend, "911 calls are getting more and more primary care-related and less emergency," Marvel said. Many of the calls EMS receives are from people who "don't really need to go to the ER, which now has compounded into long ER wait times because they're using the ambulance and the ERs to treat what could be treated with primary care." Tetra Tech compiled call data and discovered "69 unique addresses that generated the bulk of calls; 558 repeat calls, to be exact, to just 69 different addresses," Marvel said. "It was a total of 70 individuals within those addresses that we could identify right now, just out of EMS, that are prime candidates for a mobile integrated health program." "We don't want you to think we don't want to do 911 calls, but 911 is built for the emergency calls; they're not built for us to be going out into the public and taking care of these people," Marvel said. "These people need other resources. The ER isn't good for them either, because you'd see a doctor once for blood pressure medicine, and then 30 days later you're out of that prescription and then you're going back to the ER for another 30 days for blood pressure medicine." The problem is "the health care system as a whole," she said, not a single department or agency.
A map of high density response areas verified what Sheridan and Marvel suspected. Most of the emergency responses were directed to "high populated areas of foreign descent that came here and don't know how to ask for help or don't know how to get help." "What we found through the study was 63% of the contacts that we do annually don't need a paramedic at all," Marvel said. "We have limited access to health care
We have long transport times because we don't have a hospital." Lack of transportation to primary care has prompted Commission President Travis Breeding to call for a mobility on demand program.
"We have lack of follow up with primary care, and then the big one is always that transportation piece," Marvel said.
"So, what's our purpose and goal? We want to reduce those high-frequency EMS repeat callers, improve access to preventive health care in Caroline County - people need the right care when it's needed (and) a whole community effort" as well as support from the county commission, Marvel said.
"All the resources have to be on the same page and somebody is going to have to manage this data," she said.
"And then we have to figure out what that sustainable funding is going to look like because we can't do it on our own." Armed with data from the Tetra Tech report, the executive committee is seeking a Community Health Resource Commission grant, so Cahall and Trice created a Health Equity Resource Communities request for proposal, which funds up to $1 million a year for five years.
Specifically, the committee is applying for "a little over $2.7 million for a 5-year period," Cahall said. "What we're looking at (is) five years' worth of personnel and training, vehicle purchase and maintenance, community outreach education, technology upgrades, and quality assurance and program evaluation." Instead of a trip to an emergency room or urgent care, a nurse or EMS clinician potentially will be able to assess a client's needs at home, possibly through a telehealth visit with a doctor, and then follow up with appropriate resources from other community partners, like the departments of health or social services.
Letters of support for the grant application have come from University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, Choptank Community Health, the Mid-Shore Local Health Improvement Coalition, the BLS Committee, Caroline County Behavioral Health, DES, Dr. Uribe and others.
Even if that funding doesn't come through, the committee is committed to moving forward with a mobile integrated health program in the county. "We're going to keep going," Cahall said. "We're still doing a strategic plan." The committee should hear if they've received the funding by mid-February.
The full report is online at www.carolinemd.org/DocumentCenter/View/9045/Caroline-County-MIH-Needs-Analysis.
To view the full Dec. 5 presentation to the County Commissioners, visit www.carolinemd.org/667/Live-Meetings, and click on the video link. 
 
 Caption: SCREENSHOT

 Presenting highlights of the report to the Caroline County Commissioners Dec. 5 are four members of an executive committee focused on creating a mobile integrated health program. Inset from left are: Health Officer Robin Cahall, EMS Chief Kathy Jo Marvel and County Health Department Director of Nursing Holly Trice and, out of frame, Director of the Department of Emergency Services Mark Sheridan.

 COURTESY OF CAR OLINE COUNTY

title: 'We have a lot to do' - Maryland Commission on Public Health holds inaugural meeting
author: Michael Reid; mreid@somdnews.com
content:
'We have a lot to do' - Maryland Commission on Public Health holds inaugural meeting

 December 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid; mreid@somdnews.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 469
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland's Commission on Public Health met virtually for the first time as a group on Dec. 14 and spent much of the time in the organizational phase.The commission will be tasked with making recommendations to improve the delivery of foundational public health services, assessing the foundational health capabilities of the Maryland Department of Health as well as local health departments and make recommendations for reform.
It will also address foundational public health areas, including as they relate to behavioral health, and respond to COVID-19, overdoses, maternal and infant mortality and other major public health challenges.
"Our main task ultimately is reporting; it's not just meeting, discussing, working in our work groups, coming up with recommendations, analyzing," said Lushniak, who added that assessing, analyzing and recommendations are key features.
The commission will be in effect until June 30, 2025, when it must submit its final report.
An interim report was due Dec. 1, which was submitted by the co-chairs who were able to meet a few times "as we didn't want to be late with our homework assignment," Lushniak said.
That report was sent with a few amendments, one of which was a request for an extension to June 30, 2025, for its final report. Though the commission took effect last June 1, appointments were not completed until late October.
The commission also requested the ability to seek financial support mechanisms as it believes "there may be opportunities in public health foundation-level support through grant mechanisms." The commission members requested the establishment of maryland.gov emails as well as the establishment of a website. The members also officially recognized the contributions of staff providing subject matter expertise and noted "government-involved staffing helps facilitate the logistics and work of this commission." "I think we all experienced the incredible challenge of the pandemic of the century in the past few years, and during that challenge recognized how incredibly strenuous the task was ahead of our public health force in particular, and the roadblocks and the gaps in public health, funding and resources really restricted our ability," said Dr. Meena Brewster, one of three co-chairs on the state board.
"We have a lot to do to be out there and be a part of this," said Lushniak, who added the commission has no hidden agendas and will be "transparent." The next meeting will be held at 2 p.m. on Thursday, Jan. 4, at the Baltimore County Department of Health. There will also be a virtual option.
For more information on the Commission of Public Health, email MD.CoPG@maryland.gov or go to smchd.org/commissiononpublichealth/. 
 
 Caption: SCREENSHOT BY MICHAEL REID/SOUTHERN MARY LAND NEWS

 Maryland Commission on Public Health Co-Chair and St. Mary's County Health Officer Dr. Meena Brewster, top left, speaks to, clockwise from top right, Dr. Boris Lushniak, Dr. Oluwatosin Olateju, Sen. Ariana Kelly (D) and Dr. Nicole Rochester during the commission's inaugural meeting Dec. 14. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
