title: New Centreville YMCA offers programs for both physical and social development
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Bay Times Record Observer
content:
New Centreville YMCA offers programs for both physical and social development

 January 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Bay Times Record Observer | Section: Local News 
 
 1469
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — As the Queen Anne's County Family YMCA opened its doors in October, they also opened a new home to the community.The beautiful, new structure for the YMCA of the Chesapeake is located on 210 Vincit St. in Centreville and is welcoming, clean, state-of-the-art and bursting with friendly energy. The YMCA membership pamphlet states, "A better you makes a better us. With the Y, you're not just a member of a facility, you're a part of a cause. With a shared commitment to nurturing the potential of kids, improving health and well-being, and giving back and supporting our neighbors, your membership will not just bring about meaningful change in yourself, but also in your community."
Laura Feller, wellness and membership director at the Centreville YMCA, explains, "Most people think it is a gym, but we are not. We are the YMCA. We don't want to compete with any other area gyms. We are a YMCA and our motto is 'from cradle to grave' and 'diapers to diapers'."
Although many might chuckle at those mottos, they are quite evident from the moment you walk in the doors. This community home welcomes all ages to get active and stay healthy for their lifetime.
Children are not only welcomed to come, but they are also encouraged to be an active part of the YMCA family. Children up to 12 years old are welcome to join the "Stay and Play" program that encourages parents to "work out or take a class while your kids have fun in a safe environment." The large Stay and Play playroom is full of toys, coloring, a large play boat, a kitchen set, a slide, dolls, and strollers.
In addition to the inside play area, the Stay and Play room has an outside playground as well.
One Stay and Play worker said, "It's a good location. Everybody's so nice and welcoming. I like staying active and have coached little kids. This [YMCA] helps me stay active. The kids here aren't allowed to have technology [in the Stay and Play]. They have to go and play tag [and other games and activities]. They are restless from school, and this is their recess."
Without the distraction of technology, kids are enjoying each others' company, increasing their imaginative play and learning good social skills as well. Brielle Forte (age 5) always asks to go to the Stay and Play and shares, "My favorite part of the Y is playing outside when we play tag and hide and seek. I like playing in the boat and running on the track too."
In addition to the Stay and Play room, children can participate in many other activities at the YMCA including day camp, swim lessons and even have a birthday party. For an additional fee, members and non-members can sign their children up for "Schools Day Out" days for ages 4-12 from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. to help with child care when schools are closed.
Swim lessons are also open and run through March 8. Although the swim lessons are an extra fee, Feller said, "All people and all children on the Shore should know how to swim. We are so close to the water. Getting healthy should not be a luxury that only some people can afford. Swimming is a life skill."
Financial assistance is available for both YMCA memberships and programs due to generous volunteer donations. In addition, the YMCA can be rented for birthdays and other parties with pizza and swimming for a reasonable price.
Older children and teens get an added bonus at the YMCA. Once a child is 11 years old, he or she can sign up, at the front desk, to take a class to be trained on the workout machines. This personalized, youth class explains and shows how to safely use the workout equipment. This informative class is helpful for all ages and guides users on how to change the settings and use the machines for the most beneficial outcomes.
Each machine has a code to scan to show a "how-to" video as well.
Jax Forte (age 11) said, "I like the machines. It gives you an opportunity to use things you don't have at your house."
His brother, Ryland Forte (age 13), said, "I love being able to workout. It makes me feel so much better. It makes me happier and stronger for the day."
A diverse community of members of all ages are present at the YMCA classes too. Classes like cycling, boxing, strength circuit, barre, pilates, body combat, step and more run from early morning into the evenings. These classes have members from about 11 years old to 80 years old and beyond.
The sense of community is so strong with generations passionately working out together with the goals of being healthy and staying active.
Wayne Outlaw, a YMCA instructor, said, "I just wanted to help out with a need. I want to take all those obstacles [associated with working out] out of the way. I teach a stretch class, body combat, core and low intensity HIIT. I just love exercise."
One participant in Outlaw's class said, "I am 57. I am doing a seven-day trial right now [at the Y]. So far, so good. I love the classes. Some gyms there are just machines and no classes. After not working out for a long time, these classes help me get back into working out."
Whether you are an avid fitness class participant or a first timer, each class offers something for everyone. The modifications and choices allow each member to work as hard as they want or need to.
Community members of all ages are enjoying more than just the classes. Walking the track is a favorite for all ages. At any point, you can see young children running or walking with their families, couples or friends connecting and catching up while walking, as well as others running to train and strengthen their bodies.
One couple — who enjoys walking the track regularly together — said, "We come and walk together. We may try the open gym with basketball or pickleball soon. [The YMCA is] a great place for kids to hang out, both middle school and high schoolers. It's a great place to be."
In addition to the pool, members enjoy the sauna too. Queen Anne's County teacher Gabrielle Corder said, "I love [the YMCA]. I love working out before work every day and then going to the sauna. I look forward to [the sauna] after my workout each morning."
As adults become older, the YMCA offers many opportunities with their Active Aging Center. Adults, 50 years or older, can register to be a part of the Active Aging Center. Participants do not need to be a member at the YMCA to attend Active Aging Adult events, but a YMCA membership increases the number of programs available to the member. The Active Aging Center offers classes that include: walking track, pool laps, aqua zumba, creative club, lottery bingo, puzzle time, dominoes, barre class and more.
There are classes on health topics like "Top 10 Arthritis Tips" and social events like "Hot Chocolate and Snowflakes" craft event, DIY doormats, monthly birthday potlucks and more. Some older adults enjoy coming to the Y daily for lunch as a way to be social and get out of their houses. Lunch is served at noon daily, and registration occurs two weeks in advance at the Active Aging Center counter at the YMCA. There is a small cost associated with the lunch based on age and needs, but the menu states, "No one is turned away for the inability to pay."
The YMCA is the answer to so many needs in our community. Throughout the day, you can see multigenerational games of pickleball and basketball, where participants are both learning and teaching each other. You can see all ages working out together as well as sharing advice, tips, and strategies. You can hear encouraging words and friendly greetings. You can see people showing concern and care for each other in conversations as well as care for the facility in tidying up and picking up trash, even if it does not belong to them.
The YMCA is a fun place for parents to let their kids get some energy out on a rainy, cold or too hot day. It is a safe place for teens to meet their friends, workout, stay healthy and do their homework together. It is a social place to meet friends, take a new class or learn new skills. It is a healthy place to set and meet goals. It is a special place where people like to be together in community, a place to raise families, share wisdom and grow together.
For the month of January, there is no joining fee, a $75 savings. The YMCA is always looking for volunteers, donors, members and workers too. For more information, go to ymcachesapeake.org or call 443-262-9994. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the YMCA's community programs emphasizing physical health, wellness, and social development across all age groups. While it touches on local community aspects, the primary emphasis is on health-related services, fitness activities, and wellness initiatives.

title: New hospital was decades in the making
author: Natalie Jones
content:
New hospital was decades in the making

 January 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 1611
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Although the certificate of need was approved for the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's long-awaited new regional medical center, work remains to be done in the coming year before construction begins.The Maryland Health Care Commission's Jan. 18 approval of the hospital system's application is launching a flurry of activity in further developing the new medical center.
For now, the hospital system is "eagerly" awaiting approval from the Maryland Health Services Cost Review Commission on UM Shore Regional Health's full rate application in the coming months — the final regulatory approval needed to move the regional medical center project forward, said Trena Williamson, UM Shore Regional Health's director of communications and marketing.
The hospital system is continuing work with the state, Talbot County and the Town of Easton to refine and approve site and building plans. Work is also ongoing with the project architects to refine and finalize facility design, Williamson said.
Site work at the new regional medical center's location off of Longwoods Road is planned for this spring. Construction is anticipated to begin in spring 2025, with doors tentatively opening in summer 2028.
Project updates, including plans, upcoming milestones and photos, will be available to the community in a new section on UM Shore Regional Health's website in the next several weeks, Williamson said.
Ken Kozel, UM Shore Regional Health's president and CEO, said he was grateful for the hard work and dedication of the University of Maryland Medical System, the local hospital system, elected officials and the community in securing state funding and certificate of need approval.
"The level of detail, forward thinking and planning required to usher in a facility like this for our community to utilize well into the future has been monumental. I am proud of the work thus far," he said. "Bringing a project of this magnitude and complexity to fruition will require continued perseverance by all involved."
As the hospital system moves into the next phase of the project, Kozel said he's looking forward to sharing more details in the months ahead as they are finalized.
"I encourage our community to follow the progress and stay involved," he said.
Development of the new hospital is a project Mid-Shore residents and local officials have closely followed for over a decade. Many have questions on what improvements the new hospital will bring, how it will be funded and what work remains to be done in bringing the long-proposed vision to reality.
CERTIFICATE OF NEED
Although plans for the new hospital have been in the works for over a decade, the official green light to further development and begin construction was only recently received through the approval of the certificate of need.
Attaining that certificate required approval from Maryland Health Care Commission's Certificate of Need program, a state regulatory process designed to ensure that new health care facilities and services are developed only as needed.
If the commission determines a project is needed, it's tasked with ensuring the project is cost-effective, geographically and financially accessible, financially viable and that it will not have a negative impact on other health care facilities and services.
The certificate is required to build a new health care facility, to move an existing facility to a new location, to change the bed capacity of a facility, to change the type or scope of any health care service offered or to make a health care facility capital expenditure that exceeds the threshold established in Maryland statute.
UM Shore Regional Health, formerly known as Shore Health System, first began looking at alternatives for the hospital project in the latter half of the 2000s, keeping the five-county area's growing and aging population and a lack of physicians in mind.
The need for a new hospital stemmed from a number of concerns with the existing building, which the hospital system called "functionally obsolete for inpatient care" in its application for the certificate.
Easton's original 32-bed hospital opened its doors in 1907. Just eight years later in 1915, a new hospital was built on South Washington Street.
Though a small portion of the hospital built in 1915 is still a part of the current complex, the building has expanded, with the current structure including components updated throughout the last 100 years, according to the application.
A number of areas were considered for the site of the new hospital over the years, including locations in Queen Anne's County, a site near Chesapeake College in Wye Mills and a parcel off of Route 322 at Oxford Road.
Redevelopment and renovations of the existing hospital campus were also considered.
Surveys conducted early on in the project planning process made it clear that an accessible location was important to residents in the community; however, "no general agreement" on the most accessible location emerged, according to the application.
Ultimately, replacing the hospital off of Longwoods Road in Easton was determined to be the most cost-effective from the start, according to the 2012 application.
The commission considers eight criteria in its review of applications for the certificate, including the state health plan, need, viability of a project proposal, impact on existing providers, availability of more cost-effective services, health equity and an applicant's character and competence, according to the Maryland Health Care Commission.
The hospital system submitted its first application for the certificate for a new hospital off of Longwoods Road in Easton in September 2012. The application was docketed for formal review by the commission but was suspended due to financial concerns at the time.
A modified application for the project was submitted by the hospital system in October 2016, which was also docketed for formal review. But in July 2018, that application was withdrawn due to significant project changes after docketing.
Another certificate of need application for a similar hospital project on the same site was filed in September 2018, but review was deferred at the request of UM Shore Regional Health.
News on the new hospital remained relatively quiet until January 2023, when the latest application was filed with the Maryland Health Care Commission. Just over a year later, on Jan. 18, the certificate was approved.
WHAT'S IN STORE
The new regional medical center will sit on more than 200 acres of land off of Longwoods Road, adjacent to the Talbot County Community Center and just north of the Easton Airport.
The new location is about 3½ miles from the existing hospital, which is tucked into downtown Easton on Washington Street. The move puts the new hospital closer to U.S. Route 50, providing greater visibility, easier and safer access for ambulances and helicopters and more parking — over 1,100 spaces.
Sketch site plans for the hospital, which were approved by the Easton Planning Commission late last year, indicate that access to the hospital from Route 50 will be via Medical Center Drive, a new road to be developed near the existing entrance to the Talbot County Community Center.
Residents who frequently travel Route 662 will see some changes to their usual route — a portion of Longwoods Road will be relocated as a ring road around the new hospital, the site of which sits in the middle of existing Route 662.
The hospital system is working with the State Highway Administration on plans and approvals needed to relocate the road.
Physical road work, along with rough grading of the project site to prepare for construction in spring 2025, are anticipated to begin in late summer to early fall of this year, Williamson said.
The main hospital tower is proposed as a six-level, 325,000-square-foot building with 147 licensed beds in private rooms. That number includes 110 acute care beds and 12 special hospital rehabilitation beds, both of which are classified as inpatient beds, and 25 observation beds.
What's proposed is a change from the current hospital, which has 146 licensed beds in mostly semi-private rooms. The existing facility has significant excess physical capacity compared to its licensed bed capacity, according to the application, which creates "operation and cost inefficiencies."
The new hospital will see an increase in the number of licensed medical, surgical, gynecological and addictions beds and psychiatric beds, though the number of licensed obstetric, pediatric and rehabilitation beds is lower than the licensed capacity at the existing hospital.
The new hospital is slated to have 27 emergency department treatment spaces, two of which are designated as psychiatric exam spaces, and three rooms designated as psychiatric holding areas for patients awaiting admission decisions.
Seven operating rooms are proposed — an addition of one from the current hospital.
A ground level helipad will be located outside of the emergency department at the new location.
The current hospital has a rooftop helipad, but it's too small to accommodate Maryland State Police helicopters, meaning those patients must be taken by ground to the hospital after the helicopter lands at the airport, according to the application.
Adjacent to the hospital, a 60,000-square-foot medical office and outpatient services building is proposed.
FUNDING
The new regional medical center is estimated to cost $539.5 million.
Over half of the project — $333 million — is proposed to be funded through debt financing.
The state government is another significant source of funding.
Gov. Wes Moore's fiscal year 2025 capital budget, released Jan. 17, proposes allocating $20 million every year for the next three fiscal years and adding a $30 million allocation in fiscal year 2028.
The recently proposed state funding for the regional medical center adds on to the $10 million received in the state's fiscal year 2024 budget, which must be spent by the end of June.
About $39 million in cash flow from operations, $50 million in philanthropic gifts and approximately $18 million in investment earnings on bond proceeds during construction compose the remainder of the project's funding.
The proposed mix of cash flows, debt, philanthropy and state support are consistent with the University of Maryland Medical System's "historical approach to funding large, systemwide strategic initiatives," according to the application for the certificate. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the development of a new regional medical center, detailing regulatory approvals, funding, construction timelines, and healthcare infrastructure. While local government interactions are mentioned, the core subject is healthcare delivery and medical facility expansion.

title: Active Aging Center at YMCA growing in popularity
author: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com
content:
Active Aging Center at YMCA growing in popularity

 January 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 885
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — The recently opened new Queen Anne's County Family YMCA in Centreville is a "big hit", especially with senior citizens. This YMCA is only one of two in the Mid-Shore area with an "Active Aging Center" (for senior citizens, 55 and above). The other is at the St. Michaels YMCA in Talbot County.The Active Aging Center is a partnership between the Queen Anne's County Department of Community Services Area Agency on Aging, and the YMCA in Centreville.
Joining the Active Aging Center is free for seniors (55 and above), and offers so much to provide outstanding activities, the majority of those related to improving seniors quality of life. Everyone who has visited the Y in Centreville has been amazed at what a wonderful and all encompassing facility it is.
Being an Active Aging member includes the free use of the following at the Y; lap swim in the heated pool, use of indoor walking track, "wellness center" exercise equipment, art classes, lottery bingo, puzzle time, as well as a variety of specialized dance classes. These activities are all free to seniors, and come with limited use times for each, most begin in the mornings as early as 9 a.m., and concluding shortly after noon.
Growing in popularity is the weekday luncheons for seniors. A monthly calendar of what is being served each day is printed for seniors to take with them and choose which days they want to sign-up for, in advance. Meals are served promptly between noon through 12:15 p.m.
There is a small senior's cafe where the luncheons are served by Senior Center Aide Noah Fate-Cloud, always with a smile.
A sampling of what's been offered for the lunches thus far has included chicken salad, potato salad, three-bean salad, Mandarin orange slices, roast beef on a Kaiser roll, coleslaw, and fruit cocktail. An assortment of soups, sandwiches, fruit, vegetables and desserts are typically on the menu.
All lunches come with healthy choices of fruit juices, milk or water. The lunches focus on having healthy and appropriate serving portions of each item, and lean toward gourmet meals.
Among those attending regularly, Geraldine Colabella, of Centreville, said, "There is no comparison between the meals served here and fast food places, which I consider to be 'junk food'. The meals here are healthy, and if they weren't good, I wouldn't come back! Plus, for those of us who don't want to cook anymore, that's another plus."
Colabella's friend, Maggie Kovack, who comes with her, added, "Everything about these lunches are good! And the staff are very nice people."
Colabella's sister-in-law, Christine Colabella, came for the first time, after hearing her talk about how good the lunches were. After her first lunch, which was roast chicken breast with gravy, macaroni and cheese, seasoned green beans, a corn muffin and cinnamon apple slices, Christine concluded, "It was really good!"
The Active Aging Center asks only for donations, $3 per lunch per person for those over 60, and $6.30 for those between 55-59. "You can't get anything at a fast food place for those prices!", Kovack said. The note on the menu states, "All money given for meals is done so anonymously; no one is turned away for inability to pay."
Active Aging Center Manager Bethany Bennan is always there each weekday to supervise and provide information to center participants, especially any new activities or programs that are coming for seniors.
A guest speaker will be coming to a future luncheon talking about "Top 10 Arthritis Tips." Also, the second Friday of each month, along with serving their regular luncheon, a celebration of any senior's birthday for that month will be held along with potluck additions.
Any senior interested in having a regular YMCA membership, must be at least 62 years old, as the Y's definition of "senior" is different than the Active Aging program. If you qualify in that way as a senior, you should contact Financial Assistant Coordinator Lisa Everette at 443-262-9994. She meets every Friday with individuals to determine if they qualify for either the "Open Doors" or "Memberships for All" programs, which offer significant discounts.
The main benefit of having a Y membership for seniors who are in the Active Aging program is, there are no "limited access times" for Y members that seniors have to deal with as Active Aging members. A regular Y membership provides access to all facilities during all normal business hours.
Everette can inform you on what information is needed to qualify, and all meetings with her are private, one on one appointments. Membership rates can be reduced, through financial aid available from the generosity of the community who donate to the YMCA Annual Campaign.
A YMCA membership qualifies members for significant discounts for special programs and classes offered. Another special savings with a Y membership, families only pay $6 per month for each child, up to and not exceeding two children. All additional child memberships are free within that particular family. A person is considered "a child" up to the age of 26, if they are still residing at home and attending college full-time. Otherwise, a child/teen is considered age 11-17.
There are a number of discounts available for swim lessons, camps, and different programs with memberships to the YMCA, such as free "Stay & Play" childcare during morning and evening workouts by parents. Ask for a list of discounts you may qualify for. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Active Aging Center's health-focused services for seniors, including wellness activities, nutritious meals, and community health initiatives. While Local Life could be a secondary consideration, the primary emphasis on health and senior wellness aligns most directly with the Health topic.

title: Moms of children with special needs find respite at Hummingbird Inn
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Moms of children with special needs find respite at Hummingbird Inn

 January 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 1736
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Though the situations that brought six mothers of children with special needs to the Hummingbird Inn on a snowy January weekend are different, they shared a common thread: a desire to seek respite and connection.The weekend retreat, organized through nonprofit A Mother's Rest and held for the first time at the cozy Queen Anne Victorian bed and breakfast inn in Easton, provided the women with a much-needed and long-awaited chance to relax and refresh.
But the three-day weekend trip offered more than just respite — it gave the six mothers a space to be open and vulnerable with themselves and each other.
A Mother's RestFounded in 2017 by Andrea Roberts, A Mother's Rest Charitable Respite Foundation aims to improve the emotional and physical health of caregivers through affordable three-day weekend retreats.
The nonprofit operates two of its own respite inns — one in New Market, Maryland, and a second in northeastern Georgia. Both inns, open year-round, offer a multitude of weekend retreats for a variety of caregivers.
Bed and breakfast inns, like the Hummingbird, can participate, too, through A Mother's Rest's Porch Partners program, a national network of inns offering space for those seeking a break.
Eric Levinson, the owner and innkeeper at the Hummingbird Inn, learned about A Mother's Rest from his sister, a realtor in western Maryland who met Roberts.
Levinson reached out to Roberts, and from there, it became evident that his inn would be an ideal location for a respite retreat, he said.
There was also a personal connection for Levinson: his mother had specialized in working with children with disabilities and those in need of extra care, making the concept resonate even more.
"Just knowing other people who have these types of children or (who are) caretakers, and how much they give to them and take little for themselves … that opportunity just seemed like a really great thing to be able to do," he said.
Levinson first spoke with Roberts last January, blocking out all of his inn's rooms for the weekend. The inn was fully booked within three to four days, he said, meaning that the six women who came to Easton had been waiting for a year before coming to stay.
Though it's in the name, the nonprofit's retreats aren't just limited to mothers of children with special needs. The weekend trips are also offered for couples, dads, adoptive or foster parents, families and other caregivers in need of a break.
Some retreats are designated for caregivers dealing with specific disabilities or situations, like parents of children with Down syndrome or caregivers to combat-injured veterans.
But at each retreat, no matter the life circumstances that brought them there, the need for a weekend away to sleep and relax, and to have the opportunity to connect with others who understand their daily challenges, unites caregivers across all spectrums.
A weekend in EastonAlthough a snowstorm blanketed the Mid-Atlantic region on Friday, Jan. 19, it didn't deter six women from driving several hours to Easton for a weekend to themselves.
Check-in started at 3 p.m. on Friday, with inn staff helping each woman get settled in her room.
Each room, named after a town on the Eastern Shore, held a surprise care package with soaps, socks and eye masks. A floral arrangement also sat in each room, homed in a mug labeled "hug in a mug."
Though respite retreats affiliated with A Mother's Rest don't have planned activities, a number of local businesses that heard about the event reached out to Levinson asking how they could help to make the weekend even more special.
Out of the Fire offered a $50 credit for a meal. Legal Assets reached out with a special meal discount. Bluepoint Hospitality offered free coffee or beverages and free pastries, pie or ice cream. Friends called Levinson saying they'd like to buy the women a bottle of wine.
The community offered more than just food and drink, though — Chatterbox Hair Salon provided free shampoos, styles and blowouts, and the Avalon Theatre offered tickets to its weekend comedy or blues show.
Levinson and his team helped make reservations for the offerings and even drove some women to their hair appointments, taking away the stress of coordination.
"When I would talk to people about it, it was always the same: they knew somebody or they had a family member in this situation, and people just know how it's a lot, and you give up a lot — not begrudgingly, these are your family and children obviously, but everybody needs a break," Levinson said.
For Maureen Robinette, a mom from northern Delaware, the weekend served as a much-needed break from the busyness of raising her two active sons and her 9-year-old daughter with special needs.
"My husband will take my boys to whatever sporting event, he coaches them, he takes them to practices," she said. "So just every night, I'm on (daughter) duty, and it's just exhausting."
Robinette, who works full-time, spent her weekend walking around town, shopping, reading and enjoying breakfasts and dinners. She also took advantage of the offer from the nearby salon.
"It was amazing," she said of her experience, laughing. "It was very relaxing, I just felt we were pampered by this place.
And of course, as with any bed and breakfast, a mouthwatering meal was served every morning.
On Saturday, Levinson served up a sausage quiche and Belgian waffles. Sunday's menu boasted a blueberry yogurt parfait, a savory breakfast galette and creme brulee French toast.
And just before the women checked out on Monday, Levinson offered an Austrian egg cake, filled with leeks, eggs, cheese, onions and breadcrumbs, and pikelets, fluffy Australian pancakes topped with strawberry sauce.
Reflections and connectionsWhile the respite weekend primarily served as an opportunity to rest, with no pressure to do activities or engage with others, the six women who came to Easton found connections.
Over breakfast on Monday, Jan. 22, five mothers who stayed for the full weekend shared stories of hardships, interspersed with smiles at happy memories and positive developments with their children.
Candy Warner, a mom of two adult children, including a 30-year-old son who experiences uncontrollable seizures and aggression following a stroke before birth, traveled from near York, Pennsylvania, for the weekend retreat.
"It was wonderful, they always are," she said. "I'm always anxious to go home, but I don't want to go home because it's like reality."
Warner took the chance to connect with two of the other moms in Easton for the weekend, walking over to dinner at Scossa and talking in a candid way that only others like her could understand.
"I mean, we all have the same emotions, anywhere from being happy to being totally angry and frustrated, just on different levels depending on our children's diagnoses," she said. "So we can all relate to each other, no matter what diagnoses our children have or what we're going through."
"Sometimes there's a connection … you just feel like you just make a new friend for life," Warner added, choking up with emotion.
Robinette said it's easier to talk with other moms who are going through the same things, others who aren't going to judge or give unsolicited advice.
"I feel like all of us are here to just listen to our stories," she said, adding: "I just feel like it's just great to talk openly and share experiences, and understand what everyone else is going through, like stuff that you can't talk to your normal friends about."
Talking with normal friends can result in a look of pity, Warner said.
"I don't want your pity, just sit and listen to me sometimes," she said. "I don't need your feedback."
Robinette agreed.
"I didn't tell people at work for the longest time, because I just didn't want to get emotional, you don't want pity," she said with emotion in her voice. "Now I'm fairly open with it, because it's been long enough and it's just easier to explain stuff."
It can be isolating to parent a child with disabilities, said Melissa Egan Kerr, a mom of two from the Lehigh Valley in Pennsylvania. She said that feeling was compounded by the pandemic. And though some moms do choose to use the respite retreats to keep to themselves, the one in Easton was a little different.
"...This one, it is just like a really organic feeling of connecting with people and talking, and how therapeutic that is to just share your story with people who you know get what you're talking about," she said.
Deborah Adams, an adoptive mom of two children with trauma from earlier on in life, said A Mother's Rest retreats have saved her family, and at times, their sanity.
"It's easy to just feel so isolated … to just cut ourselves off," the Richmond, Virginia, mom said of her and her husband's experience raising their children with hidden disabilities. "And this is a way to get out of it and to have kind of some self-safety, and that's huge."
Adams found out about A Mother's Rest about four years ago, just before the COVID-19 pandemic.
"I went on a retreat, a random retreat," she said, "And all of the moms that were there, we all just connected on a level that you cannot connect with anyone."
A lasting impactEven before all of the women had checked in to the Hummingbird Inn that Friday afternoon, Levinson said he planned to host more respite retreats — a sentiment that still held true Monday morning at checkout.
"You could hear the gratitude in their voice, how much this meant to them," Levinson said of his six guests.
The weekend also held special meaning to Michael Abbott, the inn's event coordinator. Abbott, who lost his own mother at a young age, said he knew the retreat was something he wanted to give extra special care to.
For Abbott, that meant remembering the little things, like driving some of the mothers to their hair appointments or remembering that one guest preferred iced tea over coffee in the morning.
Being able to provide a safe, peaceful and welcoming space to decompress was meaningful to Abbott, too. He recalled one mother taking her first look at her room for the weekend.
"She's like, 'Oh my god, this is so lovely and so peaceful. I can see myself sitting here and reading in the corners. It's just what I need, and so inviting,'" he remembered.
To Abbott, that was clear.
"I just thought that she was ready to just let go, have a moment to herself, which I don't think she gets a lot," he said.
"It's just something they needed," Abbott added, choking up. "Moms go through a lot." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on respite care for caregivers of children with special needs, emphasizing emotional and physical health benefits. While it includes local elements (Easton, MD), the core theme revolves around health and well-being support for caregivers.

title: As Maryland considers medical aid in dying, here’s how it’s playing out in D.C.
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content:
As Maryland considers medical aid in dying, here’s how it’s playing out in D.C.

 January 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1368
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — A 74-year-old man with Lou Gehrig's disease. An 88-year-old man with congestive heart failure. A 54-year-old woman with cancer.These are among the 24 terminally ill patients who, between 2017 and 2022, ended their lives under Washington, D.C.'s Death with Dignity Act, according to public records.
The law gives D.C. residents with incurable illnesses the option to die by ingesting lethal medication and requires the government to generate annual reports on those who chose to do so.
Those reports are of interest this year as legislatures across the country push to expand access to medical aid-in-dying options like the one in D.C. In neighboring Maryland and Virginia, for example, measures to legalize the procedure are now pending in the legislatures.
In Maryland, aid-in-dying proposals in past years have faced pushback from a number of opponents.
Religious groups and pro-life activists argue it infringes on their belief in the sanctity of life. Physicians fear it may violate medical ethics. And disability rights groups worry that aid in dying would be used to encourage individuals with disabilities to end their lives.
But advocates say there's unprecedented momentum this year for an aid-in-dying law in Maryland — in part because arguments for the option have been strengthened by its implementation in D.C. and 10 other states.
People in Maryland "should feel safe knowing that it's tried and tested," said Donna Smith, the Maryland and D.C. campaign director for the nonprofit group Compassion and Choices. "It's not a large number of people that use this, but for the people that need it, it's everything."
In 2016, D.C. became the sixth jurisdiction in the nation to pass aid-in-dying legislation. According to a Capital News Service analysis of annual reports released by the D.C. Department of Health, the 24 people who have died under the law ranged in age from 40 to 98. Seventeen patients had cancer, while others had neurological, heart or lung conditions.
Data was available through February 2022. The District officially counts 23 people as having utilized aid in dying; however, 24 patients are listed in Department of Health records.
Many who sought aid in dying did so to end their suffering, according to Dixcy Bosley, a nurse care manager in D.C. who specializes in hospice and end-of-life care. As a volunteer with Compassion and Choices, Bosley has counseled several patients in the District who pursued it as an option.
"I've been with five people," Bosley said, "and every single one was just a really peaceful experience."
Bosley recalled the first aid-in-dying patient she cared for in the District: A man in his 60s and former electrician who depended on an oxygen tank to breathe. To be eligible, patients must have less than six months to live, make a series of oral and written requests and be sound of mind.
Bosley said she was struck by how the man planned for his death. He set a date and had family and friends visit to say their goodbyes.
"He was not suicidal," Bosley said. "He really just wanted to stop suffering."
On the day he died, his wife and daughter were by his side as he mixed and ingested the medication. Through the cracked windows in his room, they could hear the sounds of a neighboring elementary school.
"We could hear the kids in the elementary school playing and laughing outside," Bosley said. "I just felt like it was just a beautiful death."
ETHICS AND ACCESS
Fewer people have utilized aid in dying in D.C. than advocates had expected, according to Smith.
Among the biggest barriers to accessing the procedure is the lack of doctors and pharmacies willing to provide care. In D.C., there have never been more than four physicians who have prescribed life-ending medications in any given year, the CNS analysis found.
And according to Bosley, many retail pharmacies refuse to fill aid-in-dying prescriptions. Major retailers declined or did not respond to CNS requests to discuss their policies on this.
The Medical Society of the District of Columbia, which represents physicians in the District, did not offer an opinion as the D.C. Council was debating its law in 2015 and 2016. A spokesperson for the group declined to comment for this story.
But many providers feel that aid in dying is inconsistent with their obligations to treat and heal their patients.
"People bristle at the idea that we would be able to heal through killing," said Daniel Sulmasy, a physician who serves as director of the Kennedy Institute of Ethics at Georgetown University. "This is something that I think grates against the fundamentals of the profession."
MedStar Georgetown University Hospital prohibits doctors from participating in the District's aid-in-dying program, according to Sulmasy.
"We can stop treatments and make sure people are comfortable, but we never act with the specific intention of making somebody dead," he said.
Within the advocate community, there are also concerns about racial disparities in accessing aid in dying.
In D.C., where 45% of the population is Black, 22 of 24 patients who have utilized the option are white, the CNS analysis found. One patient was Black, while another was Hispanic.
Similar trends have appeared in other states that have legalized aid in dying. In California, among most racially diverse jurisdictions with an aid-in-dying law, 0.8% of patients have been Black.
The disparities stem, in part, from broader health inequities, Smith surmises.
"I know in (the Black) community, we're still fighting to live," said Smith, who serves as the diversity, equity and inclusion advisor to Compassion and Choices. "We don't get adequate health outcomes to begin with. So it's hard to say, 'Okay, let me offer you this option (at the end of life)' when you haven't been given the support you need to live."
PROSPECTS IN MARYLAND
Maryland is among 18 states currently weighing aid-in-dying legislation. The bill is modeled after existing laws across the country and is the same as a measure that failed to make it out of committee a year ago.
Like in other jurisdictions, the bill would require patients to self-ingest medication. Physicians and health care facilities are not obligated to provide aid-in-dying services.
Similar measures have been considered in Maryland in the past but failed to pass — though they came close. In 2019, the House of Delegates approved an aid-in-dying bill that failed in the Senate on a 23-23 tie vote.
This year, as issues of bodily autonomy gain heightened awareness following the Supreme Court's decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) has indicated a willingness to bring an aid-in-dying bill to a vote.
Governor Wes Moore has also expressed support for bringing the option to Maryland.
"If a bill makes it to my desk with transition with dignity at its core, I will sign it," Moore said.
Senate Minority Leader Stephen Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Caroline and Cecil) expects most Republicans to oppose such a bill.
"From a perspective of the sanctity of life, a lot of times, it boils down to our religious beliefs on some issues," Hershey said. "This is certainly one of them."
Among those who hope the Maryland bill passes is Diane Kraus, a 59-year-old Baltimore native who was diagnosed in May 2021 with metastatic breast cancer and has since been advocating for the right to end her life.
Kraus has undergone four different types of chemotherapy and continues to receive treatment every three weeks. But it's become increasingly difficult for her to manage her symptoms, which include pain, nausea, confusion and headaches, among others.
Motivated by her own experiences with a terminal illness and 35 years of working as an occupational therapist in hospice and home health settings, Kraus testified in support of Maryland's aid-in-dying bill last year.
"I wanted it for me," Kraus said in an interview with CNS. "I had seen so many people die in pain and so many people have such a poor quality of life at the very end. And they would say, 'I just want to go home and be with God and be with my relatives.' … And that just really struck me."
Kraus was devastated when Maryland's bill stalled last year and has considered relocating to a state where aid in dying is legal. She hopes that existing laws, like the one in D.C., help sway skeptics in Maryland this legislative term.
"Even people highly opposed…come around to some degree when they see it and have to live with it," Kraus said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on medical aid-in-dying legislation, patient experiences, ethical debates, and healthcare policy, all central to the Health topic. While public policy aspects intersect with Public Safety and Local Government, the core subject is medical/end-of-life care.

title: Compass CEO updates Caroline Commissioners on hospice work
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Compass CEO updates Caroline Commissioners on hospice work

 January 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 803
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — While a brick-and-mortar hospice facility isn't on the immediate horizon for Caroline County, Compass Regional Hospice has addressed the need of county residents for a higher level of care, according to the organization's CEO.Compass Executive Director Heather Guerieri explained how a memorandum of understanding with Arcadia Assisted Living works during her report to the Caroline County Commissioners at their Jan. 9 meeting in Denton.
Accompanying Guerieri were Board Secretary and certified hospice volunteer Terry Mead, who lives in Caroline County, and Clinical Homecare Manager Jessica Losten, who grew up in the county.
From January through November 2023, Compass served 90 Caroline County patients, 61 of whom were residents in one the four assisted living homes and skilled nursing facilities in the county.
The MOU between Compass and Arcadia, which is located on 5th Avenue in Denton, was effective August 2023 and allows the assisted living facility "to provide beds for Caroline County residents that want to stay in the county, aren't in an assisted living or a nursing home, (and) don't want to leave the county to come to our facility in Centreville," Guerieri said.
"Bricks-and-mortar is a lot of money, and we're not seeing the (number) of patients … that would warrant a building here currently," she said. "So, this agreement with Arcadia was a win-win, both for Arcadia and for our patients." Arcadia is obligated to provide a minimum of one to two beds for residential hospice level of care, but Compass only pays the facility when someone is admitted as a hospice patient.
The tri-county Barnette Center in Centreville has 10 beds for both a residential level of care and general inpatient care, which is the higher level of care for symptom management. Thirteen Caroline County residents were served in Centreville in 2023.
The higher level of care in Centreville that is not provided by Arcadia includes round-the-clock nursing and physicians who can monitor medications to help patients be more comfortable.
The Barnette Center is rarely at full capacity as people stay for a few days to have their symptoms safely managed and then go home, or they are at the very end of their lives.
Although he praised Compass for their work in providing "absolutely incredible" home care, Commission Vice President Larry Porter said, "I'm never going to be happy until we have a brick-and-mortar facility in this county for people to go to."
"We would love to have something here, too," Guerieri said. "We just have to be able to afford it, so it doesn't close down like the last one did. We just want to be smart."
The former hospice center in Denton opened in 2015 through an arrangement with Talbot Hospice, but was shuttered in 2018. Four years later, Compass abandoned plans to build a free-standing hospice facility in the county because of the "immense impact that the COVID-19 pandemic has had on the healthcare industry, staffing, and building material costs," Guerieri wrote in a July 2022 op-ed piece.
Guerieri provided current financial statistics about the organization which is running "at a loss of $177,943," she said. "Even though we're a nonprofit, you don't like to have a loss, that's for sure, but that's why we have fundraisers."
She said "93% of the people that we served in Caroline County were patients that had Medicare as their primary payer source, only 4% had private insurance, one patient had Medicaid and one was uninsured."
"And just to make a point about the uninsured, we do not turn anybody away based on ability to pay," Guerieri said.
Overall, Compass was able to bill people for room and board at $153,000, with a discount of $63,217.97 for charitable room and board. Insurance income was $1.6 million and lost revenue was almost $36,000 with total expenses of $1.84 million for 2023, she said.
The December 2023 Festival of Trees fundraiser at the Towers Family Museum in Denton raised over $50,000, "so a huge thank you to all of Caroline County residents for the continued support," she said.
The festival, co-chaired by Dave Whaley and Melanie McMahan, featured 76 trees. Of the 21 sponsors, 20 were Caroline County businesses and one was a family. About 150 people attended the preview party. Guerieri praised Bill and Gail Towers for hosting the event the past few years.
Mead, who is also president of the Caroline Foundation, said the foundation's board is a "strong supporter of hospice in this county," giving $800,00 to support that care for the past eight years.
Compass also provides free grief counseling services "to anybody in the community that needs our services" including children in the county's schools. Guerieri said.
Grief counselors will go to the school and even provide transportation if needed so children can receive help.
"We're doing a lot of work in the schools," she said. "The counselors are always calling us from the schools for our grief counselors to come in there." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Compass Regional Hospice's operations, patient care, financial challenges, and collaboration with local facilities, all central to healthcare services. While it mentions interactions with Caroline County Commissioners, the core content revolves around health-related initiatives and community healthcare delivery.

title: Festive crowd brings in $130K for Compass Hospice
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Festive crowd brings in $130K for Compass Hospice

 January 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 589
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Women attired in glittering gowns, men sporting bow ties, plenty of laughter and conversation, and a sumptuous dinner signaled a joyful evening gala Friday, Jan. 26 on the Chesapeake Bay's shore in Stevensville.But beyond the glamour was a goal more than met by the evening's festivities. Compass Regional Hospice's annual gala raised $130,500 to benefit hospice care, supportive care and grief support services for Queen Anne's, Kent and Caroline counties.
"This is a wonderful evening that not only brings money to Compass Hospice, it also represents what Hospice means to this county," said Compass board member Kirk Helfenbein.
Queen Anne's County State's Attorney Lance Richardson called the Chesapeake Bay Beach Club a "beautiful venue for a great cause. Compass Hospice provides exceptional care and we're very fortunate to have them in our county."
The $250 per person fundraising event that attracted 170 people began with cocktails and hors d'oeuvres, followed by a formal seated dinner, a live auction and Call to Cash, and dancing to the sounds of Sinatra Vocals performing the "Great American Songbook."
Prior to the gala, sponsorships and tickets accounted for $80,000 of the total raised. During the event, the live auction, Call to Cash and jewelry raffle raised $50,500.
Heather Guerieri, executive director of Compass Regional Hospice, thanked the organization's board members, "amazing volunteers" and the gala's sponsors and auction donors.
"Our longevity and success extends to this amazing community. We could not be where we are today without you," Guerieri said. "It's a privilege and honor to provide hospice and group support services to this community. Thank you for supporting us and trusting us with such a sacred task."
Compass grief counselor Sherrie Young offered the blessing. Matt Spedden served as the spirited emcee for the live auction and Call for Cash.
The highlight of the evening was the debut of a new video created by Chris Sciannella of Chester. In it, Camp New Dawn for bereaved children is featured, as well as the testimony of Katherine Hager, whose mother received care through Compass. She is clerk of the court for Queen Anne's County.
Guerieri thanked Sciannella for the "countless hours" he donated producing the video. "I like to give back," he said.
Sciannella said he and his six siblings lost their father at a young age. "We didn't have (a Camp New Dawn) when we were grieving."
Spedden said that each person attending the gala had probably "experienced Hospice in some way," as he had with his father and grandmother.
Calling Compass Hospice's care "an amazing, amazing experience," he praised the organization for its "programs not only for the people that are leaving us, but the ones that are left behind."
Sciannella's CAS Productions was a platinum sponsor, along with Kent Island American Legion Post 278.
Gold sponsors were the Chesapeake Bay Beach Club, R.B. Baker & Sons, Inc., and Luminis Health/Gilchrist.
Ruff Roofers, Queenstown Bank, Shore United Bank and PepUp were silver sponsors.
For 39 years, Compass staff have provided comprehensive, professional and compassionate support to people living with a life limiting illness, and those learning to cope with the death of a loved one.
All proceeds of the gala benefit hospice and supportive care, as well as our grief support services for the tri-county area. No one is turned away for inability to pay.
"We are so thankful to this community and their amazing generosity prior to and during our Gala," Compass spokesperson Lexy Mollica wrote in an Jan. 29 email. "It is such a humbling experience for us to see the unwavering support for our mission from citizens throughout Caroline, Kent, and Queen Anne's counties." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a hospice fundraising gala, highlighting health-related services like hospice care, grief support, and community health initiatives. While it includes local event elements, the primary emphasis is on health advocacy and medical services.

title: Partners In Care exchanges volunteer hours for services
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Partners In Care exchanges volunteer hours for services

 February 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 414
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Partners In Care provides services to people so they can age in place with dignity and respect.This includes all kinds of needs that pop up, like grocery shopping, pet care, completing forms, small honey-dos, and, perhaps the biggest one, transportation.
These tasks fall under the umbrella of nonmedical need, and the organization has come up with an ingenious way to provide the services.
Partners In Care has set up a service exchange. As life is long, one who is healthy at one time could use help later on. If they have earned volunteer service hours with Partners In Care, they can get services performed for their previous effort.
Kathleen Dormody is the program coordinator for the Mid-Shore Branch of Partners In Care. She serves Talbot and Caroline counties. Partners In Care is a statewide organization, which also serves Anne Arundel, Montgomery and Washington counties.
"Right now we (Mid-Shore) have truly engaged active members of less than 100. Organization-wide, we have 2,700 members. Our volunteers are considered members," Dormody said. "We are founded on the concept of time banking. What that means is with our volunteers — let's say they are doing a transport — they take a member to a doctor's appointment. They get time for that transport."
She explained that further down the road, they can use the hours they have banked. Volunteers can also used banked time for services for an older relative.
"When they get to the point where they are no longer driving, they may need our services. What we do is fill the gap between medical care and total isolation. Our mission is to help older adults, 60 plus years of age, to age in place with dignity and respect," Dormody said.
Among the services offered by Partners In Care are a small household repair program, a support group for the vision impaired, a program where veterans provide services for other veterans, trainings on internet safety and a ride partners program, in which volunteers provide transportation to those in need.
"Unlike Delmarva Community Transit, we are door to door," Dormody said.
The driver will pick the member up, take them to the appointment, wait for them at the appointment and drive them home.
"I love filling that loneliness. You may be on the phone with a member chatting for ten minutes. Letting them know that they are cared about. Most of our members are 80 years and up," Dormody said.
For more information about Partners In Care, its volunteer opportunities and the services is offers, visit partnersincare.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Partners In Care, a nonprofit providing nonmedical services (transportation, errands, companionship) to help elderly individuals age in place. While not strictly medical, the services directly relate to elder care and quality of life, aligning most closely with 'Health.' 'Local Life' is a secondary fit due to the community-based nature of the organization.

title: Senators grill pharmaceutical CEOS over the high cost of drugs in the U.S.
author: MATHEW J. SCHUMER Capital News Service
content:
Senators grill pharmaceutical CEOS over the high cost of drugs in the U.S.

 February 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MATHEW J. SCHUMER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 558
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Senators have rebuked CEOs of three major U.S.-based pharmaceutical companies for the high cost of prescription drugs in America."There is a lot of discussion in our nation about how divided our people are on many issues. That is absolutely true," said the panel's chairman, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vermont), "but on one of the most important issues facing our country, the American people… could not be more united, and that is the need to substantially lower the outrageous price of prescription drugs in this country."
Merck and Johnson & Johnson initially declined to testify at Thursday's hearing of the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee, prompting Sanders to announce a committee vote to subpoena the companies' CEOs. Both companies responded with letters accusing Sanders of targeting them for their lawsuits against the federal government over the price negotiation provisions in the Inflation Reduction Act.
Before the subpoena vote, the companies announced that they would agree to voluntarily testify. The witnesses included Joaquin Duato of Johnson & Johnson, Robert Davis of Merck, and Chris Boerner of Bristol Myers Squibb.
In his introduction, Sanders cited a recent poll published by the Kaiser Family Foundation showing that 82 percent of American adults say the cost of prescription drugs is unreasonable, while 73 percent believe that there is not enough government regulation limiting that cost.
According to a report published by the committee's majority staff before the hearing, several key treatments offered by Johnson & Johnson, Merck and BMS require U.S. patients to pay much more for drugs on an annual basis than those in other countries pay for the same drugs.
"Are the prices that you receive from countries like Canada or France — which look to me to be about one quarter of the price you get from the United States — … covering your costs?" Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Connecticut) asked.
Duato said that Johnson & Johnson is making a profit on selling treatments in those countries, and that the real difference between U.S. patients and those in other countries is that American patients get access to pharmaceutical therapies years before international patients.
He added that price caps on drugs are "not the way innovation is going to be fostered," echoing the stated reasoning in Janssen Pharmaceuticals' lawsuit against the Department of Health and Human Services and Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services.
The lawsuit filed by Janssen, a Johnson & Johnson company, argues that "the U.S. innovation ecosystem to which Janssen contributes has two vital components" that are threatened by the Inflation Reduction Act's drug price negotiation program.
Janssen's lawyers said these components are the agreement between the federal government and drugmakers when the FDA approves new treatments, and "the operation of free-market forces to establish prices for medicines during and after their patent terms."
But senators questioned the companies' commitment to innovation, citing the findings of a recent study revealing that manufacturers of drugs chosen for Medicare negotiation spent more overall on stock buybacks and dividends than on research and development in 2022.
Sens. Rand Paul (R-Kentucky) and Mitt Romney (R-Utah) reinforced the points made in the suit, suggesting that senators asking the CEOs what their companies are doing to lower the gap between costs and profits are out of step with the free-enterprise system.
"The last time I checked, when a buyer and seller negotiate for a price, that's capitalism," retorted Sen. Maggie Hassan, D-New Hampshire. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on pharmaceutical pricing, Senate hearings about drug costs, and healthcare policy debates, all central to the Health topic. While Business/Economy relates to corporate practices, the primary context is healthcare affordability and regulation.

title: Rotary packages 30,000 meals to fight hunger
author: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com
content:
Rotary packages 30,000 meals to fight hunger

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 375
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Taking a swing in the fight to end world hunger, the Centreville Rotary sponsored a packaging of 30,000 dehydrated meals to feed people who are experiencing a hunger crisis. Sixty volunteers gathered Feb. 3 at the Centreville United Methodist Church to support the mission.Centreville Rotary President Matt Schiwy had participated previously with other Rotary clubs working with Rise Against Hunger and wanted the Centreville Rotary to sponsor an event.
A global organization, the mission of Rise Against Hunger is to end world hunger by the year 2030, and the organization believes that achieving the goal is possible.
Started in 1998 under the name Stop Hunger Now, its headquarters are in Raleigh, North Carolina. From there, the international hunger relief non-profit organization coordinates the packaging and distribution of food and other aid to people in developing nations.
The food and processing materials are not free for the sponsoring organization. Schiwy said, "We had to pay $4,000 for everything to be delivered here, and hauled away to be shipped to whatever area of the world the food is going to."
The set up began before 9 a.m. on Saturday. However, the actual packing process, using an assembly line of volunteers to package the food, didn't begin until 11 a.m. The total time packaging the 30,000 meals took just about two hours.
The foods are simple essentials — rice, soy, dehydrated vegetables with seasoning, all measured out by hand, and placed in a small plastic bag which was sealed. The bag has directions on it for using boiling water for cooking the contents, which makes enough for six meals per bag.
Each assembly line person had a specific role. It worked very efficiently. After sealing each bag, the bag was placed inside a box, along with at least 40 other bags, and then the box was sealed to be placed in the cargo truck and shipped to a large warehouse.
All Rotary International Clubs are service oriented. Each performs different services and activities that bring communities together, using people of all-ages. The volunteers who helped Saturday, ranged in ages from 16 to 80. Students from Gunston School, Queen Anne's County High School and Chesapeake College participated. Gunston School Headmaster John Lewis, and Chesapeake College President Cliff Coppersmith, were both among the volunteers. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community-driven effort to combat hunger through meal packaging, aligning with 'Health' as hunger relief is a public health issue. While 'Local Life' is relevant due to the community event, the primary purpose of addressing nutritional well-being makes 'Health' the stronger match.

content:
Senators grill pharmaceutical CEOS over the high cost of drugs in the U.S.

 February 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)
