title: A child's heart at the Talbot County Free Library
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
A child's heart at the Talbot County Free Library

 July 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Life 
 
 1005
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As soon as I learned there was a new biography of Dr. Helen Taussig out, I raced to my computer, pulled up the library's website (tcfl.org), clicked on the "Find" tab at the top right of the screen, scrolled down through the drop-down menu to "Suggest a Title," and in less than a minute had asked that a copy of the book be added to our community's collection.It's easy to explain my excitement.
When I was in college and dreaming of becoming a physician, I spent two summers working in a pediatric catheterization lab. My primary responsibility in Louisville's old children's hospital was to create a database (we did this by hand in those days) of all the cases we had treated of the most common form of congenital heart defect: tetralogy of Fallot. Up until 1944, when Dr. Taussig proposed a novel surgical solution for the condition, babies born with tetralogy of Fallot were doomed to short, often miserable lives.
Tetralogy of Fallot is the result of a dreadful misstep in fetal development that, as the name would suggest, results in four anomalies in the child's heart and its major vessels.
These are:
Pulmonary artery stenosis: narrowing of the vessel meant to carry unoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs.Interventricular septal defect: a hole in the wall separating the two lower chambers of the heart, the ventricles.Misplaced aorta: the aorta seems to arise not from the left ventricle as in a normal heart, but from both ventricles.Right ventricular hypertrophy: a muscular build-up of the lower right side of the heart due to the increased pressure under which it must labor.
Children with tetralogy of Fallot may appear normal at birth (their bodies having been supplied with oxygen-rich red blood through their mother's placenta), but soon afterward their lips and nail beds grow blue (in doctor-speak, "cyanotic"). This is a sure sign that their hearts are struggling to deliver a proper amount of oxygenated blood to their bodies.
As they grow and the demands on their hearts increase, the condition worsens and, untreated, the children eventually die.
Helen Taussig was a bright young woman who, in 1927, despite suffering from dyslexia, managed to graduate second in her class from the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine.
The profession that Taussig was entering was famously unfriendly to women. A few years earlier Harvard Medical School had hired its first female professor, but only after making the poor woman sign a contract forbidding her to eat in the faculty club or walk in any academic procession. One of the country's leading academic physicians was known to tell his students that there were three types of human being: men, women and women doctors.
As male doctors were uninterested in caring for "blue babies" destined to die anyway, one of the few opportunities offered Taussig was the underpaid directorship of a small, poorly funded pediatric cardiology clinic at Hopkins. She accepted the position.
Adding to the difficulties Taussig faced when she set out to study the blue babies no one else seemed to care about was that a recent bout of whooping cough had left her functionally deaf.
It has been my privilege to place a stethoscope on any number of newborn chests and listen to the determined little beats of a heart no bigger than a walnut. To distinguish by ear between the sounds made in such a tiny heart by, say, an interatrial septal defect and an interventricular one requires intense concentration, patience, and lots and lots of practice. I never accomplished it.
Taussig taught herself to do it by touch. Placing her hand on a child's naked chest, she could make an accurate diagnosis based entirely on the minute vibrations she detected with her palm. Indeed, her diagnoses were famously more accurate than those arrived at by ear. Her clinical skills gave a whole new dimension to the phrase "the laying on of hands."
Perhaps most important for the cyanotic children in her care, Taussig quickly discerned that those whose parents treated them with tender pity (everyone knew these children would be lucky to see their tenth year) sure enough soon died, while those whose parents insisted upon giving them hope tended to live longer.
Taussig began to require a similar hopeful attitude from herself and her staff in the belief that even a year or two of additional life meant a child might survive until a medical remedy for his or her condition had been discovered.
And then she came up with the remedy.
In a child with tetralogy of Fallot, Taussig reasoned, if you took a portion of the left subclavian artery (which issues from the aorta) and surgically attached it to the pulmonary artery above the stenotic obstruction, then at least some of the poorly oxygenated blood being sent out to the body by the left ventricle should be recirculated to the lungs for an additional dose of oxygen.
Eventually she talked a surgeon, Alfred Blalock, into attempting the operation after his brilliant assistant, Vivien Thomas (of "Something the Lord Made" fame), proved the surgery could be performed successfully on dogs. Overnight, children who were expected to die received a new lease on life, and parents from all over the country began bringing their blue babies to Hopkins for the miracle cure.
The problem with reading a biography of someone you admire is that, as you approach the end of the book, you know you are also approaching the end of your hero's life. And Taussig was not just admirable, she was a tough but loving doctor who was still working hard at 87 to save lives when her own was taken in a tragic traffic accident.
You can find "A Heart Afire" — Patricia Meisol's testament to the good doctor's remarkable career — among the biography volumes under TAUSSIG in the New Books section of the Talbot County Free Library's Easton branch. And even today, anyone whose child is born with tetralogy of Fallot should get down on their knees and give thanks that a sweet yet fierce woman named Helen Taussig refused to give up on children like theirs. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Dr. Helen Taussig's medical contributions to treating congenital heart defects, detailing her research, clinical innovations, and impact on pediatric cardiology. While it mentions a library's collection, the core content centers on medical advancements and health-related themes.

title: Pregnancy has become risky in too many states
author: LENA GILL
content:
Pregnancy has become risky in too many states

 July 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Columns 
 
 703
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Access to health care for women has shrunk dramatically in red states as a result of the abortion bans that are causing OB/GYN doctors to leave these states. These are doctors specializing in women's pregnancy, child birth and follow-up care.Most Planned Parenthood clinics, providing similar care, have been forced to shut down. They were an important part of women's health care. The reasons doctors are leaving are that they are being threatened with losing their medical licenses and prison time, if treating a pregnant woman having a miscarriage or other emergency may mean the end of her pregnancy. 28 million women live in states with total or partial abortion bans.
In many red states with abortion bans, women with ectopic (outside the womb) pregnancies, natural miscarriages (which is experienced by a large majority of women who are trying to get pregnant), hemorrhaging or water breaking during pregnancy, conditions that all fall under women's emergency health care, cannot be treated under the bans until fetal heartbeats disappear or the woman is on the brink of death. Women have been refused care in emergency rooms and told to bleed out in the parking lot.
The state of Texas was one of the early states passing a ban against abortion after six weeks of pregnancy (when most women do not know that they are pregnant) along with such threats against the medical professionals. In the intervening two years, a new report reveals that infant mortality has risen dramatically in Texas.
A 2022 study by Johns Hopkins University, reported in JAMA Pediatrics found, after the ban had been in force for one year, an 8% jump in infant deaths in Texas before the first birthday due to congenital anomalies — the kind of conditions that are often identified in utero and lead to abortions in states where the procedure is legal, since they can be incompatible with life.
This compared to a decrease of about 3% in the rest of the United States. Texas women were forced to carry non-viable pregnancies to term. This sounds like some medieval torture forced upon women and their families.
The Texas ban makes no exceptions for the life of the mother, the viability of the fetus or the suffering of families across the state. When a state forces a woman with pregnancy complications to carry her pregnancy to term, she is 14 times more likely to die than if she had an abortion.
The study also noted that Texas had about 10,000 additional births between April and December 2022 due to the ban.
The maternal mortality rate for 2021 in the U.S. was 32.9 deaths per 100,000 live births compared with 20.1 deaths before the abortion bans in the U.S. in 2019. In high income countries, other than the U.S., the death rate is 13 per 100,000 live births.
Women die as a consequence of complications during and following pregnancy and childbirth. Why do three times more women die in the U.S.? Most of these complications are treatable during and following childbirth, if there are doctors and clinics willing to treat pregnant women as well as women who have just given birth. In abortion ban states these health care clinics are no longer available. In addition, many of these red states refused to expand Medicaid to improve the situation.
To remedy what has been happening in states with these abortion bans, we need a federal law guaranteeing the rights that the Supreme Court took away in Roe v. Wade and left to the states. Letting each state decide about women's health choices obviously is not working. Politicians are not doctors and should stay out of the examination rooms.
This mess culminated in the Supreme Court's Dobbs decision in which the court held that the U.S. Constitution does not confer a right to abortion. Donald Trump who installed three very conservative justices on the Supreme Court proudly takes responsibility for the Dobbs decision. He would assuredly veto any federal Roe bill that shifted control from the states to federal law, while a Democratic president would champion a federal Roe bill. Only electing a Democratic president in the fall can change the outcome for pregnant women.
Lena Gill is a resident of Easton and is a member of the Talbot County Democratic Forum. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the health impacts of abortion bans, including maternal mortality, access to healthcare, and medical emergencies. While it touches on political aspects, the core issue is women's health and healthcare access, making 'Health' the primary topic.

title: Greensboro Town Hall closed due to bat infestation
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Greensboro Town Hall closed due to bat infestation

 July 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 198
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — The Town Hall building in Greensboro is currently closed due to a bat infestation found over the weekend.The town initially discovered a swarm of bats on Friday morning. On Saturday, the town said in a Facebook post that a bat was found in the building during a normal pest control checkup.
"Since the attic isn't typically checked, this issue has unfortunately grown," the town wrote. Town Manager Tammy Kelledes said multiple bats were found both dead and alive in the building.
The town added that the closure is for health reasons since bat droppings pose risks.
"It can carry harmful fungi that, when inhaled, can cause histoplasmosis — a respiratory disease that can be severe, especially for those with weakened immune systems," the town wrote.
Kelledes told The Star Democrat that the building will be closed until at least next week, though the town is still "conducting as much business as usual."
Residents can go to Meeting Hall at 111 S Main Street for assistance, which is located across the parking lot from Town Hall.
They can also reach the town by calling 410-482-6222 or emailing greensboro@greensboromd.com.
This article has been updated to include that the bats were initially found Friday morning. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on health risks posed by bat infestation, specifically histoplasmosis from bat droppings. While related to local government operations and public safety, the primary emphasis is on health hazards requiring mitigation.

title: Cooling centers open throughout Caroline County
author: CAROLINE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT
content:
Cooling centers open throughout Caroline County

 July 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CAROLINE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT | Section: Local News 
 
 382
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As temperatures rise, so do the risks associated with high heat. Prolonged exposure to extreme heat can lead to severe health issues, such as heat exhaustion, heat stroke and dehydration.Certain populations are at a higher risk of heat-related illnesses:
Older adults: As people age, their ability to regulate body temperature diminishes. Chronic medical conditions and medications can further impair this ability, making seniors particularly susceptible to heat stress.Infants and young children: Children's bodies heat up faster than adults, and they are less likely to recognize and communicate their discomfort or need for hydration.People with chronic medical conditions: Conditions such as heart disease, diabetes and respiratory disorders can reduce the body's ability to handle heat.Athletes and outdoor workers: Those who engage in strenuous physical activities outdoors are at higher risk due to increased body heat and fluid loss through sweat.Low-income households and individuals: Limited access to air conditioning and other cooling resources can make it difficult for individuals to escape the heat.
The health department advises people to drink plenty of water throughout the day, even if they don't feel thirsty. They also say to avoid alcohol and caffeine, as these can lead to dehydration.
Wearing lightweight, loose-fitting and light-colored clothing can help people stay cool, as can staying indoors during the hottest parts of the day (10 a.m. to 4 p.m.).
The health department recommends spending time public places like libraries, malls or community centers if people don't have access to air conditioning at home. Fans can also help, especially when used with a damp cloth to create a cooling effect, the health department said.
Taking cool showers and baths can help lower body temperature quickly.
By understanding the dangers of high heat and taking these precautionary measures, people can better protect themselves and those who are most vulnerable during the summer months, the health department said.
Caroline County Cooling Centers
These centers will provide a safe environment and relief from the heat during their regular hours. Those seeking to use a cooling center are asked to call ahead to confirm hours and availability.
Denton Library — 100 Market Street, Denton — 410-479-1343.Federalsburg Library — 123 Morris Avenue, Federalsburg — 410-754-8397.Greensboro Library — 101 Cedar Lane, Greensboro — 410-482-2173.Caroline County Senior Center — 403 South 7th Street, Denton — 410-479-8065.Federalsburg Senior Center — 118 North Main Street, Federalsburg — 410-754-9754. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Food Lion Feeds donates to QAC Backpack Program
author: Staff Writer
content:
Food Lion Feeds donates to QAC Backpack Program

 July 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 230
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Queen Anne's County Backpack Childhood Hunger Program has received $1,900.00 from the Food Lion Feeds Charitable Foundation to help nourish neighbors experiencing hunger.The Feeding the Hungry grant supports community feeding partners by helping neighbors increase their access to nutritious food and providing nutrition education to eliminate health risks for those experiencing food insecurity.
"The Queen Anne's County Backpack Program and the families we serve are extremely grateful for this generous grant from the Food Lion Feeds Charitable Foundation," said Kathy Sells and Vincent Radosta, Backpack Program co-chairpersons.
The QAC Backpack Program relies on the generosity of caring individuals, churches, local organizations and the Queen Anne's County Department of Children and Families, all dedicated to addressing childhood hunger, according to a press release about the donation.
During the 2023/24 school year, the QAC Backpack Program provided over 2,200 weekend meals to 620 children. The Food Lion Feeds Charitable Foundation grant will help the QAC program provide weekend meals for about 410 children attending the QAC Public School summer sessions and provide over 1,600 bags of food and 1,200 snacks during the summer.
"We are also grateful for the 70+ volunteers who assist the Program year-round in providing the needed weekend food to children in the 13 QAC Schools," the program said in a press release.Donations can be sent to Advocates For Youth QAC Backpack Program, 110 Channel Marker Way Suite 101, Grasonville, Maryland 21638 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While related to community programs (Local Life) and schools (Education), the primary emphasis is on health impacts and nutritional support.

title: Medical intervention saves lives
author: Staff Writer
content:
Medical intervention saves lives

 July 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 275
 Words 

 Read News Document

 People pave the way to a certain place with good intentions. I am alive today, at age 74, because in 1950, doctors were unafraid to do something they fear to do today: provide life-saving care to a patient experiencing a miscarriage.My mother, Pearl, was pregnant. She was bleeding a little and waiting for her husband to come home before seeking help. Her best friend, Alice, came over. Alice was a retired nurse and immediately declared, "Pearl! You are going to the hospital now!"
The ER doctors immediately admitted my mother to the hospital, giving her confinement with hips elevated for two weeks. She was, therefore, able to carry me to term, her only child.
What they did then would not now be illegal, but in many states, ER doctors will no longer treat a miscarrying woman and her baby because of the anti-abortion laws. Babies who might be saved by medical intervention, and their mothers, are denied medical care because doctors are afraid of being accused, arrested and possibly imprisoned if the baby dies. If that happened under their care, they could be accused of assisting or performing an abortion.
The result of "well-intentioned" anti-abortion legislation is that miscarrying couples, (please remember that fathers and husbands are part of the ongoing tragedy) are refused care. Then the miscarriage happens outside a medical setting, with no help or sterile conditions and with all the blood, pain and loss. Babies that might be saved by intervention are lost. It could have been me.
The intervention of the medical profession saves lives. Get the good intentions out of the way. Let the doctors, the mothers and God do their work.
Dawn Miller
Millington 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on medical intervention's role in saving lives, specifically discussing healthcare access during miscarriages and the impact of anti-abortion laws on medical treatment. While it touches on legal and societal issues, the core theme is healthcare provision and its challenges.

title: Chestertown pediatrician closes practice amid allegations of abuse
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content:
Chestertown pediatrician closes practice amid allegations of abuse

 July 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: Crime 
 
 670
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — A Chestertown pediatrician has surrendered his license to practice in Maryland ahead of a civil case filed Tuesday morning in Kent County Circuit Court.Julio Ramirez, formerly head of his private practice at 6602 Church Hill Road in Chestertown, is being sued by a Kent County woman. The woman, who is not named in court filings, is seeking relief from the court for physical, psychological and emotional injuries she said she incurred while seeking treatment for her child in his office in 2023.
According to court documents, the woman was touched inappropriately and in a sexual manner while in the treatment room with Ramirez and her daughter. Following the encounter, which she said she tried to rebuff, the woman notified office staff and subsequently filed a report with the Chestertown Police Department.
In September 2023, the woman made a formal complaint to the Maryland State Board of Physicians.
Through the course of the board's investigation, four former employees "all testified to a pervasive environment of sexually abusive, unethical, and inappropriate behavior," according to the investigation report.
The investigation found Ramirez, on multiple occasions, sexually assaulted at least three female employees of his over the course of several years. The investigation further found that he sexually assaulted at least one other mother while in the course of treating her child.
Following the board's initial inquiry into the allegations in April, the board ordered a summary suspension of Ramirez's license, concluding "the public health, safety or welfare imperatively required emergency action in this case."
As a result of the board's investigation, Ramirez permanently surrendered his license to practice medicine, according to a letter Ramirez sent to the board.
As listed by the Maryland Board of Physicians, Ramirez, 65, graduated from Universidad de El Salvador Facultad de Medicina in 1988. He was first licensed in Maryland in 1998.
Ramirez opened his first office in Chestertown in 1999. According to information on his practice's website, he opened a second office in Centreville in 2004 to "better serve the Queen Anne's and neighboring communities." In February of 2015, he moved this office to the Shore Medical Pavilion in Queenstown. Hospital affiliations include the Anne Arundel Medical Center and Chester River Hospital Center.
The woman, named Jane Doe in the court filings, is represented by Schlachman, Belsky, Weiner & Davey of Baltimore. The complaint was filed by Michael J. Belsky and Catherine A. Dickinson.
In a statement released to the press, the law firm attorneys state Ramirez grabbed their client's breasts, vagina and buttocks in the course of examining her daughter. The attorneys state it is likely there are other victims.
"As alleged in the Complaint, Dr. Ramirez was a serial abuser of women. Our office is actively investigating these instances of abuse, especially against mothers who were assaulted while the doctor was treating their children. It goes without saying that this behavior is not acceptable, and we intend to hold the doctor accountable for his actions. We encourage anyone with information on these allegations to reach out to us," Belsky and Dickinson said in an interview with the Kent County News.
Ramirez's office is not taking phone calls. A message on his website states, "It is with a heavy heart that I announce my office has closed permanently. Due to unforeseen circumstances, and after careful deliberation, I have decided to retire and close my practice. I assure you that this decision was not made lightly, and I am deeply saddened that I will no longer be able to serve you and our community as a pediatrician."
He continues, "I would like to thank you for your time and the trust you have given me during our many years of operation in Chestertown. Taking care of your family was an honor and a privilege for me and my staff. My years here have been filled with countless rewarding experiences and the most remarkable patients. These shared moments will be remembered fondly, and will always be with me."
Contacted Tuesday morning, Kent County State's Attorney Brian DiGregroy was not able to immediately respond to inquires regarding any criminal charges. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a pediatrician's misconduct involving patient abuse, which directly relates to health care practices and professional ethics. While legal and safety implications are present, the core subject is the medical practitioner's actions within a health care setting.

title: Rotary club learns about melanoma from expert
author: PHIL REED Rotary Club of Cambridge
content:
Rotary club learns about melanoma from expert

 July 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PHIL REED Rotary Club of Cambridge | Section: News 
 
 214
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Steve Fine, founder and president of the Melanoma Education Foundation, spoke to members of the Rotary Club of Cambridge about his organization and how to detect melanoma and other forms of skin cancer.He said, "a primary activity of the Foundation is educating high school and middle school wellness teachers about melanoma and the resources available to them."
The organization provides free online lessons on things like self-detecting the signs of this disease while it is still curable.
Fine's interest in melanoma began following the death of his 26-year-old son, Dan, in 1998. Shortly after, he founded the nonprofit to educate people about the disease.
Since 2000, he has been devoted full time to the foundation. Prior to the pandemic, over 1,700 schools were using the lessons. As a member of the Rotary Club of Peabody, Massachusetts, in 2022, Fine expanded outreach to U.S. and Canadian Rotary Clubs in the Eastern and Atlantic time zones.
He uses the technology of virtual lessons to reach those who he would not otherwise be able to meet.
Fine received his doctorate in chemistry from Northeastern University, continuing his postdoctoral research at Lehigh University. After serving as assistant professor of organic chemistry at Lafayette College in Pennsylvania, he moved to New England, where worked as technical and manager in high tech chemical companies. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on melanoma awareness and education about skin cancer detection, which directly relates to health topics. While education is a component, the primary subject is health-related.

title: Kent County stresses importance of stroke detection methods
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent County stresses importance of stroke detection methods

 August 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — At their regular scheduled meeting, Kent County Commissioners proclaimed that very day, July 23, was to be designate Kent County Stroke Smart.Those presenting before the commission said it's possible to detect a stroke before it can be a lifelong problem.
Medical Director, Primary Stroke Center at University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton Rena Sukhdeo-Singh, Neuroscience Specialist/Stroke Coordinator Nicole Leonard and Regional Director, Emergency Services Tisha Thompson presented.
Their goal is to spread awareness, showing how to detect the early symptoms of a stroke and get patients medical attention in a timely manner.
"Everything about a stroke is time-sensitive," Sukhdeo-Singh exclaimed. "If a patient arrives three to four-and-a-half hours from the symptoms, their chances are better to reverse it."
Commission member John Price read off the proclamation, stating that one out of six people will suffer a stroke. It's a leading cause of longterm disability that affects 80% families.
Price further read that professionals like Sukhdeo-Singh's team, are reaching out to the public and private schools here to spread that awareness as well as to Emergency services and the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Chestertown.
Sukhdeo-Singh showed the commissioners some materials of their organization as well as how to spot stroke symptoms in an easy-to-remember acronym:
B-E-F-A-S-T
"B" stands for balance. Often the first sign of a stroke, followed by "E" for eyes, distorting of vision. Then "F" for facial abnormalities, like freezing or tics. Then there could be tingling or numbness in the arms or legs, which is "A". "S" stands for "speech," which if muddled, confused or slurred, it's then "T", Time to call 911.
The commissioners could relate, sharing experiences of their loved ones.
Price shared his father suffered a stroke at age 65, and although he lived to be 86, he said his recovery was never fully complete.
Commission member Albert Nickerson recalled an incident when his niece insisted somebody check on her grandmother when she didn't show up for her soccer game. Her insistence and instincts were good. When someone checked on her, they discovered her grandmother was in the beginning stages of a stroke.
County Attorney Tom Yeager shared also that his father suffered a stroke, but he was unsure of what it was at the time. He didn't seek help for it until a week later.
"That's why awareness is so important," Yeager said.
Sukhdeo-Singh called it, "Spot a Stroke, Stop a Stroke, and Save a Life".
And using advanced procedures such as improved imaging technology, they can spot where the source of the stroke happens, the clot in the brain, and prescribe clot-busting medication before it's too late.
Or surgery if needed.
"We work closely to reverse strokes or do surgical procedures to remove the clot from the brain," Sukhdeo-Singh said.
Leonard thanked the commissioners for making July 27, Kent County Stroke Smart.
"This will help with the partnership with the County to get education and support our partnerships." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on stroke detection methods, awareness campaigns, and medical education about early stroke symptoms. While local government actions are mentioned, the core subject is health awareness and medical response. Public safety and education are secondary considerations.

title: Church gives $1 million to new regional medical center
author: Tom McCall
content:
Church gives $1 million to new regional medical center

 August 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 415
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — St. Mark's United Methodist Church in Easton has committed $1 million to the construction of the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's new regional medical center.Frank Gunsallus III, the finance chair at St. Mark's, said the whole congregation approved the gift and was happy to give it to support the health of the community.
"St. Marks has been blessed financially with gifts by our congregation via normal funding or in the form of bequests, when people pass on. Part of our mission is to support people of the Talbot County. We do a lot of work in the local community," Gunsallus said.
He met with the hospital foundation and then presented the idea to the governing body of the church.
"We unanimously agreed to give the hospital a million dollars. On behalf of all of St. Marks, I can say we are exceptionally pleased that we can support this much needed medical center that will serve our community for decades to come," Gunsallus said.
The mission of St. Mark's United Methodist Church ties closely with service and caring for humanity's most basic needs, including health care.
"Our vision is to inspire people of all ages through love and service," said the Rev. Meredith West, the pastor of the church, in a press release. "This gift aligns perfectly with loving and serving our community."
Construction of the new medical center, located at 10000 Longwoods Road in Easton, will begin later this month, according to the release from Shore Regional.
"We are incredibly excited and grateful for what this new hospital means for residents of the region," said Ken Kozel, president and CEO of Shore Regional. "We are deeply grateful to the St. Mark's community of parishioners for this transformative gift."
The regional medical center will cost about $539.5 million to construct. $333 million has been funded by debt financing. Wes Moore proposed allocating $20 million a year for three years and adding $30 million allocation for fiscal year 2028.
The remaining cash flow is $39 million from operations, $50 million is philanthropic gifts and approximately $18 million in investment earnings on bond proceeds.
"Locally, we are committed to raising $50 million through fundraising efforts," said Trena Williamson, Shore Regional's regional director of marketing and communications. "We are currently in the silent phase of our capital campaign and are grateful to have already received a number of lead gifts from community supporters. We will be sharing more about these key partnerships in the near future."
For information about making a gift, contact 667-343-5509 or rebecca.bair@umm.edu. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Hospital is just a building
author: Staff Writer
content:
Hospital is just a building

 August 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 200
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As a senior citizen I have watched the build/don't build a new hospital with a personal interest. Access to good medical care is a top priority when choosing where to live.Unfortunately many of us are forced to travel across the bridge to either obtain good care or obtain an appointment in this century.
As a local I fondly remember the Memorial Hospital which served many of us from cradle to grave. We had the advantage of being able follow up with the practitioner who had seen us during a hospital stay. The current practice of using hospitalists sends us scrambling for post hospital care (an interesting concept which is contrary to the Joint Commission's mandate of continuity of care to ensure good patient outcomes.)
It appears we are in a health care crisis — not just doctors but nurses, techs, support staff. Do we, here on the Shore, offer competitive salaries? Does our community offer desirable amenities (affordable housing, good schools) to entice potential medical staff to our area?
I don't have those answers, but I do know this, a new hospital is just a building, unless like a Lego set it comes peopled with the staff needed to run it.
SHARON HARRINGTON
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on healthcare access, hospital infrastructure, medical staff retention, and patient care continuity, all central to the Health topic. While it mentions local community aspects, the core discussion revolves around healthcare system challenges.

title: Speakers urge women to find time for themselves
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Speakers urge women to find time for themselves

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 520
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Thursday morning, dozens of women gathered at the Avalon Theater to discuss health, work, faith and menopause at the second annual Women to Watch Summer Speaker Series.This year's series encompassed ideas of passion and purpose. Panelists, made up of women from across the Eastern Shore, spoke on their successes, failures and their hopes for the future. Throughout the morning, attendees had the chance to ask questions, network and create connections with one another.
The panel was moderated by Lesa Lee-Mulcahy, chief clinical officer at For All Seasons, and the speakers included Stefanie DeFiglia, owner of Two Tree Integrative Health; Keasha Haythe, president and CEO of Foundation of Hope; Candace Henry, director of the disability resource center adjunct faculty at the College of Health and Human Services Salisbury University; and Kelly Simonsen, marketing and communications manager at Easton Utilities.
"You may be doing something that you may not like right now, but get around some people and mentors and not be afraid to try new things, so that you may find your passion," Haythe said. "... we all get stuck, but I think taking that time to get away is very, very important so that you can get unstuck."
Throughout the morning, speakers offered encouragement and insight to the attendees and to each other. DeFiglia provided advice for attendees to take time for themselves. In the midst of their busy schedules of being professionals, mothers and wives, DeFiglia said it is basically required for women to take some time in silence to better understand themselves.
"When I separate myself. … It's really easy to get still and to hear what your body is telling you, what your life is telling you," DeFiglia said. "It's not so easy to do that when your kids are screaming. I think we create these situations for ourselves when we're holding the world on our shoulders, and then we're expecting to hear what the universe is telling us. And I think that we have to create that space and that quiet and that silence for ourselves to be able to do that."
Kristi English, director of marketing and events at APG Media of Chesapeake, led the event and provided opportunities for attendees to ask questions and network with other speakers on the panel.
Attendees met in small groups to to have group discussions with each speaker. During conversations, topics of health, relationships, faith and advocating for each other were brought up with each person leaning forward to listen to each other better and soak in the advice being given.
Attendee Eileen Gillette said she loved the event because it gathered like-minded people who provided tools and resources for encouraging each other and growing.
"I loved that it was about women empowering all people and to follow your dreams, enact boundaries and to have faith and trust in yourself," Gillette said, "and not to wait for things to fall into your lap but to go after what you want and need."
As the event came to a close, all the attendees and speakers posed for a photo then began exchanging contact information in hopes to continue the connections outside of the event. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on women's health, self-care, and personal development through a speaker series discussing topics like menopause, work-life balance, and mental well-being. While elements of education and community engagement are present, the central theme revolves around health and empowerment.

title: Shore Regional Health welcomes new executive leader
author: Staff Writer
content:
Shore Regional Health welcomes new executive leader

 August 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 332
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Aaron "Zack" Royston has joined University of Maryland Shore Regional Health as vice president of Rural Health Care Transformation and Executive Director of UM Shore Medical Center at Chestertown, a member organization of the University of Maryland Medical System.Royston transitions from UMMS and brings extensive health care administration and population health experience to this dual role, including finance, operations, process improvement, preventive health, and strategic planning and implementation.
Most recently, he served for nearly four years as director of Clinical Integration in the Population Health Services Organization with UMMS, where his responsibilities included overseeing systemwide population health services clinical integration, data and analytics, and federal regulatory program participation; leading the selection of the Population Health and Value-Based Care platform and leading the selection, contracting and implementation of the Epic Integrated Community Resource Directory that enables system team members to support the social drivers of health.
Prior to his tenure at UMMS, Royston spent 10 years with Affinity Health Alliance Inc., including two positions with Union Hospital; executive director/director of Revenue Cycle Operations and later as the hospital's senior vice president of Provider Services.
Royston's earned bachelor's and master's degrees in Emergency Health Services from University of Maryland Baltimore County, and also a master's degree in Population Health Management from Johns Hopkins University's Bloomberg School of Public Health. Early in his career, he taught in health sciences programs for area community colleges and UMBC.
Royston previously served as board chair for the West Cecil Health Center, as a board member of the Cecil County YMCA, as a Finance Committee member for the YMCA of the Chesapeake and as a member of the Cecil County Commission on Aging.
"Zack is an excellent addition to UM Shore Regional Health's senior leadership team," said Ken Kozel, Shore Regional Health president and CEO. "His diverse experience in finance, operations, population health, process improvement, preventive health and strategic planning will help us continue our progress in providing optimal health care services and programs in Kent County and throughout the Mid-Shore."

title: Democratic Women's Club hosts meeting on Reproductive Freedom Referendum
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Democratic Women's Club hosts meeting on Reproductive Freedom Referendum

 August 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 561
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Tuesday evening, dozens of people attended a dinner meant to inform community members on the Reproductive Freedom Referendum, a proposed amendment to Maryland's constitution ensuring the right to abortion access and birth control.The referendum will be on the ballot in the upcoming November election.
Erin Bradley, board chair of Freedom in Reproductive Maryland, led the event, which was hosted by the Talbot Democratic Women's Club at The Ivy in Easton.
According to Bradley, The Maryland General Assembly passed legislation in 2023 that created the ballot referendum to "allow Marylanders to make their voices heard" by codifying the right to abortion and access to birth control in the state Constitution.
"This is the highest protection we can give in the state of Maryland for reproductive freedom," Bradley said.
According to Lynne McGrath, a member of the Talbot Democratic Women's Club, a flyer shared by Health Not Harm MD, a statewide conservative political organization, has been opposing the Reproductive Freedom Referendum.
"I bet very few people know what that amendment is, what it's doing, what it won't do, and how we can help make sure that amendment gets passed," McGrath said.
Deborah Brocato, chair of Health Not Harm MD, said her organization is meant to oppose the Reproductive Freedom Referendum. According to Brocato, the two-page amendment is too vague and could, down the line, lead to future legislative changes when it comes to reproductive health.
"(This amendment) creates a brand new right to this ambiguous term of reproductive freedom," Brocato said in an interview with the Star Democrat.
Bradley stated, during the dinner, that the proposed amendment does not change what is already established in Maryland law, which defines reproductive freedom as the right to birth control, to access abortion and to continue a pregnancy.
"What I will say is (the amendment) doesn't change parents' freedom or liberty," Bradley said. "It changes nothing about the practice of health care, established regulations or laws about the provision of health care in this state or the United States."
Further on in the event, the topic of out-of-state visits for reproductive healthcare came up. Bradley said there has been a dramatic increase in out-of-state visits coming from Florida and West Virginia, states where stricter restrictions on abortion are in place.
According to Bradley, Planned Parenthoods in Maryland are able to address the influx of patients through tools like telehealth to help limit in-patient capacity.
"Right now, Maryland is in the top 10 of reproductive freedom states in this country," said Lauren Harton, an obstetrics and gynecology nurse practitioner. "... So to maintain our awesomeness, we have to make it a part of the Constitution, because if it's a part of the Constitution, then nobody can change it unless it goes back to all the people to vote again."
Throughout the evening, attendees discussed how to combat misinformation, how to maintain Maryland as a safe state for abortions and the importance of encouraging friends to go out and vote.
Toward the end of the event, Bradley went on to encourage attendees to vote for candidates that will protect the rights outlined in the referendum.
"So while I implore you all to come out and vote yes on question one, I also implore you all to vote for your senator, to vote for your congressman, and if this is your issue and this is your thing, make sure that the people you are electing align with that," Bradley said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a referendum related to reproductive health rights, including abortion access and birth control, which directly ties to healthcare policy. While there are political and community aspects, the core subject is health-related legislation and public health advocacy.

title: Republicans shoot themselves in foot over IVF
author: LENA GILL
content:
Republicans shoot themselves in foot over IVF

 August 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Columns 
 
 720
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In 2022, a miracle happened to 91,771 families in the U.S. They succeeded in having an in vitro fertilization baby. These babies constituted 2.5% of all babies born in the U.S. that year.IVF or in vitro fertilization means the joining of a woman's egg and a man's sperm in a laboratory dish. The fertilized egg or embryo is then implanted in a woman's uterus. If it sticks, this results in a pregnancy. For patients under 30 years of age the success rate is about 50%. For patients older than 42 years of age the success rate is only 7%. There is a 30% chance of a twin pregnancy with IVF.
The reasons for using IVF varies. Infertility is the most common reason. For some couples it allows them to delay when to have children — the freedom to decide over their own bodies and families. Some wait until they are on a firm financial footing and can afford IVF, others wait until they have achieved some career goal. It also allows singles to create a family by using donated eggs or sperm. A gay man must use a surrogate woman to produce the live birth. All these family issues are probably as common with Republicans as Democrats.
IVF is costly. 11 states partially contribute to the cost, if infertility is the reason for attempting IVF. Infertility is considered a disability in these states. Medicaid may meet some of the cost. A few large insurance companies may cover some of the cost of IVF treatment, if the employers have signed up for it.
In Maryland, the cost for one cycle is between $11,000 and $17,000 after the benefit has been applied. Since the beginning of 2021 there is no marriage requirement to obtain the partial benefit, but there is a limit of three IVF cycles attempting to produce a live birth with a cap of $100,000. Most couples go through two to three cycles before a pregnancy occurs.
In June of this year, U.S. Senate Democrats introduced The Right to IVF Act that would protect IVF access and lower cost nationwide. Nearly every Republican senator voted against it. Sen. Josh Hawley said that this act was really part of an abortion agenda. I consider this statement preposterous, as IVF creates new life.
Sen. J.D. Vance, the Republican party's candidate for vice president, also voted against this act, despite selling himself as the protector of families.
The same month, the Southern Baptist Convention with 13 million members adopted a resolution denouncing IVF. Again, it is difficult to understand why a pro-life religious movement is against creating new life. The answer is that the political right has proclaimed that personhood now starts with the embryo even before it is implanted in a woman's uterus.
This February, we saw where this belief can lead. Alabama's state supreme court declared that all frozen embryos are children and, therefore, protected under The Wrongful Death of a Minor Act. As many embryos are created at the same time in a laboratory dish, excess ones are frozen and kept to be implanted at a later date or perhaps never used if the desired pregnancies are successful. If so, they are usually intentionally destroyed. The lab technicians or doctors working in the lab could now be accused of murder.
It resulted in the shutdown of all IVF clinics in Alabama.
While Republicans are doing all they can to stop IVF in its tracks, there are other fertility treatments available to those who want to create a family. We do not know if the Republicans consider all fertility treatments a threat to their control over women's bodies. Tim Walz, the Democratic Party's candidate for vice president, expresses his and his wife Gwen's extraordinary happiness with their first child's birth in 2001 after seven years of fertility treatments. They named her Hope, which is what they had lots of all through those years.
Five years later they had a son, called Gus, also conceived through fertility treatments. Michelle Obama mentioned in her Tuesday speech at the Democratic Convention that one of her children was an IVF birth.
The mounting public backlash against Republicans for the threat to IVF has now prompted both Trump and JD Vance to scurry to appear sympathetic to IVF. It won't wash.
Lena Gill is a resident of Easton and a member of the Talbot County Democratic Forum. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on in vitro fertilization (IVF) as a medical procedure, discussing its accessibility, costs, legal challenges, and political debates. While it touches on political actions, the core subject is healthcare policy and reproductive rights, making 'Health' the most accurate category. 'Public Safety' is a weaker fit due to the legal implications mentioned, and 'National News' is less specific than 'Health'.

title: Local health care 'excellent'
author: Staff Writer
content:
Local health care 'excellent'

 August 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 356
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We've all heard negative comments about our local health care facilities. I'm writing to relay my recent firsthand experience with our local health care system.On Aug. 17, I experienced symptoms of a stroke and called 911. The ambulance arrived within minutes, and the EMT assessed my symptoms as a suspected stroke. They asked me if I had a preference of where they took me, and I asked their recommendation. Based on the severity of my symptoms they suggested University of Maryland Medical System Chester River Hospital. The EMT remained vigilant through the entire trip.
Dr. Lukas met us in the vestibule at Chester River Hospital to evaluate my condition and determine whether I should stay or go to another facility for more intense care. It was recommended I remain at Chester River for continued evaluation. Nurse Agnes provided constant monitoring. Dr. Lukas checked back every few minutes to make sure I was stable. The staff welcomed my husband and daughters who remained at my bedside.
Dr. Lukas said I would be transferred to a more acute-care facility and asked for my preference. They found me a bed in Easton hospital.
Best Care Ambulance transported me to Easton promptly the next morning. The EMT who rode with me had extensive military and over 25 years professional EMT experience. Our driver was a retired Black Hawk helicopter pilot. I knew I was in great hands.
The nurses, doctors and staff at Easton Hospital were exceptional, highly skilled professionals with a pleasant, caring attitude.
I was not a likely candidate for a stroke. I exercise regularly, eat right and have no pre-existing health conditions. Easton hospitalist Dr. Devkota and neurologist Valentin knew this and ordered extensive tests to find the cause of my stroke. They found I have a rare genetic blood disorder that causes blood clots, hence the stroke.
To all the naysayers and critics I say, acute care doesn't get better than the experience I just had. I often get asked by real estate buyers, "How is your local health care"? Now I have firsthand experience to tell them; it's excellent.
Thanks to all who helped with my care and recovery.
CINDY GENTHER
Rock Hall 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a personal experience with local healthcare services, detailing emergency response, hospital care, and medical professionals. title: Ironclad Crossfit: Getting 'every body' moving
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Ironclad Crossfit: Getting 'every body' moving

 September 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 538
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — For Danielle Dressel, owner of Ironclad Crossfit, Crossfit is not just a workout. It is a community of supportive and wonderful people who measure success, not by weight, but by emotional progress made in and outside the gym.Dressel said she opened Ironclad Crossfit to fill a void in Easton that prioritized encouragement and body positivity in the Crossfit community because, in her eyes, "CrossFit is functional fitness."
"Life's most basic functions, squatting, properly, pressing properly, picking things up properly," Dressel said "…essentially, that's what we teach you here, how to lift things properly, how to brace, how to get up when you get down, and then how to do it efficiently, faster, better, stronger, but always with good form."
On Aug. 24, Dressel teamed up with John-Edward Health to turn Ironclad Crossfit adaptive to better assist the disabled community.
Dressel hosted an adaptive fitness event to encourage "every body," no matter the size or ability, to exercise and get stronger.
Health, a Paralympic and adaptive athlete, veteran and founder of The Adaptive Athletics Foundation of Maryland, said the event was to encourage members of the disabled community in the Eastern Shore to get out and exercise at a gym that has taken into account their needs.
"We're educating abled-body people on what it is to be a disabled athlete, but then we're also educating the disabled community that there are ways for them to do this in a community-based environment with knowledgeable people," Health said.
Dressel said she tries her hardest to meet people where they are in their fitness journey, which is why she is hosting a free weeklong trial program from Sept. 9 to 15. Dressel said she is working hard to help as many people as she can.
"Everybody has to fight their own fight," Dressel said. "Everybody has you're trying to do better than you did last time and everyday is different. … It's really just helping people self regulate themselves to make good choices. Because we are in this for the long haul."
Angel Nagel, the gym's general manager and a former customer of Ironclad Crossfit, said Dressel has been one of the best mentors she has ever had. For Nagel, Crossfit was not just a workout but was a way for her to establish community and grow mentally.
"You think a gym is just for fitness, but it's helped me mentally, physically, with my nutrition and eating," Nagel said. "Your overall outlook on life just kind of changes within the four walls of Ironclad between the community, the friendship, the coaches. It's just a good place to be."
The term "progress" for Dressel has changed over the years to fit into the success she sees with all her customers. Weight loss is not in the center of the success she has seen. Rather, it has been more emotional growth especially when it comes to her customers' relationships with anxiety.
The more people she can help through community workouts the better.
"Everybody talks about the emotional impact, the emotional growth of the community," Dressel said. "People come for fitness, but they stay for the community. Everybody comes in... But then they don't stay just because of the workouts. They stay because of the people and what we do here as a group." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a fitness gym's community-driven approach to health, emphasizing physical and mental well-being, adaptive fitness for disabled individuals, and the emotional benefits of exercise. While 'Local Life' is a close second due to the community aspect, 'Health' directly addresses the core themes of fitness, inclusivity, and wellness.

title: Caroline Health Deptartment receives Purple proclamation
author: Tom McCall
content:
Caroline Health Deptartment receives Purple proclamation

 September 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 343
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON —On Tuesday, members of the Caroline County Health Department received a proclamation from the Caroline County Commissioners for the beginning of Caroline Goes Purple, which will last through the month of September.This month highlights drug prevention and promotes awareness of substance abuse disorder.
The proclamation recognized efforts to keep Caroline County drug-free. It also highlighted treatment options for those still struggling with substance abuse disorder.
Commissioner Frank Bartz read, "Whereas Caroline Goes Purple as a substance use awareness and prevention initiative is sponsored by a Drug Free Caroline ready to engage our community to stand up against substance use and whereas Caroline Goes Purple focuses on community engagement activities including sharing educational messages, purple clubs through middle and high school, outreach to civic groups, health and resource fairs and a community film screening."
He also spoke of the importance of the whole community getting involved to educate kids about the dangers of prescription drugs and end the stigma surrounding substance abuse disorder.
For Caroline Goes Purple, local government buildings and residences are lit up or decorated in purple.
"Every year I look forward to the purple lights going up in people's houses. And the courthouse will be purple this month too," Bartz said.
Cahall thanked the commissioners for the proclamation.
"This really takes another step at removing the stigma in terms of substance use and treatment," she said.
Then she pointed out some important Goes Purple dates coming up. Sept. 14 from 10:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. at James T. Wright Memorial Park in Preston is the Going Purple Together event.
On Sept. 21, there is a Caroline Goes Purple Color Run. Registration starts at 9 a.m., and the run starts at 10 a.m. It costs $25 and will also be held at James T. Wright Memorial Park.
The poignant Memory Walk will be at Martin Sutton Park on Sept. 27 from 6 to 8 p.m.
"It is where people who have lost individuals to substance abuse disorder can come and remember their loved ones and support one another," Cahall said.
For more information, go to the Caroline County Health Department's web page.

title: Recovery in Motion lights candles for victims of addiction
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Recovery in Motion lights candles for victims of addiction

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 709
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Saturday evening, over 50 people gathered at Fountain Park for Recovery in Motion's annual candle lighting event to recognize International Overdose Awareness Day, Aug. 31.This now annual event ushers in Recovery Month, a month where Kent Goes Purple raises awareness through purple banners and signs spread around the county.
Speakers that night encouraged attendees who suffer from addiction to find their higher power.
Steve Hafferman told the audience he struggled with drugs and alcohol most of his life. Even after he overdosed, he didn't change his ways. He was homeless until he found that higher power. He said he attended a church once where most of those gathered were former addicts.
"For the first time, I realized I wasn't alone," Hafferman said.
That support helped him, going through the steps to recovery, experiencing something dramatically different from his family background.
His new faith was life-altering, but then he got into a motorcycle accident by no fault of his own.
While riding in Easton on March 26 last year, a vehicle ran a light, affording him no time to stop. It was a devastating collision, his bike in shambles, his body mangled. Nineteen hours of surgery resulted in his leg being taken.
After the accident, he was angry at God for allowing this to happen.
"I lost my gratitude," Hafferman said, remembering being in pain every day.
Feeling powerless, like he couldn't even play with his kids, after five years of sobriety, he wanted to end his life. Drugs seemed to be the most effective method, he thought. He took enough cocaine to stop his heart, yet, miraculously it didn't.
He realized then God was not done with him.
Hafferman said, "Failure's not when you fall, it's when you stay down."
The next speaker, Recovery in Motion peer support Bobbie Sutton, didn't stay down either.
Her loving, musically talented older brother William Sutton IV died of a heroin overdose. Narcan, an effective medication used to treat overdoses, was not ready available as it is now, Sutton shared.
"He was always a such a good brother and great friend. He never treated me like a bratty sister," she reflected.
In 2009, his disappearance had sparked a year-long investigation to the dumping of his body, which furthered her pain, hurt and confusion.
The great loss and nature of the case threw Sutton into addiction as well, and after 11 years in that cycle, she wound up in prison for four years in Buncombe County, North Carolina.
With support from her mother, Phyllis Harrington, a nurse at the A.F. Whitsitt Center, and others, Sutton found her higher power in Christ and went through the steps. Subsequently, she followed in her mother's footsteps as well, helping people as a peer recovery specialist.
She said she's in awe of the change.
"I thought I would never be someone to carry titles and make a decent living. It's amazing that women come in and want to speak to me now for help," Sutton said.
"I've been able to come back home," she said, grateful of the people in her life, now three years clean.
While others lit candles, Sutton joined her mother beside a photograph of her brother, holding the flame close, remembering his personality, his talent and his band, The Big Hurt Band.
Director of Community Addiction Services Jennifer McCready and Peer Supervisor Brett Forrest thanked all those in attendance. McCready mentioned for anybody who needs help for opioids or stimulants, the center has crisis beds available.
She gestured to the table, where cards contain the phone number of dedicated peers committed 24/7 to answering questions.
And during this month, besides the purple shirts and signs, McCready noted, if you see laundry baskets placed in various sections throughout town, it's a part of the program "2 Sheets for Recovery," collecting twin-sized bedding for people going into recovery housing.
These are all events that correspond with the theme, Kent Goes Purple, an initiative of the Kent County Sheriff's Office and the Chestertown Rotary Club.
Sheriff Dennis Hickman was also in attendance, inviting the public to join them for their 5K Color Fun Run/Walk Sunday, Sept. 8.
He provided a message as well during this month of reflecting and commemorating those lost to addiction as well as enforcing prevention methods. "Law enforcement are partners in this journey to combat addiction. We're here to help in any way we can," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While law enforcement and local government entities are mentioned, the core theme revolves around health challenges, recovery support, and public health awareness campaigns.

title: Talbot Goes Purple strives for prevention
author: Tom McCall
content:
Talbot Goes Purple strives for prevention

 September 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 624
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — September is Talbot Goes Purple month. You can see the front porches lit in purple to highlight concern about substance abuse disorder glowing through the night. This drug prevention program's main focus is prescription drugs laced with fentanyl.Knock-off prescription drugs like Adderall or Xanax that are purchased on the internet or other places can be laced with fentanyl, which makes them lethal.
"What people need to really understand is the Talbot Goes Purple is a prevention initiative. So we focus on kids 11 to 17. The goal is to delay or prevent onset of use," said Kelley Callaghan of Talbot Goes Purple. "Kids need to know that they are putting fentanyl in these pills. The DEA has a campaign 'one pill can kill.' Seven out of 10 pills that they seize have fentanyl in them," she said.
Kids can order these pills online, but they are not the same as what a doctor prescribes.
"If it is not coming from your doctor, there is a good chance that it is fake," she said.
Organizers of the effort hold events in September to increase awareness of the cause.
"We had our event this past weekend for Overdose Awareness Day and also for our kickoff on Saturday, fourth annual Festival of Hope. This is our eighth year. It was at Anchor Church. The food vendors sold out. So we provided 300 meals and 500 snow cones," Callaghan said.
There was a dunking booth with the sheriff and free face painting. There was a bounce house.
"We have all the fun stuff, but at 7:30 we have a memorial piece. Aug. 31 is International Overdose Awareness Day, so places across the globe come together to remember those we have lost. We put out luminaria bags and pictures," Callaghan said.
Linda Webb, director of Talbot County Department of Social Services, said, "Talbot County DSS is a supporter of the 'Talbot Goes Purple' substance use awareness and prevention initiative. Talbot Goes Purple promotes the safety and well-being in our community, and we're proud to partner in their mission."
Naloxone, or Narcan, is a nasal mist that counteracts opioids. Businesses, churches and civic organizations can have the medicine mounted to their wall. Around 60% of overdoses occur in the home, so Callaghan recommends getting the lighter sized antidote on your key chain.
"Many of our staff have been trained on the administration of Naloxone, an opioid overdose response medication. We are a Talbot Goes Purple Operation Save a Life partner and have overdose response kits installed in both our DSS office and the Children's Advocacy Center," Webb said.
Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble was focused on this epidemic early.
"2016 was when he started talking to me about Talbot Goes Purple. He was an early adopter of all things having to do with Narcan. He was getting it out to his deputies and going and giving talks about it," Callaghan said.
Law enforcement is trying to increase the face-to-face contact with people who want help.
"The good Samaritan law is really important. If someone overdoses, and this includes alcohol and minors, call 911 and don't leave. The law protects people from six misdemeanors including possession of alcohol or drugs," Callaghan said.
People up and down Talbot County are going purple.
Executive Director of the Oxford Community Center Liza Ledford lights up their boat.
"As a tradition we turn the lights on purple on that Yankee Peddler boat that we have out front. That is how we acknowledge our partnership and show the world that we care about the epidemic that is a crisis. We have a great return your unused medicine program at the police station down here," Ledford said.
Callaghan said that Talbot County is a leader for other states and counties that are starting their own Purple programs.
For more more information email talbotgoespurple@gmail.com 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community health initiative addressing substance abuse prevention, fentanyl awareness, and overdose response. While public safety aspects (e.g., law enforcement, overdose laws) are mentioned, the core mission aligns with health advocacy, education, and public health awareness.

title: QAC Goes Purple kicks off Sept. against substance abuse
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC Goes Purple kicks off Sept. against substance abuse

 September 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 468
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Encouraging the community to stand up against substance abuse in September, the annual "QAC Goes Purple" campaign kicked-off events during the Queen Anne's Soccer Club opening weekend Friday, September 6 at Church Hill Park and Saturday Sept. 7 at Route 18 Park.Both days brought in the community for Celebrating QA Soccer Club opening weekend, official QAC Goes Purple events kicked-off Sept. 6 at Church Hill Park and Sept. 7 at Route 18 Park inviting the community to stand up to substance abuse with giveaways, county resources and soccer fun.
Marking the beginning of a month-long opioid awareness initiative aimed at educating and mobilizing the community against substance abuse, Queen Anne's County Drug-Free Coalition partnered with the QA Soccer Club for the first year.
Around a thousand kids from multiple youth soccer groups participated in the kick-off, according to Queen Anne's County Drug Free Coalition Chair Warren Wright.
As youth soccer groups registered for the season, participants received t-shirts and hot dogs from the Coalition and families partook in informational activities highlighting drug free living.
A shining light in the county coalition's efforts against substance abuse has been the Drug Free Student Ambassadors, Wright said.
A small but mighty group, the youth ambassadors work hard coming up with creative ideas for events and posters spreading awareness about living a drug free life to be rotated around the county, he said.
While the Coalition focuses on parents, the ambassadors take on leadership roles as they connect with peers and give younger students role models.
"Kids do so well talking to kids," he said.
Participating organizations welcoming a drug free September also included the Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office, the Queen Anne's County Department of Health, Veteran and Military Support Alliance and Mid-Shore Behavioral Health.
As part of its Celebrate Recovery program, Kent Island Methodist Church presented a mobile trailer demonstrating a mock teen's bedroom, showcasing the creative means in which teens are able to hide drugs and paraphernalia.
Presenting its mobile trailer designed as a mock teen bedroom, the Celebrate Recovery program of the Kent Island Methodist Church highlighted red flags to be aware of and the deceptive avenues kids can try to hide drugs and paraphernalia right under parents' noses, including hallowed out seemingly everyday items.
Member Cathy Timms encouraged parents not to be afraid of violating their children's privacy by going into their room if there is suspected substance abuse, "It could save their life," she said.
"Knowledge and awareness is everything when it comes to addiction," Timms said.
"QAC Goes Purple" signifies a collaborative effort that transcends organizational boundaries and unites the community against substance abuse. By participating in this initiative, individuals can make a meaningful impact and contribute to a safer, more informed community
Business marques are encouraged to announce the drug free month as everyone puts in purple light bulbs and proclaims QAC drug-free this September. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community campaign against substance abuse, highlighting health awareness, educational initiatives, and partnerships with health organizations. While Public Safety and Education are tangentially related, the primary emphasis is on health-related prevention and awareness efforts.

title: Peer support specialists are on the front lines of the overdose crisis
author: Tom McCall
content:
Peer support specialists are on the front lines of the overdose crisis

 September 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 580
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Kristie Thompson, a peer support specialist, is on the front lines of the substance abuse disorder crisis in Caroline County. When someone calls for help, she is there with viable options.Thompson works for the Sante Group, a behavioral health service that focuses on crisis services and treatment. She is based out of the Caroline County Sheriff's Department and rotates through the county's municipalities, offering a certain number of hours a week in each when individuals struggling with drug addiction can come in seeking her services.
Thompson helps them navigate available recovery options.
"I get to reach people and show them the other side of recovery. It is possible to get through the storm. I can help them walk through it, if they are willing to do the work. People with addictions can be functioning again and can be put back in society. They can have something to offer the community," she said.
Thompson said the need for these services is growing in Caroline County.
"Last month I had five new people, and I had six follow-ups from the previous months," Thompson said.
There are lots of possible routes to recovery based on what the individual thinks they can do. There is outpatient, intensive outpatient and support groups. Mental health services can go hand-in-hand with recovery.
"I do an assessment of their experience level with substances. From there I figure out what the plan is for recovery. I want to rebuild them. Usually it is inpatient- that is what the safe station is for," Thompson said.
Caroline County Sheriff's Office Lt. Richard Baker said that there is a private room designated for this work.
"We would love to have more people to use it. They want to receive treatment. They want to receive help, and we are in partnership with the Sante Group. I use Narcan once or twice a month. We get a chance to save a life. If you feel you need help, come to this office. You are getting help and not getting arrested," said Baker.
There is still a stigma that needs to be broken around seeking help for addiction, the lieutenant said. There is a law called the good samaritan law, and it makes it safe to bring someone into a hospital or a police station who has overdosed. Under this law, neither the person experiencing the overdose nor the person who is bringing them in for help will be charged, Thompson said, but often people in the community do not know this.
"It saves lives. Before a lot of people were leaving their friends to die out of fear and stigma," she said. "Fentanyl is laced into a lot of drugs, and it is lethal."
There is another new drug stirring concern in the county, Tompson said.
Injectable intoxicant is xylazine, which veterinarians use to tranquilize horses, is often called "tranq" and causes open flesh sores.
"Their arms are decaying, and still they are injecting these drugs," Thompson said. "Right now they have been more opioid-related. Or stimulant and opioid. We have been encountering Xylazine mixed with fentanyl, and it has been dangerous."
"... The drugs are cheaper and more easily accessed than they were five years ago. The problem is getting worse and no one is talking about it," she said. "When people have money problems or are coping with the recession, the using behavior increases."
Thompson thinks there need to be more peers like herself to meet the needs of the county.
"Even if just one person is helped, that is good for me," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
