title: Caroline Goes Purple 5K draws a colorful crowd
author: Tom McCall
content:
Caroline Goes Purple 5K draws a colorful crowd

 September 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PRESTON — A kaleidoscope of chalk was thrown into the air at the start of a 5K event to support the Caroline Goes Purple Saturday. Around 40 people started at the James Wright Memorial Park and either ran or walked the course.Catherine Bowrey is the chair of the Caroline Goes Purple Color Run.
"I am glad to see everyone out here having a good time. We have to get aware of the drug epidemic, which is a big thing. The stigma is terrible. So this way they can come out and get aware of what is going on in their communities," Bowrey said.
Caroline Goes Purple is organized by the Denton nonprofit Drug Free Caroline, a substance abuse disorder prevention and awareness program. Caroline Goes Purple is a community effort during the month of September to prevent drug use, heighten awareness and reduce the stigma around substance abuse disorder.
Jessica Tuel is the director of behavioral health for the Caroline County Health Department as well as the local addiction authority for Caroline County. She stood in front of a public health table filled with information, stress balls and pens.
"We do a lot of services in the schools both for substance use and mental health. We have full time clinicians in the north county schools and we have the Mobile Treatment Unit," Tuel said.
Her work is data-led.
"The statistics say that the earlier people start using, the longer and higher risk their use is later. Today we are bringing awareness to substance abuse in our county. We have a lot of vendors that are going to give education and services for those who need them. It is important to all these peers here, who are in a state of recovery. That is what all of the Caroline Goes Purple events are for," she said.
As a public health expert she wants both education and anti stigma to get across.
"Stigma is multifaceted. So it is stigma of the community against those who use. It is stigma of those that don't want treatment because they fear they will be judged. It is 'We don't have this problem in Caroline County,'" Tuel said.
The remedy to stigma is education and bringing statistics to the community, she said.
Angel Perez, the former Caroline Goes Purple Chair, was at this year's event as a volunteer.
"This event is important because we can raise awareness about substance abuse prevention and what is going on in our communities. We created this event last year to raise awareness in a fun way. Everybody can enjoy, but also get the information. We want to make them aware of what is going on in our community with substance abuse," Perez said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: QAC announces Suicide Prevention Month
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC announces Suicide Prevention Month

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 350
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Taking a stand against preventable loss of life and promoting available help in the community, the Queen Anne's County Commissioners, alongside For All Seasons, announced September as Suicide Prevention Month.At a Sept. 24 meeting, Susan Ahlstrom, a human trafficking regional navigator, and Carly Palmer, outreach coordinator of For All Seasons, presented information about the community behavioral health and crisis center's services, which include therapy, psychiatry, victim services, crisis support and education regardless of anyone's ability to pay.
With the proclamation, For All Seasons welcomed the community to learn more about outreach and education services, and how the impacts of suicide effect everyone.
Suicide prevention can be as simple as listening without judgement, checking in on people in your lives, and encouraging them to seek help when needed, according to Ahlstrom.
"Be open to having those uncomfortable conversations with people because it could save a life ultimately," Palmer said.
According to the proclamation, as reported by the Centers for Disease Control, 49,476 people in the United States, including 608 people in Maryland, died by suicide in 2022.
The proclamation also announced that "according to a 2021 Youth Risk Behavior Survey, conducted by local school systems with the CDC, in the 12 months prior to the 2021 survey, 15.4% of Queen Anne's County teens attempted suicide."
The economic toll of suicide on society is also immense, with suicides and suicide attempts costing the nation almost $7 billion per year in lifetime medical and work-loss costs, the proclamation stated.
For All Seasons is always looking to be more involved in schools and impact the lives of youth.
"I don't think there's any school, probably in the nation, that has enough social services or other support for the pressures and what our children are experiencing these days in terms of stress and social media effects," Ahlstrom said.
For All Seasons recently welcomed an office in Stevensville and rolled out an open-access program with no wait time, she said.
The community is encouraged to learn more about For All Seasons services, outreach and education programs including about suicide prevention and mental health.
More information about For All Seasons can be found at: forallseasonsinc.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Hearing loss requires patience
author: Staff Writer
content:
Hearing loss requires patience

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 186
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For those of us who patiently suffer hearing loss, I share some confounding demons of our plight.Certainly not as constrictive as loss of sight, the condition carries baggage imperceptible to those who shout, repeat and sigh while shaking heads.
Alas, we are indeed a frustrating lot, and believe me when I say how much we own this knowledge, chronically offering undeserved apologetics for our affliction.
Often, oh ye shouters, the solution lies in enunciation, not volume, a remedy difficult to understand and implement I concede. Bless you who get it.
For some, this sensory loss includes disorientation, which often translates as some form of idiocy, especially in public, quotidian transactions.
Consider the poor checkout clerk who struggles for a pitying smile, always received, by the way, with grateful appreciation. Bless you who know good manners.
Parking lots, with their random fly by cellphone conversations and harmonics emanating from passing cars, will find us jerking our heads in mistaken response. Bless you who, in polite recognition, just chill.
Aware of the trouble and patience hearing loss requires, I bid your forbearance and am ever grateful. Bless you who good naturedly endure.
ELINOR CECIL
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the personal challenges of living with hearing loss, focusing on health-related experiences and social interactions. While it touches on community interactions, the core theme is health.

title: Queen Anne's welcomes Secretary of Overdose Response
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's welcomes Secretary of Overdose Response

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Queen Anne's County welcomed Maryland's Special Secretary of Overdose Response Emily Keller for a tour of county programs and departments dedicated to erasing stigma and taking a stand against substance abuse September 25.Beginning at the Queen Anne's County Department of Health in Centreville, the Alcohol and Drug Abuse Services presented its focus on outreach, education and prevention programs.
Showcasing each journey to recovery was unique, but there were local travelers along the way, department Peer Support services offer one-on-one counseling, referral programs, outreach, and lending an empathic ear, Peer Supervisor Brook Todd said.
Providing resources for the community is a crucial aspect of preventing overdose deaths and just over the summer the department of health distributed 600 kits of Narcan to be available throughout the community, she said.
Over 100 One Boxes were also donated to businesses around the community, these kits contain CPR supplies, Narcan, gloves and everything needed in the event of an overdose.
A central focus of the Department of Health Alcohol and Drug Abuse Prevention Services is erasing the stigma connotated with overdose.
"No place is hidden, it can happen anywhere," Angulo Potts, peer recovery specialist said.
Housing and career opportunities are essential aspects of recovering from the disease of addiction and preventing relapse and the Department of Health requested assistance in streamlining the process to bring a recovery house to the county where there currently is none.
Keller noted the Maryland Office of Overdose Response is currently making it a priority to establish safe quality recovery houses and recommended collaboration with the county government.
More information about the Queen Anne's County Health Department's Alcohol and Drug Abuse Prevention Services can be found at https://www.dontlabelus.org.
At the Queen Anne's County Board of Education building, Keller heard about the activities and programs initiated by the QAC Drug Free Student Ambassadors, leading the way in youth advocacy.
Led by Julie Kille, opioid education and prevention coordinator, the Ambassador program puts students in role model positions to educate their peers on taking a stand against substance abuse and living naturally high.
With QAC Goes Purple, the Ambassadors work diligently with leadership opportunities and creative activities to spread awareness throughout the county with poster contests, collaborative community events and team-building exercises.
The Ambassadors recently won first place in the national Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration competition for their escape room sharing the dangers of pills with peers.
More information about QAC Goes Purple can be found at www.qacgoespurple.org.
Other stops on Keller's visit included the County Chamber of Commerce in Chester and the Opioid Awareness Park in Stevensville.
Throughout her visit Keller reiterated that recovery was possible and Queen Anne's County represented a prominent dedication to addressing overdose awareness for all ages in the community.
"It is great to hear what is going on. It is a hopeful time in Maryland," she said.
More information about Maryland's response to overdose and opioid awareness can be found at: https://stopoverdose.maryland.gov. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pretty In Pink shows art and awareness
author: Tom McCall
content:
Pretty In Pink shows art and awareness

 October 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Arts 
 
 366
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Friday, The Waterfowl Building was full of pink art to be sold to raise money for The Clark Comprehensive Breast Center in Easton. Pretty in Pink, an awareness drive, and it is highlighting breast cancer awareness month, showcased over 60 framed pieces by Working Artists Forum artists.There were rows of paintings hung with bright lights. Many of the artists were breast cancer survivors. All of the artists wanted to give back.
There were pink tables set up with University of Maryland Shore Regional Health Clark Comprehensive Breast Center pamphlets. Half of this effort was to educate about breast cancer prevention for men and women. When men get breast cancer, it is usually worse because they don't check until it is too late.
Stacey Sass, chairwoman of Pretty in Pink, said, "The Clark Comprehensive Breast Center in Easton is doing amazing things for patients, men and women, who can't always afford everything. They do an incredible job with timely diagnosis."
She is a 27-year breast cancer survivor. She said that one in eight women will have a diagnosis in their lifetime.
"This is the first time Working Artist Forum has done a charity event. We are a group of about 120 artists who have been juried into this group. Everyone really stepped up. We had 48 members contribute work," Sass said.
A lot of the educational outreach was aimed at getting people to be checked early.
"Breast cancer is not something you should be a afraid of. There is help here. You can go to the Clark Center regardless of their status of insurance, of immigration, income and get diagnosed and learn about treatment options," Mary Ford said.
On her committee, Ford did all of the group's graphics and social media.
Mary Ellen Lynott said, "The younger generation tends to think, 'That is my mom's generation,' but the statistics is it is really hitting us younger."
Lori Yates was there with her work on display.
"That is the tricky part. Getting these women in for screenings," Yates said. "It is really miraculous where we are with breast cancer. There is so much that can be done. It can be caught like before it is really even cancer."
She recommended getting checked once a year. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: New rural health initiative by University of Maryland seeks to fill medical gap on Eastern Shore
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
New rural health initiative by University of Maryland seeks to fill medical gap on Eastern Shore

 October 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 526
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Medical student Tahreem Riaz said her interest in rural healthcare was established due to the rural community she grew up in Punjab, Pakistan.Riaz is one of six students who has been chosen for the University of Maryland School of Medicine's new rural health initiative to address the physician shortage on the Eastern Shore.
Rural areas in Maryland have notoriously been medically underserved, according to the federal Health Resource and Services Administration. Students like Riaz are taking initiative to address these disparities and help close the medical disparity through the Rural Health Equity and Access Longitudinal Elective.
The students will be provided didactic and mentoring sessions as well as research and clinical experiences on the Eastern Shore.
Leah Millstein, the program director and associate professor of medicine, said there's a real challenge for the population of the Eastern Shore in finding and accessing exemplary healthcare.
"There's a shortage in primary care doctors as well as specialties, and we often have students who are interested in rural medical care in their futures, but their exposure to it during medical school is limited," Millstein said. "So this program seeks to fill those gaps, to really give the students an in depth exposure to rural health care, and give them the building blocks that allow them to feel like they'll be successful serving as physicians in those communities when they're done with their training."
Riaz said her initial circumstances in Punjab made her realize the importance of one-to-one connection with patients and their medical providers.
"I personally faced the challenges of not discussing quality healthcare due (to a) shortage of physicians," Riaz said. "Individuals of my village have to go to far off places to get necessary healthcare."
The program is designed to train and place incoming medical students in Eastern Shore healthcare practices. About $1.4 million has been secured in state funding and from the University of Maryland, Baltimore; University of Maryland Eastern Shore; the Rural Maryland Council and many donors.
Millstein said three of the six students accepted into the program were awarded full-tuition scholarships with a commitment to working on the Eastern Shore for four years after completing residency training. The long-term goal is to support 10 students interested in rural health in this elective program each year.
Ken Kozel, president and CEO of University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, said this program will help draw new providers to the Eastern Shore.
"Strengthening our provider workforce is a top priority at UM SRH, and programs like R-HEALE will help us attract providers who want to practice in rural communities," Kozel said. "We greatly appreciate our partnership with the School of Medicine toward enhancing access across the Shore."
For Riaz, she is happy for the opportunity to focus on improving rural areas and assisting caring for the people in rural areas.
"With this program, I'll be able to be involved in research projects that are deeply focused on improving population and community health, and also to deeply understand the social, economic or cultural factors that are rooted in the disparities of such communities," she said. "I think this comprehensive training through our field will allow me to deliver more compassionate and patient centered care in the future." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While education is tangentially related, the primary emphasis is on healthcare access and medical services.

title: ‘Long-held promise’: Shore Regional Health breaks ground on hospital project in Easton
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
‘Long-held promise’: Shore Regional Health breaks ground on hospital project in Easton

 October 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 605
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Local officials and stakeholders joined together at the Talbot County Community Center on Monday afternoon to celebrate the groundbreaking of a long-awaited regional medical center, complete with a visit from Gov. Wes Moore (D).The University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's project is estimated to cost around $550 million. Moore said on Monday that since he was inaugurated, the state has committed $100 million toward the hospital.
Before breaking out the shovels, Moore spoke to hundreds of attendees on what the hospital will achieve for rural Marylanders in need of improved healthcare access.
"At a time when most things are leaning away from rural health, in Maryland, we're leaning in," Moore said. "We're showing that you cannot have a growing and a thriving state if every part of the state is not seen and heard and recognized in that growth."
Moore, Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.) and other politicians emphasized the importance of bringing high quality healthcare to the Mid-Shore. The medical center is expected to attract doctors and other healthcare professionals to Easton's workforce, a point Moore hammered home Monday afternoon.
Mohan Suntha, president and CEO of the University of Maryland Medical System, thanked many partners for their commitments to the often-stalled project that has been discussed for more than a decade.
"We are delivering on a long-held promise," Suntha said. "And the future is so bright for the Mid-Shore, for the medical system and the state of Maryland."
Shore Regional Health first applied for a certificate of need to relocate its Easton hospital on Sept. 7, 2012. Industry changes, fiscal concerns and shifting project plans delayed the timeline.
This January, the Maryland Health Care Commission finally approved the certificate of need application.
Following Monday's welcome celebration, Moore told reporters he noticed the project was stalling when he began his term. He said it became a "priority" for his administration to remove "the barriers and the regulatory red tape."
"It's too long that we've had people on the Eastern Shore who have been left behind," he said.
The hospital will be built on around 230 acres just north of the Easton Airport and across from the Talbot County Community Center. It is replacing the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center that is located downtown at 219 S Washington St.
Site preparation construction is currently underway, with the bulk of construction beginning in the spring of 2025. The medical center is expected to be completed in the summer of 2028.
The campus will include a 325,000-square-foot, six-level main tower, complete with 122 licensed beds, seven operating rooms and a helipad. An adjacent building for offices and outpatient services will be 60,000 square feet.
The new hospital will serve as the primary inpatient hospital for Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties. Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) called it a "transformative" addition for the Eastern Shore.
"I plan to spend the rest of my life here. I think my children plan to spend the rest of their life here," Mautz said. "And one critical factor is are we going to be able to get healthcare. I think with this new hospital, we're going to get it."
Moore echoed Mautz's sentiments after Monday's celebration, adding that he is confident the medical center will attract quality doctors to the Eastern Shore and benefit residents for the foreseeable future.
"It's fundamentally unfair that if a person needs to see a specialist, that they somehow have to cross the bridge in order to do it," Moore said. "It's not fair.
"And if you want to be able to recruit the top talent, you have to make sure that you have a world-class facility. And that's exactly what this investment is going to bring." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the groundbreaking of a regional medical center, detailing healthcare infrastructure development, government involvement, and its impact on rural healthcare access. While local government and public notices have some relevance, the core subject is healthcare.

title: 'Breaking Bread' discussion focus on suicide prevention
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
'Breaking Bread' discussion focus on suicide prevention

 October 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 752
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A well-respected lieutenant colonel who was part of the U.S. Navy's Seal team, a local military veteran, emergency responders, law enforcement personnel and many others put their lives on the line every day to help others.But sometimes, they themselves are the ones who need help as suicide has gripped members of the military and first responders.
The Robert Irvine Foundation on Oct. 17 at Three Oaks in Lexington Park hosted "Breaking Bread with Heroes" to discuss various ways of helping those in need.
"If you've been in combat, if you've been in law enforcement and you come across a live shooter situation, if you're a first responder and you're running into a burning building, you're vulnerable," Robert Irvine Foundation Development & Impact Vice President Robert Yarnall said. "It takes courage, but you're very vulnerable because you don't know what you're going to experience. It takes courage to admit we need help."
Yarnall said the key is opening lines of communication.
"How often do you say to someone, 'Hey, how are you doing?' then [they answer] 'Pretty good,' then you move on?" he asked. "[A colleague told me] just ask the [expletive] question. A lot of times you might be surprised at the answer you get."
A news release said the event "is an important and meaningful moment to honor the experiences of veterans and their families by joining together, talking, listening and understanding."
"It's always going to be something that we just have to confront and make sure we're invested in," said Del. Brian Crosby (D-St. Mary's), who served 10 years in the U.S. Army, five of them active, and was deployed three times. "We just need to make a little bit of a difference every day and try to get somebody to the next day."
According to www.wefacethefight.org, more than 120,000 veterans have taken their own lives since 2001, and more than half of those did not have a known mental illness. Also, suicide is the second-leading cause of death among post 9/11 veterans, and the suicide rate for male veterans between the ages of 18-34 has nearly doubled since 2006.
Yarnall said one of the reasons for the high numbers — he added since 2001, more veterans have died by suicide than were killed in combat during the Iraq and Afghanistan wars — is accessibility to weapons.
"Weapons are 90% lethal ... so you don't get another chance," he said. "We all talk about how we know how to operate a weapon safely. Yes, we do but when we go into crisis mode are we thinking about the safe operation of a weapon? No, you're not thinking rational in that 5- to 10-minute time period."
Another is the stigma associated with asking for help.
"If you are suffering from some sort of depression or mental health issue or suicidal thoughts, to come forward there's a stigma associated with that and I think people fear that, 'I might lose my clearance, I won't be able to do the job I want to do,' or other reprisals," U.S. Navy Capt. Matt Farr said. "[They think] it's going to somehow negatively impact their career because a military career is everything; it's how you support your family and it's serving your country, so you don't want to put that on the line."
Farr, who lives in Leonardtown, experienced a recent loss when his Leonardtown neighbor, a military veteran, took his own life earlier this month.
The issue also exists with first responders.
"I've seen tragedy just about any way, shape or form you can imagine," said Kim Davidson, who was an EMS in St. Mary's for 48 years and one of the county's original 10 medics who started the Advanced Life Support system. "I've seen terrible things and I've seen how people react to them. It's not just, 'Oh, well put a Band-Aid on it.' It's a lot more than a Band-Aid and it goes a lot deeper than a Band-Aid can."
Davidson said there is a fine line when offering assistance.
"There is that wonder of how far can I go and how far can I push myself onto somebody else before they really turn?" he said. "I know when it's time for me to shut up and just sit there and just be company for you, and if you want me to speak I'll speak."
"We need to make sure people understand they have a support network out there," Crosby said, "and if they don't have one to help them find one because organizations like this provide them."
For more information, go to wefacethefight.org or robertirvinefoundation.org or www.militaryonesource.mil.
Twitter: @MichaelSoMdNews 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on suicide prevention efforts targeting military personnel and first responders, emphasizing mental health challenges, stigma, and support systems. While public safety and local government topics intersect with the audience (military/firefighters), the core issue is mental health advocacy and crisis intervention, making 'Health' the most precise classification.

title: Channel Marker adds 6 transitional living beds in Caroline County
author: Tom McCall
content:
Channel Marker adds 6 transitional living beds in Caroline County

 October 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 447
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Channel Marker had an open house at 2451 Willow Pond Road to show off its new six-bedroom house designed to safely accommodate people who suffer from mental illness.This is the organization's eighth such house across Dorchester, Caroline and Talbot counties. They named it Willow Pond House.
Cathy Cassell, CEO of Channel Marker, said, "Today we are opening up our eighth residential group home. It will occupy six clients and one staff. It is a part of an expansion project that the state put into play, 40 residential rehabilitation beds across the state. We applied for six and got six."
The plan is to bring clients in around December.
"All the people referred to us have to have a serious and persistent mental health diagnosis. Referrals go through Mid-Shore Behavioral Health," Cassell said.
She described this as an affordable solution for some of her clients who are on fixed incomes. It offers an economical way for these people to have independent living. One of the Willow Pond's goals is to keep these clients out of higher level of care facilities like hospitals.
The house is very light, with oak floors, and there are a few dedicated hang-out spaces. One had big bean bags in it and a flat screen TV.
One innovation the house has is machines that distribute medications to the clients right in their bedrooms. This reduces mistakes and helps keep everyone in optimal health. It is like a vending machine.
The house has a van to help take clients get to their appointments.
"All their meals are communal. They live like a family. They take turns cooking dinner with staff," Cassell said.
The average stay is two to four years, and Cassell looks at this as transitional housing. Both men and women are welcome to be clients. The goal is teach clients skills to return to independent living.
Erin Hoxter is the adult services director of Channel Marker. She leads the Caroline County program. There are 12 other beds already in the county.
"We want them to learn how to cook and keep up with their ADLs (activities of daily living) like showering and toileting. The clients here are expected to do all of those things independently. When they do transition out they have learned these skills and can be successful in these areas," Hoxter said.
One big emphasis for Channel Marker is getting to know their neighbors and letting them know that this is safe.
"We try to do all the precautions we can. For example we have security systems all over this house," Cassell said.
Although the state helped provide funding, Channel Marker is in an active capital campaign to provide for the construction and maintenance of this house. Donations can go to channelmarker.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Channel Marker's expansion of transitional living facilities for individuals with mental illness, emphasizing mental health care, residential rehabilitation, and community integration. While public safety measures are mentioned, the primary context is health services.

title: ‘Cutting edge’: Talbot County first responders create mental health peer program
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
‘Cutting edge’: Talbot County first responders create mental health peer program

 October 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 657
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A new peer support program is aiming to break stigmas around mental health and provide direct assistance to first responders across Talbot County.The collaborative program is called Talbot FiRST!, a joint effort between the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, 911 dispatch center, Talbot County Sheriff's Office, Talbot County Department of Corrections, Easton Police Department and Easton Volunteer Fire Department.
Tina Kintop, EMS division chief for the Department of Emergency Services, says the program is meant to provide mental health services for all first responders in the county.
The peer support team will be made up of a diverse selection of first responders who have been interviewed and trained through a partnership with For All Seasons. When a first responder is in need of help, they can contact a peer member.
Kintop says the program is designed so first responders don't have to "go through the ranks" for mental health assistance.
"The idea is that they can come from the bottom up, meaning that they will know who all the peer (team members) are," Kintop said. " … They will be able to contact who they want to contact."
Kintop and fellow members of Talbot FiRST!'s steering committee — made up of heads from all of the agencies — were applauded by the Talbot County Council on Oct. 22 for the initiative.
County Manager Clay Stamp, a former Talbot County emergency services director, commended the program for being the first of its kind in Maryland.
"The things that we expose our 18-year-old kids to — that become EMTs or dispatchers or police officers — are horrendous," Stamp said on Oct. 22. "We have got to come up with a better way to arm these individuals to deal with these things in a healthy manner and to give them a support system.
"And right here in Talbot County, out of the 23 counties and Baltimore City, they've stepped up, and they're making it happen first."
Former EMS Division Chief Matt Watkins said it's a step very few first responder communities around the country have taken, adding, "Talbot County should be extremely proud of the fact that we're on the cutting edge of this."
Kintop and Watkins have been involved in creating the program for more than a year. A training by former New York City Police Department detective and crisis negotiator Jeff Thompson ignited their enthusiasm for the project.
Kintop called the four-day training "rigorous," yet said all of the first responders who attended were committed to learning from Thompson's life experiences.
"By the time the day was over, you didn't even know you were there for eight hours. It was so engaging, and everybody felt the same way," Kintop said. " … It brought up all the things that maybe I didn't seek help for, that I just kind of sucked it up and handled it on my own."
Kintop says the peer program will be completing a second phase of training soon to expand the peer team, along with doing outreach to first responder agencies. Her hope is that Talbot FiRST! becomes a model up and down the Eastern Shore.
For All Seasons CEO Beth Anne Dorman said funding from the Rural Maryland Council made the nonprofit's clinical training with the Talbot County first responders possible. In fiscal year 2024, the Rural Maryland Council awarded a $30,000 grant to For All Seasons meant to aid the organization in training first responder agencies across the Mid-Shore.
Talbot County Council President Chuck Callahan recalled the stigma around mental health in the first responder community when he first volunteered as a firefighter at 18 years old.
"You kind of feel like you're out there alone sometimes, and you need to talk to somebody," Callahan said at the Oct. 22 meeting. "Sometimes, the stuff that we do feels like it's forgotten.
"As long as we're up here, you guys are never ever going to get forgotten," Callahan said, "because you're our heroes in Talbot County, and we love you guys and you protect us." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a mental health peer program for first responders, emphasizing mental health support and stigma reduction. While Public Safety is related to first responders, the core initiative centers on health services. Local Government is tangential to the program's implementation but not the primary focus.

title: YMCA welcomes community to health expo
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
YMCA welcomes community to health expo

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — On Oct. 17, health agencies, partners, businesses, nonprofits and community organizations attended the Kent County Family YMCA for the annual Health and Wellness Expo.Pickleball players and basketball hoopers were momentarily replaced with health vendors. Tables were set up in the gymnasium, where attendees could get information for health wellness; anything from house gutter protection to cochlear ear implant options.
"This expo is dedicated to fostering partnerships among local organizations that provide valuable services and education on essential health and wellness topics," said Gale Drenning president of HomePorts, a partner of the event.
This year, Acme Pharmacy provided flu and COVID vaccines.
At the next table over, the new Health Educator at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Chestertown, Sandy Wilson-Hypes demonstrated CPR practices on a mannequin, inviting guests to try it out.
Teenager, Nate Perogoy was up for the challenge, exercising chest compressions to the tune "Staying Alive," a perfect tempo at 100/120 compressions per minute.
In addition to the vendors, classes were provided.
In "Unlock the Secrets of Ancient Nutrition," Bill Schindler author, internationally-known chef and founder of Eastern Shore Food Lab, instructed how to get the most nutrients from food and sustain your health amid a worldview of unhealthy practices.
Lt. Sean Maloney of the Kent County Sheriff's Office gave his presentation: "Don't Be A Victim! The Latest Scams, Schemes, and Frauds." He said threats come from everywhere: computer hackers, romance scams, fake scanners at ATMs and stores, dumpster diving and mail.
He pointed out victims can be anybody, but especially retirees with disposable income.
Gloria Carter offered a dance-based cardio class, available Mondays and Wednesdays at the YMCA.
Throughout the afternoon, while people went from table to table, they were treated to the musical talents of River Voices from Chester River Chorale directed by Stephanie LaMotte.
Outside, under a blue sky and moderate weather, food was provided by Happy Chicken and Lockbriar Farms. Patrons enjoyed squash soup, pumpkin ice cream and fresh-pressed apple cider.
The expo was well-attended, with over 300 programs handed out, said a volunteer.
Throughout the years the expo had many homes, but for the past three years the YMCA has been proud to host it.
Executive Director of the YMCA Erica Osterhout and her staff expressed excitement welcoming the expo each year. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a health expo organized by the YMCA, featuring health services, wellness education, medical demonstrations, and community health initiatives. While there are educational elements and local community aspects, the primary emphasis is on health and wellness.

title: Water therapy is Chestertown’s healing business
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Water therapy is Chestertown’s healing business

 November 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 641
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — There is a relatively new small business in Chestertown that is combining the cutting-edge practice of sensory deprivation with the wonders and healing potential of water.Park Row Floats, located at 312 Park Row, has helped Kent County residents stress less and address certain ailments for more than a year now.
If the concept of sensory deprivation sounds harsh and uninviting, Mandi Silcox, the owner of Park Row Floats has dispelled that assumption with every tour she has given of her state-of-the-art facility since it opened in the spring of 2023.
Before she was giving these tours, Silcox had spent much of her career in education, teaching middle school in Kent County and then teaching and administrating at a private school in Delaware.
While teaching, Silcox had always contemplated owning a small business—someday, although she was uncertain what type of business it would be. And then, while vacationing a few years ago, she was introduced to a unique concept.
"My husband and I were on vacation, and he asked if I wanted to do a float. 'Do you want to do this float spa thing, this sensory deprivation thing? he said.'"
Silcox said she tacitly agreed in her effort to be open to new things. The couple did two floats at the same time for 90 minutes and then a 45-minute sauna.
"And in the sauna, I turned to my husband and said, 'This is what I want to do. I want to open a float spot. This is amazing.'"
Going from school-to-spa would not happen overnight. Silcox said she knew she needed comprehensive training and set out to do her research. She found an established and successful mentorship-oriented program and hit the ground running.
"I took a class on how to do the build out, how to do it safely, how to do it cleanly, how to do it so that the salt, which is super corrosive, doesn't eat apart your building," she said. Each float chamber utilizes 1,000 pounds of Epsom salts in its operation.
Her husband, Jay, a structural engineer, helped conceive the build-out, and Holman Building of Chestertown executed the plans.
Walking into the totally renovated space, there's a holistic, modern vibe. The facility is spotless, streamlined and light-filled.
Silcox provides each client with comprehensive, "pre-float" instructions and a run-down of cabin particulars to maximize the benefits of the float session, and she is ready to answer any and all questions about what customers might experience during and after the session.
Silcox has also schooled herself on the burgeoning research that is being conducted on the benefits of all the services she offers and is quick to share that upon request. Another question, she said she is happy to answer for prospective clients is how the facility's filtration systems work.
The system, which she said, is "very robust" and best-in-class, is designed specifically for float tanks, using a three-cycle filtration process, and an optimal micron filter. The water is then exposed to UV light and goes through an additional process where the water is injected with ozone.
"We have all these things combined to make sure that the water is perfect, and then we add an optional process where we add one-third of an ounce of 35% hydrogen peroxide to the water between every single client."
And at the end of every session, each client is invited to transition back to the real world by spending time in the facility's refreshing communal space, which Silcox calls the "plant room." This area is infused with natural light and offers a cozy respite with complimentary water and tea, and electrolyte beverages for purchase.
Silcox is pleased to report that feedback on her business model has so far been very positive, as more and more people are looking for ways to enhance their health and totally unplug from life's daily stressors.
"Everyone walks out of here asking, 'When can I do that again?'" she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a wellness business offering water-based therapy for stress reduction and health benefits, emphasizing therapeutic practices, client health outcomes, and the owner's transition to providing health-focused services.

title: Maryland enshrines abortion rights in its constitution
author: Marissa Yelenik Capital News Service
content:
Maryland enshrines abortion rights in its constitution

 November 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Marissa Yelenik Capital News Service | Section: Local News 
 
 632
 Words 

 Read News Document

 COLLEGE PARK — Maryland voted to approve a referendum affirming the right to reproductive freedom on Tuesday, making what was already state law a constitutional right.The referendum, which appeared as Question 1 on voters' ballots, states that all people have "the fundamental right to reproductive freedom, including but not limited to the ability to make and effectuate decisions to prevent, continue, or end one's own pregnancy."
The crowd at Angela Alsobrooks' election night watch party erupted in cheers when news arrived that Maryland's Question 1 passed with solid support.
"I think it's important for it to have been codified, and I'm here for women's rights," said A.C. Edwards, 34, of Baltimore, who was at the party.
However, critics fear the broad language will allow lawmakers to apply unrelated concepts to the amendment, including gender-affirming surgeries, and widen the access minors have to abortions without parental consent.
Existing state law requires parental notification of minors prior to an abortion, but does not require their consent. Parental notification can be subverted in cases of abuse, if the minor is believed to be mature enough to give informed consent, or if the notification would not be in their best interest.
The amendment follows a nationwide focus on reproductive rights after the overturning of Roe v. Wade. Nine other states placed abortion-related constitutional amendments on their 2024 ballots.
The 2022 decision caused many voters to feel unprotected and fearful for their bodily autonomy. While state law already protected reproductive rights, voters raised concerns that laws could be repealed with changing leadership.
The Maryland General Assembly is able to repeal state law through legislative action, but constitutional amendments may only be passed following three-fifths passage in the General Assembly and a majority approval of state voters.
Max Freeman, a high school senior from Bethesda, Md., has worked with the Angela Alsobrooks campaign since March and attended the Alsobrooks watch party.
"I do think it's important to codify [abortion rights], to enshrine it into the constitution, because it's such an important issue for so many people," said Freeman. "It's really affected a lot of women these past few years … so we just want everybody to feel safe."
On the way to cast their votes, both supporters and opponents told Capital News Service that Question 1 was at the forefront of their minds.
Lorie Morey, 54, of Middletown, Md., said she voted for former President Donald Trump and other Republicans on the ballot Tuesday.
However, Morey said she thinks the decision to get an abortion is up to the individual.
"I don't think anybody should tell a person what they can and can't do with their body," Morey said. "I don't think the government should have any say. I don't think the state should have any say."
Kathryn Harrington, a volunteer for the Montgomery County Republican Party, said she spent several hours outside the Summit Hall Elementary School polling station in Gaithersburg, Md., educating voters on Republican candidates and their platforms.
This election cycle, she said, she has been particularly worried about Maryland's abortion referendum.
"This ballot question is a little nefarious because it would allow a child to go get abortions without any parental involvement," Harrington said.
She worries that this referendum will allow sex traffickers to take advantage of young people.
"I stop and think about a 16-year-old who could be a victim of sex trafficking, get pregnant, get an abortion, get pregnant, get an abortion," Harrington said. "This amendment is pretty clear. [There is] no age, no limitation … I'm a mom with three kids and that scares me."
The Associated Press called the race not long after polls closed on Tuesday night. Other states showed a mix of results, with the Florida amendment to legalize abortion failing while the New York and Colorado amendments to enshrine abortion rights into their constitutions succeeded.
Sofia Appolonio, Katharine Wilson and Mennatalla Ibrahim contributed to this story. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland's constitutional amendment regarding reproductive rights, specifically abortion access. This falls under Health as it directly relates to reproductive healthcare and bodily autonomy. While there are elements of legal/constitutional processes, the core subject is healthcare policy.

title: Mid-Shore groups raise awareness for mental health needs of veterans
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Mid-Shore groups raise awareness for mental health needs of veterans

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Douglas Willey and Chuck Engh come from different military backgrounds, but they hold similar advice for how society should look at veterans struggling with mental health: "Don't judge."Willey, a 22-year Marine Corps veteran and past commander of American Legion Post 70 in Easton, says the Legion's national branch is working to provide veterans with the care they need — whether they're suffering from PTSD, depression, battle fatigue or other struggles that stem from their time serving the country.
Along with the American Legion's growing initiatives, Willey and Engh believe younger generations of veterans and military members are more adept at accessing the help they need.
"Society's put a different face on it," Willey said. "It's not a stigma anymore. It's just who you are, and it's part of you."
Engh, Post 70's current commander who spent six years in the Navy as an aviation ordnanceman, said the American Legion encourages veterans in need to call the national 988 crisis line, attend Post 70 meetings with professional counselors or connect with fellow veterans.
"Go to somebody one-on-one who's been through it themselves, and they get in a conversation with one another," Engh said. "They walk away, and they're like, 'I feel better. I got to talk to somebody that knows what I'm going through.'"
Nationwide and in Maryland, veterans experience alarming rates of suicide. Lisa Short, adult population supervisor for Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, says around 17.5 veterans die by suicide each day and more than 71,000 died by suicide from 2011 to 2021.
Short agrees that the stigma around mental health has lessened over time, but emphasizes the work to provide support is nowhere near complete, especially to the Eastern Shore's large veteran population.
"We do still see a barrier … in military and emergency response personnel," Short said. "There's a stigma for them regarding their position. They're in roles that are seen to be the protector, the tough one."
J Howard, the organization's behavioral health coordinator for DEI and specialty programs, noted many behaviors that may be exhibited by veterans in need of help: nightmares, flashbacks, survivor's guilt, substance use, mood shifts and "diminishing interest" in activities previously enjoyed.
"Veterans are not as likely to share their trauma experiences," Howard said. "Though they may not speak about it, it does not mean there are not persistent symptoms. … It's important to validate and be consistent when support is being given to the veteran population."
Willey echoed the same, encouraging spouses, family members and friends to listen instead of judge. The need for outreach and someone to talk to only increases this time of year, he says.
"The national department and Post (70) are very proactive on buddy checks," Willey said, "calling a veteran, especially during the holidays."
Since July, Short noted that crisis response groups have seen upticks in calls from veterans. The Santé Group reported serving 10 veterans in this fiscal year's first quarter, compared to 25 the entire fiscal year 2024, Short said. The Eastern Shore Operation Center had 54 Mid-Shore veterans call the 988 hotline in fiscal year 2024, with 35 calling the hotline in just the first quarter of fiscal year 2025.
Short and Howard highlighted the importance of hope for veterans and that resources are readily available, whether it's calling a crisis line or reaching local organizations like the Cambridge VA or Veteran & Military Support Alliance. Short recommended something as simple as putting the 988 crisis line on the refrigerator.
"We don't want them to give up," Howard said.
In October, Post 70, American Legion Post 77 and Mid-Shore Behavioral Health spoke to the Talbot County Council regarding Operation Green Light, an initiative to raise awareness about resources for veterans and their families.
The council passed an Operation Green Light proclamation unanimously, which encourages residents and businesses to display green lights in honor and recognition of veterans from Nov. 4 to Nov. 11.
Willey hopes Post 70 and other organizations can continue to enhance that awareness around the importance of mental health for all veterans.
"The main thing is not to judge each other," Willey said. "I'm not going to judge you, you're not going to judge me, if we want to get any progress." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on mental health awareness for veterans, stigma reduction, and support resources. While local government initiatives are mentioned, the core theme aligns with health advocacy and community wellness.

title: Here's a good question: How's your mental health?
author: CHRIS HOUSTON
content:
Here's a good question: How's your mental health?

 November 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CHRIS HOUSTON | Section: Columns 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Nobody would hesitate to explain that they missed hockey practice due to a broken leg. In some circles, scars are badges of honor. When I was a kid, students would gleefully sign their names in Sharpies on their friend's orthopedic cast.If you see a friend with a physical injury, you'll probably ask them about it, and likely they will tell you. "How are you?" is a ubiquitous greeting, and mostly people glibly give happy one-word answers like "fine" or "great." I like to surprise friends who ask by giving them sincere answers. My better half cringes when I give brief but honest answers to strangers who enquire.
I keep doing it though, because I think it's important to discuss how we are really doing. My sincere answers to "how are you?" sometimes catch people off guard. A question that I sometimes ask, however, has proven to be a real eye-opener. "How's your mental health?" never gets a glib answer. People don't expect that one. But often the question provokes really meaningful conversations.
Still, I don't commonly ask people about their mental health. To some, it remains a deeply private topic. But maybe it shouldn't be. I wonder how things might be different if we were just as quick to comment on our anxiety or depression as we were our headaches. Normalizing these chats erodes the stigma.
Stigma inhibits conversation about mental health and I think we might have more comprehensive healthcare if we were all more comfortable talking about it.
I've spoken in public and written about my mental health. I find that after I do so, people share their stories. Such stories are widespread. Years ago, I never thought much about mental health. During my recent short stint of local newspaper reporting, housing, poverty, substance use, and mental health were the most commonly discussed topics. They sometimes don't, but often do, overlap.
I used to think that when people spoke about problems, they were looking for solutions. I'm older and wiser now and I know that sometimes people just need to talk. Talking about mental health is therapeutic for folks. And yet, starting conversations about mental health can be difficult. We're not used to it. Many avoid even learning about it.
I like the BeThere.org website, which offers free lessons on how to support someone struggling with their mental health. The website offers golden rules on how to kick-start conversations: say what you see, show you care, and hear them out, know your role, and connect to help.
If you have a mental health issue, you are likely much less alone than you think. Regarding PTSD, a 2019 paper published in the Red Cross's academic journal notes that an "estimated 50 percent of men and 60 percent of women experience at least one trauma during their lifetime. Around 8 percent of these men and 20 percent of these women develop PTSD. In a given year, 8 percent of the general population has a current diagnosis of PTSD." The paper extrapolates that around 26 million people in the United States live with PTSD. The fact that women experience trauma at a rate double digits higher than men, should not go unnoticed.
According to data published by the National Institute of Mental Health 23.1 percent of U.S. adults lived with a mental illness in 2022. So, likely, you know people living with mental disorders. The sooner we all talk about it, the better it is. Practice it: "How is your mental health?" October 10 was World Mental Health Day.
Mental Health America operates a text/phone crisis line accessible via 988. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on mental health discussions, stigma, and resources, directly aligning with the Health topic. While it touches on societal conversations that could relate to Public Safety or Education, the core subject is mental health as a health issue.

title: Nonprofit asks Caroline County commissioners for veteran support
author: Tom McCall
content:
Nonprofit asks Caroline County commissioners for veteran support

 November 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 383
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Eric Johnson, executive director of the Center for the Military and Verteran Families, came before the Caroline County Commissioners on Tuesday in an effort to get more support for veterans and their families.His presentation focused on veterans from the Afghanistan and Iraq conflicts who have come home with PTSD. These veterans need better access to behavioral health services to prevent suicide, Johnson said.
Johnson said that more than financial support, he wants to restore the dignity for these men and women who have served but are not getting the help they need.
Also at the table were lobbyist Bruce Bereano the deputy director of Veteran and Military Support Alliance Lee Ellington.
VAMSA is located in Queen Anne's County but wants to expand its efforts into Caroline County and across the Eastern Shore.
Johnson said fighting with the bureaucracy to get disability services is really tough when a veteran is already sick. VAMSA, which was founded three years ago, is trying to make the system easier to navigate.
He also mentioned that a mentally challenged veteran creates a stress on their family, and he wants these collateral family members to get some help as well.
"If someone comes back from three tours in Afghanistan and has major PTSD issues, maybe some rage issues, and that is affecting their family, somebody has to take care of that family," Johnson said.
He is a veteran from the War in Afghanistan and has lost two siblings who served in the Air Force to suicide. Johnson says VAMSA has helped 20 different individuals avoid suicide 23 times.
"The number one thing that veterans can do is get involved with service to others. If we can get them to that point, those are the folks that seem to have the most resiliency and prevention of suicidal ideation in that population," Johnson said.
Johnson said veterans on the western shore get better care than veterans on the Eastern Shore. He wants to change that.
One of the ideas that VAMSA has put across is providing computer access to their program on monitors in the Denton American Legion. Virtual accessibility could help with transportation issues, and several VAMSA services can be offered via Zoom.
Travis Breeding, president of the Caroline County Commissioners, said, "We have now lost more Iraq and Afghanistan veterans to suicide than we've lost in combat." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on veterans' mental health needs, PTSD treatment, and access to behavioral health services. While local government officials are involved, the core issue revolves around healthcare access and suicide prevention for veterans, making 'Health' the primary topic.

title: Local behavioral health experts talk election stress
author: Tom McCall
content:
Local behavioral health experts talk election stress

 November 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 642
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The election results have stressed some people out.The uncertainty, the disappointment and the queasy sense that there is trouble on the horizon have caused some to have depression and anxiety. Even the people whose candidate won the election are worried there will be another assassination attempt or civil unrest.
The American Psychological Association did a poll and found seven in 10 Americans have significant election stress. Add the holiday season on top of this, and it becomes a lot to handle.
Several local behavioral health leaders had some ideas of how to handle the stress.
"Give ourselves a little space and, I would underscore, give ourselves a little grace. Also you don't know where people stand, so it is also just being respectful. Conversations about it don't need to be top of the list at the Thanksgiving table," said Kathryn Dilley, LCSW-C, the CEO of Mid-Shore Behavioral Health.
Another local behavioral health expert is Beth Anne Dorman, president and CEO of For All Seasons.
With Thanksgiving coming up with all kinds of political viewpoints, she offered a way to stay cool.
"Choose your election dialogue partners carefully — don't engage with friends and family who upset you," Dorman said.
"We may feel we are on opposite sides of the election issues with our family members, colleagues and neighbors. This creates stress and can compromise our mental health. The presidential election, in particular, affects so many aspects of our lives that it's no wonder we are all stressed about the outcome," she said.
Change is tough, and there are big political transitions happening. Stress can affect personal relationships, weight changes and sleep patterns. Getting enough rest, eating healthy and investing in healthy relationships can all help.
Dilley oversees a five-county network of behavioral health support.
"988 the crisis and suicide prevention hotline — that nationally there have been last week an uptick overall. Calls coming in to that number are from a national perspective. Locally at our Eastern Shore Operations Center, we haven't seen a huge variance yet," Dilley said.
She emphasized having hopeful conversations and minimizing oversaturation of news feeds.
Dorman had a list of tips to help alleviate election stress.
"Watch your media diet and find the least stressful ways to stay informed without getting upset, ie: maybe switch to reading news and not watching TV," Dorman said.
Dorman also said to turn election stress into action — people should consider volunteering for a campaign or even running for office. The other mood enhancers she recommended were eating healthy, exercising, getting a good night's sleep and being out in nature. Those whose daily routines are being affected by this stress can seek an appointment at For All Seasons, which has a same-day mental health access policy.
Michelle Boulden-Hammond, Ph.D., is an author and holistic practitioner and has concrete techniques to reduce stress.
"I am seeing a lot of increased anxiety and a lot of depressive states. Worrying about what is going to happen? How am I going to survive with the new administration?" she said.
"I tell them to do journaling as an exercise. I give them some guided meditation. I always tell them to express their feelings. Don't hold it in. The holistic approach will reduce the symptoms. Connect with your higher power, it will never turn us wrong," she said.
Dilley said if stress is becoming unmanagable, there are places to get help.
"That is the message above all. If this situation post election has put anyone in a position where they don't feel they can manage how they are responding to it, I would strongly encourage them to seek help," Dilley said. "There is the Eastern Shore Operations Center, which is our regional hotline to connect. It is 24/7 and can connect you to quick access to get into urgent care appointments in the region. That number is 888-407-8018."
This report has been updated from an earlier version to correct the spelling of a name. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on election-related stress and its impact on mental health, featuring behavioral health experts discussing coping strategies. While there are mentions of local resources, the core subject is health-related stress management.

title: Denton food pantry provides food for more than 1,000 families
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Denton food pantry provides food for more than 1,000 families

 November 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 354
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Aaron's Place, a food pantry and soup kitchen just northeast of downtown Denton, provided crucial meals, food and drinks to more than 1,000 families last week.On Thursday, volunteers stacked open trunks full of fresh fruit, vegetables, perishables, canned sodas, Thanksgiving desserts and, of course, turkeys. They began distributing the groceries just after 11 a.m., though cars were lined up hours in advance.
Aaron's Place Executive Director Cheryl Beulah said volunteers handed out food until around 7 p.m. Around 1,115 families were served, according to Beulah.
From seeing residents come into the food pantry every week, Beulah says "food insecurity is real." Mary Lou Russ, an administrative assistant at the food pantry, said the amount of need is "overwhelming."
During the pandemic, Beulah says they served around 2,500 people for the Thanksgiving giveaway, an all-time high. The work done by Aaron's Place, which is partnered with the statewide nonprofit Maryland Food Bank, hasn't slowed down at all since 2020.
According to Maryland Hunger Solutions, more than 6,000 Caroline County residents participated in the federal Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program in fiscal year 2022. 2020 census data shows 13.2% of Caroline County residents were below the poverty line, above the then-state average of 9%.
And according to a new survey of holiday meal costs by the American Farm Bureau Federation, the price of a Thanksgiving dinner has risen 29% from 2020. Beulah sees those rising food prices, and says it's a "challenging" time.
She said many of the residents in need, particularly during Thanksgiving and the holidays, are families and people from Caroline County. She also sees growing concern with hunger for the senior community.
Beulah said while discussions pertaining to food insecurity are important, action matters. In part, that's what drives her to lead the Denton food pantry and soup kitchen.
"That conversation's not putting food on that person's table," Beulah said. " … Your neighbors could be starving."
Aaron's Place's food pantry is open Tuesdays from 11:30 a.m. to 3 p.m., Wednesdays from 9:30 a.m. to 3 p.m., and the third Thursday at 11 a.m. in January, March, May, July, September and November. The soup kitchen opens on Tuesdays at Noon. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a food pantry addressing food insecurity, which relates to public health and community well-being. title: Hope for Hunter Cornhole Tournament brings crowd
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Hope for Hunter Cornhole Tournament brings crowd

 November 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 273
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Raising support for 13-year-old Hunter Clough of Centreville battling cancer, around 100 participants flung bean bags as Kent Island Cornhole hosted Hope for Hunter Charity Cornhole Tournament at the EShore Sports on Nov. 23.Hunter's grandfather, Jamie Clough of Easton, was blown away by the community support the tournament brought in.
This is not Hunter's first bout with cancer, but according to Jamie, she always has a smile on her face and would be honored with the amount of people at the tournament supporting her.
"It's just incredible. Hunter continues to have a joy of life, taking everything one day at a time," he said.
Kent Island Cornhole has regular leagues and fundraisers but nothing even close to the size of Saturday's event, according to owner and organizer Mike Faery, who spearheaded the event in support of Hunter and her family.
"They are a fantastic family and we wanted to support them in any way we can," he said.
With about 100 participants, the fundraiser tournament brought in cornhole enthusiasts, both experienced and amateur, looking to have a good time for a good cause.
"The community and business support has just been astronomical," Faery said.
Cheering from the sidelines for her 13-year-old son Levin and her husband Zachary was Kellie Devers of Centreville. The family was ecstatic for the opportunity to stand as a community to show their support, she said.
Along with over 30 businesses also donating items for raffles and silent auctions, the tournament raised $4,200 with all proceeds to support the Clough family, according to Faery.
"We hope the money raised will keep a smile on her face through all of her treatments," co-organizer Nikki Faery said.
