title: Wellness takes a creative twist with music and art at the core
author: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Wellness takes a creative twist with music and art at the core

 December 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 751
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Twelve days after his 1984 graduation from Queen Anne's County High School, Darrin Pruitt joined the Navy."I still had my Ocean City sunburn," he recalled. After serving for six years, Pruitt lived in Washington State, working on quality control for nuclear fuel production.
When his mother developed melanoma, along with other life changes, "it seemed like a good time to come home."
Pruitt, a self-described serial entrepreneur, works for the Department of Labor Workforce Development Veterans Services during the day. His brainchild and "sometimes beautiful disaster" is Chesapeake Creative Wellness, a nonprofit organization operating under Chesapeake Charities.
The inspiration for Chesapeake Creative Wellness came from two very different directions. As a Navy vet who works with veterans, Pruitt sees PTSD and anxiety every day. Seven years ago, as a marketer for an Australian custom guitar company, he met Alice Cooper's Solid Rock Center members in Arizona. This group uses music and art to help at-risk teens. "When I told them I wanted to bring that model back here to the East Coast they kind of patted me on the head with a patronizing 'yeah, keep us in the loop.'"
He did. In 2023, Pruitt advised them of Chesapeake Creative Wellness' projected launch date for the second quarter of 2024. In August the organization held its first music session. In September they acquired a studio on Creamery Lane in Easton. "I told our landlord I didn't want the walls or floors redone. I want people to paint on them. We're painting murals inside the studio. It has worked out well for us." Kristi Egnar, an Easton artist, is the Creative Wellness art director. Mike Elzey of Mike Elzey Studios and musician Quinn Parsley provide musical direction.
Pruitt describes the Chesapeake Wellness model as peer counseling with no set structure. Some participate regularly; others attend infrequently, while others come only to hang out and talk. "And I didn't know it at first, but that approach turned out to be the best part; it's what we do really well. We want people to know that even if they don't want to ask for help they're not alone; there are people here who can help. It's a niche that needs filling in our community. We found the right time and the right way to fill it."
Relationships with Veterans of Foreign Wars, the American Legions, and Patriot Point in Dorchester County support the work of Chesapeake Creative Wellness. The Queen Anne's County Centre for the Arts is a friend of the organization. "At a veterans' job fair at Maryland Live Casino, I met the General Manager who is also a Marine," Pruitt recalled. "I came asking for assistance but also looking for a way that we could help. The GM told me I was the first person who ever asked for assistance and followed up with an offer to help."
Today Chesapeake Creative Wellness stocks the Maryland Live employees' break room with colored pens, pencils, and adult-level coloring books. In January the organization will host a monthly music program and comedy show at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. "We're looking for other ways such as outreach to nursing homes and rehab centers with long-term patients," Pruitt announced.
Locally, Chesapeake Creative Wellness hosts paint parties at local restaurants in Easton, Cambridge, and Centreville. Dates and times can be found on their Facebook page. Plans are in the works for a blog written by professional artists and musicians, including posts from contributors who have experienced similar challenges.
Ideas fuel the engine of Chesapeake Creative Wellness. "It's the busy people who get things done and our minds are always working," Pruitt says. "If an idea pops up, we hold on to it. As soon as we're done with one, we start working on another." Their idea for Christmas 2024 is a 16-foot Christmas tree to stand outside the VFW in Easton. Chesapeake Creative Wellness will sell ornaments for purchase and decoration, similar to the concept of the Crab Basket Trees at Fisherman's in Grasonville. Each ornament is two-feet in diameter and sells for $50. Proceeds from the sale will be used to purchase supplies for the organization's operation.
Chesapeake Creative Wellness welcomes volunteers — from those with artistic talent to anyone with time to sit in the office and keep the doors open for the day. Above all, Pruitt extends this invitation to anyone in any walk of life, "If you're having difficulty with PTSD or anxiety issues, we're here for you."
Visit Chesapeake Creative Wellness at 31A Creamery Lane in Easton or call 410-340-6257. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a wellness program using art and music to address mental health issues like PTSD and anxiety, primarily serving veterans. While arts and community aspects are present, the core mission aligns with health services.

title: Music as medicine: holiday concert provides cheer to residents living with memory loss
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Music as medicine: holiday concert provides cheer to residents living with memory loss

 December 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Holiday 
 
 418
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Monday afternoon, the HeartFields Assisted Living in Easton was filled with hums and songs.The annual holiday concert led by TiShawna Jordan, a local musician, was an effort to provide holiday cheer and acted as an intervention to benefit those living with loss of memory.
Heartfields Assisted Living at Easton partnered with the Chesapeake Center in order to provide support for elderly individuals through volunteer-led events such as the holiday concert.
Erin Lewis, director of career services at Chesapeake Center, said TiShawna Jordan's concerts have provided holiday cheer and positive memory recollection to those in the Bridge to Rediscovery program.
"Watching her perform throughout the year with the people in the memory clinic. She brings them back to life," Lewis said. "They start singing, they start dancing, they remember all the words to each one of the songs. It's wonderful to see how she can interact. It's almost like a different way of communicating."
According to Northwestern University, musical intervention has therapeutic benefits for people with dementia or Alzheimer's disease and has been proven to decrease a patient's agitation and improve communication.
Megan Pinder, director of sales and marketing for HeartFields Assisting Living, said HeartFields had begun partnering with the Chesapeake Center about two years ago. The volunteer-led programs began with a bird club where volunteers come to the Heartfields and fill up the 41 bird feeders every week for the residents to enjoy.
Then TiShawna, an active volunteer at the Chesapeake Center, began to come and play music for residents at HeartFields.
According to Pinder, the first holiday concert was a resounding success, and TiShawna Jordan was presented with roses by the HeartFields Resident Ambassador because her playing had moved many attendees to tears.
Elsie Jordan, mother of TiShawna Jordan, said her daughter was always musically inclined. As a child she would play the keyboard, and Elsie Jordan said she would help her daughter learn new music through humming songs.
During the concert, Elsie Jordan sat next to her daughter humming and singing along to classic Christmas songs such as "White Christmas" and "Jingle Bell Rock." At some points they would both sing, encouraging the crowd of attendees to raise their voices and fully enjoy the memory of the holidays.
"God gave her that gift, and I want her to share her gift with other people," Elsie Jordan said. "Because if it wasn't for God, she wouldn't have the gift she has. I feel like it's a gift and you shouldn't have to be paid for something you love doing. And she loves playing." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on music as a therapeutic intervention for residents with memory loss, highlighting health benefits like improved communication and reduced agitation. While Arts & Culture is relevant due to the concert, the primary emphasis is on health outcomes and medical research.

title: QLarant Foundation: an Easton-based philanthropic organization with widespread reach
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
QLarant Foundation: an Easton-based philanthropic organization with widespread reach

 December 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 498
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Established out of a need to improve healthcare quality, QLarant Foundation has made part of its mission to provide nonprofit and grassroots organizations funds to better assist underserved communities nationwide.Over 20 years, the foundation has distributed an estimated $8 million to 145 nonprofits with grants ranging from $5,000 to $50,000. As the foundation continues to grow, its leaders are proud to have their Easton headquarters in support of the Eastern Shore communities.
Ronald Forsythe, chief executive officer of QLarant Foundation, said the QLarant company began in 1973 as a peer review organization for physicians in the healthcare field, and over time the company expanded beyond just quality improvement healthcare. Forsythe said the QLarant company has been one of the main contract holders with the Center of Medicare and Medicaid Services.
"We have expanded into program integrity, which is kind of the fraud, waste and abuse part of healthcare," Forsythe said. "And as we continued to work and grow our footprint, we also saw a need to be able to find a way to use the excess reserves that we had coming in, so we actually established the foundation to support emerging healthcare nonprofits in the area as well."
Amanda Neal, executive director of QLarant Foundation, said the foundation was launched over 20 years ago. Since its beginnings, its philanthropy efforts have been a part of the DNA of the organization.
According to Neal, the grants top out at $50,000 because that kind of money could really move the needle for a local nonprofit doing grassroots work.
"There's not a single nonprofit out there that isn't underfunded, overworked, doing good stuff and moving the needle in the communities that they serve," Neal said.
Previous grant recipients included Epoch Dream Center, a student and social-emotional wellness center; Food and Friends, an organization addressing health and food security challenges; and Horizon Day Camp, a free summer camp providing joy to children with cancer and their siblings.
According to Forsythe, the foundation goes out of its way to support Eastern Shore based nonprofits and the work they do for rural communities.
"There's a great benefit to making sure that you have an anchor tenant within the community, particularly on the Eastern Shore, where a lot of the businesses are geared toward agriculture, seafood or tourism," Forsythe said.
But as the foundation continues to expand throughout the United States, Neal says it continues to stay strong on the reason the foundation was developed: to support communities in need.
"Any time that you can invest in a nonprofit that is raising up individuals within our community," Neal said, "the ripple effect of that is just extraordinary, helping one person, one family, whether it's stopping bullying, or helping a new mother, or a young family connect with services. The ripple effect of helping just one person always has a benefit for the community."
QLarant Foundation's current 2025 grant period opened on Dec. 2 and runs through Jan. 16. Eligible nonprofits from the states of Maryland, Washington, Texas, Florida and Georgia are can apply. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the QLarant Foundation's philanthropy in healthcare-related nonprofits, its origins in healthcare quality improvement, and grants targeting health-focused organizations. While it touches on business aspects and local impact, the central theme revolves around healthcare advocacy and community health support.

title: Maryland stories: This reading club is going to the dogs
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland stories: This reading club is going to the dogs

 December 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 628
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Those who might get nervous reading in front of a group might be better suited reading for those with four legs, a shell, big floppy ears or a tail.That's just one of the ideas behind Southern Maryland-based Pets on Wheels, which recently stopped at the Leonardtown Library.
"It improves confidence, reading skills and literacy," said Southern Maryland Pets on Wheels Coordinator Sharon Stapf. "Pets don't care if you get a word wrong. They're non-judgmental."
Stapf said the program can even benefit adults learning a second language.
"It gives the kids confidence when maybe they wouldn't want to read to a big group, but they'll read to a really cute dog," Brittany Haun of Leonardtown said as she watched her daughter, Charlotte, pet a large brown dog. "I think it's great and if they had more of these events, I would recommend people coming to them."
"My son loves dogs and all kinds of animals," Cassondra West of Mechanicsville said. "It just seems like a calming effect.
But reading is not the only benefit of the program, which Stapf said started out of Johns Hopkins to see if pets could help homebound patients feel less lonely.
"Whether it's children or adults, animals are the one thing that people miss, whether it be in the military or in existed living and maybe they've outlived their pets," Stapf said. "It is a family member and they miss that contact. They may not remember what they had for lunch, but they can tell me the name of every animal that came through that facility for the entire week before I visit."
Joshua Crosley of Mechanicsville can relate. The Panera Bread manager lost his beloved 11-year-old Corgi "Izzy" in a tragic accident in 2022.
"We had a baby [several months ago], so it's not a good time to find a new family member, but when given the opportunity, trust me I'll take an animal," said Crosley, who now has a young son. "This gives me an opportunity, at least a little bit, to come down for this and get some solace. [My daughter Elliot] misses Izzy as well and she'd love to have a dog, so this is kind of a shared experience."
Stapf also relayed a story about an individual at Naval Air Station Patuxent River who was "standoffish toward dogs, but when he found out we had a giant tortoise he came alive. His home was Hawaii and he had a pet tortoise."
She also told how an individual at Charlotte Hall Veterans Home had trouble getting words out, but following a visit with a dog it was discovered that if he had two hands on the animal it connected something that allowed him to speak.
"It sparked something," Stapf said. "It was phenomenal. It gave me chills all the way down to my toes."
Tracey Quade of Drayden recalled an incident at Chopticon High School in which a girl dressed all in black reached over and hugged the dog Loki Sandstorm for a good 15 minutes, all the while crying.
"Then she stood up, wiped her tears and walked away and never said a word to me," Quade said. "And [Loki] looked at me and honest to God I think he smiled. That kid needed something and he gave it to her."
Volunteers wanting to work with the organization must have pets that meet several qualifications — the "canine good citizenship test," Stapf calls it — in which they must be good around other animals, able to be touched "nose to toes," and not be disturbed by loud noises, staring or wheelchairs.
"I wanted to serve the community and I love dogs," Quade, who is retired from the federal government, said. "Personally I see the benefits for myself, for the dog and for the community."
For more information on Pets On Wheels, go to www.petsonwheels.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the therapeutic benefits of animal-assisted reading programs, emphasizing mental health improvements, confidence building, and emotional support for participants. While education (reading skills) is a component, the primary emphasis is on health-related outcomes like stress reduction and psychological well-being.

title: Resolve to eat better in new year
author: Staff Writer
content:
Resolve to eat better in new year

 January 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 153
 Words 

 Read News Document

 New Year's resolution anyone? How about one with multiple benefits for our health, our planet and the animals? Eating more veggies, fruits, legumes, grains and nuts helps us stay healthier, reduce global warming and stop animal suffering. It requires no exertion or deprivation. And it saves money too.The abundant nutrients and vitamins in plant foods keep us in top health, while their fiber keeps us regular. Plant foods don't do drugs, antibiotics, hormones, cholesterol or saturated fats. Concerned about ultra-processed foods? Then you certainly don't want your food processed through an animal's digestive tract.
Best of all, plant-based eating is supported by your local supermarket, which offers a rich variety of plant meats, cheeses and ice creams in their frozen food section, as well as a wide selection of nut and grain milks. Same goes for your favorite family restaurant and nearly every fast-food franchise.
There is more food for thought at:
nytimes.com/2023/11/15/well/eat/plant-based-diet-nuts-beans-grains.html.forksoverknives.com.bitesizevegan.org
Bon appetit.
DALEB STOKER
Cambridge 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on health benefits of plant-based diets, including improved nutrition, disease prevention, and cost savings. While environmental impacts (climate change, animal welfare) are mentioned, the primary emphasis is on personal health and dietary recommendations.

title: Region tops flu and Norovirus charts
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub,com
content:
Region tops flu and Norovirus charts

 January 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub,com | Section: News 
 
 214
 Words 

 Read News Document

 During the holiday season, Region IV, encompassing Kthe Eastern Shore, experienced a significant increase in influenza cases, surpassing other regions and the state in prevalence.Kent County Health Officer Bill Webb said, "The influenza for Region IV shows a significant uptick. Since we are in the heart of the Flu Season this is somewhat expected. In fact, we are outpacing other regions and the state as a whole on this metric."
Viruses like this one are known to spread in settings such as households, health care settings, schools and child care centers, and during food preparation if hands have not been thoroughly washed with soap and water.
Symptoms can be nausea and vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain, low fever, headache, muscle aches, chills and tiredness, usually lasting 24 to 48 hours and go away without treatment.
Webb highlighted the significant uptick in flu season but also noted a rise in gastrointestinal illnesses linked to the Norovirus in the area.
The Norovirus, commonly spread through fecal matter or vomit contact, contaminated food, or water, can cause symptoms like nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and fever.
The rates for Norovirus in Region IV have spiked, reaching a high of 160 per 100,000 residents, according to Maryland Department of Health data sourced from diverse surveillance methods including emergency visits, thermometer sales and the ESSENCE system. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Trust your doctors on vaccines
author: Staff Writer
content:
Trust your doctors on vaccines

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 380
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We are two retired pediatricians who practiced in Easton for a number of years and who have a great concern about the risk to children posed by vaccine hesitancy. That is, the reluctance of parents to have their children receive approved vaccines according to the recommended dose and schedule.When we were both young and in our training, diseases such as measles, mumps and chicken pox were common. Cases of smallpox were not unheard of, and some survivors of this disease were left with severe facial scarring. Polio epidemics, particularly in the 1950s, closed swimming pools in the summer and both of us had schoolmates who were affected. Fear of catching polio and being confined to an iron lung caused nightmares. For this disease, the picture rapidly changed with the advent of the Salk, and then Sabin, polio vaccines. Due to those vaccines, the scourge of polio has essentially disappeared from the United States.
In 1963 in the United States prior to the introduction of the measles vaccine, according to the CDC, 400 people died annually, 48,000 were hospitalized and 1,000 developed brain swelling from measles. Now for vaccinated children, the number is essentially zero.
Vaccines to protect against common childhood diseases have been one of the greatest advances in medical science, at least as important as the discovery of antibiotics. At the current time, vaccines protecting against over ten serious diseases including diphtheria, whooping cough, tetanus, polio, hepatitis A and B, pneumococcal pneumonia, rotavirus, chickenpox and influenza are available. There are also vaccines for COVID, respiratory syncytial virus, meningitis and human papilloma virus.
Unfortunately, the dramatic decrease in incidence of those serious diseases secondary to the introduction of vaccines has been threatened by vaccine hesitancy. This hesitancy has been fueled in large part by dissemination of misinformation on social media.
The vaccines your medical care giver recommends for your child have been exhaustively tested for their efficacy, safety and scheduling. We beg for you to talk with your caregiver if you have questions about vaccines and not to rely on possible misinformation found on social media. Your caregivers have years of scientific education and experience behind them, so please trust that they are recommending appropriate vaccines with the appropriate schedules. Your child's life may depend on it.
DR. BRIAN J. CORDON DR. JUDI GIESKI
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on vaccine efficacy, medical advice from healthcare professionals, and historical context of disease prevention, all central to public health. While it touches on education and safety, the core subject is health advocacy.

title: Mid-Shore Behavior Health to host count of unsheltered people
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Mid-Shore Behavior Health to host count of unsheltered people

 January 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 313
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Across five counties on the Eastern Shore on Wednesday, Jan. 29, Mid-Shore Behavioral Health will be hosting a point-in-time count.According to Jimmy Morris, continuum of care housing outreach specialist at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, it is a count of all experiencing unsheltered (living in cars, parks, streets, etc.) and sheltered (living in emergency shelters, transitional housing) homelessness on a single night.
The results of the data gathered will be submitted to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development and can be used to secure grant funding.
The hosted locations for the count include Queen Anne's County libraries in Stevensville from 10 a.m. to noon and in Centreville from 2 to 5 p.m.; St. Luke's United Methodist Church in Caroline County; Talbot County Free Library in Easton; Delmarva Senior Center in Cambridge; and Kent County, where people will be commuting through the county to make the count.
Morris said this particular count of people is important due to the rise of unsheltered individuals on the Shore.
Morris shared that some people are coming to shelters with 14-day-old babies and even 7-day-old babies.
"There's people that lost their homes because of medical conditions or job layoff, drug, alcohol, addiction or mental health," Morris said. "We are overwhelmed in these five counties."
Getting the word out about the count has been essential for Morris and the team at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health. Morris said he has gone to tent camps around the Eastern Shore to share information about the point-in-time so those living there can have their voices heard.
"We have people in hotels that cost grant money, there's people that are living in their cars, living in the woods, and God, it's cold out," Morris said. "We don't have the funds anymore. The only way to get the funding is to let them know what the situation is down here."
For more information, Morris encourages people to call him at 443-786-0699. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Advocates say budget cuts would harm Marylanders with disabilities
author: EMMA TUFO Capital News Service
content:
Advocates say budget cuts would harm Marylanders with disabilities

 January 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: EMMA TUFO Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 444
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Advocates for disabled people in Maryland are concerned about proposed cuts to their state programs, warning that the reductions could hit quality of care for some of the state's most vulnerable residents.During a hearing Thursday, advocates described the far-reaching consequences these cuts could have on the state's Developmental Disabilities Administration.
Mat Rice, executive director of People on the Go Maryland, urged state lawmakers to "not turn back the clock on a marginalized community."
"Are we saying to my staff person that is here with two kids, that he might have to take a potential pay cut?" Rice said. "There is a human cost here."
But Helene Grady, secretary of the Department of Budget and Management, said the "cost containment" measures were intentionally designed to minimize disruption to essential services.
"There are many potential options within the DDA program that are not on the table, and very intentionally not on the table, because of the impact they would have to the services the state is providing," she said. "The package that is on the table for cost containment was structured in a very targeted fashion to impact the areas and the flexibilities within the program."
Gov. Wes Moore has proposed $2 billion in cuts in his fiscal 2026 budget, as part of an overall attempt to address the state's looming $3 billion deficit. The DDA's spending has grown in recent years, agency officials said.
Moore's proposed reductions to the current fiscal year budget would adjust wages for an overall savings to the state. One of those changes would eliminate geographic differential rates, which currently pay providers more if they work in areas with a higher cost of living.
Ande Kolp, executive director of The Arc Maryland, argued the potential harm of these reductions. It would be hard for providers in high-cost areas like Montgomery and Prince George's Counties to survive the cuts, advocates say.
"The geographic differential is foundational to our rates," Kolp said. "It amounts to kind of kicking the legs out from under these providers at this time."
"I'm not sure that they will survive," she said.
Another cut would target "low intensity" support services, designed to help people avoid more drastic intervention. They allow individuals and families to use funding for short-term in-home care, minor home modifications for accessibility, short-term respite care, adaptive equipment, summer camps and other needs.
Sen. Cory McCray told Grady that families benefiting from the program are already contacting him, expressing concern over its potential elimination. McCray, a Democrat from Baltimore City, asked why the program should be cut.
Grady said it was a part of the cost-containment plan to ensure a sustainable budget model for the DDA going forward.
"We still have work to do," Grady said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on budget cuts affecting Maryland's Developmental Disabilities Administration, which provides critical services for individuals with disabilities. While the immediate context involves government budgeting, the core issue revolves around the impact on healthcare and social services for a vulnerable population, aligning most directly with the 'Health' topic.

title: Talbot County distributing micro grants to combat opioid epidemic

Talbot County distributing micro grants to combat opioid epidemic

 Talbot County has announced the fiscal year 2025 Opioid Restitution Fund Community Micro Grant Program.This initiative provides organizations with active 501©3 status the opportunity to apply for one-time funding allocations ranging from $1,000 to $20,000 to support programs and services addressing the opioid crisis in Talbot County. Grant funds must be used by June 30, 2026.
The Opioid Restitution Fund stems from settlements with pharmaceutical companies and distributors. Talbot County is leveraging these funds to invest in community-based solutions, focusing on prevention, treatment and recovery initiatives to address the ongoing impact.
Applications must be submitted to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office by Friday, Feb. 21, at 3 p.m. Late submissions will not be considered.

"I encourage our local nonprofits to submit their ideas and partner with us to make a real difference."

title: ‘Catastrophic:’ Eastern Shore advocates share impacts proposed disability cuts may bring
author: Konner Metz
content:
‘Catastrophic:’ Eastern Shore advocates share impacts proposed disability cuts may bring

 February 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 631
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Advocates and service providers on the Eastern Shore are joining Maryland's disability community to call for rollbacks on projected cuts to funding for developmental disability services.Scott Evans, executive director of the Benedictine School in Ridgely, said the near $200 million in cuts to Developmental Disabilities Administration funding outlined in Gov. Wes Moore's proposed budget would be the worst he's seen in his 25-year career.
"Bottom line, these proposed cuts of close to $200 million in state funds would be catastrophic to the community service providers, as well as the people we support and our employees," Evans said. "It would literally set us back years in funding."
The proposed cuts come as the state faces a near $3 billion deficit. Some advocates from the Eastern Shore note they could reduce the choices available for families and people with disabilities.
Jonathon Rondeau, president and CEO of The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, says families and people with developmental disabilities on the Eastern Shore already have a limited number of options.
"There are less agencies providing services for people with disabilities on the Shore," Rondeau said. "So if there is instability in the system, it can potentially reduce choice for people with disabilities."
Evans echoed the same sentiment, and added that the cuts could hurt Benedictine's ability to stay competitive when hiring employees. In recent years, the nonprofit school and service provider has raised wages in an attempt to attract quality employees.
"All that has been an investment we've made because of the funding that we have received," Evans said. "Now to wipe that funding out basically overnight means that we're stuck in a holding pattern."
THE CUTSIn Moore's budget proposal, his office notes that in addition to the $1.3 billion set for the Developmental Disabilities Administration in fiscal year 2026, the state will "better leverage federal funding and align Maryland's program more closely with federal guidance and practices across other states."
Evans says it's not clear how DDA would implement the cuts, though his team at Benedictine team is working to crunch the numbers. Evans said it would cost the school hundreds of thousands of dollars of funding at the very least.
Specific cuts that worry advocates include reductions in "dedicated hours" funding for those in community living programs, as well as a $14.5 million blow to self-directed services funding.
"Someone who is in their late 60s and retired and chooses to stay home every day rather than going to a day program won't necessarily have that choice anymore," Rondeau said regarding the dedicated hours cuts. "There won't be the funding available for that. It'll be difficult for providers such as The Arc to support someone who may have significant health issues and need to go to the doctors."
Karenna Jones of Salisbury worries that cuts to self-directed services will impact the ability for her family to take care of her 26-year-old son, Kenneth, who has a traumatic brain injury and lives at home.
Jones says as long as she lives, she "would never put (her) kid in a provider home." But large cuts in funding may leave her with no choice.
"We might be forced to do that," Jones said. "It's not fair."
RALLY IN ANNAPOLISWith the uncertainty swirling, hundreds packed Lawyers Mall in Annapolis Monday night, protesting for legislators to reject the proposed cuts. Leaders at the Benedictine School and The Arc Central Chesapeake Region attended, as did Jones.
"I'm always amazed at how quickly the folks within the disability community can rally around a cause, and a cause that means so much to them," Evans said. "And also, to some extent, the positive response we've gotten from legislators about these cuts."
Jones said the rally — organized with just three days notice by a developmental disability coalition — was inspiring and beautiful.
"We were saying, 'Save our DDA services. Save it. Don't leave us behind,'" Jones said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on proposed budget cuts affecting developmental disability services, highlighting their impact on healthcare access, support systems, and quality of life for individuals with disabilities. While related to public policy, the core issue revolves around healthcare services and their funding, making 'Health' the most appropriate category.

title: Region's hospitals see seasonal patient spikes
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Region's hospitals see seasonal patient spikes

 February 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 873
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The dreaded season of illness has been hovering over local residents as the new year has progressed. Local health officials have confirmed that Maryland is currently seeing an increase in hospitalizations, which have been linked to respiratory viruses like COVID-19, influenza and RSV."We are surging by greater than 20% volume on any given day," Dr. Maxwell Ginsburg, University of Maryland Charles Regional Medical Center's chairman of the emergency medicine department, told Southern Maryland News. "This includes emergency medical services arrivals and patient walk-ins. We are also seeing an increase in acuity, which essentially means that we are not only seeing more patients, but also sicker patients."
The doctor continued, "This results in more admissions and/or transfers, which in turn results in more resource utilization throughout the whole hospital. We are consistently focused on supporting the continued flow of patients and make every attempt to see everyone as soon as possible."
"Every hospital is struggling," said Larisa Goganzer, senior vice president for operations at CalvertHealth Medical Center, who explained the spike is something almost predictable and likely a result of traditional holiday socializing, which often involves travel and then is brought back home and into schools when the season ends.
"It should start to taper off in the next couple of weeks," Goganzer told Southern Maryland News last week.
"Influenza and norovirus have had an incredible surge this winter season," Ginsburg said. "We are seeing an unprecedented number of patients with complaints consistent with one or the other viruses. With regards to norovirus, the good news is that most people just need some symptomatic treatment — for example, pain medicine, nausea medicine and some IV fluids — and they feel much better and go home. The majority of our patients with the flu require the same treatment, however, we are seeing that those who did not get a flu shot have much worse and significant symptoms, sometimes resulting in admissions for more acute long-term care."
ALERT CODESThere is communication and coordination among hospitals and emergency medical crews and the information is available to the public via the internet.
"We work on the flow of patients through the building," Goganzer said, adding that since Christmas, CalvertHealth has been between yellow and red codes.
According to Maryland's Hospital Alert Tracking System, code yellow "is initiated because the [hospital's] emergency department is experiencing a temporary, overwhelming overload" which can compromise the safety of managing patients classified as priority 2 and priority 3.
Goganzer said those patients in those priority areas "may experience longer wait times."
A code red means a hospital has no electrocardiogram-monitored beds available.
"Red is when all of our beds are in use, we are already at full capacity," Goganzer said. Regardless, "Our emergency room is always open."
The code alert system, Goganzer said, "helps ambulances know where to take patients."
"We have several emergency code names that are called overhead to alert staff and security that there is a threat, an emergency or incoming concern," Ginsburg said of the system used within the La Plata hospital. "For example, 'code blue Room 2512" would mean that there is a respiratory emergency in room 2512, or 'code SW,' which means there is severe weather incoming or 'code red,' which means there is a fire. Each code has a unique meaning and alerts the appropriate teams into action."
In a letter to a St. Mary's County resident from that county's health department, a copy of which was forwarded to Southern Maryland News by the letter-writer, department officials attempted to allay concerns about the information from the alert system.
"The hospital alert you referenced is intended for EMS crews," the health department letter stated. "To our understanding, they are not intended to guide the general public in making a decision to use the emergency department as a walk-in. There are many factors that influence the hospital's status, including the availability of beds and staffing, as well as how the hospital may be receiving or sending patients from and to other hospitals in their system. These status levels and contributing factors may fluctuate throughout the day."
{h2 style="text-align: center "}GOING TO ER{/h2}
The Maryland Hospital Association advises citizens "life-threatening or conditions requiring immediate attention are prioritized in emergency rooms."
Those conditions include difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, chest or upper belly pain or pressure lasting two minutes or more, fainting, sudden dizziness, weakness, changes in vision, confusion or changes in mental status, any sudden or severe pain, uncontrolled bleeding, severe or persistent vomiting or diarrhea, coughing or vomiting blood, suicidal or homicidal feelings, difficulty speaking, or numbness or weakness in any part of your body, unusual belly pain, poisoning, drug overdose, loss of consciousness, major burn, spinal cord, head, or brain injury, severe allergic reaction, a fast heartbeat (more than 120 to 150 beats per minute) at rest, especially if associated with shortness of breath or feeling faint, a broken bone with skin protruding through the skin and drowning.
The state hospital association advises for "routine illnesses," individuals should go to their primary care provider or access "tele-health."
For treatment of non-life-threatening injuries, individuals should visit an urgent care center.
"That's the place to go," Goganzer said of the urgent care centers located throughout the region. She added, however, that many of those facilities have experienced longer waits.
To visit the Maryland Hospital Association website, go to mhaonline.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on hospital patient surges due to respiratory viruses, healthcare system capacity, and public health advisories. While Public Safety and Local Life have some tangential relevance, the core subject is clearly health-related.

 CHESTERTOWN — The Laboratory Services Department at University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Chestertown is now home to two new chemistry analyzers, made possible by more than $300,000 in funding provided by the Chester River Health Foundation.
