title: Truth is written in stone
author: Staff Writer
content:
Truth is written in stone

 February 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 388
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Walking through the Christ Church Episcopal Cemetery in the heart of St. Michaels, you might notice something that we don't see very often: tiny tombstones.A daughter who lived two weeks before passing in 1901. A brother and sister, neither of whom made it to their first birthday. Three-year-olds, 9-year-olds, 11-year olds. For most of human history, high rates of infant and childhood mortality was a fact of life.
There is one specific reason why we don't see tiny tombstones in modern cemeteries: vaccines.
In 1938, Max Theiler developed the first yellow fever vaccine. In 1939, Pearl Kendrick and Grace Eldering proved the effectiveness of the pertussis vaccine. In 1945, Jonas Salk developed the first influenza vaccine and then set his sights on polio in the 1950s.
Salk tested his first polio vaccine on himself. In 1961, John Enders developed a measles vaccine that was 100% effective. In 1967, the World Health Organization began its campaign to eradicate smallpox. Smallpox was declared extinct in 1980.
Over the last half century, vaccinations for 14 common childhood diseases have reduced global infant mortality by 40%. 154 million people, 101 million of whom were infants, are alive today thanks to safe, effective vaccines. The measles vaccine, alone, is responsible for 60% of those lives saved. By almost any measure, the advent of mass vaccinations is the single greatest public health victory in modern medicine.
In the 75 years prior to the development of the polio vaccine, nine children under the age of 13 were buried in the Christ Church Cemetery. In the 75 years after, there was only one.
We are entering a dangerous new era in public health as vaccine conspiracists use fear to deprive children of access to the most effective medical intervention ever created. In Texas, 22 children were infected with measles this month. In American Samoa, a 2019 outbreak left 61 children dead. The island ran out of child-sized coffins.
The elevation of prominent vaccine-denier Robert Kennedy Jr. to the highest public health office sets us on a dangerous path toward new epidemics of old diseases. We can't allow the voices of reason, hard-won experience, community and civic duty be drowned out by fear mongers. All you have to do is walk through any historic cemetery on the Eastern Shore to see that the truth about vaccines is written in stone.
ANDREW D. THALER
St. Michaels 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on vaccines, their historical impact on reducing infant mortality, and current public health challenges related to vaccine hesitancy. While it touches on societal implications, the core subject is medical advancements and public health outcomes.

title: Green ribbon has an incredible story behind it
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Green ribbon has an incredible story behind it

 February 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 628
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Next month is National Kidney Month.According to information posted on the National Kidney Foundation website, 37 million adults in America have chronic kidney disease.
Ninety percent don't know they have it.
Approximately 750,000 individuals have irreversible kidney failure that requires regular dialysis or a kidney transplant just to survive.
Almost 100,000 of those critically ill individuals are on transplant waitlists.
The average wait times for a transplant range from three to seven years depending upon where the patient lives.
For some, that wait is ultimately futile.
The Kidney Foundation reports that only one in five on the waitlist receive a kidney transplant every year and every day an average of 10 people who need a kidney transplant die.
Until recently, I had no more than a vague awareness of the tremendous need for kidney donors.
The catalyst for learning more about this matter resulted from a chance encounter at a recent meet and greet event.
While chatting with another event attendee, I noticed she was wearing one of the ubiquitous "ribbon pins" that are used by many to express support for countless causes.
The color of her ribbon was green.
I had never seen that color before, so I asked her about it.
She smiled and said quietly, "I'm an organ donor. I donated one of my kidneys."
I told her I knew two individuals who were kidney transplant recipients, but never met a live-organ donor.
I asked her if she donated it to an immediate family member, a relative, a close friend or someone she knew.
Her unexpected reply shocked me.
She said, " I have no idea who received it. I never asked, and they never told me. All I know is someone desperately needed lifesaving help, and I wanted to provide it."
I finally recovered enough to state the obvious — her selfless actions were a wonderful thing for her to do.
It was much more than wonderful thing to do but at that time more appropriate words escaped me.
I finally followed up with telling her I was glad I saw and asked about her ribbon.
She smiled again and said, ''I too am glad you saw it and asked about it. I don't wear it for recognition or compliments. I wear it as a way to raise awareness of how important it is to be a live organ donor and the wonderful lifelong feeling it provides on making a real difference in this world."
Before we went our separate ways, she said thank you for listening and learning more about this cause.
I have not seen her or talked to her again, nor do I know who she is.
I will never forget her and her story.
I have since learned that green ribbons are not just for live kidney donors.
They can be worn by anyone as a symbol of support for those giving hope and sharing life through organ, eye and tissue donations.
I realize now, the best way to honor the green ribbon wearer I met is to share her story in this commentary.
I know recognizing her by name is not possible nor is it the proper thing to do.
She already told me she was not a seeking recognition or compliments for her compassion and extraordinary gift.
This commentary is not a call to action to become a live organ donor. I have no doubt I never will and respect all those who choose not to do so.
My hope is this commentary will help advance her goal of raising awareness on the need for live organ donors and the wonderful feeling it provided her in making a real difference in this world.
All of us can do that by simply remembering and perhaps even telling her story to others.
We can also watch for those wearing green ribbons.
When we do see them, I suggest we take a minute to listen to their unique story, whatever it may be. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on kidney disease statistics, organ donation awareness, and personal stories related to health advocacy. While it mentions a local event, the core subject is health-related awareness and education about organ donation.

title: Maryland stories: Hallo Tallow brings healthy skin, hair, lips to you
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
Maryland stories: Hallo Tallow brings healthy skin, hair, lips to you

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 286
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the quiet of her Elkton-area kitchen, Jessica Cook has been whipping up a bowl of something creamy and fluffy.But don't expect her to lick the beaters when she's done.
Instead, Cook will load the mixture into bakery piping bags, pipe the mixture into petite glass jars and affix her signature "Hallo Tallow" labels.
Hallo Tallow is Cook's chemical-free line of health and beauty care items for skin and lips.
"I started making it for my son," Cook said, adding she was not a fan of giving her child steroids for a skin condition. She did some research and found out about beef tallow.
"When you hear 'beef fat'; you think ewww," Cook said. However, after two days in the crock pot, it loses its pungent fragrance. Cook begins the whipping process, adding fragrances, castor oil, jojoba oil raw honey or beeswax depending on the recipe.
"I started by giving it to family and friends and then word got out," Cook said. She came up with "Hallo Tallow" to playfully give her product that 'come hither' persona.
"It was like, 'Where have you been all my life'?" Cook said, laughing. Hallo Tallow has made her son's skin condition just about disappear.
Cook uses the dry rendering procedure to turn five pounds of beef fat — purchased from Rumbleway Farms in Conowingo — into four cups of body lotion or lip balm or other luxurious products. While she offers unscented lines, Cook said her new favorite scent is Orange Dreamsicle. There's rose, lavender, peppermint, frankincense and other scents, some of which change seasonally.
Jars of face and body balms are $20. Whipped jars are $25 and tubes of lip balm are $4 each. Go to the Hallo Tallow Facebook page to shop and order. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a natural health product (Hallo Tallow) designed for skin and lip care, emphasizing its chemical-free composition and health benefits. While there is a business aspect, the primary emphasis is on health and wellness.

title: Maryland spent big on youth mental health — but then the budget crisis hit
author: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service
content:
Maryland spent big on youth mental health — but then the budget crisis hit

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tthe new statewide youth mental health program supported behavioral health services for more than 58,000 students in its first eight months of operations from March through October 2024. Four out of every five of Maryland public schools received aid for mental health services under the state's effort.But as the General Assembly moved to balance Maryland's fiscal 2025 budget last spring, lawmakers cut funding for the state's fledgling youth mental health program from Gov. Wes Moore's recommended $110 million to $40 million.
With the state's fiscal problems deepening, Moore is recommending the state allocate $40 million annually through 2030 to a program he once suggested should get $130 million a year starting in fiscal 2026.
Meagan Pantelis, a clinical social worker at Thrive Behavioral Health, said the proposed cuts would decimate services for students that, in many cases, are just getting off the ground.
"Whenever I found out about that proposed cut, the very first thing that came to mind is that Gov. Moore is wanting to balance a budget on the backs of our children," Pantelis said. "I just find that to be just egregious. I mean, why are our children the population that we are targeting? Why are they not the population that we want to build up and support?"
Moore, however, has stressed the state must act to close a structural $3 billion budget gap driven in part by the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the 10-year, multibillion-dollar education reform plan that created the youth mental health program.
"We only have difficult decisions ahead," Moore said in his State of the State address in early February. "We must close this $3 billion budget gap."
The mental health crisisDuring the 2022-23 school year, over a quarter of Maryland high school students reported their mental health was not good at most or all times, according to a Maryland Department of Health survey.
The percentage was only slightly lower for middle school students, with 22% reporting their mental health was not good at most or all times.
"We all know generally that there's a mental health crisis," said Lorianne Moss, the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission program manager. "So as sort of the preamble to our first call for proposals, we laid out some data."
That data, from the Centers for Disease Control, showed 40% of high school students experience persistent feelings of sadness or hopelessness. Citing such statistics, the consortium urged mental health programs and nonprofits across the state to apply for funds.
Applicants requested a total of $380 million in grants, said Mark Luckner, executive director of the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission, which oversees the consortium. That's more than three times what the consortium had to allocate.
Nevertheless, the state funded mental health service providers in every county.
Preventing youth suicide is one of the consortium's key goals, said Dr. John Campo, director of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. Sixteen of the consortium's 129 grants so far focus on suicide prevention.
Suicide is the second-leading cause of death for people ages 10-14 and third for people ages 15-24, according to the most recent CDC data.
"Suicide kills more young people in that age group than cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, respiratory illnesses, infections of all kinds, meningitis, pneumonia, HIV, COVID — the whole nine yards," Campo said. "Add them all together, suicide kills more people than all those things combined."
In Maryland, the teen suicide rate increased by more than a third from 2014 to 2022. Campo said the state's health care system has been ill-equipped to deal with that increase.
"Mental health crisis isn't a priority in most emergency departments," Campo said.
Campo is one of the co-chairs of the consortium's best practices subcommittee, a group that developed a list of evidence-based mental health practices for grantees to implement.
Each program targets a different facet of the mental health crisis. The responses are also tailored to the varying levels of severity of the mental health conditions different age groups experience.
The consortium found through surveys targeted at both students and parents that 90% of students and families were satisfied with the services.
"A lot of these practices have been tested," Campo said. "If regional organizations adopt them and implement them with fidelity, we really do want to believe that there will be positive outcomes associated with it."
From the city to the ShoreThe youth mental health crisis touches all of Maryland, and so does the state's response — but grants are tailored to the vast differences among Maryland's urban, suburban and rural communities.
In Baltimore City, the 11 grants the consortium issued take into account a stigma surrounding mental health services, said Jennifer Cox, director of the University of Maryland School Mental Health Program, which received a $970,000 grant to run a number of programs.
"We think in Baltimore City, we have to be a little bit more creative than just saying, 'Come get help,' " Cox said. "We know we have good things to offer, we just need to find a good way to offer it."
Working with trusted community organizations such as churches and youth centers, the program has been able to reach people who would otherwise not seek out mental health treatment, Cox said.
Services range from in-school counseling from certified clinicians to parent and caregiver education programs.
Meanwhile, the state's efforts on the largely rural Eastern Shore stress increasing access to treatment in a region that's short of professionals to respond to the youth mental health crisis.
According to the October 2024 report, "Investing in Maryland's Behavioral Health Talent," Maryland is nearly 50% short of the mental health workers it needs.
"There's a resounding message of 'we just need more,'" said Beth Anne Dorman, CEO of For All Seasons, a behavioral health and rape crisis center that received a grant to expand its services in Kent County. "We need more."
Caroline County, where two organizations won grants to expand their mental health services, faces the same situation, said Derek Simmons, the county's superintendent of schools.
"We are a rural county that is less wealthy than a lot of parts of the state," said Simmons, co-chair of the consortium's best practices committee. "So access to behavioral health is near and dear, and a real challenge where I'm at."
An uncertain future
If the General Assembly agrees with the funding levels suggested in the governor's budget, programs that just started last year may have to be eliminated, said Del. Eric Ebersole (D-Baltimore County, Howard).
"That group worked in good faith to bring providers online," said Ebersole, a consortium member. "If the government loses them, can you get them back?"
Dan Martin, senior director of public policy at the Mental Health Association of Maryland, said the proposed cut in planned funding comes at a time when youth mental health care is more important than ever.
"At a time when 18% of high school students and 24% of middle school students have seriously considered suicide in the past year, a reduction of this size in school mental health funding could prove disastrous," Martin said.
If the General Assembly approves Moore's budget proposal, the grants distributed by the program in fiscal years 2025 and 2026 combined will be cut 28% from the total amount distributed the prior two years.
Asked for comment, Moore's office stressed the governor's proposed allocation for fiscal year 2026 and beyond is exactly what the General Assembly approved for 2025.
"Gov. Moore is maintaining the current level of funding for the Maryland Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports," wrote a spokesperson from the governor's office. "The Governor strongly supports behavioral health treatment for Maryland's children, and maintaining current levels of funding during the state's budget crisis reflects that commitment."
The Mental Health Association of Maryland is urging action to try to persuade the General Assembly to restore funding to a higher level. The organization is circulating a fact sheet with information on the consortium, the work it's done and what a permanent cut in funding would do to students and schools.
"Use the above information and write an email to your legislators asking them to restore funding to the Community Supports Partnership Fund," the fact sheet said. "Provide testimony (either written or oral or both) opposing the cut" at General Assembly hearings.
And under the "why is funding needed" section, the Mental Health Association fact sheet reads: "Dramatic worsening of the behavioral health of children and youth over the last decade." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland's youth mental health program, funding cuts, and their impact on students, which directly relates to health policy and mental health services. While education institutions are mentioned as delivery channels, the core issue is the health crisis and resource allocation. Public safety and local government are tangential to the primary health-focused narrative.

title: 5 game-changing wellness travel trends to watch in 2025 and beyond
author: Karen Kelly Food Drink Life
content:
5 game-changing wellness travel trends to watch in 2025 and beyond

 March 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Karen Kelly Food Drink Life | Section: Entertainment 
 
 928
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Global Wellness Summit predicts spending on wellness tourism to skyrocket from $830.2 billion in 2023 to more than $1.3 trillion in 2028. Clearly, healthy holistic travel is still a major interest and is growing among older generations. Whether consumers want a yoga retreat, a spa experience on a cruise or a sound bath in the woods, travel companies scramble to accommodate the ever-growing demand for the coming years.Current growing wellness travel trends are as multifaceted as each consumer. However, specific trends are emerging this year, and customers are all too eager to sign up for the experience.
Wellness travel in high demandThe wellness travel industry was a $792.35 billion business in 2023, according to a report from Zion Market Research, which covered markets in North America, Europe, Asia Pacific, Latin America, the Middle East and Africa. The estimated worth from 2024 through 2032 is expected to reach $1.84 trillion.
The same report states that North America will be the leading region during this period. The United States will contribute the most towards this trend due to its high disposable income, availability of multiple travel options, and the ease and availability of online booking. But which trends are consumers leaning towards the most?
According to Conde Nast Traveler, the top five requested wellness travel trends are mental wellness retreats, women's health-focused programs and sleep-focused vacations. Also at the top of the list are digital detox retreats and personalized wellness experiences.
Mental wellnessAs stress grows, people seek out services to help stabilize their mental wellness. Popular wellness retreats that offer services such as neurofitness training and psychedelic-assisted feedback are in increasing demand. These neurofitness programs maximize clients' brain function, helping them reach peak mental performance.
Women's healthWomen feeling the pinch of stress and trauma or even more significant life changes also seek tailored programs that focus specifically on their needs, such as menopause, fertility and even postpartum care. According to a report from Finn Partners, sexual health for women is driving its fair share of this consumer market. Companies bring on gynecologists and hormone experts to guide women further down their road to better health.
Bella Bucchiotti at xoxoBella says, "When I plan a wellness vacation, I'm looking for a place that lets me truly unwind — whether that's soaking in hot springs, indulging in delicious food or just having a moment of quiet away from the daily chaos. As a new mom and business owner, I don't want to come home from a trip feeling like I need a vacation from my vacation. Spending extra on wellness travel is 100% worth it because when you invest in feeling good, everything else in life benefits — your energy, creativity and patience."
Sleep healthConsumers are willing to pay premium prices for a good night's sleep when sleep comes at a premium. Sleep-focused vacations honor the importance of rest and offer services focused on combating insomnia and building better sleep habits. Consumers love using sleep tech gadgets such as trackers, smart beds, sleep pods, earbuds and goggles. However, over time, expected trends will likely evolve from gadgets to services such as circadian medicines and chronotherapies.
Digital detox
One bad habit that consumers are increasingly looking to avoid, to the surprise of no one, is the digital habit. Digital detox retreats offer a reprieve from the increasing concerns over technology addiction. These vacations encourage guests to unplug and engage in mindful activities.
Customized retreatsBeyond those specific trends, people want customization. Personalized wellness programs and experiences offer highly specific wellness journeys where the entire experience is tailored specifically to the individual and their own health goals. With nomadism on the rise, consumers want to stay longer to reap the benefits of customized plans.
Driving markets
According to the same report from Finn Partners, "wellness sabbaticals — described as people taking three weeks or more to focus on their health and wellness while staying connected with work through their smart devices are a growing segment of the overall market." The trend came on the heels of remote work and digital nomadism. Solo travel is likely to be a driving factor overall, according to Forbes. Many companies are training staff to accommodate single travelers and even go so far as to adjust menus and order odd numbers of chairs. This spills heavily into the wellness market as solo travelers also desire wellness journeys.
Alex of Delish Knowledge says, "When booking a cruise, I always look for the availability of healthy meals, preferably vegetarian or vegan options, whenever I travel. As a dietitian, I recommend that clients focus on high-fiber foods the first few days of travel to help offset any GI issues that can arise, especially when traveling overseas. As a bonus, I appreciate it when properties include fitness classes as part of their wellness package; yoga after a long plane flight is a must."
Just relaxIn recent years, the shift in consumer demand towards wellness retreats and experiences has seen a significant boom, with the Global Wellness Summit also predicting wellness tourism to jump to over a trillion in 2028. Travelers increasingly seek experiences that offer relaxation and promote physical, mental and spiritual well-being. The growth in this market is encouraging rapid changes within the travel industry to accommodate the growing demand. Consumers want to rest, relax and return to better health. With this push, the industry will continue to evolve and accommodate wherever it is needed, which is likely to bring change that no one will mind seeing.
Karen Kelly is a nationally syndicated freelance food and travel writer and the founder of Seasonal Cravings. She is a regular contributor to MSN, Yahoo and the Associated Press. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on wellness travel trends, including mental health, women's health, sleep optimization, and personalized wellness experiences. While it mentions economic growth and travel industry adaptations, the core subject is health-focused travel practices and their societal impact.

title: Mid-Shore organizations team up to address veteran mental health
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Mid-Shore organizations team up to address veteran mental health

 March 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 535
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DORCHESTER COUNTY — Those working at Patriot Point know how hard life after the military can be, and they believe the retreat and help from For All Seasons will help save veteran lives.For All Seasons has established a partnership with the Military Bowl that will expand help to veterans at Patriot Point, a military retreat center.
The retreat sits on 294-acres in Dorchester County. The organization provides a relaxing and safe environment for wounded, ill and injured military members, veterans and their families and caregivers.
For All Seasons will provide on-site mental health consulting at retreats that Patriot Point holds.
"We are working very closely with the Military Bowl Foundation," For All Seasons President and Chief Executive Officer Beth Anne Dorman said. "The ultimate partnership is that we will be providing mental health services and support to Patriot Point."
Veteran and Military Support Alliance will also will partner with Patriot Point to bring more of the same veterans and military members to participate in the retreat.
For All Seasons plans to help Patriot Point's retreaters in many different ways that will kick start veterans knowledge of what trauma they may be experiencing.
"We're also working in partnership with therapeutic yoga instructors, we are bringing in certified art therapists," Dorman said. "The idea is to be able to create a safe space for veterans to have conversation, education, to bring in a mental health component, and also provide a beautiful scenery where veterans can connect in small groups and be able to receive wraparound support."
In addition to the mental health component offered by For All Seasons, Patriot Point offers many activities for retreaters to enjoy themselves, including fishing, hunting and a workout room with golf and hunting simulators.
Patriot Point is run by veterans who have experience different forms of post traumatic stress disorder and other mental problems veterans and military members may experience.
Co-General Managers of Patriot Point Will and Stephanie Moon experienced the retreat first-hand. They said Patriot Point helped them as a couple and as individuals.
Will Moon, a Navy Seal veteran, was struggling with life as a civilian. The Moons' couples therapist recommended that he attend a retreat at Patriot Point in January of 2024.
Stephanie Moon, an experienced certified trauma-sensitive yoga instructor and a certified integrative restoration meditation teacher, received a call from the previous general managers of Patriot Point stating they were leaving and wanted someone to take over.
Will and Stephanie drove all the way to Maryland from North Caroline to go see Patriot Point, during the time on the road, they researched many different things about Patriot Point to find out what they were getting themselves into.
"We gave up everything to be here," Will Moon said. "I knew the moment that I drove through the gate, everyone needs some type of therapy in a way, and in this place, it's the peer-to-peer, it's the interactions that you're not alone that people realize, they come here for retreats and then they realize they need help."
Will and Stephanie Moon have been Co-General Managers since Aug. 15.
"Patroit Point is 294 acres, but healing does occur here. Those six days really helped saved my life," Will Moon said.
For All Season and Patriot Point will conduct their first retreat together in late spring. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on mental health support for veterans through partnerships between organizations, highlighting therapeutic services, trauma care, and wellness programs. While 'Public Safety' and 'Local Life' have some relevance, 'Health' directly addresses the core focus on mental health initiatives and veteran wellness.

title: Lawmakers seek to ban gender-affirming medication for those under 18
author: SAHSA ALLEN Capital News Service
content:
Lawmakers seek to ban gender-affirming medication for those under 18

 March 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAHSA ALLEN Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 839
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Lawmakers are considering a bill that would target transgender healthcare for minors — the first time bans on gender-affirming care have been introduced at the state level.The bill, Protect the Kids Act, would prohibit licensed medical professionals from prescribing cross-sex hormone therapy like hormones or hormone blockers. The penalty for both is a felony and imprisonment up to a life sentence.
"We don't let parents neuter their children," Del. Lauren Arikan, the primary bill sponsor, told Capital News Service. "But essentially, that's what these procedures do. They're, in many cases, permanently taking away reproductive abilities of a minor child."
Arikan, who is a Republican representing Harford County, believes providing gender-affirming care to children is "akin to child abuse."
But transgender rights activists think it is necessary to publicly oppose the bill.
"This was the first time that we've had a trans healthcare ban introduced in Maryland," Charlotte Persephone Hoffman, the policy director with Trans Maryland said in testimony at the bill hearing. "It's our job to be there for the trans community."
There are an estimated 8,000 transgender youth ages 13-17 in the state of Maryland, according to the Williams Institute, a research institute based out of the UCLA School of Law.
Gender-affirming medications and surgeries for minors are currently banned in 25 states, with six states making it a felony for medical practitioners to violate the ban. Maryland is one of 14 states that has a safeguard law in place. The Trans Health Equity Act, passed in 2023, requires that Medicaid covers gender-affirming care.
This is not the first time Arikan has introduced a bill dealing with transgender rights. In 2024, she proposed a bill prohibiting health care providers from performing surgeries or engaging in practices on a minor without consent of a parent or guardian. If violated, medical practitioners would be guilty of a misdemeanor, subject to imprisonment between one and three years.
While last year's bill stalled in committee, Arikan's bill this legislative session would ramp up both restrictions and the penalty for violation significantly, a decision made because of further research, said Arikan.
Those who testified had been in the statehouse since Tuesday afternoon for the hearing initially scheduled at 1 pm. But the bill wasn't heard until after 9 pm, so numbers dwindled and those hoping to sit in on the hearing were comfortably scattered in the back of the room. Still, tensions were high and emotional testimony was given from both proponents and opponents of the bill.
Henry Mosley, a physician epidemiologist and professor emeritus at Johns Hopkins University, testified for the bill, telling lawmakers the current state of research leaves too much room for concern about the long term effects of certain therapies.
There are studies proving the short-term relief that hormones can have on gender dysphoria and other mental health conditions, Mosley said.
"However, there are no long-term studies yet," Mosley said. "We don't know what happens after five or 10 years."
Mosley said he also is worried about the personal consequences these decisions have on people.
"There are young adults that are now detransitioning," Mosley said. "They are regretting decisions they made as a child and are making efforts to reverse their gender transition."
The bill also bans children from being put on puberty blockers, a medication that delays the effects of puberty on transgender individuals. If usage is stopped, puberty of the patient's sex assigned at birth will continue.
While there was some bipartisan support with Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes, a Democrat representing Dorchester and Wicomico Counties co-sponsoring the bill, Arikan said she introduced this bill to begin talks in the legislature.
"I just wanted to start the conversation," Arikan said. "I believe that in some period of time, maybe it's 15 years, maybe it's 25 years, we are going to be on the wrong side of history with this issue."
But transgender individuals and activists are adamantly against the bill. Chloe Celeste is 16 years old and said she is the "exact person" the bill targets.
"Since starting gender affirming hormone therapy with the guidance of my doctors and my parents over a year ago I have been more confident, self aware and overall happier than I have ever been in my life," Celeste said. "Anyone who knew me pre-transition can vouch for that."
Celeste referred to the bill as the "so-called Protect the Kids Act" that would force her and other transgender minors off their "life saving medication."
Others testified in support as well. A public school teacher, Alexa Sciuto, discussed the detransitioning rates.
"There is no evidence of a high rate of regret," Sciuto said. "In fact, there is a more demonstrably high rate of regret amongst heterosexual marriages, and we love those."
After Arikan's less drastic bill on transgender care for minors stalled last year without getting a vote, there is little confidence the Protect the Kids Act will pass in the Democrat-dominated legislature.
But those against the bill were upset that it was even introduced in the state.
"I think we're definitely going to see more attacks on trans people in Maryland, especially as the second Trump administration progresses," Hoffman said. "We're definitely seeing conservative voices emboldened." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legislation regarding gender-affirming healthcare for minors, which directly relates to health policy. While it involves legislative action (Local Government), the core subject is medical treatment and healthcare rights. Public Safety is a weaker fit as the bill's primary concern is medical ethics rather than public safety.

title: Maryland lawmakers target tranquilizers behind overdose deaths
author: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service
content:
Maryland lawmakers target tranquilizers behind overdose deaths

 March 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PAUL KIEFER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 968
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — A bipartisan group of lawmakers is attempting to push Maryland's Department of Health to restrict the distribution of two veterinary tranquilizers that play a growing role in the state's overdose crisis.The agency has thus far resisted pressure to add the tranquilizers to the state's list of scheduled drugs — unlike neighboring Delaware and Pennsylvania, where officials have recently scheduled the more common of the two drugs. Both MDH and some drug-user outreach groups argue the state should avoid taking steps that might prompt the illicit drug market to find new, untested substitutes.
In the eyes of some Maryland Republicans, however, MDH's reluctance is a concession to drug dealers. "Their failure to act has cost lives," said Sen. William Folden, a Republican representing Frederick County.
Xylazine, the better-known of the two tranquilizers, has become a staple of the mid-Atlantic's illicit drug supply. According to data from the state's Office of Overdose Response, more than a quarter of the roughly 2,500 Marylanders who died from fatal overdoses in 2021 had xylazine in their system, compared to roughly 17 percent just a year earlier.
Law enforcement first detected the other tranquilizer, medetomidine, in a Maryland drug sample in 2022. In the last quarter of 2024, MDH testing detected medetomidine in just over 8 percent of samples collected.
Many of Maryland's neighbors have reacted to these regional shifts by adding xylazine to their lists of scheduled substances. Scheduled drugs are subject to stricter distribution rules, creating hurdles for those diverting the drugs into the black market. Xylazine and medetomidine aren't classified as controlled substances under federal law. Maryland law delegates that authority to schedule drugs at the state level to MDH.
MDH spokesperson Chase Cook told Capital News Service that, after reviewing the outcomes of scheduling xylazine in neighboring states, his agency determined that the restrictions could do more harm than good.
"Both Pennsylvania and Delaware scheduled xylazine through temporary orders and both are now seeing increases in opioid overdoses with medetomidine," he said. "This follows the iron law of prohibition where, even with alcohol prohibition, more potent substitutes replace the prohibited substance in the illicit supply. Pennsylvania and Delaware are seeing this less than a year after scheduling xylazine."
Though the proliferation of xylazine in Maryland began before the COVID-19 pandemic, this year marks the first time state lawmakers have attempted to restrict access to the drug.
Xylazine became a nearly unavoidable feature of the illicit drug supply during the pandemic, leaving drug users and healthcare providers alike scrambling to adapt. Unsuspecting users frequently lose consciousness, slumping over and losing circulation in their extremities. Frequent xylazine users often develop open sores on their limbs, increasing their risk of infection and amputation.
While both xylazine and medetomidine often appear in powders and counterfeit pills in combination with fentanyl, the tranquilizers — commonly known as 'tranq' — aren't opioids. That means common opioid overdose-reversal drugs like naloxone can't treat a xylazine or medetomidine overdose, although public health agencies still advise administering naloxone to people displaying overdose symptoms as a precaution.
Sarah Laurel, founder and executive director of the Philadelphia harm reduction nonprofit Savage Sisters Recovery, has more experience than most with the grim consequences of xylazine's rise.
But Laurel is also a firm opponent of scheduling the drug.
"It incentivizes the criminal drug market to find more potent, potentially dangerous substances, and then we have to test the drug supply, find out what those substances are and what the negative consequences to users could potentially be," she told CNS.
Like MDH, Laurel argues that the aftermath of Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro's decision to schedule xylazine at the state level in 2023 demonstrated the risks involved in playing cat-and-mouse with new street drugs.
"Now we see the introduction of new things such as very high amounts of lidocaine and tetracaine," she said.
Laurel says her organization now encounters anesthetics like lidocaine when testing street drug vials from Philadelphia more frequently than it encounters xylazine or fentanyl. Samples containing medetomidine are also increasingly common. Once again, her team is rushing to catch up.
But Maryland lawmakers pushing to regulate xylazine and medetomidine argue the General Assembly is morally obligated to limit access to the drugs by whatever means possible.
House Minority Whip Jesse Pippy, a Republican representing Frederick County, is the House sponsor of a bill intended to draw lawmakers' attention to the subject. While Frederick County isn't the epicenter of the state's overdose crisis, the county delegation's ties to law enforcement are a frequent source of legislative inspiration.
The bill would set civil fines for drug distributors who provide xylazine or medetomidine to customers who can't prove that the drugs are for legitimate veterinary uses — namely as a sedative for livestock. Revenues collected from those civil penalties would be spent on the state's overdose prevention programs.
"This is a midway step to where we can say, 'Look, you cannot, other than for veterinary purposes, be giving this stuff out right now,'" he told fellow lawmakers. For now, he added, "there are probably a million different ways to get it out on the street legally."
Folden, the sponsor of a parallel bill in the state Senate and an officer with the Frederick Police Department, underscored that the proposed penalties wouldn't involve jail time. "It is important to emphasize that this bill only creates civil penalties, not criminal," he said. "You want to make them criminal [penalties]? I'm not going to fight that."
The proposals have the backing of the state attorney general's office and faced no vocal opposition in committee hearings. The American Veterinary Medical Association has previously supported scheduling xylazine at the federal level, though the association's Maryland branch did not immediately respond to inquiries about its position on the legislation before the General Assembly.
Folden and other backers maintain that they would prefer to see MDH schedule xylazine and medetomidine. So far, the agency has not testified on this year's proposals. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland lawmakers addressing the public health crisis linked to tranquilizers like xylazine and medetomidine, which contribute to overdose deaths. While there is a legislative component (Local Government) and public safety implications, the core issue revolves around health impacts, drug regulation by the Department of Health, and medical consequences for users. The primary context is a public health emergency rather than law enforcement or government administration.

title: Trump administration sets stage for new pandemic
author: LENA GILL
content:
Trump administration sets stage for new pandemic

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LENA GILL | Section: Columns 
 
 666
 Words 

 Read News Document

 From new avian or bird flu outbreaks on the Eastern Shore to a new Ebola outbreak in Uganda, we need the World Health Organization to help mitigate pandemics and inform the world. We also need the medical detectives of the U.S. Agency for International Development to travel to an Ebola outbreak to do contact tracing to limit the exposure to the surrounding community and the world to this and other deadly diseases.None of this is possible today, as president Trump has withdrawn the U.S. from the WHO and virtually closed down the USAID.
Pulling out of the WHO creates a national security threat. For more than 75 years we have relied on it to protect us. It takes a year to withdraw, but many argue that China will probably try to step in and take it over. It is not clear if the president can withdraw from the WHO without congressional approval.
President Trump also paused the transfer of U.S. funds to the WHO. The U.S. is the largest donor, contributing about 18% of its total funding. The U.S. membership fee of $264 million for year 2024/2025 will not be paid. This violates U.S. law and will certainly be challenged in court.
In addition to the fees, there are voluntary contributions from foundations and other U.S. sources earmarked by the donors for specific purposes such as HIV and AIDS. President George W. Bush's successful PEPFAR progam dating back to 2003 has saved 26 million adults from dying of AIDS, mainly in subSaharan Africa, and 8 million babies from being born with HIV.
The funding has been frozen until March 25. This is the largest global health program dedicated to a single disease.
Polio, tuberculosis and malaria are still on the eradication list, and new viruses such as the Marburg virus, a deadly cousin of Ebola, and mpox have been declared public health emergencies in Africa. With a continuous stream of visitors to and from Africa, it seems impossible to keep any outbreak from not spreading. Viruses do not respect international borders.
Since early January, four flocks of chickens on Maryland's Eastern Shore have tested positive for the avian or bird flu virus. These outbreaks can severely affect Maryland's important poultry industry. Avian flu is often spread by wild birds, so we should not encourage such birds to feed here. Wild, infected birds have been found in Caroline County.
The bird flu in Maryland is of the H5N1 type. In California a new type has been found called the H5N9. One girl in Canada died from the bird flu and 67 farmworkers, that we know of, have been infected around the U.S.
Bird flu has been found in cows milk in California. KFF Health News has just published a report that discusses how 875 herds of cows across 16 states have tested positive for bird flu. This infection in herds of cows started about a year ago, and the Department of Agriculture has been slow to react. It announced in December 2024 its intention to test milk for bird flu nationwide. The virus dries out milk production in dairy cows and the virus now spreads between cows.
We have seen a drop of about 20% in milk production since 2023. Veterinarians are trying to save the cows. Cow hands are being infected with the H5N1 virus but not tested for the virus, partly because the tests are not readily available and partly because the cow hands may be undocumented. A few mutations of the virus could mean that it could be spread between humans. The H5N1 virus can also spread to cats. One such death was reported in Anne Arundel County.
In all of the U.S. about 100 million egg-laying birds were culled since the bird flu started in 2022. No wonder eggs now cost around $5 per dozen on the Eastern Shore or cannot be found on the shelves. Considering the bird virus in milk scare and the 20% reduction in milk produced, the price of a gallon of milk is also expected to rise. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on pandemic preparedness, withdrawal from the WHO, avian flu outbreaks, and health policy impacts. While it mentions national administration actions, the core subject is public health crises and their implications, making 'Health' the primary topic.

title: Building a better future: Ethan's Walk returns to raise money and support
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Building a better future: Ethan's Walk returns to raise money and support

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Events 
 
 482
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Every parent knows their child stands apart from the crowd, but parents Jon and Erin Krisman know their son Ethan really is one-in a million.Ethan is currently a pre-kindergarden student who, as a toddler, was diagnosed with Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva, a rare and disabling genetic condition that turns muscles, tendons, and ligaments into bone, progressively restricting movement.
In addition to this extreme loss of mobility, the formation of extra bone results in many other health complications and debilitating chronic pain.
With less than 1,000 cases of Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva diagnosed worldwide, the walk seeks to raise awareness for the incredibly rare condition and showcase love and support.
Because the condition is so rare, Jon Krisman noted the initial diagnosis "was like stepping into a blackhole," and it was difficult to find others locally going through the same challenges.
Being a parent to any child is never a cakewalk but the Krisman family has had a whole other level of what they have to work through, she said.
"By doing this walk we want them to know that even though we can't fully understand what they're going through and we can't provide the support that other people facing this disease can provide, we're still there for them," said Centreville Elementary School pre-kindergarten special education teacher Katie Coursey.
A 5K in honor of Centreville Elementary School preschooler Ethan Krisman, will once again be held April 27 at 10 a.m at Route 18 Park, Centreville April 27 at 10 a.m.
Kimberly Schultes, committee chair and Centreville Elementary preschool teacher said it has been amazing to see the community's rallying support behind her former student.
"It's really neat to see," she said.
Last year's first Ethan's Walk centered around dressing as a superhero in honor of Ethan who is a daily fighter, an inspiration, and a real-life superhero.
After the tremendous success of last year's fundraiser and morale booster, the Ethan's Walk Committee saw the need to continue to raise awareness for the cause, Schultes said.
With the motto, "Building a better future for kids like me," this year's walk centers around Ethan's favorite toy: Legos.
Ethan is a very smart student who loves building and gluing activities and despite being shy at school, he receives great support from his classmates, Schultes said.
Seeing the visual of a group of people all wearing the same shirt in solidarity is very meaningful, she said.
All proceeds help support the mission critical work of the International FOP Association.
This year's walk promises to be bigger than ever with sponsorship opportunities and really showcase care and fellowship for one of Queen Anne's County's very own, Schultes said.
Anyone who registers for the walk by April 6 is guaranteed a t-shirt, and anyone who donates $100 or more by April 6 will have their name/logo printed on the back of the shirt.
More information about donations and registration can be found at ifopa.salsalabs.org/ethans_walk_2025/index.html.
More information about supporting the Krisman family can be found at ifopa.salsalabs.org/teamcurefop/p/inhonorofethankrisman/index.html. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on raising awareness and funds for Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva, a rare genetic condition, through a community event. While it involves local community efforts and a public event, the primary emphasis is on health advocacy, medical support, and charitable efforts related to a specific health condition.

title: Chesapeake Creative Wellness announces first wellness 5K and arts festival
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Chesapeake Creative Wellness announces first wellness 5K and arts festival

 March 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 237
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — Supporting those with anxiety and Post Traumatic Stress Disorder, Chesapeake Creative Wellness's first Creative Strides Music and Arts Festival will be held from noon to 6 p.m. on April 5 at 511 Pintail Point Farm Lane in Queenstown.According to Darrin Pruitt who runs the charity, Chesapeake Creative Wellness uses music and the arts to help those with PTSD and anxiety related issues.
As a Navy veteran, Pruitt seeks to make a difference for those struggling in the community everyday and through a peer counseling model, anyone can find a safe place to hang out and learn music and the arts to help cope with symptoms.
"We wanted to do something fun to raise awareness in our community," Pruitt said, 19% of Americans live with anxiety and another 6% are struggling with Post Traumatic Stress, and Pintail Point is a beautiful location perfect for a mental health day."
A 5K is a great community event that can be participated equally as an individual or as a team, and the music and arts festival makes it a whole day of enjoying and resetting and stepping away from the individual issues that we each might be struggling with, he said.
Ticket sales and event support benefits Chesapeake Creative Wellness, a nonprofit of of Chesapeake Charities.
Located at 31A Creamery Lane in Easton, more information about Chesapeake Creative Wellness programs, lessons, and events as well as 5K registration can be found at mycreativewellness.org.

title: Doctors, nurses reflect on COVID-19 pandemic five years later
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Doctors, nurses reflect on COVID-19 pandemic five years later

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 774
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — For the first year and a half of the COVID-19 pandemic, University of Maryland Shore Regional Health infectious disease specialist Dr. Rosa Mateo took care of just about every COVID-19 patient brought to the Shore Medical Center at Easton."I lived in the hospital," said Mateo, who is also Shore Regional Health's medical director for infection prevention and control.
Mateo remembers working long hours, sitting in meetings to coordinate efforts and the constant communication as new information about the virus necessitated changes in practice. No one in the hospital had time to rest, she said.
"Physicians are trained to be on call all the time and not sleep," she said, laughing. "But I would lie if I said that I didn't feel burned out."
As the only infectious disease specialist within Shore Regional Health, Mateo became the person at the hospital everyone was looking to for guidance. Suddenly everyone knew her name, she said.
Mateo said she always tried to look calm for patients and staff.
"Because how do I ask them to keep doing it if I can't do it?" she asked.
Mateo said the nurses at the hospital in Easton were working even more hours than she was. She said they stepped up and "learned to do everything."
And it wasn't just nurses.
Dr. Peyman Otmishi, a pulmonologist, critical care specialist and president of medical staff with Shore Regional Health, said the pandemic affected everyone in the health care industry, from first responders to custodians.
"Work was treacherous," he said.
For Jess Caraker and Emma Zonetti, who were clinical coordinators in the intensive care and telemetry units, respectively, at the hospital in Easton, the pandemic meant they spent a lot more time on the floor helping and making sure their nurses had everything they needed to take care of patients.
Zonetti said she was often pulled where she was needed.
"And pulled to the ICU a lot too because I worked (the) night shift where there were minimal resources," she said.
Zonetti said the experience was stressful and intimidating.
"But I knew as a senior staff member that I needed to step up and be a role model for my unit and other members of the organization that were here to take care of our patients and do the best possible," she said.
With young children at home, both Zonetti and Caraker made decisions during the pandemic to separate from their families in order to protect them. For Zonetti, an incident that resulted in her exposure to the virus led her to separate from her family — including her 4-month-old — for two weeks.
For Caraker, after taking care of her first COVID-19 patient, she and her husband made the decision that she would temporarily live away from him and their three kids. This lasted for the first three months of the pandemic, she said.
"That was quite honestly the hardest thing I've ever done," she said.
Although Shore Regional Health respiratory therapist Lisa Pierson had to remain distant from her family, her team at the hospital became her family. They checked in on each other, she said.
"We would look at each other walking down the hall and say, 'Are you OK? How are you doing?'" Pierson recalled.
Pierson has noticed health care workers are still tired since the pandemic. She said there hasn't been any real downtime over the last five years.
"After COVID, we all needed a tropical vacation," she said.
Currently, the nation is experiencing a nursing shortage. According to the Maryland Hospital Association and GlobalData, which released projections in June 2022, the state is expected to meet just 80% of its demand for nurses by 2035.
Mateo said there was a nursing shortage before the COVID-19 pandemic and the pandemic exacerbated it.
"It was was just not a good combination," she said.
On the other side of the coin, Mateo considers telemedicine to be one good thing that has come out of the pandemic.
"And it is, I think, one of the best things that could have happened because even now you have patients in the nursing home that they cannot come to me because of transportation issues," she said. "And I just put them through telemedicine. So for me, now there is no reason why I could not see a patient."
Mateo said that since the COVID-19 pandemic, there are still not many infectious disease specialists in hospitals. She attributes this to the many years of training it takes to become an infectious disease specialist.
"There are not a lot of people that go into infectious diseases, unfortunately," she said. "During the pandemic, we suddenly became big."
Even still, Mateo remains the only infectious disease specialist covering five counties in the Shore Regional Health system.
"And it's the same everywhere you go," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on healthcare workers' experiences during the COVID-19 pandemic, including challenges faced by medical professionals, nursing shortages, and telemedicine advancements. These directly relate to the Health topic. While Public Safety could marginally apply due to pandemic response, the primary focus is on healthcare delivery and medical workforce issues.

title: From crisis to change: COVID-19’s enduring mark on the Eastern Shore
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
From crisis to change: COVID-19’s enduring mark on the Eastern Shore

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 642
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Five years after the COVID-19 pandemic reached the Eastern Shore, its impact lingers in ways both visible and unseen. The empty streets, masked faces, and social distancing markers have faded, but the profound shifts in health care, worship, business and daily life remain.Emma Zonetti never expected the pandemic to reach her tight-knit community.
"I remember being in church, actually. My husband's mom told me that this was happening," said Zonetti, now a senior clinical nurse with University of Maryland Shore Regional Health. "And I went, 'Oh, it's nothing to worry about. It's just another virus.' And then quickly did we learn that it was way more than that."
Zonetti, who was a clinical coordinator in the telemetry unit at the Shore Medical Center at Easton during the height of the crisis, recalled the stark reality that unfolded as cases surged.
"It certainly impacted us far larger than I could ever anticipate," she said.
Late in January 2020, hospitals began screening for the virus as patients arrived in emergency rooms.
By March, State Superintendent of Schools Dr. Karen Salmon ordered a closure of schools — a temporary order that extended well into 2021, much longer than anyone anticipated.
Beaches and boardwalks closed. And by April, the number of positive cases surged and mask orders ensued.
COMMUNITY BLINDSIDEDThe first confirmed case of COVID-19 on the Eastern Shore was reported in Talbot County on March 16, 2020. Since then, there have been 8,056 confirmed cases in the county and more than 40,000 across the Mid-Shore. The virus claimed the lives of 592 Mid-Shore residents.
For religious communities, the impact was swift and disruptive. Pastor Doug Morley of Greater Impact Church in Greensboro said the closure of worship spaces came at a critical time for his newly merged congregation.
"Building on the momentum of coming together for greater Kingdom impact in 2019 and gearing up for what would potentially be one of our highest attended worship experiences on Easter Sunday (April 12, 2020), we were definitely blindsided by the mandated closure of all religious gatherings," Morley said.
Church leaders scrambled to adapt, turning to Facebook Live for virtual worship and launching a "drive-in" service using a tractor-trailer bed as a stage and an FM transmitter to broadcast services to parked cars.
"It forced us to think outside the four walls of the church," Morley said. "That shift in approach has remained with us."
Even after indoor services resumed, Morley noted, worship attendance has not yet returned to pre-pandemic levels. While some members embraced online services, others simply fell out of the habit.
LASTING LEGACYWhen Maryland lifted its COVID-19 state of emergency on July 1, 2021, many expected a swift return to normalcy. In some ways, that happened — travel resumed, restaurants filled and hugs replaced distanced greetings. But the pandemic left lasting imprints on the Eastern Shore.
Telehealth became commonplace. Remote work grew. Businesses closed, moved or downsized. Schools and universities permanently integrated virtual options. Many delayed retirement. Awareness of mental health surged as loneliness and isolation persisted.
The pandemic reshaped our priorities, forcing people to rethink work, education and social connection. Some changes were temporary, but others — like digital access and hybrid work models — are likely here to stay.
While it has taken a few years to get back to some semblance of normalcy, the impact of COVID-19 upon regular worship attendance is still evident.
"We have not returned to pre-pandemic numbers, and we still have individuals and families who choose to worship online rather than in-person," Morely said. "A few who once attended regularly have gotten out of the habit and find it difficult to return on a consistent basis."
As the Eastern Shore reflects on the past five years, the region has found resilience in adversity. Communities innovated, businesses adapted and individuals discovered new ways to connect. The pandemic may have left its mark, but so, too, did the spirit of perseverance that defines the Shore. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the long-term societal impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, including healthcare system changes, mental health awareness, and community adaptations. While other topics like Education and Business/Economy are mentioned, the central theme revolves around health-related consequences and societal transformations stemming from the health crisis.

title: Long COVID derails boy's life for three years
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Long COVID derails boy's life for three years

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 783
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Keeping good grades — much less straight As — your freshman year of high school is an accomplishment for anyone.But when it comes to 15-year-old Dylan Smith, those good grades are a testament to Smith's perseverance.
For about three years, Dylan was too sick to attend school. After getting COVID-19 in January 2022, Smith developed long COVID.
At 12 years old, Dylan lost the ability to do anything for himself. Over time, he could no longer eat without a feeding tube or walk. He developed non-epileptic seizures, caused by trauma and pain.
"My pain got worse every day," he said. "It kind of felt like my bones were breaking every second."
There were two months where he stopped talking.
"And it's not that he didn't want to talk," said his mom, Stacey Smith. "He physically couldn't."
As his physical pain grew, Dylan struggled with his mental health. He said he was in a "dark place."
"I'd felt so bad for my sickness, and I'd felt like I'd taken time away from my parents," he said. "I kind of felt like it was my fault."
Stacey Smith said her son would have violent rages and would be in so much pain that his brain would "disassociate from his body."
"There were times when he didn't want to live anymore," she said, adding that she and her husband, Michael Smith, weren't aware of those thoughts until later. "But that was where his mindset was."
Initially having COVID-19 for two weeks in 2022, Dylan started to feel better. But a few weeks later, he began getting cold symptoms that got progressively worse.
At first, doctors thought it might be pneumonia. But as Smith's symptoms continued, doctors started to consider the possibility that it was long COVID.
"The idea of long COVID was so new at that point that they didn't know if it could be (long COVID) or it was just a possibility since nothing else was working," Dylan said.
When they went to a COVID clinic in Baltimore that June, the doctors knew it was long COVID, Stacey Smith said.
The Smith family tried everything to get Dylan back in good health, from medication to a monthlong rehabilitation program to natural supplements.
"And nothing worked," Stacey Smith said.
After the rehabilitation program, Dylan was in an even worse state than when he entered the program, his mom said.
"It was just a feeling of hopelessness," said Michael Smith, Dylan's father. "You just keep going from what seems to be the best idea to the next idea when that one's not the right one."
University of Maryland Shore Regional Health infectious disease specialist Dr. Rosa Mateo remembers patients coming to her at the beginning of the pandemic who had recently had COVID-19 and were presenting symptoms of cough, fatigue and brain fog. At the time, doctors didn't know it was long COVID.
"Of course this is five years ago," she said. "We know more. But we don't know enough."
It wasn't until the Smiths traveled to the Spero Clinic in Arkansas for treatment last June that Dylan was able to get better. Stacey Smith said the clinic, which focuses on stimulating the vagus nerve to reset the nervous system, offers a variety of therapies that are not "typical Western medicine."
The Smiths spent four months at the clinic. During a lunch break to Chick-fil-A their eighth week there, Dylan Smith gained back his ability to move his torso and chest. A minute later, while they were in the drive-thru, he was able to move his legs, he said.
"I said, 'Well, wait a minute, if I can move everything, why not just try and stand up?'" he remembered asking. "So I stood up in the van in the Chick-fil-A parking lot."
Stacey Smith remembers screaming out of excitement seeing her son walk again.
When Dylan returned from the clinic in October in good health, it was straight to the books.
"Once I got better and we came home from Arkansas, I really did have to grind out school those couple months before getting back to really understand everything because I had been gone for three years," he said, adding that he had help from a retired teacher. "It was mainly math. I really did (learn) three years of math in like three months."
Jan. 27 was Dylan Smith's first day back at school. Since going back to school, he's maintained good grades. Some of his favorite classes are English and world history.
As he sets his sights on the future, Dylan said he looks forward to taking drivers education this summer and playing on his school's soccer team next year.
For others experiencing long COVID, he advised they should not give up hope, even when things feel hopeless.
"There is a life worth living," he said. "You will gain that life back." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Dylan Smith's prolonged health struggle with long COVID, detailing medical symptoms, treatments, and recovery. While education is mentioned due to his school absence, the core narrative revolves around health challenges and medical interventions.

title: For All Seasons partners for suicide intervention
author: Staff Writer
content:
For All Seasons partners for suicide intervention

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Life 
 
 343
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For All Seasons' Center for Learning is partnering with Santé Eastern Shore to offer LivingWorks ASIST (Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training) on April 7 and 8 from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. each day at Anchor Church in Easton.This two-day in-person workshop includes interactive learning, hands-on practice, and real-world application exercises to learn the skills to provide a suicide first-aid intervention for someone who has thoughts of suicide. The workshop is designed for all caregivers (anyone over age 15 in a position of trust), including mental health professionals, nurses, physicians, pharmacists, teachers, counselors, youth workers, police and correctional staff, school support staff, clergy, and community volunteers.
Participants will learn how to recognize when someone may be thinking about suicide and take steps to support them, to develop a safety plan to keep someone safe for now and connect them with further help; talk openly about personal and community attitudes and suicide, build confidence and capacity in providing suicide first-aid, understand how attitudes about suicide influence intervention approaches and gain insights into community resources and support networks to sustain long-term suicide prevention efforts.
The training will include breakfast, lunch and snacks each day, as well as all the necessary materials. Participating clinicians will receive 12 Category I CEUs issued by For All Seasons, an approved continuing education provider for Maryland social workers and professional counselors.
The registration fee of $350 is due at the time of enrollment. All registrations are due no later than March 31 at forallseasonsinc.lpages.co/asist-training-2025/. For questions, contact Kelsey Trumbull-Meyers at CenterForLearning@forallseasonsinc.org. Because this training is grant-funded, For All Seasons is required to report program outcomes. Participants will be asked to complete multiple-choice surveys before the training begins and after the training's completion.
For All Seasons provides the highest quality mental health and victim services to children, adults, and families across the Mid-Shore and throughout Maryland. Services are offered in both English and Spanish and include therapy, psychiatry, victim advocacy, 24-hour crisis hotlines, outreach, and community education. For information about For All Seasons walk-in hours, contact For All Seasons at 410-822-1018 or visit ForAllSeasonsInc.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
