llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on PTSD awareness, veteran support, and treatment initiatives, which directly relate to health advocacy. While public safety and local government aspects are mentioned (e.g., courts, funding), the core theme centers on mental health awareness and veteran care.

title: Mental Health Awareness is bigger than May, expert says
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Mental Health Awareness is bigger than May, expert says

 May 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 418
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Throughout the world, Mental Health Awareness Month is observed in May. But Beth Anne Dorman, president and CEO of For All Seasons, believes it is important to observe and be aware of mental health year-round."While paying attention to it in the month of May is important, it's a 365-day-a-year issue, and continuing to create safe spaces for people to say, 'I'm not doing okay,' for us as individuals to reach out and be able to say, 'I'm not doing okay.' We will be a stronger community if everyone has access to service," she said.
Being aware of mental health goes way deeper than just knowing mental health issues exist, Dorman said. Being able to identify mental health issues and being able to help point friends and family in the right direction if they may be experiencing a mental health episode are vital.
Signs can be someone showing up differently, someone being more stressed, or someone who is typically outgoing being more introverted. According to Dorman, it is important to realize mental health issues show up in different ways for different people.
"When we think about mental health with grief, when you think about mental health as it's related to substance abuse and everyday stressors that we are going through, it impacts everyone differently," Dorman said.
According to Dorman, after identifying a mental health issue, the next step that can be taken is identifying what support or help a person may need.
"The first thing is to offer support, showing that you care and that you're there to listen without judgment and offer words of encouragement," Dorman said. "Sometimes somebody just needs someone to listen. Other times, it's going to be when you're listening, there may be additional health that's needed."
There could be some instances when the person may not want to receive help just yet or doesn't think they need help. According to Dorman, there are resources available for helping an individual who may not think they need service.
"It's important to remember that if someone is not ready to seek services, it may be going back and revisiting the conversation several times over," Dorman said. "What we have to remember is that it is an individual's decision to seek help and we have to create a safe space for ourselves to kind of put some boundaries and parameters around I've done as much as I can."
Anyone experiencing a mental health episode can call 988, the Suicide and Crisis Lifeline.
For more information on services provided by For All Seasons, visit forallseasonsinc.org/. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on mental health awareness, support systems, and resources for individuals experiencing mental health challenges. While Public Safety relates to the crisis hotline (988), the primary emphasis is on mental health advocacy and community support, aligning most directly with the Health topic.

title: Fishing trip gets disabled veterans out on the Bay
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Fishing trip gets disabled veterans out on the Bay

 June 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 464
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — There wasn't a single cloud in the sky as disabled veterans from Pleasant Day Medical Adult Day Care took turns reeling in lines on Wednesday morning.It was a fruitful day on the water, and spirits were high. "Trust me, fishing isn't always like this," said Captain Shannon Pinkens as he threw the 10th fish in the cooler.
The event was organized by the Easton Elks 1622 Veterans Affair Committee as an opportunity for the veterans to relax and enjoy the gorgeous day.
Fishing and hunting have been shown to help combat post-traumatic stress disorder and help foster community for veterans.
A study conducted by scholars Jessie Bennet, Jennifer Piatt and Marieke Van Puymbroeck for Springer Nature found fly-fishing significantly reduced symptoms of post-traumatic stress, depression and functional impairments while increasing overall self determination and leisure satisfaction.
The United States has more veterans than any other nation in the world, and often those returning from oversees struggle to get the help they need. According to the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs news, 22% of the 16.5 million veterans in 2020 were homeless and 15,000 of those individuals lived completely without shelter.
There are currently no Veteran Affairs hospitals on the Eastern Shore, but there is a clinic located in Cambridge. The closest VA hospital that provides full services is located in Baltimore.
The Easton Elks 1622 Veterans Affair Committee works to ensure these individuals, particularly disabled veterans, get the resources they need and then some.
The committee raises funds, hosts events and works with community organizations like Pleasant Day to ensure the best quality of life for veterans on the Eastern Shore, who are often far away from other resources.
Before leaving the dock Wednesday, Easton Elks 1622 Veterans Affair Chairman Michael Feehly presented Captain Pinkens with a certificate of appreciation for serving disabled veterans. Pinkens sheepishly accepted, and the crew set sail.
Once out far enough into the Bay, Pinkens and Feehly began live-baiting the lines with small shad, keeping three lines in the water at all times. As soon as there was a tug, it was on.
The rockfish were out in full force Wednesday morning. Also known as the striped bass, the rockfish is the official state fish of Maryland. Due to conservation concerns, fishers can keep one fish per person if they're between 19 and 24 inches long. Anything longer or shorter must be returned to the Bay.
Executive Director of Pleasant Day Erin Windsor aided each veteran as they reeled in the large specimen. Windsor made sure everyone got a chance to catch a fish.
The boat reached its maximum people-to-fish capacity an hour before the day was done. To wish the group farewell, a group of porpoises jumped in and out of the Bay.
"The only thing that would make this better would be a beer," said veteran Mike. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a fishing event organized for disabled veterans to improve mental health, citing studies on PTSD reduction through recreational activities. While it involves community engagement, the primary emphasis is on health benefits and veteran well-being.

title: Construction is afoot for Easton's new hospital
author: Konner Metz
content:
Construction is afoot for Easton's new hospital

 June 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 692
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As the summer heats up, so does construction on Easton's long-awaited, 385,000-square-foot hospital.Construction teams are in the early stages of building the University of Maryland Shore Regional Medical Center on Longwoods Road just off of U.S. Route 50. And in a matter of weeks, passersby will see vertical progress on what will be the hospital's six-story main tower.
"As part of the vertical construction, probably one of the first things that people would see from the road is the cranes," said LuAnn Brady, University of Maryland Shore Regional Health vice president and chief operating officer.
The landmark project took two major steps forward last month — on May 1 the Town of Easton granted the hospital a building permit, and two weeks later, Route 662 (or Longwoods Road) reopened for traffic after it was rerouted due to where the medical center will sit. Those advancements allowed building construction to begin on time.
Project leaders and politicians alike have touted the hospital as a significant milestone that will improve the quality of health care for Eastern Shore residents. Brady and Shore Regional Health communications marketing director Trena Williamson said the new space will improve efficiency for patients and staff.
The new center will replace Shore Regional Health's current one, a 244,000-square-foot facility in downtown Easton.
"We've been working in a space that has been retrofitted," Williamson said. "Health care changes so quickly, and our current space has grown and morphed around those changes, and part of what has made this project necessary is that we're stuck."
CONSTRUCTION TIMELINE
Project leaders expect the hospital to open in the summer of 2028. Constructing the building is likely to take much less time than the events leading up to the hospital's ground breaking.
In 2012, Shore Regional Health first applied for a certificate of need to relocate the hospital. Industry changes, fiscal concerns and shifting project plans delayed the timeline. But in January 2024, the Maryland Health Care Commission finally approved the certificate of need application.
"There was a little bit of 'we'll believe it when we see it,'" Brady said of how employees viewed the pending move. But when the commission gave the OK, the project hit the ground running.
Brady said construction will start on the east wing of the main hospital and then go to the west wing. Then workers will tackle the 60,000-square-foot medical services and outpatient services building.
By the end of this year, Brady said the east wing will be standing and there will be progress on the west end.
"A year from now, in May of 2026, both the east and the west wings will be built, and you'll see all six stories of the building," Brady said.
Whiting-Turner is leading construction.
WHAT WILL CHANGE
The project will increase the hospital's space for storage, education, meetings and parking, according to Shore Regional Health leaders, who also noted that hospital staff had significant input over the past years into where departments are located, what rooms look like and more.
There will be 122 licensed inpatient beds — a slight increase from the current 118. Bed counts are dictated by the state through the certificate of need, Williamson said. The number of total beds will be 147, nearly even with the hospital's current makeup.
While the hospital's bed number isn't significantly rising, the location of 25 additional observation beds will no longer significantly interfere with the emergency department space. Observation patients will be placed beside the emergency center.
"The dedicated observation beds will allow us to be able to be more efficient with those observation patients in terms of not taking up space in the emergency department," Brady said.
And as for the operating rooms, Williamson says space and scheduling limitations at the South Washington Street location will be improved with the new medical center. Since the downtown hospital was built before robotic surgery, most operating rooms don't have space for the robotic equipment.
"They didn't think about robotic surgery," Williamson said of when the operating rooms were first built. "Well, now we have robotic surgery, and that needs specific things. They need to have a larger space for that to operate in."
"There's a bit of liberation," Williamson said of the space the new medical center will provide. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the construction of a new hospital, detailing its impact on healthcare services, infrastructure improvements, and medical facility upgrades. While local government permits are mentioned, the core subject is healthcare infrastructure and services.

title: As young Americans struggle with mental health, online support surges
author: MAX SCHAEFFER Capital News Service
content:
As young Americans struggle with mental health, online support surges

 June 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAX SCHAEFFER Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1705
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Adolescents across the country have increasingly suffered from anxiety and depression over the last 10 years, and school officials in Prince George's County noticed the same trend locally.So when the county's public school system needed to support its struggling students, it did what schools and young people across the nation are doing — it turned to an online service.
Funded by the statewide effort to bolster youth mental health, the county partnered with Hazel Health, which specializes in providing online counseling to school-age children.
"I think accessibility is huge," Emily Pasco, the school district's mental health coordinator, said of the partnership. "That's historically been a barrier for mental health services — transportation is an issue."
Supporters of online mental health services argue that they offer a convenient option in an era when providers are in short supply. According to a 2024 federal study, more than a third of the nation's residents live in an area where there aren't enough mental health professionals.
Enter online services such as Hazel, Gaggle, Counslr and Cope Notes.
"We are not a silver bullet; we are not going to solve everyone's problems, but we can be a great gap-fill," said Andrew Post, Hazel's president.
Online mental health services surged in popularity during the coronavirus pandemic when most in-person options were shut down, and it has remained popular in the years since.
With the online medium evolving every day, there is no consensus about it among psychological researchers, but various studies have shown online interventions can do some good.
For example, a 2024 study from the National Institutes of Health found there were "promising results regarding the effectiveness of online interventions in young people, especially for symptoms of anxiety and depression and for training of social functioning."
Megan Taylor, an independent licensed clinical psychologist from Northern Virginia with online and in-person therapy experience, said online therapy can sometimes feel safer to patients than seeing a therapist in person.
Yet the online medium makes it easier for unlicensed or unreliable providers to provide services they aren't qualified to provide, said Taylor, who has extensive experience with youngsters with autism.
"I feel really passionate about the fact that there are many therapists, who advertise themselves as being neurodiversity affirming or specializing in autism, but really haven't had that training," Taylor said.
Despite such concerns, online therapy is expected to grow as an option for troubled young people nationwide. Zion Market Research projects the global market for online therapy for teens to more than triple from 2023 through 2032.
That being the case, here's a closer look at several online mental health care options available to young people today:
Hazel
Hazel was one of the big winners in the state's first round of grants from its new youth mental health program, receiving $2.75 million in Prince George's County, $1.5 million in Baltimore City and smaller grants in Charles and St. Mary's counties.
Students in Prince George's County and elsewhere access Hazel's counselors through video conference, either at school or home. Post said the medium offers limitations as well as benefits for the students who access it.
"We are raising a generation of children who are very comfortable, for better or worse, with technology," Post said. "This construct of, 'I'm going to drop you off at this office and I'll pick you up in an hour,' is a little jarring, compared to, 'I'm going to hand you this iPad and you're going to see this person and talk to them.'"
Despite being a proponent of telehealth therapy, Post acknowledged for severe cases, in-person treatment always has to be an option for young people.
Prince George's County — like Miami-Dade County, Florida, where Post taught and served as an administrator — is a majority-minority community where over half of the student population qualifies for free and reduced lunch. This comes with additional mental health challenges for students to navigate.
In 2024, Prince George's County saw 113 homicides.
"Gun violence is a significant issue," Pasco said. "Students being affected by either witnessing gun violence, or being affected by someone that they know being a victim of gun violence."
The top two most common reasons for referral, according to Pasco, are depression and anxiety, consistent with national trends.
One way Hazel looks to serve the unique needs of communities like Prince George's County is to only use providers who are licensed in the state.
"Number two is making sure that our population group truly reflects the population that we serve," Post said.
Two out of every five Hazel therapists fluently speak a language other than English, according to Post.
Gaggle
Like Hazel, Gaggle — which began in 1999 as an early email communication system between teachers and students in schools — provides online therapy. The company has evolved over the last 25 years, first into an online safety management platform and now a provider of teletherapy.
Gaggle's safety management operation is still the primary service it provides to school districts, with over 1,500 districts using it. Just over 100 school districts use its telehealth service, although no Maryland school district uses it.
Growing the company's telehealth operation is a company priority, said Heather Durkac, Gaggle's chief innovation officer.
"Gaggle started and is involved with protecting those 'digital hallways' — what kids were emailing, sending, sharing, uploading, everything that was on district-provided devices or accounts," she said.
Increasing concerns about mental health and self-harm — which company officials noted through its safety monitoring service — inspired the company to offer teletherapy as well.
"I used to talk about [during training with school districts] if students would send something like a suicide note or share suicidal thoughts," Durkac said. "Now I talk about it in a position of when students are sharing those suicidal thoughts or a suicide note. That really just compelled us to do something more."
The company made 20,000 phone calls to school districts for situations their safety analysts deemed an imminent threat for a student, and over 400,000 emails to school districts for concerns of a lower level, according to Durkac.
Durkac shared a story of Gaggle's intervention when a student wrote a suicide note on a Google Doc on his school-issued Gmail account, which school officials saw because Gaggle's safety management system gave them access to it. Gaggle contacted the school, and officials there got the student's family and police involved. The student was found at the local train tracks and taken to a hospital.
With a combination of Gaggle's services, a school district could continue to work with the student to help prevent a similar situation.
"If it is one of those districts that has both services, they can choose to move them right into our Gaggle therapy services. If not, they have other resources," Durkac said.
If one decides to access Gaggle's therapy services, the company employs a team of licensed therapists that mostly do part-time work online while working with their own practice or serving as a supervisor somewhere else.
Counslr
Another of the most widespread online counseling providers is Counslr, a service that partners with large companies, schools and communities. Counslr is partnered with school districts across 11 states but not Maryland — although it works with Child Trends, a Rockville-based nonprofit that researches child well-being.
Counslr offers text-based mental health support with a licensed mental health professional at any hour of the day. Students complete a basic intake form and are matched with a professional who is supposed to best fit their needs.
"We are particularly effective at what we call 'reaching the traditionally unreachable,'" Counslr co-founder and CEO Josh Liss said.
He said Counslr's text-based method helps people avoid typical hurdles like cost, inconvenience or negative stigma around getting help.
"The majority of the sessions on our platform deal with relationship issues," Liss said. "Very challenging to have a video session, when the person you want to talk about is lying in the bed next to you."
Counslr is free for the students or members of its partner school districts or organizations. That entity pays Counslr for its services to be accessible to its students or members.
Liss said he is confident in Counslr's ability to help its users, but recognizes its limits.
"We very intentionally do not provide therapy," Liss said. "Our counselors don't diagnose, they don't treat and they don't prescribe medication."
When someone requires a more intensive form of care, like therapy, the company works with the school counseling office to facilitate that, Liss said.
Cope Notes
Cope Notes founder Johnny Crowder said he grew up with "severe mental illness" and had always resisted seeking treatment.
Once he got older and began to study psychology and neuroscience, that aversion turned to a curiosity and passion for helping people.
"I started texting people health education content from my phone," Crowder said, "and eventually started building it into something more nuanced."
This is how Crowder developed Cope Notes, a subscription-based service that sends users a text at a random point in the day.
The texts are written by a peer, or someone with experience with whatever challenge their text references, then reviewed by Cope Notes' clinical oversight panel of mental health professionals before being sent out.
One of the biggest challenges is finding a text that will be general enough to apply to a range of subscribers but specific enough to help. The service is anonymous, so the providers aren't aware of who they're texting.
"We're serving people, let's say one of them is a rural teenager with bipolar and one person is like an urban senior with no mental health conditions," Crowder said. "How the heck do you craft a content library that is applicable across all of those demographics, if you don't have that information?"
Answering this question has become a big part of the company's content review process.
No two people ever get the same text at once, and the text comes through at a random time, although the company is working on features that will allow people to personalize their experience, according to Crowder.
The current Cope Notes pricing model allows someone to purchase an individual subscription for an annual cost of just over $100. Cope Notes also offers group subscriptions for companies or schools.
Crowder recognizes Cope Notes is not a replacement for therapy. He said he feels Cope Notes is a resource that can be used to get someone ready for treatment in therapy, or help someone who has finished their therapy have some consistent support.
"I would say it's a great step up or step down [from therapy]," Crowder said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on mental health challenges among youth and the rise of online mental health services like Hazel Health and Gaggle. While education systems are mentioned as implementers of these services, the core subject is mental health care. Public safety is tangentially related via gun violence statistics but is not the primary focus.

title: Mid-Shore could see highs in upper 90s as heat wave approaches
author: Konner Metz
content:
Mid-Shore could see highs in upper 90s as heat wave approaches

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As many regions in the United States prepare for a significant heat wave in the coming days, Maryland's Mid-Shore could see temperatures nearing triple digits next week.According to the National Weather Service, Easton is projected to see highs around 95 to 97 degrees beginning Sunday through Wednesday. Highs are expected to remain in the 90s later in the week across Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot counties.
The Dorchester County Health Department is encouraging people stay out of the sun when temperatures peak in the late mornings and early afternoons.
A press release from the department noted the following groups should take added precautions: babies, young children, pregnant women, older adults, outside workers and those without air conditioning.
Local health officials recommend regularly hydrating, limiting time outdoors and monitoring for signs of heat exhaustion — heavy sweating, cold skin, cramps, dizziness, nausea or vomiting, etc.
The Maryland Department of Health said in a press release this week that Maryland saw 26 heat-related deaths last year. The state department added that parents and guardians should never leave children in cars.
"Remember to check on those who are particularly vulnerable to heat, including young children, senior citizens, and people with chronic diseases — and confirm that they have the resources they need to stay safe during the hottest months," said Maryland Secretary of Health Dr. Meena Seshamani in the release.
EASTON FIRE PREPARES
As temperatures heat up, volunteer fire departments across the Mid-Shore remain on call. Due to the physically intensive work of firefighting and the heavy gear that must be worn, some departments are asking for water donations from the community.
Easton Volunteer Fire Department Chief J.R. Dobson says his department has received enough cases of water from thoughtful community residents and businesses to get through next week's heat wave. Dobson is encouraging residents to contribute to other fire departments in need in Talbot County.
Whether it's lending bottled waters or assisting with manpower on a call, Dobson says local fire departments work together well.
"The other fire chiefs talk a lot, and we're always here to help one another," Dobson said.
The fire chief noted that as farmers in the area start to cut their wheat, field fires could pop up, a risk fire officials are keeping their eyes on.
Weather projections are accurate as of Friday afternoon. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: MidShore Meals til Monday launches summer meals program for kids
author: Lily Tierney
content:
MidShore Meals til Monday launches summer meals program for kids

 June 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 322
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — On Tuesday, MidShore Meals til Monday rolled out its children's summer hunger relief program with its brand new big blue van, which was partially funded by No Kid Hungry and Preston Automotive.Founded in 2017, Meals til Monday has been a successful initiative that sends breakfast, lunch, dinner and snacks home with children who may not get them otherwise.
The summer program began last year and aims to target child hunger in Dorchester County, according to MidShore Meals til Monday's website. After facing a $5.59 million deficit for fiscal year 2026, Dorchester County Board of Education made cuts to afterschool and summer programs to balance the budget, according to a report by the Star Democrat in March.
According to MidShore Meals til Monday's website, one in five children doesn't know where their next meal is coming from and goes to school without enough to eat to fuel their bodies or brains. In 2024, 95% of students in Dorchester County qualified for free or reduced-price meals, according to the Maryland State Department of Education.
The Community Eligibility Provision meal program is a meal service for schools and school districts in low income areas and allows schools to offer breakfast and lunch at no cost. According to Meals til Monday's website, approximately 5,000 students in Dorchester County participate in this program.
However, the program is not available during the summer, which is where Meals til Monday comes in.
The summer meal program offers one meal box for each child per household. Each box contains seven complete breakfasts and lunches, including an entree, fruit and vegetables. Milk is optional, and a weekly menu, reheat instructions and food safety information are also provided in each box, according to the summer meal program registration page.
Meals til Monday's summer program will run from June 23 to Aug. 21. One-time registration is required and can be done online through the DCPS website or at one of the 10 sites during pick up. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a summer meals program addressing child hunger and food insecurity, which directly relates to public health initiatives. While education systems are mentioned due to budget cuts affecting meal programs, the core issue is nutritional support for children, aligning most closely with the Health topic.

title: Melas til Monday director recognized for efforts to feed children in the summer
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Melas til Monday director recognized for efforts to feed children in the summer

 June 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 435
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — MidShore Meals til Monday's Executive Director Pam Allen was recognized as one of 11 Summer Hunger Heroes by No Kid Hungry on Tuesday."I don't do what I do for recognition," Allen said {span}in an interview following the rollout event for Meals til Monday's summer program, where she received the award.{/span} "I understand that there's a need in the community, and it's not about myself. As I said Tuesday, this is about Meals til Monday as a whole, but it really felt good to be honored."
Allen began working volunteering for Meals til Monday during the pandemic. She then obtained her community health worker certificate to help people access services like Medicare and Medicaid. Allen said this naturally aligned with her work at Meals til Monday.
Her recognition comes after a yearlong process of filing for grants, receiving donations and working with community organization partners to buy a refrigerated van, which allows Meals til Monday's summer program to reach more children in Dorchester County and expands the program's capabilities.
"It's not necessarily about how many more kids that we're reaching as much as it's about what else we can give the kids," Allen said. With the van, Allen said they are able to pick up large bins, also known as gaylords, of produce and frozen foods that would otherwise go bad.
Summer is identified by Food Action and Research Center as the hungriest time for kids because they lose access to free school meals. In Dorchester County, students are provided free daily breakfast and lunch through a federally funded program called the Community Eligibility Provision.
This provision is available if 25% or more of the student population participate in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, the Food Distribution Program on Indian Reservations or Medicaid, according to the United States Department of Agriculture's website.
"We have partnered with Dorchester County Public Schools and we are delivering two meals for seven days to anyone that registers for children 18 and under," Allen said.
Allen said Meals til Monday is still providing regular weekend meal bags for anyone who needs them, and emergency food services are available with options for pick-up or delivery by appointment.
Allen encourages anyone who wants to volunteer to sign up on the website. "One of the things that we're trying to do as we continue to grow as an organization is to have the appropriate policies and waivers and things like that for our volunteers." Those can be found at midshoremealstilmonday.org.
"It feels absolutely wonderful. I am just so honored," Allen said about receiving recognition from No Kid Hungry. "Our primary mission is to feed children."

title: We may have lost the National Institute of Health
author: LARRY PIFER
content:
We may have lost the National Institute of Health

 June 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LARRY PIFER | Section: Columns 
 
 462
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The National Institute of Health, begun by President Franklin Roosevelt in Bethesda, Maryland, in 1940, is now the world's largest public source of funds for bio-medical research. 171 scientists who received Nobel prizes were supported by NIH.Yet the Trump Administration has cut in just 40 days $1.81 billion in current NIH research grants, 30% of which were to reimburse funds already spent. Judges blocked even deeper cuts in current programs.
Now Trump's budget proposal for next year would cut the NIH budget by 40%. This will dramatically affect their personnel, research, and will slow, if not stop, the progress that is being made in numerous health-related issues. Such research, trials and testing saved us from COVID-19, as just one example of this vital work.
I am personally affected by this disastrously shortsighted and ridiculous decision. I have glaucoma, and the vision in my left eye is virtually gone. The Wilmer Eye Institute of Johns Hopkins University, the preeminent institute of its kind is presently researching and has made considerable progress in a method of restoring the optic nerve. The institute has lost millions in funding for this and other vital projects, which impact me and the entire world.
Other Marylanders are especially threatened by these cuts as NIH is still based in Bethesda, and Johns Hopkins is the largest recipient of NIH funding of any medical college in America. These cuts will put added pressure on our state legislature as good jobs and the resulting tax revenues diminish.
All other Americans will also suffer. The CEO and chief scientific officer of the Association of American Medical Colleges recently stated:
"The administration's announcement that it plans to cut federal support of biomedical research by drastically reducing reimbursement of research costs related to peer-reviewed grants from NIH will diminish the nation's capacity, slowing scientific progress and depriving patients, families and communities across the country of new treatments, diagnostics and preventative interventions.
"Every American has benefitted from NIH–supported research, conducted at medical schools, academic health systems and teaching hospitals nationwide. Every American will be harmed by the undermining of the long standing partnership between academic institutions and the federal government.
"The government's support of facilities and administrative costs allows medical research to happen. These real and documented research expenses include physical lab operations and maintenance, security, data processing and storage, and daily operations of critical research infrastructure. Make no mistake. The announcement will mean less research. Lights in labs nationwide will go out. Researchers and staff will lose their jobs."
"As a result, Americans will wait longer for cures and our country will cede scientific breakthroughs to foreign competitors. These are real consequences — slower scientific progress, longer waits for cures, fewer jobs."
I can't imagine that this is what anyone voted for. Why would anyone support it? I most certainly do not. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the National Institute of Health (NIH) and its critical role in biomedical research, emphasizing the impact of budget cuts on medical advancements, public health, and specific health issues like glaucoma. While related to economic impacts and public safety, the core subject is health research and its societal implications.

title: Talbot County woman gives record $25M to new Easton hospital
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County woman gives record $25M to new Easton hospital

 July 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 417
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Talbot County woman and her family made a record $25 million gift toward Easton's in-construction medical center, University of Maryland Shore Regional Health announced Tuesday.It's the largest private donation in Shore Regional Health history and one of the largest ever across the statewide University of Maryland Medical System.
The woman, who has requested to remain anonymous, was born over 90 years ago at the former Memorial Hospital in Easton. Shore Regional Health President Ken Kozel said in an interview that he was "utterly amazed" at the family's generosity when he learned of the pledge.
"I see a woman and a family who just have the kindest heart and the biggest spirit for other people, the health and wellbeing of other people," Kozel said.
The $25 million will go toward Shore Regional Health's new medical center, a near $550 million endeavor which is under construction on Longwoods Road. It is expected to open in 2028, replacing the current hospital on South Washington Street.
Rebecca Bair, vice president of philanthropy for Shore Regional Health, and members of her team made the donation possible. Kozel said it has been a yearlong process.
When Kozel spoke to the donor, they discussed how rural Americans often struggle accessing quality health care.
"Rural hospitals are closing all around the country," Kozel said. "And those that haven't closed yet are at risk for closure because of mainly financial challenges."
Easton's new hospital has been touted as a game-changer for Eastern Shore residents. It will be over 100,000 square feet larger than the town's current hospital, improve efficiency within the medical center's different departments and increase accessibility with its proximity to Route 50.
During early stages of planning the new medical center, Kozel said $25 million was the first "concept of a goal" leaders had for a fundraising mark. That "seemed like an incredible challenge" years ago, he said, but now they're hoping to quadruple that number.
According to Shore Regional Health leaders, the recent $25 million gift has allowed the organization to expand its capital fundraising campaign from $50 million to $100 million. So far, $62.5 million has been donated, which has all been during the "silent phase" of fundraising, Kozel said.
The $100 million campaign aims to bring funds not just to facilitate the construction of the new hospital, but what comes after as well, Kozel said. This includes recruitment and retention efforts, technology improvements and advancements to clinical services such as women's health.
"Her gift has been the catalyst and the catapult," Kozel said of the Talbot County donor. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While local government and business aspects are tangentially mentioned, the core subject is healthcare.

title: Aaron’s Place continuing the legacy it was built on
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Aaron’s Place continuing the legacy it was built on

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 457
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Cheryl Beulah started Aaron's Place with an idea of honoring her father, The Rev. Aaron Moulden, but Aaron's Place has turned into more than she could ever imagine."My father had just passed away, and I couldn't think of any other way to honor him in and his legacy than to honor the work that he did in Baltimore City," Beulah said. "He ran a food pantry and a soup kitchen in Baltimore City. So, I wanted to honor him, and as I tell everyone, I wanted to honor not only my earthly father but honor my heavenly father in doing God's work and serving the communities."
In 2012, Beulah and her husband, Howard, joined Living Waters Assembly in Denton. Beulah wanted to provide service, so she joined the food pantry at the church and helped elevate the group to serve 300 food boxes per month.
After serving for six years, Beulah began to look for a location to run her own food pantry. She stumbled across a building on the property of Denton Church of Free Seventh-Day Adventist.
Aaron's Place opened its doors in 2019.
The food pantry now serves thousands of families in any given month. To get to this point, Beulah credits engaging with the community on their needs and reaching out to other companies for help.
"I believe in strong collaboration because I don't think one person can do it by themselves," Beulah said. "I believe in pulling out for support. Since we deal with health-related issues, the person may need assistance with the local health departments, mental health agencies, whatever the case may be."
Aaron's Place receives extensions from mental health agencies and the University of Maryland health network.
Aaron's Place receives food from Food Lion in Denton, Food Lion in Federalsburg, Dollar General in Denton, Dollar General in Greensboro, two Dollar Generals in Federalsburg, Aldi's and Walmart. The food pantry also picks up from Save-A-Lot in Greensboro.
Along with food, Aaron's Place provides other services and items for anybody in need.
"Think of what you need from your head to the toes, so does a person that's experiencing food insecurity," Beulah said. "They're going to need clothing. They need shoes, they need deodorants, they need non-food products, they need personal care products, personal hygiene products, and you can get enough of that."
Aaron's Place has purchased a new 140,000 location in Denton where they plan to partner with His Hope Ministries to provide a year-round homeless shelter and multiple different classes, additions and food storage locations.
When Beulah thinks about honoring her father, she gets very emotional.
"I just cry," Beulah said. "I still wish he was with me and I know he's with me in my heart. But I just feel blessed to be able to carry on his legacy." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Aaron's Place, a community food pantry and service organization addressing food insecurity and partnering with health agencies. While it involves community support and collaboration, the explicit mention of health departments, mental health agencies, and health network partnerships aligns most directly with the 'Health' topic.

title: Where to these people go?
author: Staff Writer
content:
Where to these people go?

 July 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 371
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I am writing to ask for your thoughts on the proposed Medicaid cuts that are part of the "Big Beautiful Bill" recently passed by the Senate.While looking into the impact of cuts on Maryland residents, I learned that Medicaid along with the Children's Health Insurance Program provide health insurance for 1 in 4 of our state's population. Medicaid covers the cost of giving birth for 40 percent of births in the state, provides help for 1 in 3 persons with disabilities and also covers care for 5 out of 8 nursing home residents. The proposed cuts to Medicaid would result in loss of health coverage for 229,000 Marylanders.
There are also proposed cuts to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, which would result in 200K recipients losing some or all of their benefits.
In addition, some 190,000 Marylanders enrolled in the state's health care marketplace will likely lose their health insurance coverage if tax credits on insurance premiums are not extended.
I read that Republicans think too many people are enrolled in Medicaid, so they want to cut $625 billion from Medicaid and $300 billion from SNAP.
People who benefit from Medicaid and supplemental food and nutrition programs are the most vulnerable people — mostly children and the elderly — among us. So when you cut Medicaid because too many are enrolled, who's the decider? Who decides who gets kicked out? Without health care and food assistance where do these people go? They don't just disappear. They'll still be there. I suspect hospital emergency rooms will become the obvious health care option. If you're hungry and poor, what are your options? When you distress a population, is it possible that crime will rise too?
What's really behind these cuts? We hear that the most impoverished are being asked to pay this price so that billionaires and the very wealthy can reap the benefits of tax cuts. Billionaires who can buy their own hospitals are going to pay less in taxes. The poor get poorer (and hungrier and sicker) and the rich get richer.
So, Dear Andy Harris, how is this OK?
Sen. Mitch McConnell says about these cuts, "They'll get over it." I don't think "they" will get over it, but I think we will remember.
MARION O. ARNOLD
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Medicaid and SNAP program cuts, their impact on healthcare access, and social welfare implications. While mentioning public safety concerns as a secondary effect, the core issue revolves around healthcare policy and its effects on vulnerable populations.

title: Shore Regional Health nurses graduate from leadership institute
author: Staff Writer
content:
Shore Regional Health nurses graduate from leadership institute

 July 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 277
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Three nurse managers at University of Maryland Shore Regional Health recently graduated from the Nurse Leadership Institute, a yearlong professional development program hosted by the University of Maryland School of Nursing and funded by a state grant.The NLI was designed to build leadership capacity of Maryland nursing faculty and clinicians, facilitate partnerships for developing strategies that shape effective health care and prepare a nursing workforce to assume roles within systems.
Amy Bradley, a manager at 3E and the Joint Center; Mary Collins, a manager at 2E and Dialysis; and Shawne Davis, a manager at Patient Care Services completed the intensive program along with over 40 other nurse leaders across the state.
"It was reinvigorating," said Collins, who has served on the UM SRH nursing team for nearly two decades. "When you've been doing your job for a long time, it's easy to think, 'We've got this' — but this program helps you realize there's always room to grow. This was about learning how to do what we do better."
The program included one-on-one mentorship, monthly virtual leadership meetings and three in-person sessions, including a two-day intensive leadership training. Participants also completed a collaborative project addressing a specific health care issue or topic.
Danielle Wilson, senior vice president and chief nursing officer of Shore Regional Health, championed the program internally and encouraged her managers to apply.
"Investing in nursing leadership is investing in patient care," Wilson said. "Nurse leaders have the opportunity and responsibility to continue to innovate and advance standards of care. We are grateful that three of our nurse managers had the opportunity to engage in this transformative initiative."
For more information on the Nurse Leadership Institute, visit umshoreregional.org/nli.

title: Beating the heat: drive delivers fans, air conditioning to those in need
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Beating the heat: drive delivers fans, air conditioning to those in need

 July 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 475
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — During a summer of extreme temperatures, the Zeta Phi Beta Sorority Inc., the Iota Chi Zeta Chapter, and the Dorchester County Health Department have joined forces to provide air conditioners and fans to residents who may otherwise go without.The FANtastic Fan and A/C Drive started in June when temperatures reached upwards of 90 degrees.
"Those temperatures were really, really extreme," said Tavonya Chester with the Dorchester County Department of Social Services. "And then, Zeta Phi Beta Sorority Incorporated was like, 'Man, just imagine if you didn't have an AC.' Just imagine, right?"
Drive organizers began collecting box fans and smaller air conditioning unites to donate to neighbors in need.
"If you're saying, 'Oh, it ain't that bad outside' cut your AC off. Cut it off. And then you know exactly how hot it is and how desperate people may be to have an air conditioner to cool their home off," Chester said.
So far, 12 air conditioners have been distributed, along with many more fans, thanks to overwhelming community support.
A grant from the City of Cambridge funded 10 air conditioners, which must be distributed within city limits.
"What I want to say is that the community has overwhelmingly stepped up and has done a very good job with donating fans and ACs. It makes me want to cry," Chester said.
While the drive is open to all residents, Chester wants to ensure those taking advantage of the program truly need it. Because of this, the elderly, critically ill individuals, and families with young children take priority when it comes to receiving an air conditioning unit.
However, they are not as strict when it comes to who receives fans because the fans are cheaper to purchase. An air conditioning unit can range from $139 to $150 and Chester said they are not picky about the brand, but the units have to be new.
"The air conditioners are so expensive that we can't afford to give them to everyone who needs it, so we're trying to give it to at least the people who needs it the most," she said.
New box fans and small air conditioners can be brought from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Monday to Friday to the Dorchester County Health Department at 627 Race St. in Cambridge, according to a press release from the Health Department.
According to Chester, the Cambridge Walmart no longer has A/C units, so people are ordering them online and having them delivered to the Health Department.
"Well, I always say, if you want to donate a fan, just go on Amazon and order it and have it delivered here. That way you don't have to leave the comfort of your home. You can stay home in your air conditioning," Chester said. "If you want to donate an air conditioner, same thing."
Monetary donations are also accepted and can be made out to Zeta Phi Beta Sorority Inc. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community initiative led by the Dorchester County Health Department to provide air conditioning and fans to vulnerable residents during extreme heat, emphasizing public health needs and partnerships with health organizations.

title: From signs to survival: a family’s kidney campaign
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
From signs to survival: a family’s kidney campaign

 August 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 883
 Words 

 Read News Document

 POTOMAC, Md. — Melanie Flamenbaum and her family are on a life-saving mission to find kidney donors for her sister and brother-in-law, Dana and Andrew Goldstein of Lewes, Del.Her husband, Ed Goldstein, and their sons, Ranan and Brooks, have been posting signs linking to the National Kidney Registry website. They've placed the signs in storefront windows, near a soybean field at the Inn at Huntingfield Creek, and even at a Boston Red Sox–Washington Nationals game.
Last weekend, they brought the campaign to Kent County while picking up Brooks from camp at Echo Hill. The family stayed in Rock Hall, enjoying the peaceful surroundings while continuing to spread awareness.
Throughout High Street in Chestertown and surrounding areas, signs share information about Dana and Andrew's circumstances and promote awareness of organ donation.
Flamenbaum said she overcame any shyness to give her sister and brother-in-law a chance to live and witness future milestones — including those of their daughter, Jelena Goldstein, who recently earned a master's degree from the University of Delaware.
Dana and Andrew's story is deeply personal and heart-wrenching.
Both in their 50s, Dana and Andrew have lived with Type 1 diabetes most of their lives, Flamenbaum told Kent County News.
Andrew was diagnosed in infancy. He underwent radiation treatments that left him with one functioning kidney and a pancreas that never fully recovered.
Dana was diagnosed at age 8 and has been taking insulin ever since.
Originally from New York, the couple met while attending Case Western Reserve University in Ohio. Andrew studied biomedical engineering, and they bonded over their shared experiences managing diabetes. They fell in love, got married and later welcomed Jelena.
Despite their medical challenges, the couple thrived for years. Andrew built a career in the biomedical field, and Dana held various jobs before focusing on raising their daughter.
But toward the end of the COVID-19 pandemic, their lives changed dramatically.
Dana was rushed to the emergency room with breathing difficulties and tested positive for COVID-19. She spent two weeks on a ventilator in the ICU and faced a long recovery once discharged.
Even after the couple relocated to Lewes in 2022, Dana continued to struggle. Climbing stairs became difficult, and weakness persisted. At a routine checkup, her blood and kidney levels raised concern. Soon after, she began dialysis treatment.
Dana initially underwent hemodialysis three days a week, where blood is drained through a chest port, cleaned, and returned to the body. The process was exhausting and consumed much of her energy.
Eventually, she transitioned to peritoneal dialysis at home. Using a port in her abdomen, a cleansing solution flows into the body and is later drained through a hose into the shower. While more convenient than hospital visits, the daily process was just as draining. At first, she performed treatments four times a day. Now, she undergoes dialysis overnight for eight hours while sleeping.
Andrew was by her side through it all, specially trained to help administer treatment. But soon, his own health began to decline.
After attending a social event, Andrew contracted pneumonia and began experiencing kidney failure. Like his wife, he started with hemodialysis and now performs peritoneal dialysis at home.
Flamenbaum said that while he is still able to work from home, it is not sustainable long term.
"Diabetes and dialysis have taken over their life," she said.
Everyday tasks have become increasingly difficult. Boxes of dialysis solution are stacked in the living room — a constant reminder of their new reality.
"Activities we take for granted, like a routine trip for a cup of coffee, are a draining affair for them," Flamenbaum said. "It takes a force of will to just do something natural."
That's why the family is being proactive — raising awareness, reaching out to as many people as possible, and dispelling fears and misconceptions about kidney donation.
With her loved ones' lives on the line, Flamenbaum has become well-versed in the process.
She explained that through the National Kidney Registry's voucher program, finding a compatible donor is now easier and more efficient than ever. Donors undergo a comprehensive medical exam, speak with doctors and counselors, and can opt out at any time with no pressure.
While kidney donation is still a major procedure, Flamenbaum said it is one of the safest surgeries with a relatively short recovery time.
"Someone who receives an organ from a live donor can generally go back to work immediately," she said — something Dana and Andrew hope to be able to do again.
Receiving a kidney from a living donor also means a lower chance of rejection, fewer anti-rejection medications, and fewer long-term complications.
For donors, she said the risk is minimal.
"I've talked to people who have donated," she said. "One told me, 'If not for a small scar, I wouldn't even know I did this.'"
But the emotional and spiritual reward, she said, is immense.
"They feel really good, emotionally and spiritually, because they've given someone their quality of life back," Flamenbaum said.
That's the outcome Dana and Andrew are fighting for as they continue their campaign across Maryland and surrounding states. If successful, they plan to have their transplant surgeries at the MedStar Georgetown Transplant Institute, one of the country's highest-volume organ transplant programs.
For more information or to begin the donor screening process, visit: nkr.org/TDE863 for Dana or nkr.org/TKZ944 for Andrew.
"We want to spread our message as broadly as possible," Flamenbaum said. "We take our signs everywhere we go — and we're not stopping." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a family's medical campaign for kidney donors, detailing health challenges, dialysis processes, and organ donation efforts. While local outreach is mentioned, the core subject is health-related advocacy and medical conditions.

title: Camp Scrubs teaches about all aspects of hospital health care
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
Camp Scrubs teaches about all aspects of hospital health care

 August 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 407
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Nearly two dozen high school students spent last week at ChristianaCare Union Hospital in Elkton attending Camp Scrubs, where they learned about every aspect of health care in a hospital setting."We tried to show them that a hospital is run by so many people; not just doctors and nurses," said Katie Hunter, project coordinator. Working with Cecil College, Union Hospital has been offering Camp Scrubs since 2014 (pandemic notwithstanding). Hunter said the program has gained popularity with a waiting list for next year. Middle school aged students attend Camp Scrubs in June, with the high school cohort in August.
"We had two camps last year and this year," Hunter said. "There will be three next year."
Tuition is $315 and eight scholarships are made available each year.
On Friday, Camp Scrubs was learning CPR and how to use a mechanized and an inflatable lift — a hover jack and a hover bed respectively — for easier and safer patient transfer. As one group took turns learning the different transfer methods, another was run through the paces of treating a patient in cardiac arrest.
For Brionna Iraca-Reeves and Simone Akehurst, Camp Scrubs is an introduction into what each hopes will be a career in medicine.
"I've wanted to be a trauma surgeon for as long as I can remember," Iraca-Reeves, 16, from Oxford, Pa. said. "I didn't have a Plan B."
Akehurst, 16, from Bear, Del. also plans to be a trauma surgeon.
"We learned a lot in the OR," Akehurst said of their visit to an operating room at the hospital on Bow Street in Elkton. "We saw a total hip replacement and a tonsillectomy.
"I also got to hold a gall bladder in the (pathology) lab," Akehurst said.
Along with getting introduced to the many aspects of a hospital the teens also got to talk with some of its professionals, which Akehurst called valuable.
"This morning I got to talk to a general surgeon," said the trauma surgeon hopeful. "He told me trauma surgeon is more medical than surgical. I want the opportunity to do more surgery. General surgery is a very broad skillset."
"A lot of it is mentoring in the field you want to pursue," Iraca-Reeves said.
Iraca-Reeves said any student with health care aspirations should consider attending Camp Scrubs. She credits Hunter with making the program valuable, informative but also engaging.
"She's all wrapped up in giving people the best experience," Iraca-Reeves said. "I think it's really important to recognize Katie and all she's done."

title: Hole In the Wall Gang Camp on track to open May 2026 in Queenstown
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Hole In the Wall Gang Camp on track to open May 2026 in Queenstown

 August 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 442
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — Nestled in the scenic landscape of Queenstown, expansion of Paul Newman's vision for a camp for children with serious illnesses comes closer to fruition, with renovations well underway.Expansions to bring The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp to the Eastern Shore are more than halfway complete. The camp hopes to welcome the first session of campers in May 2026.
Founded in 1988 by Paul Newman, The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp provides a different kind of healing to thousands of children with serious illnesses and family members annually, free of charge.
Renovations are underway to transform the property's former Aspen Institute buildings into camp-friendly spaces.
Inclusion and accessibility and intention are key components of the camp as it seeks to provide the whole camp experience to all children regardless of illness, according to Hilary Axtmayer, chief program officer.
Features of the developing facility include complete ADA compliant ramps, temperature controlled swimming pool, and bringing vibrant fun colors to all corners of the campus.
As a medical camp, a state-of-the art infirmary will serve all camper care on-site.
Building off the success of its original Ashford, Connecticut location, the Hole in the Wall in Queenstown will provide transformative camp experience for Mid-Atlantic children with serious illnesses including rare diseases, and their families.
Like the original Connecticut location, the Queenstown camp will serve as a place of joy, connection, healing and respite, designed to support not only the child with serious illness but their entire family.
For many of these campers and their families, Hole in the Wall provides camp experiences they would not otherwise have opportunity for, Axtmayer said.
Years in the making, officials are more than excited to expand the camp's reach and bring the medical specialty camp to the area.
The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp is always adapting and improving to meet the unique and varied needs of campers and their families, Axtmayer said.
The Eastern Shore's centralized location close to Baltimore and Washington D.C is ideal for the camp's extensive hospital outreach program, she said.
Expanding The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp experience to the Eastern Shore, the future Queenstown campground will soon be a place where children with serious illnesses will have the chance to simply be kids, and, as Newman famously said, "raise a little hell."
The camp expects to welcome about 15 families per weekend during its first phase family program sessions opening in May 2026. A second phase to provide independent-camper opportunities is expected further down the line.
Officials have begun connecting with hospitals and organizations specializing in rare diseases to help recruit eligible campers.
"We can't wait to welcome families," Axtmayer said.
More information about Hole in the wall can be found at www.holeinthewallgang.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the expansion of The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp, a nonprofit medical camp providing free healing experiences for children with serious illnesses. The health-related mission, inclusion of medical facilities, and emphasis on patient care align most directly with the 'Health' topic. While 'Local Life' is relevant due to the community impact, the primary focus is on health services and accessibility.

title: My aging body: 'I feel like I'm being evicted'
author: ROBERT C. KOEHLER
content:
My aging body: 'I feel like I'm being evicted'

 August 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ROBERT C. KOEHLER | Section: Columns 
 
 768
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I thought I knew myself pretty well, but then this old-age thing hit ... hard. Both physically and psychologically.I'm still in Appleton, Wisconsin as I write, awaiting my second cataract surgery, right eye, tomorrow. The first one went well. I'm not concerned about No. 2, at least not in and of itself. But I've felt myself plunging into a sense of deeper stress, feeling, with increasing regularity – as I stay here with my loving family – like a shrug of nobody.
Only minimally am I a participant in the basics of life. Yeah, things are essentially taken care of for me, which is great – it's why I'm here – but nonetheless it leaves me feeling like a spectator of my own life. And it hurts to get up. Achy thighs, wobbly knees. Plus I don't hear well, don't see well (yet), and am good at pummeling myself into a state of uselessness: what I call I-don't-matterness.
As Leonard Cohen said shortly before he died, speaking of his body, "I feel like I'm being evicted."
And that state intensifies the aches and wobbles. Prior to standing up, for instance, I know the pain is coming and psychologically start cringing and grimacing, feeling the pain before it even starts. I'm just an old fart and this is what I get. This is what I deserve. Ouch!
But then something happened. This was just a few days ago, as I stood up from the kitchen table. A sense of awareness clicked – I'm not sure why – and my looming pain was not the focus. Instead, I just stood up ... oooh, ahhh ... and it simply was what it was. What I felt wasn't the pain, it was the effort. What? The feeling was there, but I didn't torture myself with it. It wasn't pain, it was simply reality. And my legs pushed against it. They did their job. I was up. Life goes on. I had a smile on my face.
I'm not saying all is good, all of a sudden. I'm still this old guy and my life is full of challenges. But this click of awareness at the kitchen table has reverberated. Think positive – my God, that's just a cliché. But I don't know how else to put it. It doesn't push away life's difficulties or make life pain-free. It just clears away some of the psychology – the shame and anger, the fear and despair. You know, all those emotions that intensify the hurt.
OK. Life goes on. But loosening the psychological impact pain had on me seemed to matter. I don't mean in a full-blown way. with life now problem-free. I simply found myself, much to my astonishment, letting myself focus beyond my depression and self-annoyance. There was a bit of a sparkle in me, a sense of self-caring, a sense of ... yes, yes, self-respect, which I had angrily snorted out of my mind.
I was, and am, staying at my sister's part of the house, which she shares with her daughter and family. One day when she was off somewhere, and I was alone, instead of simply losing myself on my computer and staying invisible – unwanted – I called my niece and asked if her husband was interested in doing a drawing with me, as he had once mentioned to her. It was Sunday, so they weren't working, so this might be a good time, maybe even the only time. She asked him and his answer was yes.
So I went over there, and we sat together for an hour, maybe more. We danced with drafting pens and colored pencils and magic markers, and I felt a gleeful fullness in me. I wasn't just "the guy they were taking care of" but a participant in their lives. When I came back to Sue's place she was there. She looked and me and said, "You're in pretty good spirits."
And the words stuck. I was. I had reclaimed a sense of agency. I wasn't just living a shrugged-off life of I-don't-matter. I could stand and I could connect. I felt the return of a forgotten self, an abandoned self. And a couple days later, Sue and I went to visit a nearby retirement community – just to look, y'know. Just in case I decided to leave Chicago and move up here.
The place had a slogan: Strength. Purpose. Belonging.
It was also pretty costly, so I probably won't be moving there. But the words pulled something huge together for me, and still do, as I continue to absorb them. They're all of us, standing up together at the kitchen table. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the author's personal experiences with aging, physical health challenges (cataract surgery, mobility issues), and psychological impacts of declining health. While there are mentions of family interactions and local community (sister's house, retirement community), the central theme revolves around health and aging. The title's metaphor of 'being evicted' from one's body directly relates to health deterioration.

title: 3rd annual Build-a-gym 5K set for Sept. 6 in Federalsburg
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
3rd annual Build-a-gym 5K set for Sept. 6 in Federalsburg

 August 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 241
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — The More4Life gym is hosting its third Annual Build-a-Gym 5K at Marina Park in Federalsburg on Sept. 6.The hope with the annual race is to raise funds to bring a More4Life gym to Federalsburg, although plans for a location have been shifted in recent weeks.
Originally, Executive Director of More4Life Donte London, made plans to have a gym in the Federalsburg Activities Center. According to Federalsburg Activities Center Executive Director Pamela Bockart, the agreement was shut down due to lack of available space.
Now, with hopes of finding a new location, London said annual event can help raise money to promote healthy living in Federalsburg.
"My goal was always to assist the town of Federalsburg to encourage the residents to take on healthier lifestyles," London said. "... My plan is to work with the community leaders on needs where they don't have the funds."
London said, during the first 5K event, More4Life lost money, but by the second event, the organization was making a profit. The goal is to raise $10,000, and the fund currently sits at $5,500, but some purchases have already been made for the new gym.
The 5K run and walk will begin at 8:30 a.m. with bib pickup starting at 7:15 a.m. The race is for all ages and features a scenic loop through the Marshyhope Creek trails of Federalsburg.
London encourages all ages to come out and enjoy the race. Dogs are welcome as well.
To sign up, visit runsignup.com/Race/MD/Federalsburg/buildagym5k.
