title: ‘The most vulnerable’: Rural, inner city communities brace for impacts of Trump's Medicaid cuts
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia
content:
‘The most vulnerable’: Rural, inner city communities brace for impacts of Trump's Medicaid cuts

 August 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia | Section: News 
 
 1323
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Hospitals and medical providers serving rural and lower-income communities are on edge after President Donald Trump's mega bill passed by Congress includes looming Medicaid cuts.Some of them are on the financial edge, literally — and fear the worst.
Trump's Big Beautiful Bill (BBB) will cut close to $1 trillion from Medicaid and Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) by 2034, according to the Congressional Budget Office (CBO).
The government programs offer medical services to low-income Americans. Close to 78.4 million Americans are enrolled in Medicaid and CHIP, 23% of the U.S. population. BBB cuts aim to reduce Medicaid and CHIP roles by 10.5 million people by 2034 via tougher eligibility rules and work requirements
"Everyone's panicked," said Jennifer Mensik Kennedy, president of the American Nurses Association.
She worries about the Medicaid cuts prompting layoffs, hiring freezes, reduced staffing, missed payrolls and hospital closures.
Medicaid reimbursements accounted for 19% of all U.S. spending at hospitals in 2023. That totals $283 billion of the $1.5 trillion Americans spent on hospital care, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation.
"Rural hospitals were already in dire straits," Mensik Kennedy said of the financial situation and short financial reserves already facing some small-town hospitals.
New work requirements require adult Medicaid recipients without exemptions for disabilities to work 80 hours per month. The BBB also institutes copays of up to $35 for Medicaid-related doctor appointments. Work requirements go into place in 2027, while the federal funding changes and copays go into effect in 2028, according to an analysis of the BBB's Medicaid impacts by the Hirija & Chau LLP, a Los Angeles-based law firm.
MORE THAN HOSPITALSRural and inner-city hospitals in lower-income areas will feel the brunt of the Medicaid and CHIP cuts, according to health care industry experts and executives.
"They're the most vulnerable," said Peter Kowey, chair of cardiovascular research and a professor of medicine and clinical pharmacology at Thomas Jefferson University.
"They don't have the high-end stuff like cardiovascular surgeries or neurology or orthopedic surgeries that generate a lot of revenue," said Kowey, who has authored a new book, "Failure to Treat: How a Broken Healthcare System Puts Patients and Practitioners at Risk."
Kowey said hospitals have already been struggling since the pandemic and those overly reliant on Medicaid are facing "very fragile" operating margins.
A report by the Center for Healthcare Quality and Payment Reform found that as many 700 rural U.S. hospitals are financially struggling and 300 are at risk of more immediate closure.
David Navazio, CEO of Gentell, Corp. a Philadelphia-based medical company specializing in wound care, said rural hospitals don't have the population or revenue bases to give them financial resilience.
Some hospitals "never recovered" financially from the pandemic when other procedures, appointments and surgeries were canceled or not pursued, he said.
Navazio said the U.S. health system needs more preventive care and more community and other health clinics to serve communities.
"Maybe we have too many hospitals," he said. "There's so much more to health care than hospitals."
But he also worries about how Medicaid cuts will impact health centers in rural and underserved communities with significant Medicaid patient populations..
"Those clinics are the ones who are the most vulnerable to closure," Navazio said.
He called the BBB cuts "short-sighted" and cautioned that the result will be more uninsured Americans putting off health needs until they are more serious, then showing up at emergency rooms.
Navazio said the American health care system still struggles to provide medical services to the uninsured, who are often workers in lower paying sectors or for smaller businesses whose health care plans are not affordable.
"The uninsured are really the working poor," he said.
According to federal data, 27.2 million Americans were uninsured in 2024. That accounts for 8.2% of the U.S. population and is up from 25 million in 2023, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. The CBO estimates the Medicaid pullbacks could increase the number of uninsured persons by 10 million.
Mensik Kennedy and others worry about the creation of more health care deserts with patients having to potentially drive long distances to deliver babies or for more specialized care.
"You are going to see nurses and providers leave," Mensik Kennedy said of the Medicaid cuts' potential impacts on rural and other underserved communities.
"Once they leave those communities, they aren't coming back," she said.
Struggling hospitals could go toward an emergency room-centric model in order to survive, dispatching other practice areas because of the financing challenges.
DEBT CRISISConservative backers of the Medicaid cuts say they are needed to cut out waste and fraud and help curtail federal spending and debt loads.
Medicaid spending will total $873 billion this year, according to federal projections.
In 2023, the federal government accounted for 69% of total Medicaid spending and states 31%.
Medicaid accounts for 18% of total U.S. health care spending (compared to 30% for private insurance, 21% of Medicare and 10% for out–of–pocket payments), according to federal data.
Conservatives favor the Medicaid changes saying they are needed to root out waste and fraud to help better control federal debt, which now totals $37 trillion.
"Along with Medicare, Medicaid is the main reason the federal government is hurtling toward a debt crisis. A debt crisis would trigger significant economic hardship and require drastic cuts to both programs," the conservative Cato Institute said in an analysis.
Cato said U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO) reports found $31 billion in improper Medicaid payments in 2023 and $500 billion over the last decade.
Critics of the Trump bill say tax cuts in the measure will magnify federal debt and shift money from the poor via cuts to Medicaid and food stamps to the wealthy via tax reductions.
'A DIRTY WORD'There have already been efforts from congressional Republicans to recoup some of the Medicaid cuts and help vulnerable hospitals.
A $50 billion fund was created to help rural hospitals — though skeptics say that falls short of the cuts Medicaid providers will face.
U.S. Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Missouri, wants to double that fund to $100 billion and has introduced a measure to block future Medicaid cuts.
States, who accounted for 31% of Medicaid spending in 2023, could try to fill the void of federal cuts. But that is not easy with state balanced budget requirements and a hesitancy even in Democratic states to raise taxes, including on the wealthy.
"Raising taxes is a dirty word," Navazio said.
Christoph Dankert, chief network officer at Carrum Health (a San Francisco-based health care technology firm), said hospitals and other providers poised to be impacted need to start forging paths forward well before the BBB cuts commence.
"They are going to have a shortfall of funds," Dankert said. "You have to make it somewhere."
He said a drop in Medicare revenue from hospitals and the potential increase in more uninsured, uncompensated care will put upward pressures on private insurance rates.
"It's going to create upward pressure on employer rates," Dankert said.
The American Hospital Association opposes the Medicaid cuts, saying they will reduce access to care and adversely impact "the most vulnerable populations" such kids and those with disabilities.
'COST CONTROLS'
The Medicaid cuts will propel more health care industry efforts to control costs, said Nate Favini, chief medical officer with Pair Team, a California-based digital health company focused on Medicaid.
"Controlling costs is a major priority, and there's recognition that the system has significant inefficiencies in how care is delivered," Favini said.
He said there will also be efforts to help Medicaid patients stay eligible once the work and other eligibility requirements begin.
But financially strained hospitals don't have a lot of wiggle room to take more hits, said Eddie Qureshi, CEO and founder of Rainfall Health, an artificial intelligence-focused health technology firm.
Quareshi said some hospitals have less than 30 days' cash on hand.
"We are going to see some hospitals close because they aren't able to keep up with the changes," he said.
Both Qureshi and Favini say Medicaid and other changes with health care — including a Trump administration's push for more data sharing of medical records and other information — will propel more technology, including AI.
"Our most forward-thinking health system partners recognize they can't continue with business as usual," Favini said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Medicaid cuts and their impact on healthcare access for vulnerable populations, discussing hospitals, medical providers, and policy implications. While 'National News' is relevant due to the federal policy aspect, the core subject is healthcare policy and its societal effects, making 'Health' the most precise classification.

title: Four join Shore Regional Health Board of Directors
author: Staff Writer
content:
Four join Shore Regional Health Board of Directors

 August 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 738
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The University of Maryland Shore Regional Health Board of Directors recently welcomed four new members: Aaron Gabrielian, Pamela Metz Kasemeyer, Michael Molino and Kevin M. Morgan.The Board's membership includes representatives from the five counties served by Shore Regional Health, the regional physician community and the University of Maryland Medical System, of which Shore Regional Health is a member organization. In addition to these new members, the following members have been elected as new officers on the board: Steve Satchell has been elected to serve as chair and Marlene Feldman as vice chair.
Gabrielian, of Easton, is senior vice president-branch director and senior portfolio director of the Coastal Private Wealth Group at RBC Wealth Management in Easton. He began his career as a financial adviser at Morgan Stanley and prior to joining RBC, worked at a leading independent advisory firm providing family-office style investment advisory services, business succession planning and estate preservation strategies to some of the nation's most successful business-owning families, institutions and endowments. He has extensive experience managing individual investment portfolios on a discretionary basis and providing multigenerational wealth planning to corporate executives and business-owning families.
Gabrielian graduated from Towson University with a Bachelor of Science degree in finance where he played baseball and was the recipient of the Towson University Tiger Leadership Award for his efforts on and off the baseball field. He went on to graduate study in financial planning through New York University. He holds active volunteer roles with several local organizations including the Mid-Shore Community Foundation Board of Directors, The Sultana Education Foundation Board of Directors and Shore Regional Health Board of Directors, where he serves as chair of the Finance Committee.
Kasemeyer, of Easton and Columbia, Maryland, currently serves as director of the Office of Government Affairs for Baltimore County. She was formerly a partner with Schwartz, Metz, Wise and Kauffman, P.A. in Baltimore, representing business, professional and trade associations before Maryland's legislative and executive branches. Before joining Schwartz, Metz, Wise and Kauffman, P.A., Kasemeyer held several positions, including associate attorney at the law offices of J. William Pitcher, executive director of the Maryland Delaware Solid Waste Association and director at the Maryland Association of Health Maintenance Organizations.
Kasemeyer earned a Juris Doctor from the University of Maryland School of Law, a Master of Health Services Administration from George Washington and a Bachelor of Arts in public policy studies from Duke University. Her bar admissions include the Maryland Court of Appeals, the United States District Court-District of Maryland and the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals. Kasemeyer is chairman of the Board for Sisters Circle, a mentoring organization in Baltimore City, and serves as a court-appointed special advocate for CASA on the Mid-Shore.
Molino, of St. Michaels, is executive vice president of corporate growth for SeaCorp, an engineering and technology company that builds electronic systems for submarines and related technology solutions, where he oversees corporate strategy, mergers and acquisitions, business growth and federal government affairs.
Before joining SeaCorp, Molino served in similar positions at ASRC Federal and Leidos, both government contracting firms. Prior to working in the private sector, Molino served in the U.S. Army, handling various logistics roles and leading deployment exercises, natural disaster relief and training programs. He continues his military service by volunteering on the Army Science Board, where he reviews Army projects involving robotics, personnel management, nuclear testing and technology. Molino earned a Bachelor of Science degree from the U.S. Military Academy at West Point and a Master of Business Administration from Cornell University.
Morgan, of Cambridge, currently serves as regional health and wellness senior director for Sam's Club Inc., based in Annapolis. In this role, he oversees a large network of pharmacies, as well as optical and hearing centers, across 12 states. During the COVID-19 pandemic, Morgan played a key role in the vaccine rollout within Walmart, collaborating with Walmart Supercenters, Sam's Club and Neighborhood Markets to deploy immunization services across the various retail platforms supporting all 50 states and Puerto Rico.
Morgan served as a commissioner on the Maryland Board of Pharmacy from 2016 to 2024, including three terms as board president. He has represented Maryland as a delegate to the National Association of Boards of Pharmacy and contributed as a member of multiple pharmacy committees. He holds a Doctor of Pharmacy from Shenandoah University and a Bachelor of Science in biology and environmental studies from St. Lawrence University. His professional certifications include APhA immunization delivery, American Board of Opticianry and basic life support. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the addition of new members to the Shore Regional Health Board of Directors, which is directly related to healthcare governance. While some board members have business backgrounds, the primary context is health organization leadership. The 'Health' topic is the most specific and accurate match.

Rabies case discovered in Caroline County

 August 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News

 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Wednesday, the Caroline County Health Department announced a positive case of rabies in the area of Cool Spring Road near Henderson."The Maryland Department of Health laboratory has confirmed a positive rabid case in the Cool Spring Road area," the department said in a release to the public.
The health department warned residents that any person near or in the vicinity of Cool Spring Road should avoid contact with wildlife, feral cats, unknown animals or any animal that appears sick or to exhibit signs of rabies, including cats and dogs.
The health department also urges residents in the area to make sure their pets and mammal livestock are up to date on rabies vaccinations.
The department urges residents to report potentially rabid animals at 410-820-1600 or the non-emergency line of the Caroline County 911 Center at 410-479-2222.
For more information on the rabies case, visit carolinehd.org/rabies-alert-near-henderson-august-27-2025/.

title: Mobile crisis services expanding in Southern Maryland
author: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com
content:
Mobile crisis services expanding in Southern Maryland

 September 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 512
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Since March, clinicians and peer support specialists with Santé Group have been driving a light blue Ford Escape in Southern Maryland to help resolve immediate behavioral crises and offer resources in the community.St. Mary's County Health Department received a grant from the Maryland Behavioral Health Administration for mobile crisis teams across the state, Tammy Loewe, director of the behavioral health division for local department, said. Mobile crisis teams align with the national Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration practices.
Goals of the mobile crisis teams include providing in-person care and deploying in real time to the location of the person in crisis to begin the process of assessment and treatment, Loewe said.
"We really felt with our expertise, in both urban and rural areas, that coming into Southern Maryland could be a really great support for the community," Sam Richberg, chief of programs for Santé, said.
Phone counselors determine if a person's situation can be deescalated on the phone and be connected with appropriate resources or if a team of a clinician and peer support specialist needs to visit them, Richberg said.
During visits, the team identifies what triggered the call, who is involved and next steps. Peer support specialists use their shared experience to make a connection, Richberg said, and they determine which resources to provide to keep someone from going to the hospital or criminal justice system.
The team follows up the next day, whether it be in-person or over tele-health, Tina-Marie Brown, a director with Santé, said. At the minimum, the team will visit the client once every seven days for two weeks.
"What's great about crisis response services … is the immediacy of the support you get," Richberg said. "You have somebody who then can support you in getting connected to more of that long-term care."
It could be a child acting out and the parent does not know what to do or talking someone out of suicide, Brown said. Santé can also offer support to law enforcement and the community after a tragedy.
Community outreach is key, Richberg said. Letting people know Santé is available is important, but so is making connections with local resources. They have an agreement to start working in Charles County, too.
Maryland has just half of the therapists they need, Brown said. The mobile crisis is a stop gap, meaning they can support individuals until they get help or until help becomes available.
"If we're doing our job well, we should be connecting that person to community resources," Brown said. "The more support someone has, the more successful they're going to be."
The workforce for behavioral health is a statewide concern, Loewe said. St. Mary's County worked with St. Mary's College of Maryland and College of Southern Maryland to promote behavioral health degrees.
As Santé continues to grow in Southern Maryland, they hope to offer suicide prevention work, Brown said.
"It takes a special person for crisis," Brown said. "Not everybody likes it. It's very fast-paced. You never know what you're going to have from one day to the next."
Call the Maryland Crisis Hotline at 988 to connect with crisis teams and resources. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on mobile crisis services for behavioral health, mental health resources, and community support systems. While there are elements of public safety and local government collaboration, the primary emphasis is on healthcare services related to mental health and crisis intervention.

title: Talbot goes purple another year
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Talbot goes purple another year

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Business 
 
 524
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County is going purple for the ninth year this September to engage the community and youth in standing up against substance use.During the monthlong awareness and education campaign, businesses, organizations and government agencies will be lit up in purple not just in Talbot County, but throughout the Mid-Shore.
The program was founded by Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble to raise awareness about the prescription opioid crisis. Gamble said the program has since changed to reflect the evolving drug trends in the county.
Gamble said he created Talbot Goes Purple to start a conversation the county wasn't having. He said he was speaking at a fundraiser when he had this realization.
"I stood up and I said, 'raise your hand if you talk to your kids about drinking and driving,' and all 400 hands went up. And I said, 'raise your hands if you talk to your kids, your grandkids, about seatbelt use,' and 400 hands went up. And then I said, 'Raise your hand if you talk to your kids about prescription painkillers,' and only 11 hands went up," Gamble said.
For Gamble, these were conversations that parents, guardians and community members needed to be having with their children to give them the proper tools to handle situations involving drugs.
"In my world of policing, 80% of what we deal with is connected to some form of substance abuse," Gamble said.
Maryland has tracked much fewer overdose deaths for the past two years. According to Gamble, there has only been one overdose in Talbot County this year.
However, fentanyl is still a major concern, he said. "We're not seeing any heroin in Talbot County, Maryland that doesn't have fentanyl in it," Gamble said. "We're seeing a lot of cocaine in Talbot County, Maryland that has fentanyl in it."
Educational efforts through September will be extensive, Goes Purple organizers said, and they will address fentanyl along with other substances.
Talbot Goes Purple Coordinator Kelley Callaghan said the broadening of the program's focus to include education on marijuana is more important than ever with a potential dispensary coming to Easton, and Gamble agrees.
"Youth are being hospitalized for marijuana use," Gamble said. "I want parents to understand, you know, the weed they smoked when they were in college 30 years ago is not the same weed today."
Callaghan highlighted alcohol as one of the commonly abused drugs by youth.
There will be posters around Talbot County schools of a real prescription pill next to a fake one, showing how difficult it is to tell the difference.
Teaching the youth about the Good Samaritan Law, which protects individuals from prosecution for minor drug or alcohol offenses when calling 911 for a medical emergency, is a critical part of the prevention tactics, Goes Purple organizers said.
In addition, Talbot Goes Purple provides Narcan trainings and has installed Narcan boxes at several business and trained the employees how to use them. Narcan, or Naloxone, is a medication used during opioid overdoses to reverse or reduce the effects of the drug.
There is also a comprehensive toolkit on the Goes Purple website to help families navigate recovery services and find help regardless of insurance status.
For resources regarding substance use, visit talbotgoespurple.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community health initiative addressing substance use, opioid crisis, and drug education. While public safety and education are related components, the primary emphasis is on health awareness, prevention, and community wellness efforts.

title: QAC Goes Purple 2025: standing stronger than ever
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC Goes Purple 2025: standing stronger than ever

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 709
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEEN ANNE'S COUNTY — QAC Goes Purple is once again rallying the community this season to stand against substance abuse, as county leaders note progress but stress that education must continue.The countywide initiative, launched in 2017, is a collaboration of the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff and the Queen Anne's County Drug-Free Coalition, in partnership with the Opioid Intervention Team and Health Department, Queen Anne's County Public Schools, the county commissioners, the Mid-Shore Community Foundation and other agencies. Its mission is to raise awareness of substance abuse and opioid overdose prevention.
One of the program's first actions was to place six opioid signs across the county, updated weekly to show overdose data. At the time, opioid misuse was on the rise.
In 2018, Queen Anne's County reported 122 overdoses and 16 overdose-related deaths. By 2024, those numbers had dropped to 18 overdoses and four deaths.
So far in 2025, the county has recorded eight overdoses — and no overdose deaths — an encouraging sign, officials said. But they stressed that continued education and prevention efforts are needed to keep the numbers low.
"Even one death due to opioids is too many, and work must continue," coalition members said.
Education, Prevention and Treatment
Through awareness campaigns, free Narcan distribution by the county Health Department, a standard reporting system developed by Queen Anne's County Emergency Services, and the QAC Data Dashboard, local leaders say the effort is showing results.
In 2025, the initiative expanded its banners across the county to more than 100, all carrying the slogan: "Taking a stand against substance abuse."
Progress is being seen "across the board," said Warren Wright of QAC Goes Purple. He credited strict penalties for drug sellers, enforcement against tobacco and liquor outlets that sell to minors, and the strong work of the county's Drug Court.
Also contributing are Prevention Services, Peer Support Workers and the Local Management Board, which is conducting an asset-mapping project. The county Board of Education has added Bodkin life skills programs for younger students. The commissioners are working with neighboring counties to expand treatment services for residents at the Whitsitt Center.
Youth Involvement
Recognizing that most young people make choices about alcohol, tobacco and drug use during middle school, QAC Goes Purple has focused on youth outreach.
A Youth Risk Behavior Survey found that more than 13% of Queen Anne's County high school students reported taking a prescription drug not prescribed to them — a troubling trend that highlights the need for early conversations at home and in schools, officials said.
To reach peers directly, the QAC Drug-Free Student Ambassador Program includes students from public and private schools who design posters, lead team-building events and stage award-winning activities.
"We believe that involvement is key to prevention for our students," Wright said. "Join a team, try a club, and discover your passion. After-school programs and activities are offered through schools, the YMCA and the Giving the Edge Foundation."
Changing Perceptions
QAC Goes Purple emphasizes that substance use disorder is not a choice but a disease that affects the brain. Understanding the science of addiction, officials say, can reduce stigma and encourage compassion.
September is recognized as National Recovery Month, followed by Substance Use Prevention Month in October. International Overdose Awareness Day is marked every year on Aug. 31 to honor those lost and support families affected by substance use disorders.
"We can all make a difference," said Emily Keller, Maryland's special secretary of overdose response. "Hundreds of lives are saved every year from bystanders who had naloxone and knew what to do in the event of an overdose. We have to make sure that anyone who wants naloxone can access it wherever they are and whenever they need it."
Free naloxone is available at the Nielsen Center, 205 N. Liberty St., Centreville.
Upcoming Event
The sixth annual Going Purple Together event will be held Sept. 27 at Church Hill Park from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. The family-friendly gathering will feature live music, food trucks, face painting, dunk tanks and raffle prizes, while celebrating recovery and raising awareness.
The community is also invited to complete the QAC Goes Purple Marijuana Survey, available at the county Health Department website under the Behavioral Health tab.
"Everyone in Queen Anne's County can keep fighting by knowing the facts, discussing them with loved ones, colleagues and friends," Wright said.
More information is available at qacgoespurple.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a countywide initiative addressing substance abuse and opioid overdose prevention, involving health departments, education campaigns, and community health efforts. While public safety and education are related, the primary emphasis is on health awareness, prevention, and treatment programs.

title: Maryland kids celebrated in Times Square national Down syndrome video
author: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland kids celebrated in Times Square national Down syndrome video

 September 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 458
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Five kids from Southern Maryland appeared in the annual National Down Syndrome Society Times Square video in New York City on Saturday.The one-hour video will show over 500 photographs including children, teens and adults with Down syndrome from all 50 states and 11 countries, a release from the National Down Syndrome Society said. The photos of Ellie Griffin, Norah Smith, Harrison Bonovitch, Arthur Schaefer and Josiah Gross were selected from more than 2,600 entries in the society's call for photos.
Ellie, Norah and Arthur are from St. Mary's County and Harrison and Josiah are from Calvert County. Their photos will be displayed on two screens in Times Square above Dos Caminos restaurant in Father Duffy Square.
Ellie is 5 and was diagnosed with Down syndrome when she was born, Jessica Griffin, Ellie's mom, said. Ellie was also selected to be in the video in 2022, but this is the first time the family is going to New York to see it.
"I can't wait to see her reaction," Griffin said before the event. "Hopefully she realizes what's happening."
While Ellie might not understand everything that's happening, her 8-year-old brother is excited and "thinks she's famous," the mother said.
Outside of the national society, the family participates with other Down syndrome organizations, Griffin said. They do fundraisers with the Down Syndrome Diagnosis Network and have raised over $20,000 to connect families who are new to the condition, in which a person is born with an extra chromosome causing mild to moderate cognitive disability, developmental delays and physical challenges.
"It's amazing the support that we get through our community," Griffin said.
Griffin is also a parent volunteer with Jack's Baskets, which hand delivers baskets with gifts and resources for families to celebrate babies with Down syndrome.
The Times Square video presentation kicks off the New York City Buddy Walk. The walk has taken place in New York City since 1995 as part of the National Buddy Walk Program.
The National Down Syndrome Society video allows Ellie and the other Southern Maryland residents to advocate the message of inclusion, Griffin said. The photos were taken by 21FIVE Photography by Teresa Tucker, a resident in Southern Maryland who did free photoshoots for the kids to submit to the society.
"Everyone's goal is to support their kids and help them be the best versions of themselves," Griffin said.
Ellie does not have a lot of words, but she is a huge Taylor Swift fan, Griffin said. When Swift plays Ellie screams "Tay Tay" and starts dancing and singing.
"She's been hitting a lot of the words to the songs," Griffen said. "We think it's actually helped improve her language and speech skills."
The presentation was slated to be live-streamed on the National Down Syndrome Society Facebook page from 9:30 to 10:30 a.m. on Sept. 6. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'It's rewarding and motivating': Eastern Shore resident speaks on recovery
author: Lily Tierney
content:
'It's rewarding and motivating': Eastern Shore resident speaks on recovery

 September 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 573
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Norm Townsend spent his entire life on the Eastern Shore, growing up in Easton and spending half of his life in Cambridge. Since starting his sobriety journey in 2017, he said his "life has gotten 100% better."For Townsend, recovery is a daily practice. He participates in Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous, has a sponsor, sponsors four others and has worked and re-worked the 12 steps over and over.
"We never complete it because once we finish the steps, we just go through them over again, and every time we go through them again, there's something else that we work on," Townsend said.
Townsend frames recovery as a lifelong lifestyle rooted in spiritual principles. He believes choosing the right peers in the 12-step rooms are critical. "Vigilance is the key to success," Townsend said.
He's been in and out of recovery since May of 2017, relapsing for a few years following his first time getting sober. He now works as a peer support specialist at Grace Street Recovery in Easton and has adopted the philosophy of recovery as a lifestyle.
As a peer support specialist, Townsend connects individuals with housing or treatment options. "It's rewarding and motivating seeing people still stuck out there in a spot that I was at," he said.
Though he finds the work rewarding, it's also difficult. "It's kind of like a double-edged sword. You get attached to people and try to help, you know, and some of them don't make it," Townsend said.
He described addiction as a disease where drugs or alcohol are a symptom of an underlying issue, saying it's like having a hole that needs to be filled.
"You have to make sure you're filling that hole with the right things, which is like spiritual principles, the program, being honest," he said. "Because the disease can show up in other ways."
For Townsend, acceptance really came with the fourth of the 12 steps, which is when he wrote down an inventory of his life. He said he no longer feels guilt or shame because he's no longer the person on that piece of paper anymore.
He's stopped doing the things that once caused him shame.
"I'm a totally different person than that. And that's the blessing of this is our message, is hope. Our promise is freedom from active addiction," Townsend said.
In his sobriety, Townsend takes pride in having stability at work and being an improved parent to his two kids and partner to his girlfriend.
Townsend also expressed his gratitude toward Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble for the work he does for the recovery community.
"I mean, he's a huge resource and a huge asset to the recovery community here in Talbot County," Townsend said. "You know, he does a lot of behind the scenes stuff that people don't know about. He really cares and that's that's a plus."
He is also appreciative of the Talbot Goes Purple initiative, which was spearheaded by Gamble to raise awareness about substance abuse and prevention. Townsend said it allows him to remember those he's lost to the disease and to think about how far he has come.
His advice for people who are seeking to get sober but may not know how is to not be afraid to ask for help.
"The best thing you can do is just ask for help, man. There are plenty of resources out there and people that would do anything for you to help you get on the path that they're on," Townsend said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on addiction recovery, personal health journeys, and community support systems. While it mentions local figures and initiatives, the core subject is health-related, specifically substance abuse recovery and mental health advocacy.

title: Suicide Prevention Walk at Perry Point attracts 525 participants
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Suicide Prevention Walk at Perry Point attracts 525 participants

 September 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 356
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PERRY POINT — More than 500 people participated in the 3rd annual Suicide Prevention Walk on the Perry Point Veterans Administration Medical Center Campus in Cecil County on Thursday morning, continuing the year-to-year climb in numbers.September is Suicide Prevention Month, and Thursday was World Suicide Prevention Day.
The annual event, which is part of the VA's initiative to end veteran suicide by, in part, raising community awareness of the subject, attracted approximately 200 walkers in 2023, according to planners. That number hiked to about 300 walkers last year, they reported.
On Thursday, marking a gigantic leap, 535 people participated in the Suicide Prevention Walk on the medical center campus, including VA employees — leadership, clinicians, staff — and VA volunteers. Military veterans, their families and community members also walked the route during the event.
In addition to raising awareness about the help available to prevent suicide, the walk helps reduce the stigma associated with suicide and mental health challenges.
Along the path of the walk, with a route that started outside the chapel and ran through sections of the campus, stations were set up and they offered activities like drumming, painting rocks, creating hope boxes, and petting ponies from one of the VA's community partners, Chesapeake Therapeutic Riding in Harford County.
In addition to the walk, there was a Health & Resource Fair for veterans in the gym.
Each year, there is a unique, commemorative T-shirt featuring artwork by one of the veteran patients.
U.S. Army Veteran Nicole Spencer (Army 82nd Airborne) created the artwork on the T-shirts that were given to the people who participated in Thursday's event, according to a VA spokeswoman, who commented, "Nicole began exploring her creative talents in recent years, through multiple tough health challenges, and says it helped her get through some long stays in the hospital."
The slogan for this year's event was "Hope Through Connections."
Veterans can sign up for VA health care at V-A-gov and ANY Veteran in crisis can call 988 and press 1 for free, 24/7, confidential help.
Among other activities the VA Maryland Health Care System has planned for Suicide Prevention month is a Tree of Life/Day of Remembrance ceremony on September 29. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Local testicular cancer survivor shoots for a hole in one
author: Amelia Blades Steward
content:
Local testicular cancer survivor shoots for a hole in one

 September 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Amelia Blades Steward | Section: Events 
 
 867
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to Johns Hopkins Brady Urological Institute, testicular cancer is one of the most common cancers in young men, with nearly 10,000 new diagnoses each year in the United States. It is highly curable when it first develops but can quickly spread if not treated promptly.Andrew Dorbin of Preston is a husband, father and testicular cancer survivor who hopes to educate men about the risks and symptoms of testicular cancer at the "Putts Fore! Nuts" miniature golf tournament on Oct. 18 from 11:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. at Embers Island Mini-Golf in Ocean City. The rain date will be Oct. 25.
Dorbin was diagnosed with late-stage testicular cancer (Choriocarcinoma) in the spring of 2023. It then metastasized to his lungs and abdomen.
While undergoing multiple rounds of chemotherapy, he was overwhelmed by the generosity of his family, friends and community, who rallied to support him and his family through his diagnosis and treatment. That experience of compassion and care lit a fire in him.
"During my longest inpatient stay at Johns Hopkins Hospital, I witnessed other patients facing their battle alone without the same support system I had. That was hard for me to stomach. It made me realize that I wanted to give back when I was able and build something that could offer strength, resources and connection to others navigating their fight against testicular cancer," Dorbin said.
"Honestly, I'm not particularly good at regular golf — I'm only there for my friend's comic relief — but I've always enjoyed miniature golf and came up with this funny tournament name on one of the sickest days of my treatment," he said.
The idea eventually grew, and Dorbin founded the Wayfinders Testicular Health Fund, a component fund of Chesapeake Charities Inc., a Maryland-based nonprofit. The fund is focused on raising awareness, providing education and building a supportive community fighting this disease.
He is committed to making testicular health a topic that young men are not afraid to talk about and ensuring that no one faces cancer without a community standing beside them. The tournament is the first step to accomplishing that.
"I chose an amazing partner in Chesapeake Charities to help make my dream a reality. The money that was used to found this venture came from what was left over from my personal GoFundMe campaign, making this essentially a 100% community-funded initiative," Dorbin said.
The fund's fundraising efforts will go toward community networking opportunities and mental health and wellness programs to ensure no one feels like they are facing the testicular cancer fight alone. Dorbin hopes his educational outreach will encourage young men to challenge the stigmas and pay attention to their health.
"We are encouraging our communities of young men, ages 14 to 35, to be aware of their bodies and to take action when something doesn't feel right," he said.
Dorbin reflects on his journey, sharing, "My journey almost ended before it started. When I found the lump, I almost didn't act. It seems petty now, but I was worried about the cost of my health insurance deductible and thought it was nothing serious. Through the encouragement of a friend who was a nurse, I decided to get it checked out. If I had not acted as quickly as I did, I'm not sure I would be sitting here today."
He said that, like him, men in their early 20s and 30s feel they are invincible and that they will not develop any major medical issues.
"No one wants to go to the doctor when they are young. Also, I had never been shown how to correctly check myself for abnormalities in my testicles. Self-examination is key to early detection," he said.
Dorbin hopes that teens and adults will participate in the tournament while learning more about the disease and how to protect themselves and their loved ones. He shares that the event will also create community connection — helping people learn who the disease is affecting, what support people need and connecting people to resources in the community.
"This event is going to be a blast. Participants can expect to play two rounds of mini-golf, all while challenging their knowledge, luck, and putting skills. Hole Hecklers — professional comedians will set up a mock sports casting both at one of the miniature golf holes and roast participants as they putt. We also have a variety of prizes and awards that will make the event enjoyable for everyone. For me, the best part is that you don't have to be standing on the podium to walk away a winner," Dorbin said.
In the future, Dorbin hopes that the Wayfinders Testicular Health Fund can support outings for survivors of testicular cancer and help build a community of survivors, since many men still suffer in silence with the stigma attached to the disease.
"This launch would not be possible without the incredible generosity of my friends, family, and neighbors here on Maryland's Eastern Shore. Their belief in this mission, and in me, has carried me through the toughest years of my life," he adds.
Sponsorships are still available for the event. Registration information and sponsorship opportunities are available at wayfindersthf.org. Participants are limited, and registration will be available online on Sept. 18. Registration is non-refundable.
For further information, contact Andrew Dorbin at wayfindersthf@gmail.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it includes a community event (Local Life), the core emphasis is on health advocacy, early detection, and supporting cancer patients, making 'Health' the most accurate classification.

title: Inside Caroline County's fight against substance use
author: Staff Writer
content:
Inside Caroline County's fight against substance use

 September 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Headlines 
 
 106
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "Caroline Goes Purple" is a big initiative.When the proclamation was made at the Caroline County Commissioners meeting at the beginning of this month, it made me think about all the work the county does to make residents aware of substance use.
I talked to multiple county officials about services available, different programs and what is so important about "Caroline Goes Purple."
All county officials gave me great answers, but one stuck out the most — the work of substance use awareness is bigger than just one month. Its a 24/7 effort.
You can read more about the county's efforts in my story below. Thanks for reading.
— Ahmad Garnett

title: Caroline County officials share why substance use awareness is bigger than just a month
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County officials share why substance use awareness is bigger than just a month

 September 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 793
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — While all Caroline County substance use awareness programs acknowledge the importance of "Caroline Goes Purple" in September, they know the work is done all year-round.The Caroline County Health Department credits this work for a dramatic reduction in overdoses.
According to Health Department officials, in 2023, Caroline County experienced 19 overdoses. In 2024, the number was less than 11 overdoses, and that trend seems to be continuing this year.
When number is under 11, the county is not allowed to share the exact number due to state regulations, officials said.
The efforts to reduce overdoses are celebrated during the month of September, when the county holds multiple substance use awareness events to connect residents to services the county provides. Jessica Tuel, director of Caroline County Behavioral Health and director for Caroline Goes Purple, said all these events are designed to show residents they're not alone.
"I think that people need to understand that a lot of these events are obviously to bring education and prevention services, but it's also to provide connection to those who are experiencing substance use," Tuel said. "We have a motto here. It is 'the opposite of addiction is not sobriety, it is human connection.' So, by bringing these things to the community, number one, it gives a level of education and prevention services, but it also helps those who have been through it or going through it know that they're not alone."
This is a goal stakeholders in Caroline County try to meet outside of September.
Monthly, the county and several municipalities hold joint meeting, called the Drug Free Caroline Group, to close gaps in service so the county can be strong year-round.
"We have a local drug and alcohol council meeting once a month to discuss trends that's happening," said Sloane Franklin, Caroline County state's attorney. "It has the law enforcement, courts, mental health, and substance abuse counselors, clergy, county behavioral health or substance abuse programs… We talk about grants that might be available to our partners to go out, and I seek those grants so they can continue to provide services to these people."
These services include a "safe station" located at the Caroline County Sheriff's Office.
The safe station allows an individual to come into the Sheriff's Office and say, "I need help." An off-duty officer will then search the person and confiscate any paraphernalia without charging the person.
The Sheriff's Office also has an on-site peer, Kristie Thompson, five days a week in partnership with the Sante Group. Thompson goes into the community and makes residents aware of options available.
Thompson said the goal is to get the individual experiencing substance-related difficulties into inpatient treatment.
"Our partnership and relationship with Sante Group is is definitely a high point for the county as far as being able to provide this service to citizens of Caroline County," Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker said. "As far as working out of this building, having one of their employees here being able to people who are in distress needing support services or wanting to get off controlled dangerous substances, I think that is definitely a high point when you can take somebody and give them the services they need."
The Health Department is another community partner that helps residents be aware of the dangers of substance use and their options. Tuel highlighted some of the services the Behavioral Health extension offers.
"We have a level one outpatient mental health and substance use program," Tuel said. "We serve a lot of different people throughout various stages of substance use. We provide medication-assisted treatment, as well and we have clinicians in the schools. We do mobile treatment for adults and for kids at the both high schools, and we're expanding into the middle schools. We try to offer as many services as we are able to as a public health system."
Tuel said the key to reducing overdoes in the county has been including peers who have lived the experience to help others still struggling.
"I think that in the last couple of years, we've done a really great job of including peers," Tuel said. "Peers are those who have lived experience and are on the other side of it. They've really given us a great perspective and hope that we're doing the right thing and that there is success in this.
"I think that sometimes as first responders, and sometimes people in our field, what happens is we get very discouraged because we don't see the hope at the end. Having peers embedded in a lot of these services, like at the sheriff's department and in our services at the Health Department and throughout the community, it really even gives us hope that we're doing the right thing and that we're on the right path and that people can heal and they can get better." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Caroline County's substance use awareness initiatives, overdose reduction efforts, and public health programs led by the Health Department. While there is some overlap with Public Safety due to law enforcement involvement, the primary emphasis is on health-related services, prevention, and community health outcomes.

title: Compass Regional Hospice Fashion Show raises funds for local care
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.comANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Compass Regional Hospice Fashion Show raises funds for local care

 September 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.comANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Compass Regional Hospice welcomed more than 200 guests to shop, bid on auction items and enjoy lunch while benefiting local hospice care during its annual fashion show Sept. 18 at Kent Island Resort. The sold-out event showcased selections from Compass Closet, the organization's retail consignment boutique, with prominent community members serving as volunteer models. "We are excited to reach out to more of the community," said Jessica Sherbrooke, volunteer manager. This year marked the first time the event was held at Kent Island Resort, providing more space for the growing attendance. Guests shopped a pop-up boutique featuring items from Compass Closet and bid on donated auction pieces while community celebrities modeled the boutique's featured selections. Compass Closet has offered affordable fashion finds to benefit the hospice's mission since 1991. Volunteers carefully select standout pieces throughout the year to feature in the annual fashion show, with all modeled outfits available for purchase. The fashion show has been a community fundraiser for Compass for at least 30 years, according to Heather Guerieri, chief executive officer. Compass Regional Hospice is celebrating its 40th year of providing care to patients and families in Queen Anne's, Kent and Caroline counties. "The community always comes out for a great time and shows their full support," Guerieri said. The consignment boutique operates entirely through volunteers, who Sherbrooke described as essential to Compass' mission. Leading up to the event, Compass highlighted volunteers through fashion show model spotlights on social media. Compass Closet is located in Kent Towne Center in Chester. More information about Compass Regional Hospice is available atcompassregionalhospice.org
.

title: Don't base medicine on politics
author: Staff Writer
content:
Don't base medicine on politics

 September 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 599
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As two pediatricians with over 80 years of combined practice, we are witnessing with increased concern the direction health care for children in our country is taking. The Trump Administration's public health decisions, in particular those of the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., appear to be based more on the results of a political calculus than established medical facts and experience.Indeed, we recognize that medicine is not free of erroneous practices. For centuries, blood-letting was considered a necessary adjunct to the treatment of serious illness. George Washington was bled multiple times on his death bed without success. Up until recently, we recommended that all families have syrup of Ipecac on hand to give to a child who had ingested a possible poison. This was found to be counterproductive and the practice discontinued.
Possibly the most important pediatric issue that RFK has questioned has been with regard to vaccines.
Starting over 100 years ago, vaccines began to be an essential part of childhood health management. The result has been a dramatic increase in the survival of children. Before widespread vaccine use, death from infectious diseases in childhood was common. It is estimated that more than one in five children in the United States died before five years of age of infection in the early 1900s. Of the eight most common infections, seven are now prevented by vaccination, and the death rate from these diseases has almost vanished.
In many cases, increasingly so at the present time, vaccines are approved only after study in the laboratory and with live patients. Longitudinal study is a further safeguard. An oral vaccine against the diarrheal illness cause by rotovirus is a good example where a rare adverse event was observed in practice and the vaccine was withdrawn, reformulated and reintroduced. The currently approved vaccine is considered to be much safer than the original formulation.
Vaccines are incredibly safe. RFK mis-uses data from the Vaccine Adverse Reporting System to scare parents into believing that there have been multiple childhood deaths caused by vaccines. With our 80 years of experience, neither of us has seen a vaccine-related event that caused pediatric death. Furthermore, he has continued to contend that vaccines, in spite of multiple studies to the contrary, cause autism.
The question can be raised as to why does RFK carry forth this program of mis-medicine?
As a very public person, we can look to his own life for possible answers. It is known that at some time in the past, RFK Jr. harbored a parasite in his brain. This has apparently been shown to be inactive. However, he retains evidence that his brain contains a cyst with calcification. In addition, he suffers from a disability called spasmodic dysphonia. It should be noted that this rare disability is not due to a local vocal cord dysfunction but is the result of a central neurologic, i.e. brain, abnormality. Finally, he has reported that he had evidence of heavy metal (mercury) poisoning that required medical treatment. Mercury poisoning is a serious problem and can cause neurologic damage as the people of Minamata, Japan, can attest.
Is it not reasonable to ask whether a person who has almost dictatorial power with regards to our children's health has compromised neurologic function? The problem here, as we mentioned above, is that any discussion of RFK and his bizarre behavior and decisions is deflected by the underlying political ramifications of such questioning. We ask, in all due deference, should our children's health and even survival be determined not by science, but by a single person's political beliefs.
DR. BRIAN J. CORDEN
DR. JUDITH P. GIESKE
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on medical practices, vaccine safety, and critiques of public health policy decisions by a government official. While it touches on political aspects, the core subject is healthcare and medical science, making 'Health' the most accurate category.

title: Five counties unite for recovery awareness event at Church Hill Park
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Five counties unite for recovery awareness event at Church Hill Park

 September 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 534
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHURCH HILL — Standing united as one community in support of recovery and awareness across the area, Mid Shore Behavioral Health, Inc. hosted its annual five county collaborative Going Purple Together at Church Hill Park Sept. 27.Organizations and agencies from neighboring counties of Queen Anne's, Talbot, Kent Caroline, and Dorchester came together to show the community all the resources available for substance recovery, mental health, addiction, and support.
Annually supporting recovery across the Mid-Shore region, the 2025 Going Purple Together event offered a blend of, fun, education and community engagement, with local vendors, activities, and the message of continually learning about substance abuse, overdose, recovery, peer support, and prevention.
Highlighting important community resources in a fun, casual environment, festivities were complete with DJ, food trucks, giveaways, family fun activities and performances by Hula Hoop Love.
Building awareness through engagement
Recognizing substance abuse awareness and prevention is more nuanced than "Just Say No" community engagement is the first step in addressing issues.
By building awareness in a fun environment, the community can be proactive and not reactive, said Queen Anne's County Circuit Court Judge Lynn Knight, a founder of the Queen Anne's County Circuit Court Assisted Recovery and Treatment program.
Ten years ago substance abuse resources did not exist in the county like they do today, and the growth in support is tremendous, she said.
Personal stories of recovery
Showcasing the possibilities of recovery straight from those who have lived it first hand, peer support specialists shared their personal experiences to help inspire and encourage those in need.
One such peer, Kaylee Whitby, of Federalsburg, noted for the longest time her personal story was a continual cycle riddled with active addiction, treatment, jail, and legal issues.
Finally after an attempt on her own life, Whitby fought to give herself a new way of living because "it was obvious my way was not working."
Through continual effort and the support of peers, Whitby was able to join in recovery services that finally made a lasting impact on her recovery journey and ultimately her life.
Whitby voiced gratitude for the opportunities offered through supportive recovery houses, including security, accountability, growth, and networking connections still part of her life today.
"Recovery saved my life," she said. Because of recovery Whitby learned to surrender and make amends to rebuild relationships. Whitby was able to be the mother that her children deserved and be the person she wanted to be.
Knowing there were others out in the community with their own similar experiences helped shape Whitby and she was eager to pay that forward to inspire others and be part of that journey.
"Today I chose to live," Whitby said.
Comprehensive support services
Understanding the many avenues that go hand in hand with recovery, organizations connected the community with the tools for support including behavioral and mental health, social services, gambling help, out and inpatient services, as well as resources for loved ones of those facing diseases of addiction.
Mid Shore Behavioral Health, is proud to continually work closely with community and county health departments and administration to erase stigma and further advocacy said Alisha Saulsbury, forensic mental health program manager.
Seeing people smile proud of themselves on their recovery journey makes it all worthwhile, Saulsbury said.
More information about Mid Shore Behavioral Health can be found at midshorebehavioralhealth.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

It highlights health-related organizations, resources, and personal stories of recovery, aligning most directly with the 'Health' topic. While 'Public Safety' and 'Local Life' are tangentially related, the primary emphasis is on health advocacy and community wellness.

title: Notice a copperhead? Leave it alone
author: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com
content:
Notice a copperhead? Leave it alone

 October 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 732
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Steve Irwin was Brittani Long's idol growing up. Too bad the copperhead snake that bit her foot didn't get the joke.Long, a resident in Mechanicsville, got bit by the snake when she checked on her chicken and ducks after work one evening in July, she said. It was too dark to see the copperhead snake in her path, which was between a shed and her back deck stairs.
"I knew they existed," Long said. "But I never would have expected to see one."
When the first paramedic arrived, Long received epinephrine and Benadryl, she said. At the hospital, she was given an IV and morphine, but not CroFab, a type of antivenom.
Copperhead snakes are one of two venomous snakes in Maryland, Beth Schlimm, Maryland state herpetologist, said. The other is the timber rattlesnake, which is primarily in the western part of the state.
Copperheads are tan or a light bright with darker blotches being an hourglass or a Hershey's Kiss shape.
The active season for most snakes, including copperheads, is April through October, Schlimm said. During the fall, snakes look for places to spend the winter.
MedStar Health in St. Mary's County treated 18 people for snake bites so far this year.
Swelling can progress quickly, which affects the doctor's decision to give antivenom, Dr. Maria Lawrynowicz, emergency department doctor at Medstar Health in St. Mary's County, said.
If bitten, it's recommended to take off jewelry and immobilize the joint to slow the venom. Doctors will mark where there is redness and swelling and do measurements on the area that was bitten to see how fast swelling progresses.
If the doctor decides to administer CroFab, they start with four vials, Lawrynowicz said. Each vial can cost between $3,000 to $6,000. A repeat dose is given every six hours depending on the swelling, blood count and ability to clot blood, which is tested every few hours.
"This isn't something we give to everyone because it's extremely expensive," Lawrynowicz said.
Anyone who receives antivenom goes to the intensive care unit for 24 hours to monitor swelling, blood pressure and dizziness, the doctor said. If patients are seen for a small copperhead bite and they don't receive antivenom they usually can go home after six to eight hours with measurement marks.
There will be local symptoms around the bite like puncture marks, redness, pain, swelling and bruising, Lawrynowicz said. Around a quarter of copperhead bites are dry bites, meaning the snake gives a warning shot and does not release any venom.
"If you're going to get bit by a [poisonous] snake, a copperhead is one to get bit by," Lawrynowicz said.
More severe bites can affect the whole body over the course of hours, she said. These symptoms include dizziness, low blood pressure, local tissue destruction and bleeding and oozing from the site.
"I was terrified," Long said. "I kept it elevated the whole time to keep the main swelling away from my foot."
Long experienced swelling up her leg to her thigh, she said. Once the swelling went down, her leg was bruised for three or four weeks.
University of Maryland Charles Regional Medical Center treated three people since the start of 2025 for copperhead bites, Dr. Maxwell Ginsburg, medical director and chairman of the Department of Emergency Medicine at the center, said. Each of them required the use of CroFab.
"Copperhead bites are not something the medical center sees often, but it is something they are aware of and always have the antidote for," Ginsburg said. "The sooner you get started, the better the outcome will be."
For any snake bite, do not suck out the venom, cut into the wound, apply a tourniquet, shock the area or apply ice to the area, Lawrynowicz said. After getting bit, immobilize the joint then go to the emergency room.
"Don't mess with snakes," Lawrynowicz said. "If you're hiking, stick to the trails … if you do get bit don't try to get the snake."
Copperheads are often found in spots with lots of leaf litter or wood and rock piles, Schlimm said.
It's best to keep yards maintained and clean. If homeowners have bird feeders or cat food outside, keep them away from the house. During the summer and at night, wear closed-toed shoes during yard work, don't reach into dark areas, wear garden gloves and try to use a rake to pull debris.
"It's not something to be afraid of," Schlimm said. "It's just a species to be aware of and to be cautious around." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'To save lives, break the silence': Speakers share suicide prevention experiences
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
'To save lives, break the silence': Speakers share suicide prevention experiences

 October 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 662
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The aim of the day was pretty basic — "to save lives, break the silence and remind every person that hope is within reach."The Southern Maryland Suicide Prevention Summit, a four-hour session, was a way to share strategies to stop someone from ending his or her life.
Hosted by Unstoppable You Ministries Inc., the event was held Sept. 27 at University System of Maryland's Southern Maryland location in California.
The ministry's founder, Jennifer Foxworthy, said her organization provides services to deal with the impacts of homelessness, human trafficking and domestic violence, noting that "suicide" is a looming demon in all of those adverse situations.
To the attendees of the event, which was free to the public, Foxworthy warned "some parts of the presentation may be heavy."
The event's two keynote speakers, in fact, articulated the gravity of the issue in their brief presentations.
Kim Klump's story was about her son, Jesse, a senior at Snow Hill High School on Maryland's Eastern Shore who died by his own hand in 2009. Klump noted Jesse was an athlete, scholar and student leader.
"This is not someone you would expect would take his life," she said.
Klump admitted that "in hindsight" she saw signs that her son was consumed with "depression."
"He gave precious possessions away," Klump recalled.
Her son also kept a journal, which was found later and revealed some of his anxieties of the present and future.
Since her son was an avid kayaker and had worked at The Pocomoke Canoe Company, Klump and others organized a fundraiser called "Jesse's Paddle," which raises funds for scholarships in his memory.
Klump said that while the fundraiser is a good way to keep her son's memory alive, she decided it wasn't enough. That's when she decided to start a prevention program in schools.
In addition to teaching coping skills, the Jesse Klump Suicide and Awareness Program started an open conversation.
"Every conversation has the power to make a difference," Klump said.
Last school year the awareness program visited four high schools and saw nearly 1,500 school students. This past summer the program hosted a "summer eco-therapy camp," which included such challenging activities as kayaking, canoeing and rope-climbing.
Klump said the organization uses grant funding to fund its programs.
Pressures of serving the nation
The summit's second keynoter, Navy Capt. Byron Lee, began his talk on a light-hearted note, passing a beach ball to attendees and engaging them in a game of "bump, bump, catch."
"We all react to things differently," Lee told the audience, adding that things that bring stress into people's lives aren't much different than the things that make people happy.
Lee's jovial demeanor turned emotional when he revealed that at one point in his 28-year armed forces career he had considered taking his own life.
"Nothing looked positive, nobody knew," Lee said.
He was able to get help on the base he was assigned to from a mental health expert.
Lee said that with its pressures to be ready to react and serve as a protector, while dealing with the pressures of assignment moves, raising a family and maintaining personal health, members of the military are emotionally vulnerable.
"All of those things were weighing on me," he said.
Lee provided 2023 statistics from the U.S. Department of Defense (now the Department of War) that showed that year there were 523 suicides in the nation's military, which was 9% higher than the previous year. The data also showed firearms were the primary method for carrying out a suicide.
In noting her own prior experience in the armed forces, Foxworthy said, "We may look big and strong but we often suffer in silence. It's important to know your resources."
Nearly 20 vendors participated in the summit, including the health departments of all three Southern Maryland counties, the Maryland Department of Health Behavioral Health Administration, service members, veterans and their families, as well as the Charles County Center for Children and Community Crisis Services Inc.
For more information about Unstoppable You Ministries, go to www.unstoppableyouministries.org.
For immediate, confidential mental health support, call or text 988 to reach the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on suicide prevention, mental health awareness, and strategies to address emotional crises. While it mentions military personnel and local organizations, the core theme revolves around health-related initiatives and mental wellness. 'Health' is the most direct match, with 'Public Safety' as a secondary consideration due to the life-saving focus.

 Samantha Basham Loza greeted me with a cup of coffee and a warm smile as I joined her at the Village Maternal Holistic Wellness Center she opened last year.She showed me around the beautiful building and explained the uses for each room.
