title: Wellness center offers support for mothers on the Shore
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Wellness center offers support for mothers on the Shore

 October 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 661
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Village Maternal Holistic Wellness Center opened its doors last October to provide women on the Eastern Shore with a single, trusted source for various services.Samantha Basham Loza was inspired to create a space like this after having her first child in the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. She was astounded by the lack of resources, education and community she had during this time.
"I was so blindsided by the entire experience, and it was really frustrating because I consider myself a highly educated person that works hard to find the right resources," Loza said. "And the fact that I couldn't even find what I needed to help me at each stage of this process was just completely shocking."
The entire process of giving birth was scary for Loza. She was at a hospital in Anne Arundel County and was given an epidural that made her completely numb from her neck down, which she said caused her to have a panic attack.
Loza said her daughter was immediately transferred to the NICU after delivery.
Because she was was numb from the epidural, the baby was crowning without Loza realizing or feeling it, and none of the doctors or nurses noticed. This caused Loza's daughter to have meconium aspiration syndrome. According to John's Hopkins Medicine, meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in 5 to 10% of births.
"I was reflecting on that entire experience thinking like, 'How is this the standard?'" Loza said.
With her first child, Loza said she didn't have the knowledge base on the process of giving birth, breastfeeding or managing hormonal changes. She described the experience as isolating.
"We don't talk about pregnancy often enough, and how isolating it can be, and all the changes and all the sacrifices. We don't talk about fertility issues often enough. We don't talk about miscarriages enough. We don't teach any of it," Loza said.
She said her goal with the wellness center is to start these conversations and create community while doing so.
The center offers an array of classes and playgroups for children. There are courses for pregnant women and new moms, and the University of Maryland's obstetrics practice comes in to talk about fertility and prenatal care quarterly.
In addition, the wellness center has birth doulas, massage therapists, lactation consultants, a speech language pathologist, a pediatric nurse practitioner and a craniosacral therapist, who will be starting in November.
"A really big misconception about the name of the business, The Village Maternal Holistic Wellness Center, is that holistic means crunchy and it doesn't," Loza said. "It just means we're considering you as a whole person."
Loza defined a doula as a non-medical support person who provides educational, physical and emotional support during pregnancy, birth and postpartum and also helps connect clients with resources.
The center recently received a grant from the Talbot County Health Department to fund the training of 18 new doulas, four of whom are bilingual and two of which whom exclusively speak Spanish. The grant is also assisting the doulas with Medicaid credentialing.
When Loza got pregnant with her second child, she decided to have a home birth midwife, one of the first contacts she made when looking into starting her business.
Loza said her pregnancy and birth with her son was a completely different experience than with her daughter.
"It was so personal. She knew exactly where I was coming from. She knew exactly what was happening with my mental state, and what I was eating and all the things. And she always had a recommendation for a book to read, or YouTube videos to watch or things like that," Loza said.
"Though she planned to deliver at home, she was transferred to the Easton Hospital because her son's heart rate was low. Her midwife stayed by her side and advocated for her throughout the process.
After having two very different birthing experiences, Loza has become passionate about educating pregnant women about the entirety of the process. She hopes to expand the centers services by opening a nonprofit arm in the near future. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a maternal wellness center providing health-related services, education, and community support for mothers. While there are educational elements and local community aspects, the primary emphasis is on health and wellness services for maternal care.

title: Working Artists Forum raises $14,000 for breast cancer treatment
author: Konner Metz
content:
Working Artists Forum raises $14,000 for breast cancer treatment

 October 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 342
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Waterfowl Festival building was decked out in pink last weekend, including over 50 works of art on display for a special breast cancer fundraiser.The Working Artists Forum held its second annual Pretty in Pink event Oct. 3 and 4, raising funds for the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's Clark Comprehensive Breast Center.
Stacey Sass, co-chair of the fundraiser, said around $14,000 was raised over the two-day event. Between the forum and the Washington Society of Landscape Painters, nearly 60 works of art were on display and for sale. More than 20 sold, Sass said.
Some pieces were full of pink or pink-adjacent colors, while others sported a small speck or dot of pink.
"Our mission this weekend is not only to raise money, but to educate everybody about the symptoms, treatments and support of those facing breast cancer," Sass said in opening remarks on Oct. 3.
The Clark Comprehensive Breast Center, located near Route 50 and off of Idlewild Avenue, delivers professional treatment and support to women with breast cancer and other breast diseases.
Dr. Kathryn Kelley, the center's director, said 2025 "has been a year of transition and really positive growth" for the center.
The team has made 137 new breast cancer diagnoses and completed over 12,000 imaging studies for women on the Mid-Shore, Kelley said.
"You can tell how hard our team is working to care for our patients in our five-county area," Kelley said, referring to Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties.
On Friday, the center's former director, Dr. Roberta Lilly, was honored for her longtime leadership. Lilly retired first in 2020 after 13 years as director and again in June after serving a stint as interim director.
Dr. Chris Levey, a radiologist with Shore Regional Health, credited Lilly with having the initial vision to create the Clark Comprehensive Breast Center.
"What truly defines her is the way she made her patients feel," Levey said. "Across every platform, she earned consistent five-star ratings, praised not only for her surgical skill, but also for listening, explaining and treating each patient as an individual." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Prescription drug roundup runs Oct. 23-28 at Queen Anne's County locations
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Prescription drug roundup runs Oct. 23-28 at Queen Anne's County locations

 October 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEEN ANNE'S COUNTY — Giving anyone with unused, unwanted or expired medications the opportunity to safely dispose of them and help keep dangerous prescriptions off the streets, the Queen Anne's County Drug Free Coalition is once again partnering to provide prescription drug drop-off locations throughout the county with its 14th annual Rx Roundup.Taking unused medications out of harm's way, together, the community can make a difference in protecting children and the environment and keeping dangerous medication out of the wrong hands.
The Rx Roundup accepts prescription and over-the-counter medications, medication samples, pet medications and vape pens or e-cigarette devices with batteries removed.
Drop-off locations and dates include:
Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department: Thursday, Oct. 23, 3-7 p.m.
Kent Island Elks Lodge: Friday, Oct. 24, 5-7 p.m.
Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office: Saturday, Oct. 25, 10 a.m.-3 p.m.
Sudlersville Senior Center: Tuesday, Oct. 28, 8-10 a.m.
Grasonville Senior Center: Oct. 28, 11 a.m.-1 p.m.
Stevensville Senior Center: Oct. 28, 2-4 p.m.
September might be wrapped up as National Recovery Month, but combined efforts of community organizations and representatives through the Queen Anne's County Drug Free Coalition continue year-round to educate the community on substance abuse awareness.
October is recognized as National Substance Use Prevention Month by the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration.
Oct. 23-31 serves as Red Ribbon Week, providing an opportunity for the community to learn about substance misuse in honor of the death of U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration Special Agent Enrique "Kiki" Camarena in 1985.
More information about the countywide drug-free initiative QAC Goes Purple can be found at www.qacgoespurple.org.
More information about Drug Enforcement Administration drug take-back events can be found at www.dea.gov/takebackday.

title: Broomsticks look to sweep away breast cancer
author: Staff Writer
content:
Broomsticks look to sweep away breast cancer

 October 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Headlines 
 
 167
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Witches and warlocks paddled down the Miles River in costume Wednesday, combining Halloween spirit with breast cancer awareness and early detection education.The inaugural witch paddle at the Oaks Waterfront Hotel raised $28,200 for Breastcancer.org and Clark Comprehensive Breast Center. As paddlers floated downriver, survivors and medical professionals shared crucial messages about screening.
Chelsey Townsend, diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer at 28 in December 2023, credited her doctor, Audrey Drummey, with saving her life through proactive genetic testing. Now one year cancer-free, Townsend encouraged women to prioritize early screenings and self-examinations.
Dr. Drummey, of the University of Maryland Shore Medical Group, emphasized that routine mammograms should begin at age 40, or earlier for those with family history.
As UM Shore Regional Community Health outreach specialist Catalina Billings noted, self-examinations are crucial because "no one knows your body like you do."
Reporter Lily Tierney captured the humor and seriousness of the witch paddle in the story below. It is just one of many stories online and in The Star Democrat today.

title: Broomsticks battle breast cancer in first witch paddle
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Broomsticks battle breast cancer in first witch paddle

 October 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 424
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Witches and warlocks floated down the Miles River on adorned paddle boards and kayaks for broomsticks and dressed in witches hats, wigs and costumes.The first ever witch paddle to support Breastcancer.org and Clark Comprehensive Breast Center took place at the Oaks Waterfront Hotel on Oct. 15 and raised $28,200, just shy of its $30,000 goal.
The event was a nice mix of Halloween fun and education on breast cancer awareness and early screening measures from doctors, volunteers and those who have experienced the disease firsthand.
As the witches paddled down the river at leisure, survivors and doctors spoke to attendees.
Chelsey Townsend, who is now one year cancer free, received the devastating news that she was diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer in December 2023 at the age of 28.
Townsend got her diagnoses after genetic testing that revealed a breast cancer gene mutation, which prompted her to get an early mammogram. She credits her doctor, Audrey Drummey, for saving her life.
Drummey is a doctor in obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Group in Easton. During the event, Drummey highlighted the importance of proactive genetic evaluation and early detection, especially if the disease runs in the family.
She emphasized the importance of access to genetic testing in health care and leveraging available resources.
Drummy said routine mammograms should start at age 40 unless there is a family history of breast cancer in which earlier screening may be recommended and potentially covered by health insurance.
In addition, she said a healthy diet, regular exercise, intaking less than seven alcoholic drinks a week and breastfeeding are good preventative measures.
For Townsend who said she doesn't like to be vulnerable, it was important to reframe her vulnerability as a strength. As she told her story, she was nervous and emotional while recounting her experience as a breast cancer survivor.
She encouraged attendees to check in on their friends post-treatment saying that community is incredibly important because a diagnoses like this can instill fear and change your perspective entirely.
"People think that we go through this experience, and when it's over, that we're OK. And we are OK, we survived, but for your mental health it's still something where every little thing that goes wrong, there's still that fear," Townsend said.
Townsend does not want others to live in fear, which is why she encourages other women — like her two sisters — to do self breast exams and early screenings. UM Shore Regional Community Health outreach specialist Catalina Billings encourages self examinations because "no one knows your body like you do." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Mallard Bay nursing assistant honored
author: Staff Writer
content:
Mallard Bay nursing assistant honored

 October 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 254
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Mary Camper, a certified nursing assistant at Mallard Bay Nursing and Rehab in Cambridge was chosen as the Mid Shore Nursing Assistant Advisory Council's 2025 CNA of the Year. The awards ceremony took place at the Health and Education Center of the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health in Easton on Sept.30.Camper has been a CNA for 46 years. She was nominated by Mallard Bay and described as "the embodiment of what health care should be," whose work ethic, leadership and professionalism "set the standard for those around her."
Camper was chosen from among 17 nominees across the region: Akai Cephas, Emma Dwyer, Katt Gray, Alexia Kelley, Megan McKeever, Jocelyn Rafael, Lisa Swain, Teaira Thompson, UM Shore Medical Center at Easton; Brandy Fanton, Dixon House Assisted Living; Crystal Godley, Lori Perry, UM Shore Medical Center at Chestertown; Da'chell Hains, Candlelight Cove Assisted Living; Debora Copper, Complete Care at Corsica Hills Nursing Home; Jessica Krieger, Home Instead; Mary Camper, Mallard Bay Nursing and Rehab; Monica Roberts, Compass Hospice; and Sa'niya Ennals, Heartfields Assisted Living at Easton.
The selection criteria for determining the winner included work ethic, leadership skills, professionalism, compassion for others, teamwork, dedication to health care, good attendance, friendliness with family and visitors, work flexibility, safety skills and professional image.
The Mid Shore Nursing Assistant Advisory Council supports health care in the community by promoting the nursing assistant profession. The council helps nursing assistants improve their skills by providing resources and networking and hosts the annual "CNA of the Year" to recognize outstanding certified nursing assistants.

title: State overdose official tours Mid Shore programs
author: Staff Writer
content:
State overdose official tours Mid Shore programs

 October 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Life 
 
 258
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Mid Shore Behavioral Health Inc. welcomed Maryland Special Secretary of Overdose Response Emily Keller on Sept. 23 for a regional visit focused on recovery efforts in the Mid-Shore region. The visit was part of a statewide initiative to connect with organizations providing substance use prevention, awareness and treatment programs.Keller began at Foundations Recovery House, meeting with alumni, residents and Executive Director Tabitha Gross. Discussions centered on peer support, trauma-focused care and wraparound services for families. Residents and staff emphasized how Maryland Recovery Net funding and extended stay resources have been critical during early recovery stages.
Keller then toured Chesapeake Voyagers Inc., speaking with peer support specialist James Carter about fostering peer wellness, advocacy and connection for individuals with mental health and substance use challenges. They discussed sustainable funding, workforce support and collaboration to strengthen peer-led recovery services.
At Mid Shore Behavioral Health, Keller participated in a briefing highlighting regional programming addressing substance use and behavioral health needs. Topics included crisis bed availability, harm reduction strategies, problem-solving courts and coordinated recovery initiatives.
Local addiction authorities and health officers from Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties shared jurisdiction-specific updates, outlining challenges and successes. Keller engaged with leaders about unique county issues and recognized local teams' dedication.
"Organizations in the mid-shore are demonstrating the tremendous power of collaboration as we work to reduce overdose in Maryland," Keller said. "I applaud our local partners in the mid-shore and across the state for their tireless efforts to support individuals on their recovery journeys and for showing what we can accomplish when we work together."

title: Easton Orthopedic Center temporarily closed due to MRI recall
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton Orthopedic Center temporarily closed due to MRI recall

 October 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 156
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Orthopedic Center in Easton is temporarily closed due to an MRI recall, according to a University of Maryland Shore Regional Health official.Spokesperson Trena Williamson indicated the center — which provides X-rays, physical therapy, rehabilitation and surgeries — closed Tuesday after being made aware of a "vendor-issued stop use recall affecting the MRI machine" at the facility.
"Due to the complex nature of MRI technology and out of an abundance of caution, the decision was made to temporarily close the building while the issue is evaluated and addressed," Williamson wrote in a statement Wednesday morning.
Williamson said Shore Regional Health officials are working with the vendor's technicians "to ensure the machine is safely shut down, serviced, and restored as soon as possible." The Orthopedic Center is located at 510 Idlewild Ave.
Safety of patients and staff is "of the utmost importance," Williamson said. Patients are being notified about rescheduling appointments, she added.
This story has been updated.

title: Cardiologist marks 40 years on Eastern Shore
author: Staff Writer
content:
Cardiologist marks 40 years on Eastern Shore

 October 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Life 
 
 286
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Jeffrey Howard Etherton has spent four decades providing cardiac care on Maryland's Eastern Shore, and this summer University of Maryland Shore Regional Health and UM Shore Medical Group celebrated the milestone.Etherton, who earned his medical degree from the University of Maryland School of Medicine in Baltimore in 1985, established device-based interventional cardiology, electrophysiology and cardiac research programs at Peninsula Regional Medical Center on the lower Eastern Shore after completing his residency at University of Florida Health Shands Hospital in Gainesville, Florida.
He returned to the University of Maryland as a cardiology fellow three years after graduating and received additional training at the Baltimore Veterans Affairs Medical Center. He also served briefly at Bethesda Naval Medical Center during Desert Storm.
Before joining UM Shore Regional Health, Etherton co-founded Delmarva Heart LLC and the Delmarva Heart Research Foundation. He directed cardiology services at multiple institutions and served as radiation safety officer for nuclear cardiology programs.
Etherton joined UM Shore Medical Group — Cardiology in 2016 and sees patients in Easton and Cambridge. He is board certified in cardiovascular disease.
That year, he launched the Interventional/STEMI Program at UM Shore Medical Center at Easton. During construction of the cardiac catheterization laboratory in 2017, Etherton worked alongside builders to ensure the facility met standards for patient safety and innovation. The cardiac cath team has since treated more than 1,000 STEMI heart attack patients.
A fellow of the American College of Cardiology, Etherton has received the Bausch & Lomb National Science Foundation Award. He is active in the Association of Military Surgeons of the U.S., the Maryland Medical & Chirurgical Society and the Wicomico County Medical Society.
A U.S. Navy Reserve veteran, he was commissioned as a lieutenant in the Medical Corps in 1985.
